PETITION.TITLE: Lowering of Moral Standards in ABC Programs

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition from 56 petitioners which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to register a protest against the lowering of moral standards by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as evidenced in the new Australian made drama Phoenix.

The drama is screened at the prime viewing time of 8.30 p.m., and a warning that language used may be offensive is hopelessly inadequate if intended to protect young people, who may be unlikely to switch off what appears from the previews to be an interesting program. Such young people are tremendously impressionable, and could mistakenly be led to think that such language is normal and acceptable.
Likewise the recent documentary Cop it Sweet, also shown on ABC could by its example foster the offensive behaviour the Police Force is established and maintained to discourage.
As taxpayers we strongly object to our funds being spent on such productions, which could by their example have a corrupting influence on many people.

The BBC production The Bill, which also depicts the Police Force with its interrogations, car chases and moments of heavy drama, is realistic, without having to resort to offensive language and blasphemy.

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ELEC TORAL) (MODIFICATIONS OF THE COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL ACT 1918) REGULATIONS
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.397
28 February 1992
The Hon Wendy Fatin MP
Minister for the Arts and Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

I refer to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) (Modifications of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No.397, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 27 February 1992.
The Regulations modify many provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 in its application to the Australian Capital Territory under the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988.

Clause 32.2 of the Schedule modifies the Act to provide that a person who either does not reply to a "please explain" notice from the Divisional Returning Officer for failing to vote in an election or whose explanation for not voting is not accepted by that officer, may opt either to pay $20 to the Electoral Commissioner or have the matter determined by the Magistrate's Court where the maximum penalty is $50 plus costs. These provisions are set out in Form G in the Regulations.

Similar provisions were provided in the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No.186, which originally introduced these provisions. The Committee wrote to the then Minister on 29 August 1989 pointing out that the Form does not advise that if a person opts to pay the $20, that not only does that discharge any liability and ensure that no further proceedings can be brought, but also, of special importance, that the elector is not to be regarded as having been convicted of an offence. This is a very significant provision which should receive the widest publicity.

On 3 November 1989 the Committee received a very helpful letter from the Minister, which advised that he agreed with the Committee and undertook to take administrative action to ensure that the full safeguards were brought to the attention of those affected. The Minister also attached a draft amendment of the Form.

The Committee believes that the present Form should include notification of the full protection for the individual which the Regulations properly provide. This should preferably be done in large and bold type.
Since the Regulations apply to the recent Australian Capital Territory elections your advice would be appreciated as to the action proposed to inform voters of their rights.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
3 April 1992
Senator P J Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles

Thank you for your letter of 28 February 1992, concerning the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral)(Modifications of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918) Regulations. I note your Committee's views on the need to include certain additional material on the Notice sent to apparent non-voters by the Australian Electoral Commission, in order to fully inform such electors of their rights.

While Regulation 32 of the Regulations specifically provides the rights accruing to the elector on payment of the penalty concerned, I agree with the Committee's views on this matter and have been advised that the sentence conveying the information concerned was inadvertently omitted from the Notice (Form G) during the preparation of the Regulations in late 1991.

I am also advised that the Australian Electoral Commission wishes to ensure that all electors concerned are fully informed of their rights. The Commission has undertaken to include in all of the `penalty' Notices in question, a note in bold type, informing apparent non-voters that payment of the penalty of $20 not only discharges any liability, but ensures that no further proceedings can be brought and that the elector will not be regarded as having been convicted of an offence.

With the passage of the Australian Capital Territory Self Government Legislation Amendment Act 1992, the Regulations mentioned above will remain in force only until the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly enacts its own electoral legislation. In view of the limited life of the Regulations, I believe it would be appropriate to proceed on the basis of the Electoral Commission's undertaking, rather than to seek to formally amend the Regulations. I trust that this solution is acceptable to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
WENDY FATIN
GUIDELINES HSB 3/1992 MADE UNDER S.82F OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953
6 March 1992
The Hon Brian Howe MP
Minister for Health, Housing
and Community Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to Guidelines HSB 3/1992 made under s.82F of the National Health Act 1953, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 5 March 1992.

Clause (c)(1) provides that appointments of the Commissioner, other Members and Deputies to the Private Health Insurance Administration Council under s.82B of the Act shall be at the pleasure of the Minister, except that any appointment shall be deemed to expire after three years.

The earlier Guidelines No.1 of 1989 also provided that appointments shall be at the pleasure of the Minister. However, the Committee now considers that removal of appointees should only be made for proven misbehaviour or physical, mental or other forms of incapacity. This is because the professional reputations of persons could suffer if they were removed without reasons. In addition, if appointees could be removed at the pleasure of the Minister then this could compromise the independence of the advice given by such appointees.

The Committee raised this same issue in respect of the first set of Therapeutic Goods Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No.88. Those Regulations provided that the Minister may "remove a member (of certain statutory committees) from office at any time". The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services undertook to amend this provision to meet the concerns of the Committee, which he did in the second set of Therapeutic Goods Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No.394. The relevant regulation now provides that the Minister may remove a member for misbehaviour, physical or mental incapacity, bankruptcy or imprisonment.
The Committee asks whether you could undertake to amend the Guidelines to provide for similar objective criteria to guide and limit the exercise of the power.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
24 April 1992
Senator P Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
Thank you for your letter of 6 March 1992, referring to Guidelines HSB3/1992 made under section 82F of the National Health Act 1953, and considered by the Committee at its meeting of 5 March 1992.
I am pleased to advise that I have approved amended guidelines prepared by my Department, which take into account the Committee's concerns. Clause c(1) of the guidelines now states that:

"Appointments shall be made by the Minister. The Minister may for reasons of misbehaviour, physical or mental incapacity, bankruptcy or imprisonment remove an appointee from office at any time. Appointments shall however be deemed to expire after three years. Any appointee shall be eligible for reappointment.
Officers of my Department are currently preparing the necessary documents for gazettal and tabling of the amended guidelines in both Houses of Parliament.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Ray on behalf of Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 established the National Industrial Chemical Notification and Assessment Scheme. The Act establishes a national system of notification and assessment of industrial chemicals which, among other things, aids in the protection of the Australian people and the environment.

When the Government introduced the Scheme, it decided that the regulatory impact on industry be reviewed after two years of operation. This Review is currently in progress. This is known as the Regulatory Impact Review. I anticipate further amendments arising from this Review, aimed at minimising the regulatory impact of the Scheme on industry to the extent that this is consistent with the maintenance of adequate safeguards for workers.
The Bill presents a small but significant amendment to the Act. It addresses one aspect of the legislation of particular concern to industry because of its impact on product development.

The Bill amends the Industrial Chemicals (Notifications and Assessment) Act 1989 to allow for the introduction of new industrial chemicals for the sole purpose of commercial evaluation. New industrial chemicals introduced for this purpose are to be exempt from the assessment provisions of the Act. This means that importers and manufacturers may evaluate the commercial potential of a new industrial chemical without having to invest resources in preparing the detailed notification package covering the chemical's physical and chemical properties and toxicology which is currently required. The Bill enhances innovative product development by significantly reducing regulatory requirements.

The Bill provides that new industrial chemicals introduced for the sole purpose of commercial evaluation have to be notified to the Director of the Scheme and that information on occupational health, public health and environment protection is provided.

Proposed section 21A deals with the object of the commercial evaluation permit system. The object is to provide a simple means of by-passing the assessment certificate system where a new industrial chemical is being introduced for the sole purpose of commercial evaluation while ensuring that adequate safeguards are imposed. One safeguard is the provision of a Material Safety Data Sheet to the Director of the Scheme. This specifies any health hazards that could be caused by the chemical, the manner of handling the chemical and procedures to be adopted in the event of any emergency involving the chemical.

Another safeguard is to be found in Clause 6 of the Bill which subjects chemicals introduced for commercial evaluation purposes to the priority existing chemical provisions of the Act. These allow for the chemical to be assessed.

The Bill provides that chemicals introduced under a commercial evaluation permit would normally be introduced for a period of one year only and in quantities not exceeding 1000 kilograms and must be used for the sole purpose of commercial evaluation. There is facility to increase the amount up to 2000 kilograms and for a period up to 2 years where the Director is satisfied that the increased quantity and the increased time is necessary for an effective commercial evaluation. The Bill also includes a power to impose conditions and a power to revoke or vary any condition on permits granted to allow for commercial evaluation.

There is a significant penalty for a breach of the conditions on which a commercial evaluation permit is granted. As confidentiality may be an important consideration in new product development the Bill allows an applicant the right to apply for certain information to be granted confidential status.

The needs of industry are met because a manufacturer or importer of a new industrial chemical will be permitted to test the chemical with a view to ascertaining its potential for commercial application without the regulatory burden of having the chemical fully assessed. If the evaluation indicates that the chemical has a commercial market then the importer or manufacturer can make an informed decision whether it is worthwhile to apply to have the chemical notified and assessed as a new chemical. In this way the Bill will remove some of the commercial risks currently associated with product development.

The passage of the Bill will show the strength of the Government's commitment to reducing the regulatory burden on industry. The Bill provides an easy and cost effective way for Australian industry to extend existing markets and create new markets. By minimising the regulatory cost of developing and improving products, while maintaining safeguards the Government is determined to create a regulatory climate which will foster industry development. This will assist in achieving the Government's micro-economic reform goals.

In canvassing the need for the commercial evaluation category in the Act the Government has consulted widely. It has consulted with relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory agencies as well as the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Chemical Confederation of Australia, The Australian Chemical Industry Council, their affiliates, other industry associations not affiliated with these peak bodies, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and interested non-government organisations.

All parties support the amendment. Industry have sent a clear message that the new category will have benefits flowing from it. These include a proper consideration of possible risks to health and environmental matters and removal of a restraint to innovation and trade.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution of $A350 million towards the Fifth Replenishment of the Asian Development Fund (ADF).

Contributions to the ADF are one of the largest single items in Australia's official development cooperation program. As such the size of payments can have a significant impact on other components in the program. A $350 million contribution represents an appropriate balance that will enable Australia to continue playing a significant role in the Asian Development Bank while allowing financial flexibility in the rest of the development cooperation program.
The ADF is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The Bank provides roughly one third of its loans on concessional terms.

The Asian Development Bank is a major international development agency. It is owned by the governments of thirty-six countries from the Asia Pacific region and sixteen countries from Europe and North America. The Bank provides financial support for development activities in its medium and low income developing member countries in the Asia Pacific region. Access to the ADF is confined to the poorest developing member countries.

In twenty-six years of operations, the ADB has become a major catalyst in promoting the development of the most populous and fast-growing region in the world today. The ADB's operations cover almost the entire spectrum of economic development, with particular emphasis on agriculture, energy, capital market development, transport and communications and social infrastructure.

The ADF was established in 1974 and Australia has participated in the previous four replenishments of the ADF. Participation in the ADF has been an efficient means of achieving aid delivery to the poorest countries of the Asia Pacific region. ADB activities also complement our bilateral aid to PNG and the South Pacific.
Traditionally, the terms on which ADF loans are made are very favourable:
.Loans are repaid over a period of up to 40 years
.repayment begins only after a period of 10 years
.borrowing countries pay a service charge of 1

PARA.TAB: per cent on their loans.

SPEECH.PARA: In general, only countries below a per capita GNP of $US860 (in 1990 dollars) may be considered as eligible for ADF resources. ADF borrowers are thus among the poorest countries in the world. They face serious constraints in building their economies and alleviating poverty.

Australia is currently the second largest regional donor to the ADF, after Japan, and the fourth largest overall. Since the inception of the ADF, Australia has pledged an average 6.1 per cent of total funds. As a major shareholder of the Bank and contributor to the ADF, Australia plays a significant role in formulating the Bank's policies.

During the replenishment negotiations, the donors to the ADF set policy guidelines for the Bank on the use of ADF-6 funds. These policies include focusing on poverty alleviation, the role of women in development, cooperation with non-government organisations (NGOs) and the environment. Development of the private sector is also a major policy aim of the Bank and the ADF.

We have come to regard the achievement of economic growth without corresponding poverty alleviation as unbalanced. In the ADB, poverty issues are now systematically considered when designing development strategies for member countries. An increasing number of projects and programs is aimed at meeting specific poverty alleviation goals. An example of a successful ADF poverty alleviation project is provided by the "NGO-Microcredit Project" in the Philippines. In the initial phase a loan of $US8 million was made available to the rural poor by using NGOs as intermediaries. The NGOs lend the money for small scale projects that will increase farmers' incomes and enable others to become self employed.

One of the major objectives of the ADB's policy on the role of women in development is to fund projects which enhance women's status in society and improve their quality of life by providing education, employment, training and income generating opportunities. For example, the ADF "Rural Women Employment Creation Project" in Bangladesh involves collaboration with local NGOs to mobilise women in rural areas and facilitate their access to credit.

During the 1980s, the ADB became increasingly concerned about the impact of development on ecological balance. A framework has now been established for incorporating environmental concerns into the overall objectives and strategies of loans for socio-economic development in the Bank's developing member countries.

Australia's representatives on the boards of the multilateral development banks are required to examine environmental issues. The Bank is responding to our concerns and other donors on this issue. For projects that have a significant impact on the environment, the ADB releases environmental impact assessment statements at least four months before the project goes before the executive board for consideration. This enables concerned groups to examine the proposals in detail and raise any concerns.

Contributions to the ADF are a significant conduit for achieving the objectives of Australia's development cooperation program. About 60 per cent of ADF funds has been committed to projects in Bangladesh and Pakistan, where the average per capita income in 1989 was $US180 and $US360 respectively. Australia's bilateral aid programs in these countries are relatively small in terms of their total development needs. Thus, channelling funds through the ADF is a significant means of achieving the humanitarian objective of providing assistance to the poorest countries.

Australia, along with most other donors, argued for access for China and India to ADF resources during the fifth replenishment of the ADF. Unfortunately, a consensus amongst donors could not be reached on access by China and India. The ADF-6 negotiations concluded, to our regret, on the basis of no access by China and India, but our policy stance is unchanged.

Indonesia and the Philippines were granted renewed access to ADF resources during the previous replenishment period. These funds were made available on a temporary basis to assist in their major economic restructuring efforts. These countries' economic shocks are not as yet fully overcome, and in each there are significantly large numbers of very poor people. Australia and several other donors successfully argued for continued support for them over the ADF-6 period. ADF activities complement our considerable bilateral programs in Indonesia and the Philippines.

In introducing this piece of legislation, the government takes this opportunity to express the hope that the international community will see the importance of working together to overcome the very significant developmental challenges confronting Vietnam and Cambodia.

Australia, in the negotiations, argued strongly for a resumption of ADF lending to eligible countries in Indo-China, including Vietnam and Cambodia. Donors have agreed that these countries should have access to ADF funds as soon as conditions become appropriate for the Bank to resume lending to these countries.

Australia has been successful in getting the ADB to provide more assistance to the small Pacific Island developing member countries as well as to Papua New Guinea. The ADB is now a major participant in policy dialogue in South Pacific countries in cooperation with the World Bank. Australia has played a major role in encouraging the ADB to strengthen the Bank's resources in its South Pacific regional office in Vanuatu. As a consequence, the ADB will be better placed to undertake detailed country economic assessments for its seven Pacific Island member states.

In Papua New Guinea, the ADB is taking a lead agency role in the agricultural, ports, roads and health sectors and the Bank is implementing a number of major projects in these sectors. ADB involvement has broadened the base of assistance available to Papua New Guinea, at a time when there has been a reduction in budgetary support under the Australian bilateral development cooperation program. The ADB is the only major Multilateral development bank providing concessional credit to Papua New Guinea for new loans. Overall, ADB lending to Papua New Guinea is expected to be in the region of $US100 million annually.

The ADB provides a significant source of procurement for Australian business. In 1990, the total value of procurement by Australian businesses from ADB projects was at least $US77.6 million; $US21.9 million of this total was from the ADF. I am keen to maximise Australian business opportunities with the Bank. At present an inter-departmental task force is examining the issue and will be reporting to me soon on what action can be taken to improve on this performance. As a result, I hope that we will be able to see a significant increase in procurement from Australia for ADB projects.

The ADB is seeking to improve the quality of its projects. Emphasis is placed on post evaluation work to improve the quality and sustainability of projects. According to the ADB's latest assessment of the success of its ADF projects, on average, fifty-two per cent were assessed to be generally successful and forty-three per cent were assessed to be partially successful. While these figures are somewhat skewed because they are based on sampling mainly poor projects, Bank staff argue that valuable lessons have been learned. The Bank is incorporating these lessons of experience in current operations. We will continue to monitor ADB performance in this area very carefully. In my opinion, it is highly desirable that evaluation of projects should be as open and independent as possible.

Australia's Executive Director on the Board of the ADB has an important role in encouraging the adoption of better management procedures to improve the administration of the bank. Australia, with strong support from other members, was instrumental in getting the ADB to establish an external tribunal to handle staff grievances. In other administrative changes, the ADB has adopted much more transparent processes in staff selection and promotion procedures. It has also improved its program operations through the preparation of a medium term strategic plan.

Another key achievement—which Australia has supported—has been to reduce the share of the ADF replenishment that could be allocated to program as opposed to project loans. Program or sector loans are relatively new and there is insufficient evidence at present to assess their long term success rate. Australia argued that there should be a cap specifically for ADF program loans. A 22.5 per cent limit has now been agreed.

Against this background of increasingly satisfactory performance of the ADB in Asian Pacific development, we have to consider our capacity to contribute in future. We are conscious of financial pressures on the development cooperation budget in general, and in particular on the bilateral programs.

Under the last replenishment (ADF-5) Australia contributed 7.98 per cent of the total replenishment value. To maintain a 7.98 per cent share of the replenishment would have required a contribution of $431 million.

In the course of the negotiations, several other donors appealed to Australia to maintain its ADF-5 share. We explained to them that the reduction from our last share was necessitated by our difficult economic and budgetary situation, and our wish to maintain flexibility in the aid budget. While a share of 6.5 per cent represents a significant drop in Australia's share from the last replenishment, it is still higher than the 6.1 per cent average of Australia's previous contributions to the ADF, and we remain the second largest regional donor in the fund, after Japan.

Unlike other commitments under the development cooperation program, payments to the concessional arms of the Multilateral development banks are made over a period as long as ten years. We now face a situation where, to fulfil past commitments, the share of the development cooperation program allocated to the Multilateral development banks could rise to over 18 per cent in 1994-95. This compares with a share of 8 per cent in the mid 1980s.

The move to limit the growth of the share of ADF in the overall development cooperation budget reflects the need to maintain flexibility in the program, given budgetary constraints on the overall development cooperation budget.

While this Bill is concerned with contributions to the ADF, I have already indicated to the World Bank that our contributions to their concessional lending fund, the International Development Association (IDA), will be similarly constrained. With a similar approach to reducing Australia's share in IDA, the $350 million contribution to ADF-6 could eventually stabilise the multilateral development banks' share of the aid budget at around 12-14 per cent.

I would like to conclude by outlining briefly the payment arrangements for ADF-6. In accordance with previous practice, payment will be made in the form of non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes. The promissory notes will contribute to the ADF-6 lending authority for the period 1992-1995. It is expected that the promissory notes will be encashed over a period of eight to ten years beginning in 1992/93. These funds will be included in the annual development cooperation budgets.

Estimates of drawdowns for ADF-6 are $1.8 million per year over the period 1992/93 to 1995/96, $9.6 million in 1996/97, and approximately $83 million per year in the following four years. These estimates of drawdowns are subject to change, as they are dependent upon exchange rates and the actual rate of disbursements by the fund.

In summary, the Asian Development Bank and its Asian Development Fund have an important role to play in continuing to foster economic and social development in the region of immediate interest to Australia. Our contribution to the fifth replenishment will confirm our support for the poorest developing countries in our region by providing highly concessional assistance.
I commend the Bill and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, entitled The John Curtin School of Medical Research, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Senate Committee began its inquiry into the John Curtin School in December 1992, individual members held widely divergent views, both on the events which had led to the Senate's reference of the issue to the Committee and on the likely outcomes of the Committee's deliberations. Five months later, after four public hearings and receipt of more than 100 written submissions, some of us have modified our earlier assessments of the situation. Although we have not reached unanimity on all of the issues under consideration, it would be fair to say that our views are much closer now than when we began the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: During the course of our inquiry, arrangements at the John Curtin School have changed significantly. Originally the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) had proposed that funding for the school be removed from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and placed with the National Health and Medical Research Council. He saw this as a means of improving accountability for public funding of research conducted at the school, and of enhancing peer review of the work undertaken there. In reaching this view the Minister relied heavily upon the advice of a committee which reviewed the Institute of Advanced Studies—of which the John Curtin School is a part—in 1990. This committee was chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen.

The ANU opposed these arrangements.It considered that the university itself could rectify the problems identified at the John Curtin School without reliance upon external bodies. It also regarded the move as a potential threat to its autonomy and, by implication, to the autonomy of universities in general. In the event, negotiations between the university and the NHMRC broke down and funding of the school is now being channelled through the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services rather than through DEET. This is still a concern for the university, which prefaced its agreement to the new arrangements with the statement that its preferred position was a return to funding through DEET. The Minister's concerns about accountability and peer review have been largely addressed through the establishment of an advisory board at the John Curtin School and through NHMRC involvement in peer review and funding decisions.

When this Committee began its inquiry into the John Curtin School it assumed that the issues and arguments had already been well-rehearsed in earlier inquiries. The task, it appeared, was primarily to evaluate the merits of the arguments and conclusions of the Stephen committee, in particular as they related to the John Curtin School. In the event, the Senate Committee has felt bound by the evidence before it to subject to critical analysis the procedures, as well as the findings and recommendations, of that committee.

While attention in recent years has focused on problems at the John Curtin School, the Senate Committee's view of the school is very positive. The school can continue to play a major role in Australian biomedical research. The future will rest largely with the younger scientists, and the Committee feels very strongly that their work should be nurtured and supported in an environment of career opportunity and excellence in research. To this end the Committee has recommended the introduction of five-year rolling appointments for non-tenured members of the school.

This is the only recommendation we make in this report. We are pleased to note, as explained above, that many of the original difficulties at the school which led to the Senate's reference of this matter to this Committee have since been resolved to the satisfaction of all the interested parties, thus rendering further recommendations superfluous. We are hopeful that outstanding issues still in contention will, in time, be resolved in a similarly satisfactory manner.

The Committee has made no recommendation relating to the source of funding for the school since it could reach no agreement on this issue. The view of a minority of Committee members is that, in the absence of any clearly demonstrated benefits from the current arrangements, funding should be returned to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. They, the minority, are concerned that the university's autonomy is diminished by current arrangements because the university can no longer determine the allocation of funding to one of its component schools. The majority view is that the source of funding is of no practical import to the school and that, given the need for stability there, the current agreed funding arrangements should remain in place. In its view the new arrangements do not impinge upon the university's capacity to discharge its responsibilities under its Act so that its autonomy is not at risk. I commend the report to the Senate, to the university, to the John Curtin School of Medical Research and to all of those individuals who may in the future be called upon to sit on committees of inquiry.

I just indicate that it was the unanimous view of the Committee that we needed to spend a considerable period of time examining, not only the recommendations of the Stephen committee, but in fact the processes which preceded those recommendations. We believe that in our analysis of the processes followed by the Stephen committee we may be able to point out some handy hints, if I can put it that way, to all committees of inquiry, government, Senate, or eminent persons in committees of inquiry, which may at some time be looking at various institutions around this country—whether they happen to be banks, education institutions, or whatever.

We believe that it is very important in the processes of any inquiry that hypotheses that the Committee members may be close to reaching should be tested on those people who are most affected by it—and possibly on the community at large. Then at least a public debate could occur and people might respond to what they believe to be the possible recommendations of a committee. Those people who feel in some way that they have not had their day in court or their opportunity to put their views would be given an opportunity to respond. We believe that during the process this was one of the problems that the Stephen committee faced. The likely recommendations that they were going to arrive at—the hypotheses that they were testing in their own minds—were tested only with two senior members of the university. That that was considered a sufficient basis to provide appropriate feedback before the committee then made its final recommendations.

We believe that that was a flaw in the processes followed by the Stephen committee, and it is in some cases a flaw in the processes followed by a number of committees—some in this place, some in public inquiries. In other words, they do not give people sufficient chance to respond to their likely judgments so that, when the reports are tabled, not only the nature of the recommendations but also some of the judgments made often come as a surprise to some people. It seems to us that, in many cases, if the community at large and those who are affected by an inquiry are given the opportunity to have their say, to know that in fact the inquiry is focusing on them, then they are in a better position to put forward their views and to contradict, say, some assumptions which may be underlying the nature of the inquiry into their particular area.

We felt that during the Stephen inquiry it was pretty obvious that the focus not only moved from the other schools to the John Curtin School of Medical Research but that it moved without, in a sense, many of the people in that school being aware that they were in fact the school that was primarily under the spotlight. If they had known that there was a change of emphasis in the Stephen committee's processes, that in fact they were at the centre of the attention of that committee, many of them, I believe, would have responded in a way which would have been more detailed and would have taken into account some of the assumptions underlying the Stephen committee's views.

That is not to say that the recommendations of the Stephen committee were wrong. We are saying that the process itself created two problems. Firstly, certain factual matters were overlooked and certain assumptions were not tested in the broader university context or, for that matter, in the broader context of the community's views. Secondly, the people within the school felt that the emphasis had swung to them, but they were not quite aware that they were the subject of intense scrutiny on the part of the committee.

With that in mind, those people who read the report, I think, will find some interest in what the Senate Committee has to say not only about the John Curtin School of Medical Research and the ANU, but also about the way that all committees of inquiry should operate so that everyone gets a fair opportunity to respond to accusations that are made against them. We believe that in the long run, for the health of any institution, if accusations and assumptions are going to made about the necessary improvement or some of the faults that may be prevalent in a particular institution, they should be made at least publicly or semi-publicly so that they can be tested on those people who are most affected by the ultimate recommendations of that inquiry.

We leave the Senate with that timely reminder, I believe, about the way in which all our committees should work, where possible. We understand that in some situations, obviously, the highest confidentiality might have to pertain to the committee's likely recommendations. I believe that that is important only in areas which might relate, for example, to foreign exchange values or other areas where it may be possible for someone who wishes to make money out of the committee's likely recommendations. In most other cases, I believe, a public exposure of the criticisms and the likely recommendations of a committee, either through a working paper or a discussion paper before the final recommendations are made, could help people to believe that they have had their day in court and that they have been given a fair hearing, and ultimately the final recommendations are likely to be more sophisticated and realistic as a result.

With that, I thank my fellow Committee members for the work they did on this Committee, and the secretariat of the Committee. I thank the various people affected by the inquiry—the 100 or so people who put in submissions and the hundreds of people who attended the four public hearings assiduously—for their cooperation. I do not think we have had, outside of a game between Collingwood and Carlton, such a crowd in this place to hear the workings of a committee. We believe that what we have recommended here not only traverses the history of what occurred and, therefore, tries to place much of it in context, but also gives people an opportunity to feel satisfied that their viewpoints have all had some expression in public and have had a reasonable hearing before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training presents its report into the John Curtin School of Medical Research. The Committee was asked to look at the proposal to divest the Australian National University of administrative and financial control of the John Curtin School by transferring the funding responsibilities to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The Committee was asked to pay particular attention to the most desirable mechanism of control and administration of the school, relevant communications between the school and the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), and the implications of the proposed funding arrangements for the autonomy of Australian universities in general.

PARA.TAB: The Committee was split on its findings. I would really like to pay tribute to other members of the Committee for the extremely thorough and professional way in which they went about their deliberations. We did have considerable agreement on a number of things, particularly on the area of process, but in our findings there were a number of areas that we did take a different view on; and I will come back to those as I go through this report today.

It is my belief and the belief of my colleagues that the autonomy of all our higher education institutions is threatened by the precedent that will be established by this attack on the John Curtin School of Medical Research. The school was originally set up under the Australian National University Act as an integral part of the Institute of Advanced Studies within the university. It is clearly the intention of the ANU Act that the funding of the university be allocated by the Parliament to the ANU and that the ANU Council then allocate funding in the way it feels appropriate.

The Government has actually taken part of the funding of the Australian National University, that is, funding for the John Curtin School of Medical Research, and placed it in the hands of another department—Health, Housing and Community Services. In this way the Government has the facility to directly influence what goes on in that school. It is, I believe, an outrageous action by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. It is, in effect, circumventing the will of this Parliament and the ANU Act. It is amputating a dynamic and integral part of the university. It is an invasion of the autonomy of the university. It is being done against the will of those involved in the John Curtin School, as indicated by their staff meetings on this issue. It is being done against the will of the Australian National University, as indicated by the resolutions on this issue by the ANU Council. It is being done against the will of two of the founding fathers of the university, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombes, both having expressed vehement opposition to the actions of the Minister. It is clear, therefore, that the Minister must not be allowed to continue with this action.

The Committee has been looking at the basis upon which the Minister made his decision to intervene so radically in the affairs of an autonomous university. The Minister has been called on countless times not to proceed with this action until the Committee has reported its findings, but the Minister refused and pursued an inappropriate course of action. The findings of this report must surely make the Minister look again at the facts surrounding the John Curtin School inquiry and reverse his decision on the funding of that school.

The action of the Minister was precipitated by the findings of the Stephen committee. This committee was established to look at the operation of the Institute of Advanced Studies within the ANU. The result was for that committee to single out the John Curtin School for scathing criticism and recommend this radical move by the Minister. From the report presented to the Senate today let me present this quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee is unanimous in its concerns over shortcomings in the processes followed by the Stephen Committee during its review of the Institute insofar as this related to the John Curtin School. The Senate Committee considers that such shortcomings diminish the value of the decisions arrived at.

There is no doubt that the findings of the Stephen committee can be seriously questioned. The process of collecting evidence, communicating with the school and consultation with the Australian National University was completely unsatisfactory. The Senate Committee reports that it has found that there developed different interpretations about the terms of reference of the Stephen committee. It is clear that the Stephen committee was established to review the Institute as a whole, not the individual schools in detail.

PARA.TAB: The Committee interpreted the terms of reference in relation to the JCSMR as licence to investigate the extent of the implementation of the recommendations of previous reviews of the school, particularly the review in 1988 led by Professor Korner. As it developed, the Stephen committee did start to look more closely at the John Curtin School and whether the recommendations of the 1988 review were being implemented. It is particularly unfortunate that, at this point, it was not made clear to the school of the development in the focus of the Stephen committee. Many argue that, had they been aware of the specific attention being placed on the JCSMR, they would have ensured that the Stephen committee received a comprehensive range of views. As it is, it appears that the Stephen committee received a reasonably narrow range of opinions on the school.

The Senate Committee found that the Stephen committee determined that there were problems particular to the JCSMR that required particular attention. Having discovered this, I believe, they should have advised the school that such a specific interest had emerged. The Committee is also concerned that the members of the Stephen committee who visited the school gave no indication to the people they interviewed that the school and its progress and the 1988 review reforms were of particular concern to them. The Stephen committee acknowledged that it relied heavily on the findings of the 1988 review. The Senate Committee finds it curious, therefore, that it failed to hold discussions with members of that review.

The Stephen committee also failed to check with the divisional heads of the school the extent to which the 1988 recommendations were being implemented. From this, the Stephen committee made recommendations in direct conflict with those of the 1988 review. On evidence presented to the Senate Committee it was concluded that the Stephen committee had overstated the case that the John Curtin School was alone within the Institute in attracting a significant number of critical submissions. It would therefore appear that the critical submissions exerted a disproportionate influence both on the Stephen committee and, presumably through that committee, on the advice given to the Minister.

Oral submissions to the Stephen committee and the consultative process can also be criticised. The Senate Committee has found that, during consultation, the Stephen committee gave those people interviewed no indication of its line of thinking. As a consequence, people were denied the opportunity to rebut unfounded criticism or not prevent a different perspective from emerging, which might have resulted in a more balanced assessment of the situation at the school.

The Senate Committee disapproves of methods which restrict opportunity for a fair exchange of views and argument, particularly between people legitimately and responsibly involved in the significant features of the debate. It is interesting that in contrast to the procedures of the Stephen committee, the Senate Committee allowed a very wide range of expression of opinion and did weigh up evidence very carefully. The Stephen committee found that the John Curtin Medical School had special problems not shared by other schools. The Senate Committee findings, based on the reviews of the research schools made available to the Stephen committee, are that this was not necessarily the case. If we actually did a study of criticisms of other schools and the sorts of things that were being criticised, it did not particularly stand out.

The Stephen committee also found that the implementation of recommendations of the 1978 and 1988 reviews had been slow, if they had been carried out at all. There is conflicting evidence on this, but the Senate Committee concludes that all but one of the 1988 review recommendations were being implemented within the time frame specified, and morale at the school had improved significantly. The Senate Committee concludes that the Stephen committee findings on morale and on the reforms implemented at the JCSMR were less than accurate and attributes this to the Stephen committee's failure to seek adequate advice on the progress of the implementation.

The Senate Committee is not convinced that the Stephen committee's report demonstrates that the problems it identified would be resolved by the solutions it proposed. It has not been made clear, for example, how the transfer of funding would improve morale and leadership, assist in the recruitment and retention of staff, or reduce criticism. Bound by the evidence before it, the Senate Committee believes that the shortcomings of the Stephen committee review process detract from the validity of its conclusions and bring into question actions predicated upon its findings. It is clear from the evidence presented before the Senate Committee that the proposed funding changes had disadvantages for both the John Curtin School and the ANU. The Minister has failed to demonstrate any overriding benefit from this transfer.

It is also clear that the autonomy of Australian universities, in general, is threatened by these new arrangements. The JCSMR is unlike any other medical research institute that has funding through the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. It is an integral part of the university and not merely affiliated to one. The removal of funding from DEET sets a precedent for this situation where any faculty could be removed from DEET and placed in the hands of another department whose operations are viewed as congruent with the subject matter of the faculty concerned. Clearly, this is an undesirable situation and it cannot be tolerated.

The most desirable mechanism to control the administration of the John Curtin School is through the ANU, as it was originally established. This means that funding must come through DEET. Given the findings of the Senate Committee, the Minister must reverse his decision and return the funding arrangements to DEET. The decision of the Minister has been based on poor information and it cannot be demonstrated that the Minister's actions will actually correct the problems identified. It is clear that the problems identified by the 1988 review have already been addressed during the Stephen committee review, with one exception and that exception is now being corrected. I commend the report to the Senate and urge the Minister to act now.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I rise to speak to this long awaited report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Employment and Training inquiry into the John Curtin School of Medical Research. The Committee found itself examining the school following a reference passed by this place last year, moved by the Opposition, which the Democrats supported. At the time, the issue of the transfer of funding for the JCSMR from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the National Health and Medical Research Council caused an enormous controversy at the ANU for a whole variety of reasons. It was a view of the Democrats that these issues were sufficiently serious as to warrant further scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: I supported this reference because, clearly, the funding transfer had caused enormous public and private controversy, and as a result had distracted many scientists at the school and at the ANU from the important business of medical research. The actions of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) appeared to lack justification, and appeared to represent a direct threat to the autonomy of the ANU, and the ability of the university to administrate and fulfil its duties under the Act.

After lengthy public hearings, to which I brought a fairly open mind, I have arrived at the conclusion on the matter, which is largely reflected in the minority report. The funding transfer of JCSMR to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is of no demonstrable benefit to the school and is a threat, in the words of the report, `to the autonomy of the ANU', and `an unwarranted and unnecessary interference in the activities and administration of the University'. To that extent, it does represent a threat to the university's autonomy. However, it was my view—this is where I differ from those other honourable senators who supported the minority report—that the funding transfer does not have serious implications for the autonomy of Australian universities as a whole.

The John Curtin School of Medical Research is one of four research schools within the Institute of Advanced Studies. It is a unique institution which was founded many years ago in a vastly different university research climate. The institute has no teaching functions and, therefore, cannot be considered a faculty in the accepted sense of the word. It is a ridiculous proposition to suggest, as Senators Crane, Calvert and Tierney have done, that as a result of this move every faculty, at every university, is potentially under the same threat of having its funding arbitrarily removed.

The reality is that university faculties are already under threat from under-resourcing and the squeeze on funds. Arts faculties, in particular, are under enormous stress as they face budget cuts, staff retrenchments, cutbacks in tutorials and so forth. However, the funding transfer is, in my view, a repudiation of the unique position held by the Institute of Advanced Studies. It appears to represent a desire on the part of the Minister to tidy up medical research funding without recognition of the special place the John Curtin School holds within the academic community at the ANU. Given that many witnesses, and even the Stephen committee report itself, considered plurality of funding to be a desirable mechanism in research activities. Further centralisation of funds for medical research within the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has no demonstrated benefits in this particular case.

As we continued to hear evidence it became clear that the Minister had placed enormous weight on the opinions of the Stephen committee, which recommended the funding transfer for JCSMR. Indeed, early on, the Stephen committee considered breaking up the school and transferring its activities to other centres. However, the Senate Committee report clearly demonstrates that the Stephen committee based its view of the school on preconceived notions about the problems the school faced. The views of one or two committee members—in particular, those of Professor Niall—were extremely influential in the Stephen committee's recommendations but, in our view, the information collected in respect of the school was highly deficient and could not support the Stephen committee's recommendations.

Only two visits were made to the school itself, one by Professor Niall in February 1990 and another by Professor Kramer in July 1990. These were informal visits and no formal evidence was collected, yet considerable attention was placed in the Stephen committee report on John Curtin School. The Committee can find no justification for this on the basis of either the Stephen committee's terms of reference or the evidence collected by the Stephen committee in respect of the school. The nature of the consultations and processes used by the Stephen committee left a great deal to be desired, especially in relation to the recommendations made in respect of the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

As my Committee colleagues have already said, it is vitally important that inquiry processes be open, transparent, known to all and widely advertised. For any committee deliberations and recommendations to have credible force, due processes must be adopted. As a result of the processes adopted by the Stephen committee, in the words of the report, `to the extent that the advice given to the Minister was flawed, any action flowing from that advice risked being impaired'. Mindful of this, the Senate Committee has endeavoured, to the best of its ability, to conduct its inquiries in a fair and open manner. We have sought a wide variety of views and have endeavoured in good faith to present the issues relating to John Curtin School fairly and without undue influence of partisan views. I believe we have achieved our goal.

It is the hope of the Democrats that, now that a range of issues has been canvassed and had a fair hearing, the able scientists at John Curtin School of Medical Research can continue unimpaired their important work. Most of the reforms outlined in the 1988 Korner review are now in place and should result in a more robust organisation whose work is subject to independent scrutiny. The Democrats believe, however, that as a result of this inquiry the Minister should see fit to return funding of the John Curtin School of Medical Research to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and back into the hands of the ANU where it rightly belongs.

On behalf of the Democrats, I would like to thank the witnesses who appeared before the Committee, the many people who made submissions to the Committee in writing, and in particular the Committee Secretariat, whose hard work and research has done so much to present this important report in its final form before us today. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity now, because I will not have it later, to make a few observations about the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into the proposal to divest the Australian National University of administrative and financial control of the John Curtin School of Medical Research. I endorse everything that Senator Sowada said, except for one matter that we disagree on, which is about the staff and the amount of work they did. This morning I managed to grab a sample of the evidence we received and the work that has been put in by the staff. What I have here is about a quarter of the material we had.

PARA.TAB: I have no doubt that the inquiry that we carried out into the John Curtin School of Medical Research was much more thorough and much better researched than the previous one, done by the Stephen committee. I was concerned, as we all were, about the findings of the Stephen committee and the way in which the committee was used to try to divert funding away from the Australian National University.

As was touched on by the Chairman of the Senate Committee, I think it also highlighted the problem that arises when Ministers call for eminent people to conduct inquiries. I have no argument with the appointment of Sir Ninian Stephen or Dame Leonie Kramer—I think they are very eminent and very honourable people—but in this case I think there is very good evidence to suggest in the report that the Stephen committee was heavily influenced by one particular person, who is himself recognised as a very well-known scientist. I tend to think that he may have been somewhat biased in his views. I remember one classic statement that was reported where he referred to the John Curtin School as a sheltered workshop.

I think that every member of the Committee certainly spent more time in the John Curtin Medical School than some members, if not all members, of the Stephen committee. I certainly saw no evidence that this particular medical school was a sheltered workshop; in fact, to my way of thinking, it was quite to the contrary. It seemed to be a vibrant research centre comprising young talent, conducting research of a very significant nature that will be, in the future, I believe, of tremendous value not only to Australia, but to the whole world. For the evidence that was given to us during our inquiry to indicate that a lot of the work being done there was irrelevant was—to me, anyway—quite erroneous.

Being a lay person and never having been involved very much with research scientists, the thing that came through to me was the very competitive nature of some academics. They certainly defend very strongly their ability to do research.

I hope, now that this Committee report has been tabled and all of the facts have been put down, that the morale of the school will lift and that those rumblings that have been going on underneath the surface—quite bitter rumblings, as we saw in some of the evidence that was given to us—are put aside and the researchers get back to doing what they do best, that is, finding cures for the common cold, or transplanting thyroid glands from mice into the foetuses of sheep. As a former member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, I was particularly pleased to see the efforts to which the researchers had gone to protect the welfare of the animals on which they were experimenting for the good of human beings.

Senator Tierney has raised most of the concerns that Opposition members had. I am pleased to say, as the Chairman indicated earlier, that there was general agreement on most of the important issues. The only recommendation made, of course, was that in future there be rolling appointments for non-tenured members of the school. Far from being a sheltered workshop, the quality and youth of the researchers certainly did impress me.

I do not intend to say much more, Mr Acting Deputy President, other than once again to thank my colleagues for the amount of work they put in—some more than others. I particularly commend Senator Tierney for bringing this matter forward. If he had not pushed so hard to have this matter referred to our Committee, then a grave injustice would have been done to one of the finest research institutions that we have in this country, an institution that we should be very proud of.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few general comments on the matter of the autonomy of universities. It seems to me that what is occurring here is a symptom of the onslaught which this Government has made against the universities over some considerable time, in a variety of ways. As Senator Sowada mentioned, it is occurring in relation to funding, the amalgamations and, in this particular case, the removal from the university of the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PARA.TAB: It should be self-evident, I would think, that the universities contain some of the very best brains, the best minds, in this country. They contain those minds, those brains, those concerns, in institutions of learning where, in a number of formal and informal ways, the whole panoply of social processes are discussed on a daily basis. Consequently, the universities, more than any other institution, are those institutions best qualified to hold up a mirror to society, to say to society, `Look, we believe that perhaps you are going in the wrong direction with respect to this or that. There are alternative courses of action open to you, there are alternative options which can be pursued. There are alternative paths, there are alternative futures'.

For the Government, with its rather narrow and restricted and politically oriented views of the future, it is a vision—in fact, I would say in this case lack of vision—to be intruding into those institutions and to be attempting to impose on them through these various processes a narrowing. I think this marks a very dangerous trend, of which of course this was simply one symptom.

To give just one example from my own former field of research, in the medical area a lot of research will be done from time to time in the area of occupational and environmental health. This will bring researchers in these areas into direct conflict with many of the most powerful influences in our society. For those institutions to be in any sense more directly under the control of government or any other body—and also I would reflect here on the need for CSIRO to get 30 per cent of its funding from private sources, and the same sorts of pressures are being brought on universities to get funding outside from private bodies—and for them to be put under those sorts of pressures seriously impacts on their ability to speak out fearlessly and openly in defence of the public interest.

For those reasons I think it is very important that the Senate be aware of the pressures being brought by government upon the tertiary institutions, particularly the universities. We must resist those things and seek to ensure that the universities maintain that academic freedom which has been their right, their privilege and their social responsibility. I would stress that in relation to the universities themselves, because they have not always discharged their social responsibilities, it is very important that those matters be defended, and accordingly it seems to me that this Committee report is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly and then to adjourn the debate. The reason for this is that the report is not yet generally available. There are a number of senators with a strong interest in this subject, including the Deputy President, who is a member of the ANU Council, who have not seen the report and who no doubt will wish to comment on it when they have. I personally would like to reply in some detail to Senator Tierney's remarks when I have had the opportunity to have a good look at the material. I have established that there is nobody else in the chamber who wishes to speak at this time so I do not feel bad about adjourning the debate. Therefore, I shall make a few remarks and develop my argument on another occasion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Calvert congratulated Senator Tierney on referring this matter to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I strongly disagree with that point of view. I think this whole matter could have been handled in a much better way had it not had the spotlight of a Senate inquiry. To my mind, it is largely an internal matter within the ANU and between the ANU and the relevant government funder. If it were happening at any other university in Australia, the position may be different. I know of no case, for example, in Victoria in regard to Melbourne University, where internal university matters have been the subject of lengthy debate by a committee of the Parliament.

I disagree with the view that has been put to us on a number of occasions by witnesses and by members of the Committee that there is something very special about the ANU. There was when it was set up originally, but I do not think those arguments apply any longer. Nor do I agree—to mention one of the points where I would disagree with the minority on the Committee—that, to use Senator Tierney's words, there is any invasion of the autonomy of the university. I will develop that on another occasion because I strongly disagree with that.

Senator Calvert referred to this matter and the reason for referral to the Committee as a grave injustice averted. I do not see it as an injustice to have similar funding arrangements for the John Curtin School as applies in other equally eminent research institutes around Australia such as, to name two in my own State, the Hall Institute and the Baker Institute. In fact, Sir Gustav Nossal, one of the most eminent medical scientists in Australia, made this very point in a letter to the Committee.

I also disagree that bringing these things out into the open and letting—to quote our report—`everyone have their day in court' is necessarily a good thing. To my mind, if you are trying to negotiate a new situation, sometimes a lot of publicity in a sensational way, at least in the local press, often negates both the healing process and the process of getting on with the negotiations and coming to a conclusion, rather than helping them.

I should add that the Committee completed its report only last evening, which is the reason why it is not available to senators this morning, apart from members of the Committee. I think that a number of us would like longer to consider the remarks that we would wish to make. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 26 March 1992.
Clause 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Several weeks ago, the Senate comprehensively addressed the Forest Conserevation and Development Bill 1991 in the second reading debate. I am sure that anybody who has followed the media in the past few weeks would be well aware that this is an issue that certainly excites the community. My only regret is that it is a pity that some of the Tasmanian media, particularly the Mercury, take such a biased, restricted and, frankly, awful, view of reporting of this particular issue, particularly when it is so important in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Let me come back to the issues that now have to be addressed. In closing the second reading debate, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) made and put down an important government position. It would appear that, in the three intervening weeks, this Labor Government has got itself into an even worse mess on this issue than it has got into on the economy. The Labor Party politics on this issue are shameful and disgraceful. The discussions between the Opposition and the Government, between the industry and the Government, among all of the interested parties on this matter, have been blown out of the water by crass politics within the Labor Party in the last few days. It is now seeking to jeopardise jobs for thousands of Australians.

The coalition has argued consistently for months that the Government has been trying to introduce impossibly compromised umbrella legislation to cover specific major projects and the myriad smaller timber projects in the regional forests. At the same time, because of the struggle in Cabinet between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), this Bill fails adequately to provide the resource security necessary for the smaller projects under $100m. That is why we, in conjunction with the industry—particularly the peak body, NAFI, and the timber unions—have prepared amendments to do just that. In the course of this committee stage, I will be proceeding with those amendments.

We also wanted to enhance investment prospects by removing the no compensation clause. We—that is, the Liberal and National parties and also, Mr Temporary Chairman, the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, of which you are a member—received a great welter of evidence that totally supported the view and the need for change to amend them. We highlighted the weaknesses in the legislation, such as the unnecessary and the expensive duplication of State and Federal procedures, as well as the lack of genuine resource security because of the ability of the Federal Minister to alter an earlier decision to provide resource from a given area.

We argue that it is better to have separate project specific legislation for major projects such as pulp mills and to use the State and industry regional forest agreements as the basis for development of the timber industry. It must be remembered that there cannot be a paper mill without the timber industry also involved to utilise the heavier logs and to maximise the value adding of the total resource. This approach has been increasingly confirmed by the report of the Resource Assessment Commission, which, of course, we discussed in this chamber in the last couple of days and which ironically was tabled in the Senate only after the legislation had been wheeled and dealed with by the Government. It had been held back very specifically from the Senate Standing Committee; by the evidence before the Senate Standing Committee inquiry itself; by the recent Western Australian southern forest agreement; and even by the One Nation statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The amendments moved by the coalition in the House of Representatives were designed to provide reasonable resource security for investment to take place in Australia's 1,200 small mills to improve utilisation and value adding as well as to embrace investment prospects for major projects. The Government had indicated its inability to accept these amendments, but it was prepared to recognise that the Bill really covers only major projects of more than $100m—that is, pulp and paper mills; to establish a monitoring process to check whether industry and coalition doubts about its effectiveness, even for major projects, are correct and therefore changes need to be made; and to enter into genuine negotiations with NAFI on providing resource security for the rest of the industry.

I would like at this stage to refer to the basic agreement between the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the National Association of Forest Industries, the Tasmanian Government, the Forest Industry Association of Tasmania, and the Forest Protection Society. I had hoped, and anticipated by the moves that were being taken in the past week or so, that this agreement would have resulted today in compromises and in legislation that the Government itself would have been prepared to initiate in this chamber.

What would have been achieved, what would have been done, under that agreement? We anticipated that the Government would have agreed to re-title the Bill to the Forest Conservation and Major Projects Bill and that all provisions of the Bill would then remain unchanged. This would have accommodated all of the issues and would not have enabled so many things to take place. The understanding would have been that the Government would then undertake to monitor and review the effectiveness of the legislation to ensure that it achieves its objectives of certainty and security for the industry and generates value adding investment and jobs in the forest industries. If it can be demonstrated that the legislation has not achieved its objectives within a reasonable timeframe, the Government would, in consultation with the industry, consider what further action might be appropriate.

Another point from the intended agreement is that the Government would agree to consult with industry concerning the development of the concept of enhanced intergovernmental agreements designed to provide resource security on a regional basis for those forest industry investments which would not otherwise qualify under the forest conservation and major projects legislation.

A further point is that the Federal Government would agree to ongoing discussions with industry and trade unions—very importantly—regarding the provision of certainty and security for investment related wood supplies in the context of reviewing ESD, National Plantations Advisory Committee and RAC recommendations prior to developing the national forest strategy. The final point of the intended agreement was that the Federal Government would announce these commitments in the resumption of the debate here in this chamber.

What happened? This was rejected and thrown out of court only in the last few days, obviously after some incredible wheeling and dealing in the back rooms of the Government. One only has to look at today's media to see that, very obviously, the Left of the Labor Party—whether it was Senator Bolkus or Mr Balderstone in the Prime Minister's office or whoever—the Labor Party's factional-ridden emphasis, has taken over again.

The industry and the coalition had agreed to accept the way in which we would have wanted to go because none of us wants to prevent the development of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, in Gippsland, or anywhere else in Australia. But the Government's bona fides must now be called into question and into account. I refer senators to clause 10(1) of the Bill, where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister is satisfied that the conditions imposed by sections 11 to 15 (inclusive) have been met in relation to a particular wood processing project, the Minister must, by instrument in writing, declare that this Act applies to the project.

Put that with the proposed amendment to the title of the Bill, and the other commitments that the Federal Government was to have put on the table, and we could have achieved the objectives that we were all after. But, no, the Government has now rejected and thrown this out, as I said, because of crass Labor politics. Let me quote from today's Australian under the by-line of Lenore Taylor, where under a heading, `Resource security deal killed by Kelly', it states:

PARA.TAB: After three days of intense negotiation, Mr Griffiths had stitched up a deal between the Opposition, formerly bitter opponents of the legislation, the forestry industry and the Tasmanian Government, which involved only minor amendments.
He was then told by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that he would also have to secure the agreement of Mrs Kelly and the Left faction of the ALP before the deal could go ahead.
Mrs Kelly on the Left took the opportunity to dump the legislation they had bitterly opposed when it was forced through Cabinet by the then prime minister Mr Bob Hawke last year.

SPEECH.PARA: That article goes on, and obviously Lenore Taylor has some excellent contacts who have told her about the inside innuendo and dealing of the Labor Party and what is going on with this particular issue, and where it is going.

PARA.TAB: Our doubts still remain about the detail of the Bill. We say to the industry, large and small, that it has been the victim of the Government's crass, short term, political manoeuvring.
