The industry has been ready to invest billions of dollars in an environmentally responsible way, in value adding, in timber and paper, and by so doing to create jobs in regional Australia and reduce the $2 billion trade deficit in wood and paper products. If this Government is unable to deliver the commitment it has made to the industry, the employees of the industry, and the coalition, to provide genuine resource and investment security, we will certainly alter it after the next election. We will certainly go down that track that the Government was supposedly committed to do.

Mr Temporary Chairman, I draw to your attention an amendment that I will be moving to clause 1, which I believe is shortly to be distributed in the chamber, which will challenge the Government on this very issue of the agreement that Minister Griffiths struck with the industry, that it indicated to the Opposition it was prepared to work with. We will move that amendment to change the title of the Bill, making it the Forest Conservation and Major Projects Bill, and we will test the Government by saying to the Government, `Why won't you now give the other commitments that you indicated in the consultations and the discussions that you were prepared to move? Why won't you give the commitments that guarantee jobs? Why won't you give the commitments?'.

It is only because of the internal faction-ridden Labor Party politics that the Left, the green Left of the Labor Party, has obviously done deals with the Democrats. They are obviously worried about that new magazine flavour because `socialism' is no longer the easy word for the Labor Party to sell; it is pandering to the green Left and the Left of the Labor Party. It is now very easy to see where they have got the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), where they have got the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), and where they have got any of the Ministers that have got anything to do with resource development or security. Yes, we will move the amendment that the Government ought to have put on the table here, as it indicated it would, and we will certainly say that in clause 1 this is an issue that should be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is totally inappropriate for Senator Tambling to attempt to take the moral high ground on this matter. When we reflect—and I think we need to reflect—on the very extensive number of speakers which the Opposition put on during the second reading stage and the—
—We get a right to speak whenever we want to, as members of the Senate—

—Absolutely. That is the very point I am making. The Opposition has a right to put on as many speakers as it likes, and it took up that right and put on many speakers. However, that was not the point I was making. I was trying to make the point that every single one of those speakers said that this legislation would not be passed unless the 17 amendments which have been consistently before this chamber were inserted into the legislation. Every single one of them said that this legislation will not pass unless those 17 amendments put up, originally by NAFI, are accepted. What do we find? We find Mr Lloyd and Mr Griffiths trying to do a grubby little deal which would have changed two words only in the title and that, as Senator Tambling has just said, would have made it acceptable to the Opposition. I ask: what sort of a back-down is that? Senator Tambling comes in here and tries to claim the moral high ground over this by saying that this would have made it all acceptable to them, despite everything that has been said in the past. To blame the Government for some sort of dealings is totally reprehensible and does not accord with the facts at all.

PARA.TAB: In relation to those 17 amendments, I understand the Opposition wants to rehearse them yet again. We have spent a great deal of time with this legislation in the second reading stage, during which time those amendments have been thoroughly rehearsed. All of those matters have gone off to a committee. They have been dealt with extensively in the committee. We now come back to the committee stage of the Senate in dealing with this legislation. We know what will happen: those amendments will not be acceptable either to the Government or to the Democrats and they will not pass. In view of the fact that it costs something like $26 per word to run this chamber, let us, for heaven's sake, vote on those 17 amendments—if that is what the Opposition wants—and get rid of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here in the committee stage the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. The second reading debate of this Bill, in which honourable senators addressed themselves to the broader issues encompassed by this Bill, has been held. As a result of that second reading debate, this Bill has been sent to a committee of inquiry, which took public submissions and heard the views of the major players in this debate. That has concluded, and we are now back to debating whether the clauses in the Bill are properly expressed, in terms of the objectives of the Bill and the aims of the Government. This is a Bill with a very long history and a Bill to which the Government has strenuously devoted its energies. This is a Bill which is aimed at fundamentally securing—after an exhaustive study of environmental, economical and Aboriginal issues—a resource so that development can proceed in the sure and certain knowledge that that resource base is available.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a foreshadowed amendment to the first clause of the Bill, the short title. We have—and I must say I agree entirely with the last speaker—an extraordinary situation from the Opposition. We have just heard from Senator Tambling what I regard as one of the most extraordinary self-exposes of perfidy that has been revealed in this chamber.

The Opposition, on this legislation, can run, but as sure as hell it cannot hide from its own position here. Let me quote to the Committee the front page article in today's Hobart Mercury. Before I do so, we had a quote from the Australian delivered to us for our edification this morning by the Opposition. Essentially, the case made by the Opposition was that there is some factionalism within the Labor Party, that there are conspiracies, there are byzantine manoeuvres, there are shadowy deals, and for those reasons—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are your words.
—This is your allegation. I am just defining your allegation.
—They are your adjectives.

—If the honourable senator is not satisfied with my definition of what he said, I cannot recall precisely the words he used, but the Hansard will reveal the words he used. As I recall, the weight of his remarks was that some deal had been made with the Green Left in the Labor Party, and he quoted approvingly from a report I have not seen which he alleges was in the Australian, written by reporter Lenore Taylor, about some alleged involvement by Minister Kelly. I would have thought that the intention was to indicate that something shadowy or undesirable was occurring. Maybe he wanted us to be led to the conviction that something elevating and desirable was occurring; I must say that is an odd conviction in the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The response of the Opposition has been to try to pretend that we are at this impasse for reasons that are internal to the Labor Party. I think it is about time that the Opposition stood up and declared itself as to what principle it does support. Why does it hate Tasmania? I would not mind having an answer to that question. Why does the Opposition hate Tasmania? Why does it not put its actions where its policy mouth so frequently is when it talks as it does, from a self-righteous plane, saying that it is in favour of development and jobs? Self-righteous indignation synthetically developed in the pretence to principle—that is the Opposition's position, and here it stands exposed.

I talk about principle: I ask the Opposition to declare exactly what the principles are. What it has said in this debate is that the name of the Bill will determine whether it supports it. As I recall, it was Shakespeare who said:

SPEECH.PARA: What's in a name?
A rose by any other name smells as sweet.

If you change one or two words in the title of this Bill, the content of the Bill smells as sweetly as it does before or after that change occurs. The principal objectives, the mechanisms of the Bill, remain. If the Opposition is obstructing this Bill simply because it has a pedantic fascination with expression in title, I do not see any simple principle involved in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to save face.
—I accept that interjection. In order to save some face, Opposition senators have contrived an argument in the pretence to principle which revolves around a name.
—It is what Minister Griffiths said.

—It revolves around a name. That is a pathetic position. Let me go to the front page of the Hobart Mercury. The Opposition can quote from national newspapers, but the impact of this Bill is felt in Tasmania most of all, and I look forward to hearing the answer to my question—why does the Opposition hate Tasmania?—in the latter stages of this debate.

PARA.TAB: What the Tasmanian newspapers say, because it is their interests that are being affected, is probably of more importance than what national journals might pretend to report in the hothouse atmosphere of this Parliament, as some journalists in the gallery scurry around in the non-members bar and other back reaches of this building to try to winkle out a rumour or two. The headline in the Hobart Mercury is `Goodbye, pulp mill'. That is the headline, `Goodbye, pulp mill: Senate poised to reject resource security bill', and under the by-line of Angela Leary it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania's long-awaited billion-dollar pulp mill appears doomed with vital legislation set to be rejected by the Senate this morning.
That—if I might divert for a minute—is prophetic, because clearly what is being said by those on the Opposition benches is that they intend to defeat it. The article continues:
A week of tense negotiations in Canberra fell apart yesterday with the Federal Opposition maintaining its opposition to the Government's resource security legislation.

PARA.TAB: It was "the end", a spokesman for the pulp mill's proponents said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Forestry Commissioner, Mr Evan Rolley, was sent to Canberra urgently yesterday in a last-ditch bid to persuade Opposition and Democrat senators to save the legislation.

PARA.TAB: His mission follows a long series of similar desperate trips going back to the days of the Labor Government and culminating in a crushing defeat for the state Minister for Resources, Mr Tony Rundle, this week.
Mr Rundle went to Canberra to lobby his Liberal colleagues and the Federal Government confident that a compromise could be reached.
But last night he said he was dismayed at what happened and that it looked "very grave" for the legislation.
The only glimmer of hope for the mill came from the Premier, Mr Ray Groom, in his "state of the state" speech in Parliament yesterday.
He said that in the event of the legislation failing the Government would look at alternative measures.
Tasmania already has resource security legislation—passed during the Labor Government's term with the backing of the then Liberal Opposition. But the State Government and forest companies—

SPEECH.PARA: and I should emphasise `the State Government', a Liberal State Government, and `forest companies', that is, the major developers—
maintain they need the complementary federal law.

This is the complementary Federal law, this one that is before the chamber now. This is what the Tasmanian Liberal Government wants. This is what the developers of the pulp mill in north Tasmania want and this is what the Liberal Opposition is voting down. This is an Opposition which parades itself around Australia as pro development and in the recession as the supporter of full employment and jobs.

PARA.TAB: What is unarguable in this debate is that, if this Bill were to be passed, a major development project in north Tasmania would go ahead and jobs would be created in that State. What is also unarguable is that there is a high level of unemployment in that State and any job created would be welcome. But this is what the Opposition is voting down. So—and let every unemployed person in Australia hear this—the Opposition's credentials in arguing for development and in pretending to support full employment and employment opportunities are nothing short of hypocritical.

The Government has a difference with the Australian Democrats because they are going to vote this legislation down, too. But, might I say, it is an honourable difference. The Australian Democrats have not wavered in terms of their views of this legislation; and they have conducted their affairs, in terms of this debate, while not in a way which pleases us in policy terms, honourably. That is not what the Opposition here can say.

I could go on and end my quote, but at this stage perhaps I should say that what the Opposition has made clear is precisely what Senator Coulter has said: there are 17 amendments; every one of them has to get up; if none of them gets up then the Bill will not go through. I put this to the Opposition: why not rediscover principle? Why not do something which is actually consistent with what you say? Why not declare support for this legislation so that jobs can be created in northern Tasmania? Why not do something which will actually enable a major project to go ahead? Why not do something that will support the Liberal State Government in Tasmania?

Premier Ray Groom, in his `state of the State' address in Tasmania the other day, made it clear that the future of development and employment in the Apple Island State of Australia is dependent on there being a viable forest products industry established in that State. He has made it clear that that is one of the clearest development objectives of his State. That was also the view in previous statements of the Labor Party in that State. What he has also made clear, in a myriad of statements and many of the lobbyings that he has made, is that he wants this Bill to go ahead.

Mr Tony Rundle, according to the Hobart Mercury, has been lobbying the Federal Liberal Opposition—a Federal Liberal government defies belief! There is a desire for this Bill to go ahead, but no, the name ought to change. Unless the name changes it will not go ahead.

To conclude, there is no principle. There is arrant and blatant hypocrisy and at last it stands revealed. I do not take any joy from that at all. It is a nice political point to make, and it is one that we will continue to make, but in the end it is a political point.

The tragedy is not that we can win a political argument against the Opposition; we can do that any day of the week. The tragedy is that those people who would get jobs do not get them. That is the tragedy. Real Australians looking for work and looking for futures do not have them—that is the tragedy. In the end I would hope that somewhere deep within its soul the Liberal Opposition would find some skerrick of principle and at least have the courage to reverse a decision which is palpably wrong, on all the evidence, and vote for this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker went through so many total errors of fact that I really would not know where to start. For a dissertation of pure humbug and hypocrisy it would have outclassed even Senator Evans at his best. As far as being lobbied by our State colleague Mr Rundle is concerned, I have not been lobbied by Mr Rundle—the Minister may take my word for that. I can also say the same for my colleague Senator Walters; I can also say the same for Senator Calvert—that is, the three of us from Tasmania who happen to be in the chamber at the moment. Why does the Minister not make sure that if he is going to start quoting stuff he does not quote from the gutter press? If the Minister wishes to quote I would suggest he at least quotes from authentic sources. I would give him the alternative of seeing what the Burnie Advocate said on the same thing.
—Where is the Burnie Advocate? Is that in the same area as the proposed mill?
—This is the area that is most affected. Under the heading `Govt shies from Bill compromise' the paper says:

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government's on-again, off-again resource security legislation took another dive yesterday as furious Coalition members and industry groups claimed the Government had reneged on a deal stitched up in the past few days.
The Forest Conservation and Development Bill has been on shaky ground ever since both the Opposition and the Democrats said they would vote against it.

Last-minute talks this week between Opposition primary industries spokesman Bruce Lloyd, Resources Minister Alan Griffiths and industry groups produced a three-point agreement, including a change of title to the Forest Conservation and Major Projects Bill.

However, the Opposition yesterday said the agreement did not widen the legislation to include smaller projects but had simply changed the speech which would accompany the Bill. National Association of Forest Industries executive director Robert Bain said the industry was "amazed" at the about-face of the Minister yesterday, particularly given the amount of ground already conceded by the Opposition and the industry on key points of the Bill.
"After three days of discussions and two days of apparent agreement, the Government has walked away and left their Minister with an agreement they're not going to honour", he said.
"If it fails now it will be 100 p.c. the responsibility of the Government".

SPEECH.PARA: That is the thing that the people of Australia, and in particular the people of Tasmania, need to know. It is 100 per cent the responsibility of this Government. Right since day one the Government has not been bona fide towards this legislation. It never wanted to see it go through, and it still does not want to. I would like to ask many of the honourable senators opposite what their view of this legislation really is. We know what it is, and they should be required to say so publicly.

PARA.TAB: We have this rubbishy document, One Nation, which made all sorts of ridiculous statements about industry and what the Government was going to do about it. It even mentioned pulp mills. The first time that anything crops up to do with industry in any way and the Government has the opportunity to do something, what happens? It goes to water, backs off, and the Left takes over, and it goes down the chute. The Government does not want the legislation and it never did. The legislation could not work in the form in which it was presented to the chamber, and we all know that. The total lack of bona fides and the build-up of the humbug and the hypocrisy that has gone on in the Government really is monumental.

I give credit to Minister Griffiths. He has met us, he has talked to us, he has given us undertakings, he did whatever he could to see that this would work. Several of us had undertakings from him that he would go along with the compensation clause, for instance. Not only has he said that once; he has said that to probably a dozen of us. But we have not got it now because he could not get it through whatever they call that mess on the other side. How can there be a Ministry when the Minister can make arrangements and then get dumped by the Prime Minister or when he is not game to go to Caucus or something of that nature?

The company knows full well what the situation is, the Tasmanian Government now knows full well what the situation is, but the agenda of the Left seems to override everything. It does not matter what happens as far as the Tasmanian Government or the Federal Government is concerned; it does not matter what Parliament thinks; it is what some closet group of Lefties somewhere in Australia decide they will or will not do. For instance, I realise that at present Mr Ferguson may be a bit upset about what his actions brought him into in Tasmania in the last week or two, but surely that should not be enough to determine what happens here concerning national legislation. No amount of legislation can cover the lack of good faith and goodwill that is necessary at a time like this. There never was any, and legislation cannot provide it if it does not exist.
While the Prime Minister is tearing about trying to design new flags, destroy the Commonwealth, abolish the Senate, or whatever his agenda is at the moment—

TALK.START.PARA: —He will not spell it out; that is his problem.

—No, we do not know what his agenda is, either. But we do know that he threw out Minister Griffiths and the agreement last night. He would be much better advised to look after what is happening in Australia now and what could affect jobs and to try to recover something from the One Nation document that he is still parading, or what is left of it. If he would consider what he said with that and if he had any intention of seeing that the future of Australian working people was maintained, he would be spending more time on that than on redesigning flags. Still, I realise that he now appreciates that that is about his limit when it comes to political matters.

PARA.TAB: This title change is essential, and it is very much an integral part. It is part of the bona fides of the Government now. It is the bona fides that are on the line. This agreement between the Minister for Resources, the Tasmanian Government, NAFI, the Forest Industries of Tasmania and the Forest Protection Society covers everybody. We have an agreement made without duress by all those people. There is the resolution—I hold it in my hand. But no, what did the Prime Minister say? He said, `No—out'. Minister Kelly has more power than the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Remote control in Malaysia.

—That is right. But that is the way the Government is run. Goodness gracious me! I really did not understand Minister Cook when he spoke in this chamber a few moments ago. When we get lectured in here about principle, of all things, by people like Senator Cook, I really do wonder.
—That is because I have got them and you have not.

—There we are: it is like measles—he does not know he has them until somebody points them out to him. But what principles are there in supporting the reneging of an agreement that has been reached? That is what the principle is. The principle is that an agreement was reached. This negotiation has gone on since November. We are now through to the end of April. It has not been easy. We have made every possible manoeuvre that has been known to endeavour to obtain agreement. We have a very strong desire to see that legislation is passed.

PARA.TAB: I do not accept that legislation should be necessary, and it is necessary only because the investing public and the companies of Australia cannot trust those opposite in government. There would no need for this legislation—none at all—if there were trust. But there is no trust. There is no principle, as those opposite are demonstrating. So how can there be trust?

What we have to do is to make the Government realise that, if it wants to proceed with the One Nation policy, it must show some goodwill and must demonstrate a capacity to do it. It has not done either at this stage. We are still waiting on it—and there is still time. While ever this legislation is before the Parliament, the Government has the opportunity to bring about this development which, very weakly, a minority of the members of the Government claim they want. I cannot see that the Government has demonstrated that it wants to carry that through.

The people of Australia more and more are starting to see through the Government. The people of Tasmania now fully understand where the blame lies for the hold-up that there has been. But while ever I can delay this, with a view to giving those opposite the opportunity to do what is necessary, I will keep delaying. I make no apology for that. My constituency would like me to continue to do what I am doing, with a view to getting this approved. We want development in Tasmania; we need development in Tasmania; and we have been hamstrung by the tuppeny-ha'penny Government we have had for the last 2 1/2 years down there.

We now have an opportunity to get ahead but we are hamstrung by a Federal government. I wonder whether honourable senators opposite would have taken such a ridiculous attitude if the Government had been that puppet government which we had before. But that is the way they have chosen to do it. At this stage I still give them the opportunity to accept the agreement that has been reached as the basis under which we proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want any of the Opposition members to allege that I have misled the Senate because I quoted from Shakespeare in my earlier address and I got the quote wrong. The quote is from Romeo and Juliet, act II, scene ii, line 42. What I said was:

SPEECH.PARA: What's in a name? A rose by any name smells as sweet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just redesigning the name.
—The actual quote is:

SPEECH.PARA: What's in a name? that which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say the same thing to Mrs Kelly?
—Having corrected that, I can save Senator Crane a trip in here to make the allegation he normally makes, inaccurately as always.
—Have you apologised to Senator Panizza yet?

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I notice some agitation in the Opposition ranks. I know that some other Opposition senators intend to rise in this debate and we are on notice that Senator Tambling will move an amendment shortly, so I would like to take this opportunity, in view of what Senator Archer has said, to make it clear that, irrespective of his views of the Hobart Mercury, the article that I have referred to, printed on the front page of the Hobart Mercury today, quotes Mr Chris Oldfield—who, I might add, has gained some notoriety lately—the spokesman for the proponents of the pulp mill in northern Tasmania, NBH-Peko, as saying when referring to this legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: But no security resource, no pulp mill.
That is the view of the company that is proposing this major development. Mr Oldfield is reported as saying:

PARA.TAB: A new pulp mill would have provided 2,000 jobs in northern Tasmania in the construction stage.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the construction phase alone. He is further reported as saying:

PARA.TAB: A pulp mill would have provided the impetus for an economic revival in northern Tasmania.
But no resource security legislation, no pulp mill.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the legislation that is before this chamber. If we do not get it, there will be no pulp mill, no economic revival in northern Tasmania, no 2,000 jobs in the construction phase alone.

PARA.TAB: So I pose this question to honourable senators opposite and I hope they answer it. When one of the Opposition senators rises to receive the call or when Senator Tambling moves his foreshadowed motion, I would like an answer to this question. The Federal Government wants this legislation. We know that Ray Groom, the Premier of Tasmania, on behalf of his State Liberal Government, wants this legislation. We know he is supported in that by the Labor Opposition in Tasmania led by Michael Field. They want this legislation. North Broken Hill, the proponent of this development, wants this legislation. Why will the Opposition not agree?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, it really is the dregs when the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) says that the coalition should rediscover principle. The Minister has never had any principle. I only have to quote from a few years ago—
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. That is an unparliamentary reflection on a member of this chamber.
—It is not.
—It is also untrue, but I ask that it be withdrawn as an unparliamentary reflection.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, the words are not unparliamentary.
—The words containing an allegation that I am unprincipled person are untrue. I resent them. They are unparliamentary and they should be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—It is a very hard point to rule on. I think Senator Walters's words were that the Minister had no principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—I think the Minister interprets that another way.

—I do not accept that. I think that is a reprehensible reflection on a fellow senator; it is fundamentally untrue and it is meant to be a term of abuse in this chamber. Senator Walters is well known for hurling abuse and attacking the individual, not the issue. I ask for her to show some decency on this occasion and withdraw it.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I have no intention of asking the Minister to withdraw that. I am prepared to take the heat in this kitchen when he is not. I have no intention of withdrawing my comments, either. As I said, honourable senators will remember debating the remuneration of Ministers in this place some time ago. The Minister was questioned on his remuneration; I queried it and he said that it was the perks of power that he was getting. He says that he has principles; this Minister has no principles. That is my main concern about this Minister telling us to rediscover principles.

PARA.TAB: Let us look back on the history of the two parties, because that is what I want to do in relation to this particular resource security. This Government has always used environmental issues as a political plaything—a political football. We all remember in this place what happened prior to the last election and the election before that. We remember, particularly in Tasmania, because we had the opportunity of a pulp mill on our north-west coast. We remember very particularly the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) saying to the greenies, `I will stop the mill, if you will give us your preferences'. And he stopped the mill being built on the north-west coast of Tasmania for the greenies' preferences—no other reason, no other issue, but for the greenies' preferences.

The mob on the other side tell us that we have no principles. We stated publicly that we needed that development. Unemployment in that particular area in Tasmania is extremely high and we went out and said, `It is to be the best pulp mill in the world'. We had been given that promise and this Government refused to allow the development in return for the handful of greenie preferences that won it the election. As a coalition, we received at that election the highest number of votes in Australia, but because the Government was given the handful of preferences from the greenies in exchange for refusing to allow development in our island, it was able to win in some of the marginal electorates. That is how it got into government.

So government members have always used environmental issues as a political football. When they got into government, they denied us that development in our State. We have to remember that it was not just that development, because when a government has a big industry with a very large investment hanging around waiting expectantly for permission to go ahead, and for political reasons alone it is denied it, then credibility for investment, and the confidence of those people wanting to invest, are completely scuppered. That is what happened in Tasmania. The Government scuppered the confidence of anyone who wanted to come in and invest in development. That was as a result of this Government and Senator Richardson stopping the mill and allowing just a handful of votes to get them into power. It has allowed our State's unemployment to rise to the extent it has.

We know the way those opposite play politics; we know that they have absolutely insisted on having a recession. We were told so by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he was Treasurer—the `recession we had to have' that has become the depression we had to have. We know that we have over a million unemployed. We have just on a million that do not do an hour's work a week. If they have done an hour, according to the statistics, they are employed. So imagine how many people are really underemployed. Those opposite are a disgrace, and they are here again now denying us further employment in Tasmania.

They created the problem; they did all that destructive work; and they got into government. Now they are saying, `Look, we really are good boys. We know that the inter-governmental agreements that we made prior to the election cannot be trusted'—and everyone who gave evidence to our Committee said that the inter-governmental agreements could not be trusted and that we needed legislation—`so we will give you legislation'. Who spoke against that legislation in the Cabinet room when Bob Hawke, who was Prime Minister at that stage, was putting it through? I will tell honourable senators who spoke against it. It was Mr Keating. He opposed that legislation in the Cabinet room—he opposed it very strongly—but, when he became Prime Minister, he agreed that the legislation would go through.

That legislation is rubbishy legislation, and let me explain why. We need three main amendments, if it is to apply to all resources in Australia. This legislation applies only to investments over $100m. So the timber industry in our State, which wants to invest $32m, has no security of resource at all—none at all. Anyone who has an investment of $40m, $50m, $60m, or $90m has no security at all; it applies only to investments of $100m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—It is in the legislation and, indeed, combined companies wanting to invest down at Geeveston, south of Hobart, have said that they need security of investment. Gunns and Risby want to invest $32m. However, they say, `We are not prepared to go along with that $32m investment unless we have security of resource'. How can they? How can they invest $32m in Geeveston unless they have got some security that they will have a resource to use? They said, `However, this legislation does not cover us and we are not prepared to go ahead with it until it does'. The Minister says, `That is not true'. He cannot be trusted.

PARA.TAB: We had a committee of the Senate inquire into the legislation. The umbrella group of the industry, NAFI, which covers all forestry industries, came before us and said, `We need the amendments the Opposition is putting. If we do not get them, the legislation is no good'. That is what the forestry industry umbrella group said. We had the unions come before us. The unions said exactly the same thing. The employees, the unions, of those forestry industries said to us, `We want the Opposition amendments. Without them, the legislation is rubbish. It is no good'.

We then had Tasmanian Forest Products and Petersville Sleigh come before us and say exactly the same thing; `We need the Opposition amendments, without them the legislation is no good'. We had APPM come before us saying, `We want the Opposition amendments'. APPM is the company building the mill. However, the Minister quoted APPM as saying that it will not go along with the mill unless it gets this legislation. APPM has said, `We want the Opposition amendments but because we are very keen to build that mill, even though the legislation is not what we want, we will accept a second-rate piece of legislation and we will attempt to get partners to support us'. When APPM was asked whether it would go ahead with the mill if this legislation went through, it said, `No, we cannot give you that guarantee. We will not say that we will not go ahead without it but we will not give you a guarantee that we will build the mill if we get it because our partners, the people we are going to try to get, may not think this legislation is good enough to join us'. So APPM will not give us a guarantee that it will go ahead with the mill if this legislation goes through.

Who did we have then? We had Premiers and representatives of Premiers, and we had letters from Premiers to the Committee saying that they all wanted the legislation. This Minister has denied that. Because my time is almost out, I will come back to the main thrust which is that this is a political decision by the Government to destroy the mill on the north-west because of the pressure of the Left. I only want to substantiate that with one quote and that is from the Labor Leader of the Opposition in my State. When he was asked, `Was he happy with the legislation?', he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, I would regard the legislation as not perfect and not a completely accurate reflection of the forest strategy in Tasmania, but I am used to being in positions where I do not get my own way completely.
When asked if he would be happier if we got the amendments he said:
What I see is that the Left of the Labor Party has grave reservations—
the Left of the Labor Party, the factional situation in the Labor Party—
about the principle of resource security and there are some in the Right who think that it would be politically expedient if it did not succeed.

So the Labor Opposition Leader in our State says that the Labor Party will not take it back because the Left will not agree and a lot of the Right have reservations about it. Do not let the Minister stand here and say that it is not a factional business in the Labor Party; it is nothing else but a factional situation. Senator Bolkus rung the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in Kuala Lumpur and told her to get onto the Prime Minister to stop it before an agreement had been reached. I will come back to that later.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to reflect briefly on two remarks made, one made by Senator Archer and one made by Senator Walters a moment ago. Senator Archer in his contribution said, `This legislation is unnecessary'. Of course, he is reflecting there on the report to the principal recommendation of the Resource Assessment Commission. We have debated that report in the last couple of days in this chamber and Senator Tambling strongly praised that report. After two years of very careful consideration, the Resource Assessment Commission has said, `This legislation is unnecessary'. That is the first point I want to make.

PARA.TAB: The second point that I want to make reflects on a remark made by Senator Walters: there is abundant evidence—and it has been said over and over again—that, even if this legislation is passed, there is no guarantee that a pulp mill will be built in Tasmania or anywhere else, with or without the amendments which the Opposition is putting. So let us not base arguments on the supposition that, if the legislation is passed, or is passed with or without amendments, there is some guarantee that a pulp mill will be built, because that is false. Nobody has been prepared to give any guarantee that there will be any development whatsoever as a consequence of this legislation being passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is a good place for me to come in. Senator Coulter said that there is no guarantee that the mill will be built even if this legislation is passed. I think that is patently obvious after what has happened in the last couple of days. If the Government cannot even deliver an agreement that was made between the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the industry, then how the hell can it believe that a Bill that was passed here today would not be interfered with by Mrs Kelly or by anybody else? She has proved already that she can stop an agreement being honoured by one of her fellow Ministers. So why would the Government, when it suited it—whether it be a political reason or otherwise—not find a way around a Bill that has already been passed?

PARA.TAB: I was a member of that committee that took evidence. We heard plenty of evidence about agreements that had been broken in the past. In fact, we even had copies of them given to us as evidence. I remember it being put forward by the Minister's representatives at that meeting that these new agreements were going to be enhanced intergovernmental agreements. Quite frankly, if the Government thinks that we would believe that those intergovernmental agreements would be honoured, when we have found out during the last day that it cannot even honour an agreement made between the Minister and the industry, it just shows how worthless and what a waste of time that was.

My colleague Senator Walters referred to the real reason why there has been an about-face and a breaking of this agreement with the industry yesterday. Mr Field, a former leader of the State Government, made it quite obvious—and I quote from the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: What I see is that the Left of the Labor Party has grave reservations about the principle of resource security, and there are some in the Right who think that it would be politically expedient if it did not succeed.

That is what he said. I will not mention the names of members of the Government, but even as recently as last night at a committee meeting I said to a member of the Government that this agreement had fallen apart because of pressure from the left wing, and he said to me, `You are not a thousand per cent wrong on that one'. We know the real reason, and for the Minister to come in here and try to ram down our throat that there is no other reason for that agreement being broken is absolute rubbish.

PARA.TAB: I bet that APPM is sitting back and looking at the situation that it is left with. If it could believe this Government, as Senator Coulter said, it would not need any resource security legislation. As Senator Walters said earlier, there is a lot of doubt whether the company would build a mill, anyway. Even if this Bill were passed today, we know for a fact that the company is going to face up to two years of scientific investigation into the resources for that particular mill. So it would have to wait for up to two years anyway, even if the Bill were passed today. What guarantee is there that in that two years Mrs Kelly or somebody from the Green movement or any other movement does not find a five-leaf clover or something similar to hold it up again?

The history of this matter is that, ever since day one, there has been a hold-up—all the way through. There have been 11 inquiries in 15 years into timber resources in Tasmania. Another two years of delay is coming about even if the Bill is passed. I do not believe that, if enough pressure is put on Mrs Kelly by the conservation movement, she would not find another excuse to hold it up for even longer. So where would we be?

Are we on record as saying that this legislation is no good? We have the support of the industry and of the unions—or we did have the support of the unions; I think they have changed their mind now after a media release I saw this morning, where the branch secretary of the Tasmanian Workers Union, Mr Ken Bacon, in a letter to the Minister for Resources said that APPM was guilty of atrocities and had ignored its responsibilities to the forest industries. He indicated to the Government that the Bill did not apply to APPM. That is a typical example of what is going on behind the scenes.

One would have to be an absolute idiot to think that there has not been pressure applied to the Government by the union movement over this APPM-union dispute at Burnie. I am not going to buy into the rights and wrongs of what is going on there, but one would have to say that APPM was less than smart in pulling on the unions at such a time. If it was so fair dinkum about having this resource security legislation pass, it certainly chose its time unwisely. Sometimes I wonder what its agenda really is. Nevertheless, it has said that it can live with this Bill. I do not believe it could live with it. In fact, if it were passed, I doubt whether it would, because, as I said previously, if enough pressure were put on Mrs Kelly from the anti-mill people, I am sure that she would find some way around it. She has done in the past, and she would again. We have demonstrated that, and that is the reason we put these amendments forward—to try to tighten up the Bill to make sure that once approved, it would be workable.

I think the real answer to all this mess was summed up in the National Association of Forest Industries release put out yesterday by Robert Bain. It is headed `Government Credibility Collapses'. He is quoted as saying:
Industry and Opposition made major concessions and we negotiated in good faith with the relevant Minister, who then presented a workable solution to a political impasse to the Prime Minister.

Now, despite the assurances of a Cabinet Minister, it appears that forest industries—and the Australian economy—may be left out in the cold again, and no amount of interest rate inducement is going to change that.
If the legislation negotiated by Minister Griffiths fails, thousands of rural job opportunities will be lost and large sections of Australian industry encouraged to move offshore.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember very well when the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs was receiving evidence. This particular matter has been going on for a long time and I admit it has caused me and, I think, every other Tasmanian senator, a fair amount of heartburn, because we have been concerned about getting the right sort of Bill. But when the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) presented his evidence at that Committee hearing, I began to see a glimmer of hope.

PARA.TAB: In fact, when I returned to my home State and was speaking with particular people who were interested in the Bill, I said, `I have not given this away yet. Comments made by Senator Cook gave me an indication, anyway, that their interpretation of the Bill is a bit different from what we think it is. Perhaps there is room there for negotiation and an agreement down the track'. In fact, I said to somebody down there, `I do not think the opera is over until the fat lady sings'. It looks like the fat lady has sung now and the opera is over, because those glimmers of hope that we saw, the comments that were made, and the agreement that was drummed up yesterday between Minister Griffiths and the industry, have all gone for nothing. The fact is that the coalition parties have moved 95 per cent and the Government will not even move one per cent. That is because they are not allowed to, because the unions are not letting them, and the Prime Minister does not want it, anyway.

I was quite amused to hear the Minister for Resources this morning in an interview with Andrew Sholl. Andrew Sholl said, `Okay, at the last minute you had a solution and now it is lost'. Mr Griffiths went on to talk about a discussion paper and the discussions they had. He said, `I have to bring the Bill on today because I do not want to delay it'. He said, `In the end no-one was of a view that a delay was justified'. He made out that it was not worth putting off for another week because Caucus was not meeting for another week. Therefore it would delay matters if he did not bring it in today. After all the hold-ups we have had, to turn around and say that the reason why it came in today was that it would be delayed if it had to go to Caucus was quite amusing because we know that if it went back to Caucus it would be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that, do you?
—We know that because Mr Field told us. It is on the record.
—You know what our Caucus will do?
—Mr Field seems to know.
—Is he a member of our Caucus?

—He has a fair idea and he speaks to members of your Caucus. You can bet your life on that. He spent enough time up here trying to convince them to do the right thing. In the finish, when he could not convince them he tried to convince us. He said so. He said, `I have no hope of convincing my colleagues because they do not want it so it is up to you fellows to compromise'. That is what he said. The Minister knows he said that.
—And we did.
—We have done what former Premier Field said. At least we have tried to help. What happened?
—You ratted.
—You even ratted on your own Minister. He came to an agreement—
—That is arrant rubbish.

—The Minister knows he came to an agreement with the industry yesterday. Senator Tambling presented it here this morning. What happened to that? The Minister talks about the Mercury newspaper. I am not going to go as far as my colleagues and call it what they did. I thought it was pretty good when we had to turn around and spend our own money to put an advertisement in the Mercury to tell the people of southern Tasmania what our position was because no-one else would. I do not have the quote here. Senator Sherry is not here but I wish he were so I could tell him to his face. He would remember the interview he did with the Advocate. I was quite amused. In that article he said, `We need compensation. Compensation will have to be provided'. Where is the compensation in this Bill? Even you, Minister, said in the hearing, if I remember, `We have paid compensation in the past in unusual and exceptional circumstances and perhaps we might pay it again', or words to that effect. Senator Sherry said we need compensation. He is on record as saying that. It is in the Advocate in his own article. Yet where is there any mention of compensation in this Bill? PARA.TAB: I would also like to put it on the record that, whilst not being too critical of my State colleagues, I was not lobbied by Mr Rundle when he was up here. I have been here since Monday morning and he has not contacted me in any shape or form except for a copy of a letter I received yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could not find you.
—My staff were there.
—Where were you?

—If you would like to know where I was all day Monday, I was at a committee hearing regarding another Bill that is coming up—the Deer Levy Slaughter Bill. You will hear a bit more about that later. The Minister quoted from the Hobart Mercury this morning. There was something else in there that he may have seen. I only hope that this may come to pass. I hope that this Government does not interfere with it. The Premier, Mr Ray Groom, and not Robin Gray as you quite wrongly said, in his speech to Parliament yesterday, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the event of the legislation failing the Government would look at alternative measures.
If it does I hope it does not run into the same sort of interference that this has had from Mrs Kelly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been told that I said that Robin Gray, not Ray Groom, was the Premier of Tasmania. I would want to insult neither Ray Groom nor Robin Gray by saying that. So if I said that, I correct the record: it is clearly Ray Groom who is the Premier of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: In this committee stage debate on the Bill we are debating the first clause, the title. Precious little has been said about the title in this debate until now. Honourable senators have seized on this opportunity to perambulate around the chamber all their indignation and all their views about the body of the Bill, something that they had an opportunity to do, and did do, at the second reading stage ad nauseam and something that some of them have done in the Senate Committee inquiry.

While Senator Calvert may not be able to get his views into the Hobart Mercury on something that has been aired in the public debate that has ensued, it would be very useful if we could concentrate on what is before the chamber, namely, the title, because it seems that the vote of the Opposition depends on what we call this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the commitment of this Government.

—I just put it again to the Opposition that the Bill's title accurately describes what it is about, and those opposite should come off this pedantry and sophistry and allow the thing to pass because, as the company has said, as quoted in this morning's Hobart Mercury, `no resource security legislation, no pulp mill'. There are 2,000 jobs in northern Tasmania in the construction phase alone, and this pulp mill would provide the impetus for economic revival in northern Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: My reason for rising at this point is to reply to some of the wilder allegations made by the Opposition thus far in the debate and to return to an entreaty I made when I last sat down. None of the Opposition have accepted my invitation to answer the question, so I take this opportunity to remind them of the question. The Federal Government wants this Bill and has put it forward. The Tasmanian Government wants this Bill, has said so and supports it. The proponents of the pulp mill in northern Tasmania want this Bill and have said so, and have asked for it to be supported. The question is: Why will those opposite not vote for it? I would be grateful to hear an answer to that question, because the silence is deafening, and silence is condemnatory in this context.

Senator Walters has said a couple of things that also require an answer. She made a long contribution here a moment ago about the so-called defects in this Bill on the basis that only projects of $100m or more can get up under this legislation. She cited a number of projects valued at less than $100m in various places in Tasmania that, in her assertion, were unable to get up under this legislation. It is true that this Bill prescribes projects of $100m or more as being encompassed by it. They are substantial projects. Projects at that level are substantial. But it is not true to say that other projects cannot be embraced by the terms of this Bill. In fact, everyone knows that they can. But the obligation on the proponents of projects of lesser value than $100m is to aggregate their projects with other projects drawing on the resource.

We cannot have the view that, no matter what else, the resource is infinite. The resource is the forests of Tasmania; they are not an infinite resource. They are finite. In order that development and industry can proceed, there is an absolute need to know what all of the projects will be that want to draw on that resource and to encourage those projects of lesser value to aggregate, because what the Government does under this legislation is to conduct up-front an analysis of the environmental and ecological properties of the resource that is to be drawn on for development purposes. Once that is completed, and if it meets a reasonable standard, the legislation will enable development to proceed—not to be re-examined—so that the development has, as the title says, resource security.

What is lacking from the Opposition side in this debate is a consideration of the environmental issues. We make no bones about our position as a government. We are in favour of development, but we are in favour of development that is balanced against the environmental concerns. Untrammelled development without regard for the environment is not on. Total and absolute reservation of forests with no development is not on. The question is about having a proper balance between both. So projects below the $100m level, which is the benchmark in this Bill, need to be considered with other projects for the all-round maximum utilisation of the resource, the greatest level of value adding and the greatest return to Australia, either as export or import replacement. It is not right to say that projects worth less than $100m cannot get up. They can, but they do have this obligation to aggregate their project with other projects that are wanting to utilise the same resource so that an overall consideration can be given.

The other point that I wish to reply to is a point made by Senator Calvert and other honourable senators opposite, as they have tried to blackguard the name of the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths. I must say that Senator Calvert praised Mr Griffiths in order to condemn him. In summary, what has been said by the Opposition is that Mr Griffiths reached an agreement and that was then ratted on. That, in summary, is what has been said. In fact, that may even be an accurate quote from some of the remarks made by honourable senators opposite. I am here to tell them that that is just not true. Mr Griffiths did not make an agreement and nothing has been ratted on. What Mr Griffiths did say, in dealing with this issue, was that, when the Opposition put particular views to him, those views would be relayed to the Government and the Government would respond. That is what Mr Griffiths did. That is an honourable course for a Minister to take. It is a proper and prudent course for a Minister to take. It is what Mr Griffiths did, and the Government has responded. The Government's position is, as is clearly the case, that we want this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what he told the industry?

—The interjection is: Is that what he told the industry? In the case of the industry, Mr Griffiths issued a paper which is headed, `Commonwealth of Australia, A Policy Position in Relation to Integrated Activities under the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991'. In fact, this was a paper to clear up the point that Senator Walters was trying to make yet again, ad nauseam, a moment ago—the alleged point that projects valued at less than $100m could not be embraced by this Bill. This paper was issued for the purpose of clarifying the Government view about that.
—Put it in Hansard.
—I am prepared, with the leave of the Committee, to incorporate the paper presented by the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, to the industry. I seek leave to incorporate it.
—What is the date?
—There is no date on the document, Senator, but—
—When did it occur? How old is it?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of interjectors asking when it occurred and how old it is. The actual document does not carry a date. I am not going to falsify the document by adding a date. This is the document.
—What is the title?

—As I said before—but apparently the honourable senator was not paying attention, so let me say it again—the title of the document is A Policy Position in Relation to Integrated Activities under the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. I seek leave to incorporate it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: A Policy Position in Relation to
Integrated Activities under the
Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991

During the period 30 March to 1 April 1992 the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs inquired into the amendments moved by the Opposition to the Government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. During the course of public hearings evidence given to the Committee indicated that there is not a full appreciation of the types of projects that would be eligible for resource security under the Bill. In particular, there is considerable misunderstanding of its application to `integrated activities'.

With this in mind the Government believes it would be helpful to articulate further what is envisaged by the term `a group of integrated activities that could reasonably be considered when taken together, to constitute a project' [clause 5(2)].

The overriding objectives of this legislation are to provide security and certainty to industry. This is necessary to encourage major long term investments in value adding wood processing projects while at the same time protecting and conserving the environmental, cultural, heritage and social values of Australia's forests.

In introducing this legislative reform to forest policy, the Government is establishing the policy framework to facilitate major investments in pulp and paper mills, integrated activities undertaken by an enterprise encompassing a range of commercial wood processing projects and, of course, large scale investments in plantations.
Under the legislation, all projects must meet the following criteria (clauses 11 and 12)
an investment of at least $100 million for the purpose of producing goods from the project
the dominant purpose of the project must be for export and/or import replacement
the investment must be value adding
consideration must be given to plantation development
completion of an integrated up-front assessment to the satisfaction of Commonwealth Ministers.
Any proponent seeking legislative resource security for integrated activities would have to satisfy two additional key requirements
that the entity undertaking the project meets the definition of an enterprise [clause 4(1)] and
it would have to demonstrate that the activities are of an integrated nature [clause 5(2)].

As regards the interpretation of enterprise in clause 5(1), the entity undertaking the project must be either a partnership, body corporate or joint venture as defined in clause 4(1). The legal definitions of `body corporate' or a `partnership' are well established.
The expression `joint venture' is not a technical one with a settled common law meaning. Its meaning is to be ascertained as a matter of ordinary language.

`Joint ventures' include partnerships but are not limited to them. They also include a joint undertaking or activity carried out through a medium other than a partnership, such as a company, a trust, an agency or joint ownership. However, a `joint venture' is more than a set of activities conducted in contractual association.
Companies could be considered to be conducting a joint venture if, for example, their mutual arrangements contained provisions for
jointly building and maintaining facilities used in common;
mutual leasing or use of machinery; and
some employees of each company were made available as needed to the others.

In relation to integrated activities under clause 5(2), the Government recognises that the maximum benefit from the use of Australia's wood resources is often achieved through integrated logging and wood processing operations.

An integrated project could, for example, include a project involving investments in separate wood processing plants so as to maximise the economic value of the different qualities of logs harvested from a catchment area. In this instance, a project might consist of a veneer plant producing high quality veneer for plywood and furniture manufacture, one or more sawmills producing a wide range of value added timber products, and a flitch mill, with residues from all activities being directed into the production of pulp and paper. The project could be formed either through investments in greenfield processing plants or expansions of existing plants provided the whole project is subject to an up-front integrated assessment.

However, a mere collection of sawmills not integrated in the above terms and operated by separate companies would not qualify nor would any project involving predominantly woodchip exports based on native forests.

The Government will examine project proposals on a case-by-case basis. Any proponent of a project comprising `integrated activities' would need to detail the nature of the whole project and its component parts and the interrelationships between those components, in terms of the resource and product flows and the corporate or other arrangements. The relevant factors the Government will look at in determining whether a proposal meets the condition of being integrated activities include:
whether the wood resources for each activity are sourced from the same catchment area;
the nature of a commercial relationship between the entities undertaking the activities;
the economic interdependence between the activities; and
any technological relationship between project components or entities.

With this approach to `integrated activities' and `enterprise', the Government believes that, provided the industry structures itself so as to meet the eligibility criteria in the Bill, almost all of the investment that industry has indicated is in prospect would be eligible for consideration by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you also incorporating the Minister's letter of the same date to the industry and to Mr Lloyd?

—If there are other documents—I will take advice as to whether that is a fact. If it is a fact, I will seek advice from the Minister as to whether they relate to this matter. If they do, I will seek advice from the Minister as to whether they ought to be incorporated.

PARA.TAB: The view of the Government would be that all relevant material ought to be before the Senate. We are not in the business of withholding relevant material. The document that I have now incorporated is what Mr Griffiths put to the industry. He put it to the industry on the basis of a discussion paper so that discussions could ensue, which they did.

What I am doing in this exercise is pinning the allegation that Mr Griffiths or the Government has ratted on their word. Those discussions went ahead, quite properly and quite reasonably. There is no agreement with Mr Lloyd and Mr Griffiths. What Mr Lloyd has done on behalf of the Opposition is to put certain views to Mr Griffiths, who has then relayed them to the Government, and the Government has made a consideration. That, therefore, means that an allegation that Mr Griffiths has ratted or the Government has ratted is not substantiated. It ought to be withdrawn as a bad reflection. It is also wrong. I have taken the opportunity to reply to those allegations.

Senator Calvert said in conclusion—this is a fashionable remark which has gained currency in public debate—`The opera is not ended until the fat lady sings'. I am not sure what that is supposed to mean, but Senator Calvert has said that the fat lady has sung. Has she? Maybe she did somewhere in the world; I do not know. But this debate is not over. This issue is not ended. This issue still has several laps of the course to run, but it can be ended now. Two thousand jobs can be created in northern Tasmania, according to the estimate of the company concerned. The economic revival can occur in northern Tasmania according to the views of the company. The members of the Liberal Opposition in the Senate can support the view of the Liberal Premier of Tasmania on this matter. They can do that. They can support the legislation. As long as they do not, the question hovers in the air as yet unanswered: what is it that those opposite have got against Tasmania?

INTERJECT.PARA: Thank you for your letter of 16 April concerning the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 and your offer to discuss the legislation further. The attachment to the letter setting out the Government's policy position in relation to integrated activities under the Bill has been very helpful in enabling industry to assess the likely coverage of the legislation in its current form.

It appears likely that projects valued at $100m or more will be undertaken in Northern Tasmania and in Central Gippsland in the short to medium term and these should be able to be covered by the legislation. The legislation may also give impetus to a major plantation development in Western Australia. In addition, there may be other $100m plus projects in Southern Tasmania and East Gippsland later in this decade but these are not nearly well enough defined at this stage to commence the five stage approval process.

This leaves the issue of how much of the industry will be covered under the `integrated activities' eligibility provisions. The attachment to your letter states that a `joint venture' is more than a set of activities conducted in contractual association. Therefore, given the diverse and highly competitive nature of the ownership and operations of the sawmill industry this sector could not meet the requirements for an `integrated activity' without a very major change to the normal commercial pattern of industry operations and development.

In this context, it is worth noting the view of the Resource Assessment Commission `that the primary role of Government should be to set policy parameters for forest use such as land use, zoning, codes of forest practice, environmental standards, log pricing and allocation of use rights. In relation to other aspects of forest management, the inquiry is of the view that the private sector should make decisions on the basis of its own assessment of commercial opportunities, risks and investment prospects. The private sector should also be free to determine the pattern of development of downstream industry, subject to planning and environmental requirements.'

Hardwood sawmilling provides about half Australia's domestic wood production and is a major regional employer in Queensland, NSW, Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia. Given the approach adopted by Government in relation to `integrated activities' and `enterprise' it is highly unlikely this diverse and competitive industry would be able to restructure itself to the extent envisaged by Government to meet the Bill's eligibility criteria.

Under these circumstances much of the prospective industry investment and employment would not be eligible under the current resource security legislation. Industry would therefore feel compelled to continue its campaign for legislation linked to accredited state forest industry development plans.

Our legal advisers are still strongly of the view that legislation provides the only `bankable' basis for investment in the industry. It was very noticeable at the public hearings on the legislation that virtually every witness, including Mr Michael Field and North Broken Hill Peko, stated that intergovernmental agreements are a totally unsatisfactory means to provide resource security. Under these conditions, industry could not support or endorse the current proposals that envisage intergovernmental agreements being the basis for resource security for most of the industry.

A meeting of NAFI Executive, including representatives of North Broken Hill and FIAT, was held in Melbourne on 10 April, primarily to review the resource security situation. The meeting agreed to promote two possible alternatives.

1. request the Government to retitle the Bill for major forest projects and agree to pursue resource security for the rest of the industry in the context of the RAC recommendations and the National Forest Strategy.

In other words, the Bill would become major projects legislation. Government would be requested to agree to continue negotiations with the industry on resource security on the basis of regional assessments backed by legislation in the context of developing the National Forest Strategy.

2. amend the current Bill to achieve resource security for accredited state forest industry development plans, possible by rewording definitions, or give a clearer broad interpretation to the integrated project approach so that it will incorporate most major forest investment and restructuring proposals.
In addition, the North Broken Hill Peko proposal to provide scope within the legislation for the Government to vary the $100m limit by regulation could be considered.
We would be very grateful if we can discuss these alternatives at our meeting with you at 10.30 a.m Monday, 27 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I rise to comment once again on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, this time on the first clause, that is, the title to this legislation. That is what the problems have been about in the past 24 hours. We have attempted, and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) has attempted, to make this legislation project specific and, had that been achieved—a relatively simple task—then those jobs would have been available in Tasmania. Therefore, it rests fairly and squarely on the shoulders of this Government. People in Tasmania are now saying that the Government's stance in the last 24 hours is a true indication that it never wanted this legislation in the first place.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that disappointment runs extremely deep and painfully within me because, until yesterday afternoon, I and the rest of the coalition, particularly my Tasmanian colleagues, believed that after six months of discussions and debate the Government had finally been prepared to admit that part of its highly flawed resource security legislation is designed only for major projects and does not have anything to offer the rest of the industry.

The Resources Minister had entered into negotiations with the coalition and with the industry and, contrary to what has been said here today, the understanding was that finally a suitable compromise had been found. Indeed, the coalition was prepared to pass the Bill as three elements of agreement had been found, and the Government, through the Resources Minister, had stated that it was now committed to opening up real and meaningful discussions with the industry and the unions to develop a concept of resource security on a State or regional basis which would cover smaller projects.

We were prepared to accept the Government's commitment to monitor workings of the legislation and we were happy about the prospect of having the Bill renamed as a major projects Bill to more aptly reflect its project specific nature. What has happened? Why, on this side, are we all so disappointed? The Resources Minister goes to this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with a compromise welcomed by both the Opposition and the industry, and is told that it is not acceptable. The Resources Minister has been unable to convince the Prime Minister and the left wing of the Cabinet to support the changes proposed to the legislation. Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations, has not denied that.

I note that this very morning on the AM program the Minister used the excuse that the time was available in the Senate for debate and it was important that it go through. The Minister gave the impression that it was imperative that it go through the Senate as soon as possible, as the changes were minimal. I think that he referred to `a slot being available'. To the fullest extent of my knowledge, there is no rush on the part of the Senate to have this legislation passed in its present form. Indeed, the changes are minimal, but they are very significant. That is the point.

Further, I would like to put on record that the Senate has not requested a cut-off motion on the debate on this Bill and there have been no cut-off notices given. The point that I wish to make is that there is no rush on the part of the Senate to have this Bill passed in its present form. In fact, there is no motion in relation to issues coming up from the other chamber which is operative as yet; I understand that the Democrats' motion has not yet been put. So I think it is rather a poor excuse to say that the slot is there, it must be debated and voted upon today. The opportunities are still available and will continue to be available. The motion does not relate to amendments which might be required by this part of the chamber which would go back to the other place, as frequently happens in relation to legislation. So the Minister really is trying to pull the wool over people's eyes about the urgency of this. There is something wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people who are unemployed would like work and that is the reason for the urgency.

—Senator Cook is now opening up a different point of the debate. I am raising the issue about the urgency and the excuse that was offered by Minister Griffiths on the AM program this morning. He was talking about slots available, and he was obviously referring to cut-off motions, the implications of that for legislation and the ability to debate them. The opportunity is still there for the Minister to take it back and to bring it to the Senate in an amended form. The Senate procedures and this side of the Senate are not denying the Minister that opportunity. There is still time to go off and refer it. But the Minister is not game because he knows what the outcome will be. He has tried to hide behind the procedures of the Senate and the forms of a motion, which has not been put, and he has incorrectly interpreted the significance of that motion. I think that is somewhat reprehensible.

PARA.TAB: The Government has failed to deliver on a sensible arrangement, which the Government itself proposed, to ensure the passage of the Bill. We now have a Prime Minister who does not back the Minister he appoints. I presume that the Minister would have a thorough knowledge of what is the best course of action. Indeed, this Prime Minister has embarrassed his own Minister by refusing to confirm his suggested changes. Given that this Bill has been around so long, the Prime Minister must have given him a degree of freedom to negotiate, and that is exactly what he did. The pressures came on after the event and caused severe embarrassment to Minister Griffiths. Where did that pressure come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —It came from the Left and it came from Mrs Kelly.

—We are told that it came from the Left and from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) who has indicated that a second essential step in this process—a further environmental impact assessment under her direction and control—would be frustrated. The integrity of the Government's commitment to every step in this process, the quality of the legislation and the environmental impact statement, must be seriously questioned. Those are the issues that the Government has failed to answer. We have a Prime Minister who not only thinks he knows better than anyone what the majority of Australians, think about the flag, but now he also presumes to know better than his appointed Minister in the forestry area. I think this is unfortunate.

PARA.TAB: The Minister knows that this Forest and Conservation Development Bill is riddled with inadequacies. However, my colleagues and I were prepared to accept the other shortcomings of the Bill, which included no compensation clauses and the unnecessary duplication of Federal and State procedures, to indicate that the Opposition has moved a long way—even the company acknowledges that. The Government has not been prepared to move one step. The Minister was prepared to move but when it came to the crunch of delivering it, the Caucus made life intolerable, it backed down and it failed to deliver on an honourable undertaking. When is a Minister's word his bond?

DEBATE.TITLE: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN BUSINESS REGULATION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator McMullan:
