SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the internationalisation of financial markets, it happens from time to time that an exchange of information is necessary between foreign business regulators and their Australian counterparts. For example, many companies operate on an international basis. Undesirable market practices may operate across national borders; or a person prohibited from operating in one country's financial markets may try to move into those of another country.

PARA.TAB: While this can be pursued through voluntary agreements, there is a need to formalise cooperative arrangements. This has been recognised by the International Organisation of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), by the OECD in its review of the impact of internationalisation on financial markets, and by the Commonwealth Law Ministers at their meeting in Auckland in 1990.

This Bill, which the coalition is supporting, provides for the Australian side of the process. It sets up a two-stage procedure for the provision of information by the Commonwealth to foreign business regulators. It is hoped that offering such assistance will put Australian regulators in a strong position when seeking similar assistance from foreign business regulators.
The object of this Bill is set out in clause 5, and I think it is worth quoting in full:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Act is to enable Commonwealth regulators to render assistance to foreign regulators in their administration or enforcement of foreign business by obtaining from persons relevant information, documents and evidence and transmitting such information and evidence and copies of such documents to foreign regulators.
The scheme is designed to be sufficiently flexible to cope with requests from any type of foreign business regulatory agency and to ensure that requests for information are responded to quickly.

PARA.TAB: An important aspect of this Bill is that it complements the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act of 1987. If a foreign business regulatory agency is investigating an offence, it must seek assistance through that Act and not through the provisions contained in this Bill. Circumstances in which this Bill would apply include, for example, where information is sought in the process of deciding whether to allow a person into the market or where civil legal proceedings for market fraud or misconduct are being undertaken.

As I mentioned, the scheme set up in this Bill is essentially in two parts. The first part, set out in clause 6, consists of a foreign regulator making a request directly to a Commonwealth regulator on an agency-to-agency basis. Pursuant to clause 6(2), the foreign regulator is required to make an undertaking to the effect that the information and evidence to be sought by the Commonwealth regulator from a person will not be used against that person for the purposes of criminal proceedings. Clause 7 of the Bill provides that, where such a request is received by a Commonwealth regulator, that agency can either refuse the request or inform the Attorney-General that it does not oppose the request or that it does not oppose the request subject to specified conditions.

The factors which the Commonwealth regulator must take into account when considering the requests are set out in subclause 7(3). They include whether the Commonwealth regulator is likely to be able to obtain the requested information, documents or evidence and the cost in so doing and whether the foreign regulator would be likely to comply with a similar request from the Commonwealth regulator. In the second stage of the process the Attorney-General must consider the requests referred to the Commonwealth regulator. The factors to which the Attorney-General must have regard in considering whether to authorise the provision of assistance are set out in subclause 8(2). They include whether it is in Australia's national interest to comply with the request, whether the request is consistent with international law and whether the information provided in response to the request might be used for prosecuting, punishing or otherwise harming a person because of that person's race, religion, nationality or political opinions.

The coalition is of the view that perhaps another factor which the Attorney-General should be able to take into account is whether the foreign regulator has complied in the past with conditions and undertakings relating to the supply of information. However, we are prepared not to press this point at this stage.

Pursuant to clause 9, the Attorney-General may also impose conditions subject to which material may be provided. If the request for information or assistance from a foreign regulator clears both these hurdles, the Commonwealth regulator may then serve written notice upon the person to whom the authorisation relates, requiring that person to provide information in the form of a signed instrument, or to produce documents or to give evidence before a person acting on behalf of the Commonwealth regulator. The coalition would also take the view that written notice should perhaps contain some indication of the matters to which the request relates.

Witnesses will be able to be represented by a lawyer or other person who can assist—for example, an accountant—and legal professional privilege will apply. Clause 14 provides that, where a person claims that the information or evidence might tend to incriminate him or her, then it will not be admissible against that person in criminal proceedings or proceedings for the imposition of a penalty. The Liberal and National parties have concerns, also expressed by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, about the fact that clause 14 does not include derivative use immunity; that is, it would not protect the persons from their information or evidence being used against them indirectly. This is therefore an abrogation of the common law privilege against self-incrimination. As this question of derivative use immunity is shortly to be dealt with in detail in the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992, I will not be pursuing that any further at this stage.

I understand, from the debate on this Bill in the other place, that where information which is on the public record is required by a foreign business regulator, it will need to be sought through a memorandum of understanding between the regulators concerned. The passage of this Bill will not affect the necessity to secure such memorandums of understanding and we encourage the Government to continue to pursue them vigorously. This Bill has the commendable objective of improving international cooperation in business regulation, and although the coalition is concerned that the two-stage approval process is perhaps unnecessarily cumbersome, it nevertheless supports the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to make some remarks about the Constitutional Centenary Foundation, which was launched in Parliament House, Melbourne, on Thursday 11 April. In a little over eight years, Australia will complete its first 100 years as a nation. There will be much to celebrate. Our achievements have been many and among them the place of pride must be given to the Constitution, which has played a vital role in the progress of our people. Of course, the Constitution is not perfect. No constitution in the world is perfect and nor can any constitution in the world be made perfect.

PARA.TAB: Practical men and women know that a democratic constitution can provide only the basic framework for fair government. It cannot, nor should it try to, tell us how we should live our lives. No constitution can tell us what education we should choose; what particular industries we should encourage: what foreign policies we should follow; how hard we should work; and, who we should choose as our friends. All these decisions must be left to our commonsense, to our wisdom, to our courage and to our imagination. If we lack these qualities, no constitution, however perfect it may seem in the eyes of the purists, can help us.

What therefore can be said of the Constitutional Centenary Foundation at the early stages of its life? The aim of the Foundation is, in the words of Sir Ninian Stephen, its distinguished Chairman, `to encourage a public process of discussion and of review, of heightened awareness and better understanding of our Australian constitutional system'. On the face of it, this is an aim we could all agree with.

Education is always a good thing and educating the people to know more of the Constitution than they do is unquestionably always desirable. Senators must be aware, however, as doubtless is the Foundation, that there are many troublesome questions. For example, what does a heightened awareness and better understanding of the Australian Constitution mean? Does it simply mean a greater knowledge of the history, content, law and argument about the Constitution, in other words, the kind of education we should give or aim to give in our schools and universities, or is it intended to be an education for a particular purpose? If so, what purpose is it intended to serve: is it to make the citizens better informed to prepare them for another batch of referenda? It would be barely credible and indeed unfair to the Foundation if we were to assume that its purpose is to walk over the same grounds that the Constitutional Commission walked in 1988, or that its purpose is to achieve what the 1988 Constitutional Commission failed to achieve.

The massive problems created by the initial proposals of the costly Australian Bicentennial Authority, as well as the unprecedented failure of referenda submitted to the public in 1988, are still fresh in our minds. The distinguished board of the Foundation will undoubtedly avoid such obvious pitfalls. Nevertheless, we should recognise that there are philosophical assumptions underlying the research of the Foundation which are difficult to avoid. These assumptions in themselves will inevitably create debate. We do not want a constitutional foundation to be agnostic on issues such as federalism, responsible government and effective executive accountability to the Parliament. Even the selection of papers and authors themselves will reveal implicitly a philosophy about the type of constitutional change the Foundation gives some priority to.

One issue that the Foundation will find difficult to avoid is a view on whether the Australian Constitution is basically sound, or hopelessly out of date and in need of major surgery. On the one hand, Sir Ninian praises Australia's great democratic record. At the same time the Foundation has a wide ranging program which could imply to some observers that a major rewrite is needed.

It has to be said at this time that the Constitutional Centenary Foundation seems to be coming down hard on both sides of the fence on this important philosophical issue. The Foundation, in my view, must be careful to avoid promoting a monologue about the real or supposed problems in our Constitution. I think it would be useful initially if the Foundation could produce an early paper outlining Australia's constitutional achievements. Why is it that Australia has led the world in many important democratic initiatives? Why has Australia, in comparison with most other countries, been able to produce a stable democratic system enjoying widespread public support? Why have we been able to avoid the strains that have brought many other federations undone? Australians, as I have said, can rightly feel proud of their democratic achievements and the constitutional system that has given us stability few others know in a century of great change and great distress.

Such an analysis by the Foundation about our constitutional achievement might make some reference to and some study of the recent Canadian experiences of constitutional reform on a grand scale. In the late 1960s and early 1970s then Prime Minister Trudeau adopted the goal of strengthening the Canadian union and quelling the separatist movement in Quebec. To this end, he patriated the Canadian Constitution and amended it to include a charter of rights and freedoms akin to a Bill of Rights which the Constitutional Centenary Foundation has announced it will investigate.

A key message from Canada's experience is reflected in the view of a well-regarded British weekly, The Economist, that Canada's current problems with its federation stem from the constitutional adventurism of the Trudeau period. Next October Quebec will hold a referendum on secession from the Canadian Federation. I am told that, if Quebec leaves the federation, it is possible that British Columbia and Alberta will follow suit. I think we would all agree that it would be a great tragedy if that great nation was so split.

An issue the Foundation will find difficult to avoid is the attitude that it will take on the virtues or otherwise of constitutional gradualism. There is no doubt that the initial work program outlines a number of difficult and contentious issues. These include Bills of Rights, treaties with the Aboriginal people, powers of the head of state, separation of powers and so on.

In my view, Canada carries the message that wholesale constitutional reform or change, however well meaning, comes with substantial risks that the end result can be worse than the problems that the constitutional reformers seek to remedy.

I believe the Canadian experience demonstrates the virtue of what Professor Rufus Davis has referred to as `constitutional gradualism'. In this term, Professor Davis refers to the gradual development of constitutional practice and convention over time—such process as is no more clearly demonstrated by the example of Australia itself. It is true that our Constitution is supporting activities, endeavours and enterprises of a kind the founding fathers could never have foreseen. Yet, to the greater degree, it has performed the tasks asked of a constitution admirably well. On the whole, this is because the Australian Constitution has allowed a flexibility whilst ensuring that the main aim of a constitution, `to submit government to an agreed system of constraints', in the words of Professor Davis, has been fulfilled.
Greg Craven, a reader in constitutional law at the University of Melbourne, makes a similar point when he warns about constitutional adventurism. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In renovating our constitution, we must be careful not to bring down a supporting beam. Constitutional reform is a painstaking and thoughtful process, and while we should not be frightened to discard a failed mechanism, we should be slow to make a fundamental change unless we are sure it is going to work.

One of the challenges facing the Foundation as it begins its work will be to decide which road it will take. With the example of Canada to guide us, one can hope that balanced, informed debate and a healthy observance of the gradualist approach will result in the avoidance of the pitfalls of radical constitutional change.

PARA.TAB: The Constitutional Foundation should be mindful of the degree to which any reforms considered necessary can be accommodated by changes outside the Constitution. A possible danger to the Constitutional Foundation is that major changes in the working of the federation can come about without constitutional amendment. Such issues include Federal-State relations, particularly of a financial nature, the role and effectiveness of our parliaments, including executive accountability and the roles of presiding officers, to name but two.
An example of such an area of reform is that concerning Federal-State relations. As Premier Nick Greiner has observed in a speech in 1990 to the Press Club:

SPEECH.PARA: A new constitution is not necessary in order for sensible reforms to take place in Commonwealth-State relations. The idea that we have to wait for constitutional lawyers to draft us a new constitution is a myth which should be exploded now.
Premier Greiner went on to say:

With the possible exception of the section 90 prohibition on State excises, there is nothing in the Constitution that would prevent a transfer of functions and powers or stand in the way of remedying the fundamental problem of vertical fiscal imbalance.

Premier Greiner's comments on the issue of Federal-State relations, a current issue, that I have just quoted raise the wider question of federalism itself. This is another of the philosophical issues which the Foundation will find it very difficult to avoid. Do we wish to strengthen the States at the expense of the centre—in other words, giving better expression to the views of the founders of our Constitution and the founders of our nation?

PARA.TAB: Proponents of centralism and the States' righters will be able to produce reams of evidence supporting their respective positions. In the end, I believe, the argument will come down to a philosophical debate, which the Foundation will find difficult to avoid. It is a good start, in my view, that the Foundation has strongly supported a continuation of the federal system. However, does this mean that the legislative and fiscal independence of the States should be increased? It would be interesting to see to what extent the debate on renovating the States is furthered.

I happen to believe that a federal system is an effective way of dividing government power and limiting the damage that any government can do. At the end of the day, a Joan Kirner can muck up the schools in only one part of Australia.

The world trend is to federalism. We tend to pretend in Australia that the trend is towards central government. The world of the twenty-first century may well be dominated by suprafederations—Western Europe, Russia and some of its neighbours. In commissioning papers and evaluating its proposals, the Constitutional Foundation cannot avoid taking a position on the issue of federalism.

The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, pointed out to me some time ago that Australia is arguably one of the world's oldest democratic constitutions, if not the world's oldest continuous democratic Constitution. This claim by Senator Tate is based on the fact that Australia and New Zealand were the first countries to introduce universal adult suffrage combined with the right of women to stand for parliament.

We have worked this Constitution for close to 100 years. In my view, that alone merits the title as one of the world's great constitutions and we should recognise, as we go towards the year 2001, our great constitutional achievement and be careful that we do not denigrate and possibly, by foolish change, destroy this great document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, has a commitment in Hobart today and will be absent from Question Time. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will take questions relating to the Attorney-General's portfolio. Questions relating to the portfolio of Health, Housing and Community Services should be addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In the light of the Minister's answer to my question yesterday in which he stated that he did not attend the Cabinet meeting at which the Budget decision to halve commercial radio fees was taken, can the Minister assure the Senate, on New South Wales right wingers' honour, that he both declared the conflict of interest arising from his directorship of commercial radio station 2HD and absented himself from all Cabinet discussions relating to each and every one of the following eight broadcasting related Bills which were debated in this chamber during the time he was improperly both a director of 2HD and a Cabinet Minister: Broadcasting (Foreign Ownership) Amendment Bill 1990, Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990, Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1991, Special Broadcasting Service Bill 1991, Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1991, and Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991?
—I have no way, I do not think, of checking all of those pieces of legislation. What I have done is via the Cabinet note takers—
—What about your diary?

—My diaries do not list each piece of legislation discussed on a Cabinet agenda. I would be very surprised if any colleague has a diary that does that. However, if I could be given an opportunity to answer the question, I asked Cabinet note takers to go through Cabinet records of the relevant period during which I was a director of radio station 2HD. There were, during that period of time, eight occasions on which broadcasting matters were discussed in the broad. As far as I can ascertain, two of those occasions involved 2HD directly—perhaps it could be said three, given that one was a flowover of one debate over two days. This list I have here—I will have to check—says 22 July 1990. I believe that is a misprint; it should be 1991. I will check that when I have finished answering the question. The other dates were 23 July, the next day, and then 6 August.

PARA.TAB: They were the times when the licence fee reduction debates were conducted and a check of the records shows that I was not in Canberra on any of those days. In fact, I was ill at the time and I had a few days off. That having been said, as far as the other dates are concerned, it should be noted that Cabinet records do not necessarily show when Ministers are in the room and not at Cabinet meetings, as colleagues would be aware.

TALK.START.PARA: —If not, why not?

—Just listen for a minute. As I was saying, Cabinet note takers do not necessarily record every time Ministers walk in and walk out. In fact, the rule that they try to observe—even that is not always possible—is to record a Minister leaving if the Minister is to pick up all the papers and leave on the basis that he or she will not be returning.
—Were you there or weren't you?

—Just listen. I am trying to get the answer out. If Senator Kemp can display some of his well-known patience, we will all get there. So in terms of other occasions upon which broadcasting in much more general terms has been discussed, I am not recorded as having participated in any debate and on one occasion I am recorded as having left. That does not mean, of course, that I was in the room at the time.

PARA.TAB: There is only one occasion on which I am recorded as having made a speech and that was when the Cabinet debated in September of last year some matters related to the Fairfax takeover and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers in relation to it. I did not declare my directorship of radio station 2HD during that debate. In retrospect, I should not have anyway, and would not if it was on tomorrow.

The only other time I am recorded as having made a comment is on 19 December 1990 when the Minister, Kim Beazley, brought to Cabinet the broad principles upon which a broadcasting Bill might be re-drafted. Cabinet decided not to deal with it because the agenda was too big. Apparently I made a comment about the resources that Mr Beazley's department would need to get the drafting done. Beyond that, I am not recorded as having contributed to any debate that took place on broadcasting.

There were only eight occasions upon which these debates took place during the period. In accordance with the information which I have just given, I am recorded as not having attended on three or four of those times and as having spoken only twice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister, but he seems to have raised a few more serious problems. My supplementary question is: does Cabinet, the Cabinet secretariat or anyone keep a record of any declarations of interest that are made at Cabinet deliberations on any matter and do they record any determined absence, deliberate absence, on the basis of conflict of interest? If so, has the Minister ever been recorded as having made such a declaration or being the subject of deliberate absence? When the Minister is checking that, perhaps he could also check whether, apart from the eight specific instances which we both agree on, there were any general Cabinet discussions relating to broadcasting policy which he attended while improperly being both a director of 2HD and a Cabinet Minister?

—I am advised that these were the only discussions on broadcasting that took place during the period. I cannot go beyond that. That is what the Cabinet Office told me last night and I accept what it says. I certainly do not recall any others. I do not think it is my place to talk about what Cabinet procedures there might be for declarations of interest, other than to say that I did not declare an interest on any single occasion.
—Why?
—I think it is only appropriate for me to talk about myself. What other colleagues might or might not do is up to them.
—What is the practice?
—I said yesterday that questions on Cabinet practice should be directed to the Prime Minister and not to me.
—It will be.
—I am sure it will be. I did not declare an interest and I have just given honourable senators all the information that I have on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of a review by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission of the enterprise bargaining principle established by the Commission in its October 1991 national wage case decision which is scheduled to commence on Friday, 1 May? Is the Minister anticipating that the ACTU will lodge a claim for a general wage rise at this review, as allowed for by the Commission's October decision?

—The October last national wage case decision introduced principles for workplace bargaining into Australian wage fixing and made observations and suggestions, of which the Government has taken note, about changes to the legislative framework of the Industrial Relations Act which would facilitate workplace bargaining. I shortly will be proposing some measures to meet the observations that the Commission has made.

PARA.TAB: The Commission next month, in May, also will conduct a review of progress in Australian industry on the extent of workplace or enterprise bargaining in order to monitor developments. But in the October national wage case decision the Commission also said that the door would be open for parties to lodge an application for a general wage increase from 1 May 1992; that is, from tomorrow, the door swings open and any party can lodge an application for a general wage increase. The normal party to do that is the ACTU. If it did, the normal expectation would be that it would lodge an application tomorrow, a hearing probably would occur in June, a decision may be made in August, and possibly the decision would be prospective with an application date for an increase under a general wage round for September. It could be earlier than that, but that is a reasonable possible scenario for what could happen.

The point is that this will not occur for the reason that the Government and the ACTU have a wages policy and have worked out an approach on wages. The approach we have worked out with the ACTU followed hard upon the heels of the Prime Minister's One Nation statement—a statement aimed at stimulating economic growth in Australia and creating further jobs, and aimed at locking in a low level of inflation in this country. As a wages policy approach it ought to be contrasted to that of the Opposition, which is a total free-for-all in the market. The Government's is a disciplined and considered wages policy approach. Therefore, in the immediate future Australian workers can look forward to pursuing further wage increases through workplace or enterprise bargaining; that is, through productivity negotiations generating further productivity in the economy.

The ACTU and the Government have agreed that the priority is to lock in the low level of inflation that Australia has experienced as a permanent feature of our economy. The big `0' was reported by the Treasurer yesterday for the March quarter, leading to an annual rate of 1.7 for Australia, which in terms of inflation puts us well below the OECD level and makes us the second lowest OECD country in the world. The objective is to lock that level in as a permanent feature of the economy. Therefore, an application by the ACTU for a national wage round is deferred. It will not make one, thus allowing job stimulation by the One Nation statement, preventing inflation growing and giving workplace or enterprise bargaining a chance to spread more widely.

The Government and the ACTU will later agree on timing and on an amount for a national wage case increase. We believe that there should be not only stimulation to productivity bargaining but also attention to fairness in wages. People in poor bargaining positions who do not have access to productivity negotiations should be able to get a wage increase for a general round in the economy. So we will agree with the ACTU on timing and amount for a future national wage case increase.

As I say, that ought to be contrasted against a free-for-all wage round that would apply under the Opposition. The last such free-for-all under the Fraser Government led to a wages explosion in this economy. The thing that this Government has been able to deliver, which the Opposition can never even approach, ne'er promise, is that we have a wages policy that works, that delivers an outcome, that is effective and that maintains a household disposable income in relative terms for ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and follows my question to him yesterday. Is the honourable senator aware of allegations that Mr Symons used not only the reference that the Minister gave him—which I do not think the Minister has yet tabled as he promised to do—but also his close association with the Minister, to convince officials of the Marshall Islands that he could foster permanent migration arrangements to the US?
—I would have absolutely no idea.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Was the Minister able to find the letter of reference and will he table it? Further, will the Minister indicate to the Senate whether the President of the Marshall Islands has returned his call after saying that he would consider the matter?
—I have said publicly a few times that that was the only conversation I had with the President. But he made no undertaking to call me back; so I am not surprised that he has not.
—Are you going to table the letter?
—As far as the letter is concerned, I have not seen it yet. If and when I do, I will table it.
—Have you looked for it?
—Not personally, no.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Reith, today claimed that, `You always get low inflation in a recession'? Was Mr Reith correct in saying that low inflation always accompanies a recession?

—I am aware that this morning Mr Reith made a statement on Channel 9 to that effect. He said, `You always get low inflation in a recession'. Once again, he has shown a complete ignorance of the facts. If the leadership of the Liberal Party is any indication of the `followership', I am not surprised that Mr Reith made a substantial error in respect of that matter. When I raised this issue in Question Time in the Senate yesterday, everybody said, `Oh, that was a few years ago' and all that sort of stuff. The problem with members of the Opposition is that they are all refugees from the 1970s. They have a very selective memory about what happened in that period. Mr Reith, who is not only the shadow Treasurer but also the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party for goodness sake, said this on television this morning.

PARA.TAB: Before going to Mr Reith's ignorance—about which I could wax eloquent for some time—let me say that the facts are that the latest CPI figures confirm that this country has returned to low inflation. CPI inflation is now down to 1.7 per cent, which is below the latest average of our annual inflation rate of our trading partners at 2.5 per cent. The underlying rate, excluding volatile and seasonal factors, is now down to about 3 per cent for the year to the March quarter. This is the lowest underlying inflation rate since the series was first constructed in 1971. The latest CPI figure supports revised official forecasts of reduced inflation for 1991-92 and 1992-93.

That may not be good news for members of the Opposition who, as I said yesterday, get very excited about bad news because bad news is their only opportunity—wallowing in ignorance as they do about these matters—to get their backsides on these seats over here. When the unemployment rate goes up, the Opposition gets very excited; when the CPI goes down, it gets miserable. That is the indicator of the Opposition's political knowledge and political success.

It is very clear that inflationary expectations have come down, indicating that the community accepts that low inflation is sustainable. Policies instituted by this Government will ensure that Australia remains amongst low inflation countries. This is no small achievement and I can understand the Opposition's concern about it.

As for the comments of the shadow Treasurer, which Senator Beahan, who takes an intelligent and thoughtful interest in these matters, asked me about, the shadow Treasurer is clearly wrong, clearly ignorant. I did not need this piece of evidence to make that assertion, but it is a useful peg on which to hang an illustration of what I am talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister is clearly debating the matter, and that is not allowed under standing order 73(4).
—The question was in order and, so far, the Minister's comments have been in order. There is no point of order.

—In contrast to what Mr Reith said, not only is the outlook for continuing low inflation during the period of economic recovery good, but also Mr Reith should remind himself of the economic situation when this Government took office in March 1983.

PARA.TAB: Mr Reith said this morning that recessions are always accompanied by low inflation. Look at the 1982-83 recession. In 1982-83, the inflation figure was 11.2 per cent. Does Mr Reith not remember that? He was here. Does he have a selective memory with regard to these matters, or was he telling fibs to a Channel 9 audience this morning? Mr Reith has to make up his mind about those things. He holds himself out as an alternative Treasurer of this country, and as an alternative Deputy Prime Minister of this country to Hewson, Howard or whoever it may be, yet he went on Channel 9 television this morning and misled the people of Australia through either sheer ignorance or a deliberate misleading.

In his bid to score a few political points—points that the Opposition is finding harder and harder to put on the board—the shadow Treasurer appears to have forgotten what happened just nine years ago. The Government's—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Prime Minister lies to the Australian people; he doesn't tell fibs.
—It is to wise up the Australian people. I thank Senator Campbell.
—No, your Prime Minister lies to the Australian people.
—Senator Campbell will have the opportunity to make that assertion. I am just making it about his Deputy Leader at the moment.
—Order! Senator Campbell, you will withdraw that comment.

—Mr Deputy President, if the Leader of the Government in the Senate says that our shadow Treasurer tells fibs to the Australian people, the Australian people should know that this Prime Minister lies to those people.
—Senator Campbell, you will withdraw the comment you made about the Prime Minister.
—I will withdraw my remark when the Leader of the Opposition withdraws his.
—Senator Campbell, you will withdraw that comment unconditionally.
—I withdraw.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask Senator Campbell to withdraw his description of me as Leader of the Opposition.
—I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy President, I ask you to apply the same standard to the Minister and ask him to withdraw his assertion of mistruth.

—There is a definite precedent in this chamber that the word `lies' is not to be used. There are ways of getting around it by saying similar things. Senator Button has not used the word. I ask Senator Button to continue.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether you could make a ruling for us because you seem to have indicated that the word `lies' is unacceptable but that the word `fibs' is acceptable. Are you ruling that `fibs' is parliamentary language? We need to be sure because we would not want our chamber to have a Leaping Leo in it.

—I want to speak to this point of order. I do not want to be patronising, but with some experience in the Senate one develops forms of art in debate. I said—and I was very careful—that Mr Reith either is ignorant or is telling fibs. I gave those opposite an option. If they want to decide that he is ignorant, they can put up their hands and vote for that. The expression `telling fibs' has never been ruled out of order in this place. If I may, Mr Deputy President, I will continue with my answer.
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! I am ruling on a point of order.
—It is a different point of order.
—Let me rule on my point of order first. There is no point of order. However, I think the language that is used in the chamber could come to a higher plane.
—Mr Deputy President, as you are well aware and as the President is well aware—
—What is your point of order?
—I am just trying to tell you.
—Well, you are taking some time.
—Would you shut up.
—Senator MacGibbon!
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy President.

—Mr Deputy President, I am trying to explain. As you are well aware, and as the President is well aware, since the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, admitted that he lied to the people of Australia, the term has been used time and time again both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate without—and I stress `without'—the President pulling us up. It has been used on many occasions. Mr Deputy President, if you wish, I will get the Clerks to point out how many occasions on which that term has been used. I will get them to do the research for me. It has been used on many occasions in this Senate and people have not been pulled up for using it. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to clarify now just what you are talking about when you say there have been precedents in the past, but since the time I referred to there have not.
—The word will not be used while I am in the chair.

—I come back to the point I was seeking to make in respect of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer. What might constructively come out of this is that honourable senators opposite could go to him and say, `You have been accused either of ignorance or of being in danger of getting a pimple on your tongue'. That could be put to him. The Government's position on inflation stands in sharp contrast to that of the Opposition with its inflationary taxes on food and clothing and other items which are of prime concern to the people of Australia. Such attacks on Australian families would take inflation back towards double digit figures.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is Question Time; it is not debating time. The Minister is clearly debating.
—But you are allowed to debate all these silly points of order.
—No, the Minister is now seeking to use this time to debate the Opposition's policies, which is clearly out of order, Mr Deputy President. I ask you to rule accordingly.

—I have been listening to the answer when I have been able to do so and the Minister is answering the question that he was asked. I think he is drawing to a close. If there were not so many interjections, he would have finished his answer long ago.
—I conclude by saying—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With respect, the precedents to which you referred earlier clearly show that if the Minister chooses to answer a question—and he may choose not to—he is obliged to answer it only as it is relevant to his own portfolio, and not Opposition policy or anybody else's portfolio that he does not represent. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to rule that way, as you have already said today that you are very concerned about precedent.
—There is no point of order.

—For Senator Bishop's information, I am Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, but I also represent the Prime Minister, Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Science and Technology in this place. I am entitled to answer in those capacities. From an industry Minister's point of view, the question of inflation is of enormous importance because it is a cost that our trade exposed industries cannot pass on. That is why the inflation figure is so important and is so encouraging to the Government and to the rest of the community, including the stock market and so on, but is such a cause of miserable concern to the Opposition because it does not like good results in this community.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister been interviewed by the Australian Federal Police regarding matters concerning him and former ministerial adviser Michael Ross? Was any other Minister present at any such interview and, if so, what was the purpose of the presence of that Minister?

—I was interviewed by a Federal Police officer on this matter quite some time ago. I have no recollection of exactly when, but it must be a year ago. I will try to find out when it was. It was not a particularly long interview. Not only was there no Minister present, there was also no-one else present.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and it relates to Australia Post. Is the Government concerned at the drastic effect that the phasing out of the longstanding registered publication service is having on non-profit religious and charity publications, to the extent that many of those publications are likely to fold, to the distress of their dedicated readership? If so, what action is proposed to reverse the dramatic effect so that non-profit religious and charity organisations are not required to pay more than the direct cost of postal transmission?

—I was asked a question on this matter by Senator Bjelke-Petersen a few weeks ago. I reported then that there has been a considerable loss by Australia Post on this service over a number of years. The loss is approximately $20m a year. Obviously the users of that service are being subsidised by every other citizen who posts a letter. That being the case, late last year Australia Post decided to phase out the registered publication service. It will be phased out during 1993 and non-commercial publications will be phased out during 1994. The new print post service will be established to replace it.

PARA.TAB: Non-commercial publishers, clubs and societies have been given a longer lead time. Many of those organisations have been managed by volunteers, and one can understand why they would need a longer lead time. The commercial publications are able to be dealt with much more quickly.

Having said that, I have been making some inquiries on this matter. I will be discussing it with Minister Brown over the next week or two. I have had a number of representations on the matter as to whether or not some further concessions might be made. I am seeking information and I will report to Senator Harradine when I have those reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response, but ask him to bear in mind that I am dealing with non-profit religious and charity publications which are now meeting 97 per cent of the direct costs.

—As I said, I have had some representations along these lines, not from Senator Harradine but from others. I am already checking on it. I understand the problem. I should be able to report to Senator Harradine on the outcome within two or three weeks.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. The Minister will recall that earlier this year the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services granted extra bed licences to Tasmania's Cosgrove Park Home for the Aged. That enabled that institution to be sold by the State Government to a private operator. Given that precedent, what impediments exist to stop the Minister approving the sale of Evandale Hospital to private interests, or even to the local council, as a nursing home, given that late last year the Minister approved the transfer of 24 nursing home bed licences to Evandale Hospital? If any impediments include the need for capital funding or improvements, will the Minister explain what improvements are required and why? Will the Minister list any other bureaucratic or procedural impediments which may exist?

—I have had some briefing on this matter by Minister Peter Staples. That leads me to say in answer that the preamble upon which this question is based is, fortunately, a preamble that is ill-conceived. I am advised that the Federal Government did not grant extra bed licences to Cosgrove Park and was never involved in or consulted on the sale of this age care facility to a private operator.

PARA.TAB: In the case of Evandale Hospital, it is a Tasmanian State Government facility and its future is the responsibility of the Tasmanian State Government. The Minister in this case, Mr Staples, has no responsibility for approving or otherwise the sale of any aged care facility. The Federal Government provides subsidies for nursing home care and can only approve or disapprove the transfer of beds. In the case of Evandale, a sale of the facility would be a decision of the owners, the Tasmanian State Government, and, of course, of any potential buyer.

However, the matter that has been raised by Senator Bell is a complex one. I am advised by the Minister that he is happy to provide a full answer dealing with all of those complexities direct to Senator Bell, if he wishes, or through me to this chamber and to Senator Bell.

TALK.START.PARA: —To this chamber, please.
—If that is the wish, I will provide an answer to the chamber.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the Government's plans to upgrade living standards on our Indian Ocean territory of Christmas Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government has taken a key and very welcome step towards bringing conditions on our Indian Ocean territories of Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands up to the standard of those in Australia. I would have to give very significant credit for this to my colleague in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, who lobbied very hard and, in fact, made frequent visits to the territories prior to this being done.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories recently announced a major infrastructure program for Christmas Island to upgrade living standards and create 400 jobs. I regret to say—and it has become a very disturbing pattern lately when any significant Commonwealth money is directed towards northern Australia—that this was immediately attacked by Senator Tambling. I have here a transcript of what Senator Tambling said.

Honourable senators will recall that Senator Tambling was only recently complaining bitterly about the Commonwealth Government instituting studies instead of actually putting money in. That was his complaint a few days ago. But this is what he said about the upgrading of capital works on Christmas Island:

ANSWER.PARA: I would rather see that assessment made by either the Grants Commission or the Public Works Committee rather than the Government jumping in and committing large amounts of money in advance of doing a study to work out what is the appropriate need and relativities. It seems to be someone's pet project.

It is nothing of the sort. These very important facilities at Christmas Island—as Senator Tambling knows himself, having been there—are literally falling down. My colleague the Minister for Territories announced the program in a press statement on 26 March, more than a fortnight before Senator Tambling made his public statement. Senator Tambling clearly did not even bother to read that statement.

PARA.TAB: The statement, which I have a copy of here and which I will provide to Senator Tambling later, clearly states that $37m—that is, the initial stage of this allocation—has been allocated to the most urgent of capital works, as I said, such as the new hospital, the upgrade of the sewerage and water supply works, a new police station, an extension to the school and an upgrade of the housing on Christmas Island—in other words, the very projects which Senator Tambling himself in his public statement conceded were necessary.

The Minister then goes on to say in her statement that funding for all but these urgent works has been referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Public Works. It is there in the statement. Senator Tambling clearly did not even bother reading it before he attacked this grant of $37m of Commonwealth money to northern Australia. It is obvious that Senator Tambling needs to do just a little more homework himself before he continues to continually knock this Government's program of northern development. I conclude by asking, as I have done on previous occasions, just what is it that Senator Tambling has against northern Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Why is it so difficult for the Prime Minister of this newly genuinely independent Australia to meet with the Nobel Peace Prize winner, the Dalai Lama? Is his reticence not simply tugging the forelock to another major Asian state?
—It may not be difficult at all. Wait and see.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports that have linked industrial relations changes in New Zealand to an increase in productivity of 6 per cent? Can the Minister advise whether the Government is contemplating introducing similar changes here to get similar productivity results?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports. In fact, at page 9 of a speech delivered by Dr Hewson in Auckland, New Zealand, on the 22nd of this month, he says:

ANSWER.PARA: In the last few years I have seen a 6 per cent increase in productivity growth in New Zealand compared to less than one per cent in Australia.

The next time Dr Hewson goes overseas to criticise the performance of Australians, whether they be companies or workers, he should get his facts straight. To criticise Australian companies and workers to a foreign audience, while also getting the facts wrong, in order to make a political point is an abomination.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the New Zealand Department of Statistics does not publish an official series on productivity in New Zealand. There is no official statistician in New Zealand to publish figures on productivity, so Dr Hewson could not have been relying on any official publication for the figure of 6 per cent. However, the OECD did make a calculation of New Zealand productivity growth, and it calculated New Zealand productivity for the 1991 calendar year as a negative—minus 0.9 per cent. So, according to the OECD, there was negative productivity growth. According to the OECD's calculation for 1990, there was a positive growth in productivity in New Zealand of 0.9 per cent. So there was a plus of 0.9 per cent for 1990 and a negative of 0.9 per cent for 1991. Therefore, Dr Hewson's claim of 6 per cent productivity growth in New Zealand cannot be substantiated if one has regard to the OECD calculations as a benchmark.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics is the recognised agency publishing figures on statistical behaviour in Australia. It keeps a series on trend labour productivity increases in this country. For the year ending in the December quarter 1991, the ABS figures show that labour productivity in Australia rose by 4.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—The figure was 4.2 per cent.
—In which period?

—To the December quarter, 1991. Dr Hewson claimed in front of an audience in New Zealand that New Zealand's productivity went up by 6 per cent when in fact in the calendar year ending 1991 it went down by 0.9 per cent and that Australia's productivity went up by less than one per cent when in fact Australia's productivity went up by 4.2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: What is the purpose of Dr Hewson misrepresenting—and, apparently, deliberately so when one looks at the official statistics—the productivity performance of Australian workers as compared with the productivity performance of New Zealand workers, particularly when one has regard to the draconian industrial relations circumstances of that country? One can only speculate about that, but it does appear that Dr Hewson wants to tailor the facts to fit his arguments—to push Australia down the New Zealand industrial relations road and pretend that there is some benefit in the New Zealand system when the figures show that there is a negative to justify his industrial relations policy. He claims this policy as the centrepiece of his consumption tax package, yet in the whole 600 pages of his consumption tax package there are only two pages on industrial relations, both of which are devoted to cutting expenditure and programs in my Department.

Dr Hewson is talking about a low wage approach—turning Australian workers and Australian wages policy into the white trash of Asia wages policy—to pay less but not work smart. He is proposing a losers approach. As I described in answer to an earlier question today, we have a winners approach. Dr Hewson wants to reintroduce the conflict and chaos that this country endured during the Fraser years in tenancy on the treasury bench in this place; that is, to maintain high levels of industrial disputation and conflict and to demolish the cooperative approach—the team work approach—that we have engendered with Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to Commissioner Turbet's statements on his resignation from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in which he said that the Government could not be trusted and that the accord process has been manipulated to such an extent that it is now only the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, who are now involved in its decision-making procedures. Have members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission rejected the offer from the Minister to discuss the deterioration in relations between the Commission and the Government? How many commissioners rejected the offer? Who were they? How many commissioners share Commissioner Turbet's views?

—I should restate the Government's attitude to the Industrial Relations Commission because it would inform this debate greatly. The attitude of this Government to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is best summarised by saying that we may disagree from time to time with some of its judgments but we will fight to the death to protect the institution and its right to make those judgments free of outside interference or involvement. That is the attitude of this Government, and I contrast that to the attitude of Opposition members who are on record as declaring their intention to abolish the institution and replace it with what they call an employment court.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane has a continuing fascination with industrial relations, for which I congratulate him. One day it may be accompanied by some study of the subject, which will be even better. I make this threshold point that we are committed to a free and independent commission. The Opposition is committed to its abolition and does not come into this debate with clean hands.

It has been reported in some newspaper columns I have read that I have written a letter to the Commission inviting commissioners to put forward their views to me if there are matters of concern. That is true; I have done that. But I have been asked who has replied and what they have said. That correspondence, to the extent that it has occurred—if it has occurred—is privileged correspondence in my view, and it is not a matter for me to answer in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. The Minister has said that that correspondence is privileged. Will the Minister please tell the Senate what he has to hide?

—I am glad to see that Senator Crane is consistent. He constantly wishes to be provocative. I have nothing to hide. Should Senator Crane last in this chamber long enough to gain more experience, he will know that correspondence between Ministers, discussions in Cabinet and correspondence between a head of an independent organisation such as the Industrial Relations Commission are commonly regarded as privileged. Certainly the correspondence is not available, and I am not going to make it available on this occasion.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Is it true that the Government is looking to change the regulations concerning up-front full fee paying university postgraduate courses with a view to deregulating the industry? If so, what steps is the Government taking to ensure equitable access to these courses and, hence, to postgraduate education and the monitoring of quality in these courses?

—I am advised by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services that the Government will continue to fund universities for an agreed level of student load and is committed to ensuring that access to study through the higher education contribution scheme is maintained across the full range of disciplines.

PARA.TAB: Further, the Minister advises that the Higher Education Council advice on fee paying postgraduate courses, which was tabled in the House on 2 April, is consistent with that policy. It recommends refinements to existing guidelines for fee paying postgraduate courses by providing further rationalisation and greater flexibility in this area while at the same time protecting HECS liable provision for HECS liable students. The Government is considering the HEC advice. Any revised guidelines for fee paying postgraduate courses would need to incorporate safeguards to ensure that HECS liable students have access to the range of postgraduate activities.

The Government is concerned to ensure that access to high status institutions and high income earning professions will not become dependent on means as well as ability as would be the case if the Opposition's policy were to be implemented. The Opposition's policy espouses deregulation but in fact implies greater central control over the detailed operation of institutions in admissions policies, in determining the mix of students, in the accreditation of institutions and in the assessment of standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does `further rationalisation and greater flexibility' as described in the Minister's answer mean further deregulation of course fees?

—I do not think that is what I have said but, if Senator Sowada wishes, I will refer her question for an even further answer by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and reply to her in due course.
—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to a report on 16 April—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Deputy President, could I have some protection, please.
—Ignore them, Senator Boswell.

—I refer the Minister to a report in the 16 April edition of Agra Europe that following the talks in Australia between Mr Crean and the Danish Agricultural Minister, Mr Toernaes, Mr Toernaes was optimistic that a deal could be struck between Australia and the EC, partly reversing the promise given to Australia by former EC Agricultural Commissioner Andriessen that the EC would not give the EC export subsidies for beef to Japan. It is also reported that the Danish Minister was putting pressure on Australia to conclude a new agreement on EC beef exports. Could the Minister tell the Senate whether Mr Crean has struck a deal or is considering a deal which would alter the Andriessen agreement, considering that the Andriessen agreement is vitally important to the Australian beef industry and the EC would not be able to compete in the Japanese export market without export subsidies?

—I welcome Senator Boswell back to the chamber; it is a pleasure to see him here. It is a pity he could not have been here for the tariff discussion yesterday afternoon, but I understand he had a prior engagement—along with Senator O'Chee and Senator Bjelke-Petersen—coincidentally with the tariff debate.

PARA.TAB: Several reports have appeared recently in the Danish press which suggest that Australia has agreed to renegotiate the Andriessen assurance, the undertaking given by the EC in 1985 not to export subsidised beef to Australia's most important Asian-Pacific markets. I am advised that these reports are not at all correct. The Andriessen assurance remains fundamental to the security and profitability of the Australian beef industry. In our view, it is the cornerstone of our relations with the European Community and we would regard any attempt by the Community to resile from it as a serious setback to the overall relationship.

Australia has often conveyed its views in this regard to leaders of the European Community and we are pleased to have received in return—most recently at the ministerial level discussions in Brussels in March this year—the European Community's assurance that it intends to abide by its commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister would be aware that the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in August 1990 resulted in the dislocation of the Ayta people when a number of villages were buried under the volcanic ash. Is the Minister also aware that current estimates indicate that these people will be unable to return to their traditional homelands for 50 years? Further, is the Minister aware that the Aytas have no right of tenure in Philippine law and that their absence may result in their losing access and rights to their lands? Will the Minister undertake to raise this matter with the Government of the Philippines at the earliest opportunity?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that the General Manager of the ABC, Mr David Hill, has issued an edict that all ABC on-air announcers who have nominated for Western Australian local government elections should be removed from their on-air duties and, in the event that they are elected on Saturday, they must either resign from their unpaid local government positions or face dismissal from the ABC? Does the Minister agree with Mr Hill's blatant and intrusive interference with the rights and responsibilities of ABC employees who may wish to make a voluntary contribution to the affairs of their local communities? Finally, is the Minister aware that this edict was issued by Mr Hill following representations by a Mrs Robyn Hanningan, an ALP apparatchik and member of the Broome Shire Council?

—I can now give an answer concerning conflict of interest, which has been a matter of some import in here in recent times. ABC radio's regional program manager for the Kimberley, Mr George Manning, was nominated to stand for a position on the Broome Shire Council in the local government election. Under section 33 of the staff rules of the Corporation an officer or employee shall not accept or continue to hold an office in or under the government of any State or in any public or municipal corporation without the express permission of the delegate.

PARA.TAB: In the specific circumstances of Mr Manning having a daily ABC radio program dealing with local issues, problems of conflict of interest impacting on public perceptions of the ABC's independence came to light. The ABC cannot legally intervene or interfere in an election process which is under way and has not sought to do so. Mr Manning reviewed his position and independently decided to withdraw from the election. As his nomination had already been accepted under the Western Australian Local Government Act, he found he was unable to withdraw and is required to see the election process through.

In light of the conflict of interest problems associated with a nominee for local government presenting a radio program covering local issues in the lead-up to the shire elections, ABC Western Australia radio management discussed this issue with Mr Manning and, with his agreement, decided to withdraw Mr Manning from his on-air role. Alternative on-air arrangements and an off-air role for Mr Manning were implemented by radio management.

Mr Manning has advised that he will review his position following the election. ABC radio management will then review Mr Manning's continuing on-air role in the Kimberley. A couple of other ABC radio Western Australia staff are currently seeking office in local government and are involved in an election process.

Yesterday Western Australian radio management issued a directive also withdrawing these staff members from their program making roles. These cases are currently being reviewed on an individual basis by ABC radio management and, as is the case with Mr Manning, the staff involved are currently working in an off-air capacity.

As Senator Crichton-Browne was kind enough to give me some notice of the general nature of the question, I was able to find out as much as I could. He will note from the answer, though, that this suggests the directive came from Western Australian radio management, not from Mr David Hill. I will certainly recheck that matter for Senator Crichton-Browne and give him an answer tomorrow or as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Major National Research Facilities: A National Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) relating to major national research facilities, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant component of any nation's science and technology base is its system of major national research facilities.
Australia currently has six such research facilities, including the Australia Telescope, the Oceanographic Research Vessel Franklin, and the Australian Animal Health Laboratory.
Major advances in science and technology increasingly depend on research workers having access to the type of complex and expensive equipment contained in these facilities.
However their high cost, in terms of establishment and maintenance, is often beyond the resources of individual institutions.
In response to a request from the then Prime Minister, ASTEC investigated this issue and produced what is a very important report.
Major National Research Facilities: A National Program, recommends that a program of major national research facilities be established.

This would provide for the consideration of new major research facilities proposals, phasing-out of facilities that no longer satisfy national needs and priorities, and access to major research facilities overseas where such access is an appropriate alternative to the creation of an Australia-based facility.
As part of its report, ASTEC established assessment criteria to enable proposals for funding to be judged in terms of their benefits to science and technology and to the nation.
Using its criteria, the report listed some 15 likely candidates for major facilities over the next five to 10 years.
Among these proposed facilities is an upgrade of the Australia Telescope, a new Marine Geoscience Research Vessel, a Mining Materials Research facility and a Tropical Marine Research Network.
The ASTEC report notes that a further process of rigorous evaluation will be necessary before any decision can be made to proceed with any of these.
I must emphasise this point.
Any hasty decisions on new facilities would be inimical to the spirit of the report.

In particular, members will note that one of the facilities recommend for further investigation is a new Hi-flux Research Reactor to replace the existing reactor at Lucas Heights. No decision will be taken on the establishment of such a facility without an inquiry process consistent with the decision of last year's ALP National Conference.

Major National Research Facilities: A National Program, is in many ways a landmark report. It recognises that major national research facilities are too important for decisions to be made on an ad hoc basis.
It recognises that Australia's future need for national research facilities must be planned as an integral part of our national research and technology priority setting process.
ASTEC has produced a valuable report which will enable us to establish procedures for assessing the relative benefits to Australia of proposals for major national research facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare on the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE ON CULLING OF LARGE FERAL ANIMALS IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY
PREAMBLE

1.The report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on Culling of Large Feral Animals in the Northern Territory, tabled on 21 June 1991, is the eighth report of the Committee and addresses the significant problems encountered in the Northern Territory with feral animals. The Government is now in a position to respond to the report.

2.The report contains ten (10) recommendations which form the basis for improvement in welfare aspects of controlling feral animals. Despite the restrictive terms of reference for the inquiry, reflected in the title of the report, the Committee's conclusions and recommendations apply to management of introduced animal pests throughout Australia. The word "feral" should, therefore, be taken in the context of the Government response, to apply to all introduced animal pests, and not in its more restrictive sense of members of a domestic species which have reverted to a wild state.

3.Australia's feral animal population poses a major problem. Feral animals cause serious damage to agricultural production by competing with livestock, they can be extremely harmful to the environment, and they are a potential major reservoir for endemic diseases, such as brucellosis and tuberculosis, and exotic diseases, for example foot and mouth disease. For these reasons it is essential that effective steps be taken to control the impact of feral animals in Australia.

4.Over the years Governments have been confronted with many conflicting considerations regarding feral animal control. These include the historical and sentimental value of camels and horses (particularly the descendants of the "walers", a generic name applied to the stock-horse types widely used as cavalry mounts, originally for the British Army in India), the commercial value of pigs, and the tourist potential of horses, buffalo and camels. The views of Aborigines, who control a large percentage of Northern Territory land and utilise feral animals, need to be incorporated in decision making. Cost/benefit analyses should be undertaken to ensure that a rational approach is taken, and the humaneness of control methods also has to be taken into account.

5.The control of vertebrate pests is one of several Australian animal welfare issues which have assumed international significance. The Commonwealth Government receives many letters of complaint from overseas countries, particularly Europe and the United States, about the perceived inhumaneness of vertebrate pest management in Australia. International concern directed at Australia as a whole has the potential to tarnish our image abroad. It also has the potential to affect our trade in goods and services, not only in direct action against items such as fox skins and kangaroo products, but through consumer boycotts against other goods and even the tourist industry. Apart from the kangaroo cull, which is outside the scope of this report as it involves a native species, the issue which has attracted most criticism, both from within Australia and abroad, is helicopter shooting of feral horses.

6.Public attitudes to pest management and associated welfare issues are often based on incomplete or misleading information and are strongly influenced by perception and emotion. However, there is an increasing expectation within the general community that people involved with animals—whether in livestock production, research, or pest management—must pay greater attention to animal welfare, and the general public is demanding to be included in the process for deciding what is acceptable. It is in the interests of the authorities responsible for implementing pest control programs, and of those with an interest in the outcome of those programs, to ensure that the process is as transparent as possible and that the public is able to express its views from an informed position.

7.The fact that the existence of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare was extended to enable it to undertake an inquiry into the welfare implications of culling feral animals is an indication of the seriousness with which the Government views this issue. The Senate Select Committee's report provides an objective assessment of the major concerns and proposes some measures for addressing them. It is essential for Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, conservation and animal welfare interest groups, livestock producers, Aboriginal communities and other parties with an interest in the issue, to work together to address the feral animal problem in a way which takes into account the many different views, concerns and objectives.

8.As the Senate Select Committee mentioned, the question of animal welfare in relation to management of introduced animals has been addressed by the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare (NCCAW), which advises the Commonwealth Government, through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on animal welfare issues of national significance. The control of feral animals was referred to NCCAW by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy as a major issue which needed to be considered from an animal welfare perspective. NCCAW established a working group comprising experts in the field of vertebrate pest management, as well as representatives of producer and animal welfare interests.

9.In its report, the working group concluded that pest control will need to be based on currently available methods for the foreseeable future, but that these methods need to be reviewed with regard to humaneness and, where necessary, refined or replaced by more humane methods. It also concluded that more objective and reliable methods of assessing pain and distress in animals need to be developed and that pest control needs to be placed on a more rational basis by assessing the impact of pest species and the long term costs and benefits of current approaches to their control. The report has recently been made available as a reference document.

10.The Government is aware that efforts are currently being made to develop humane culling methods, and it wishes to encourage the initiatives of organisations which are involved in such research. A New South Wales Pastoral Protection Board, for example, in response to the increased use of helicopter shooting of feral animals over the last few years, is conducting research (an assessment into various types of ballistics) to determine the most suitable, single, type of round.

11.There is a need for control programs to be planned, systematic and sustained. They should also be co-ordinated with surrounding landholders and community programs. One-off and sporadic control measures must be discouraged. It is important, also, to realise that elimination of feral animals is only possible in very restricted environments, such as islands, or where an intensive, co-ordinated national effort is made, such as in the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign—a program which has virtually eliminated feral cattle and buffalo but at a great cost to both the Government and the livestock industry. The use of the term "control" instead of "elimination" is more appropriate as it reflects achievable aims.

12.Under the auspices of the Vertebrate Pest Committee of the Standing Committee on Agriculture, the Bureau of Rural Resources (within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy) is implementing a project to develop national strategies for the co-ordinated management of the major vertebrate pests in Australia. This approach will be developed and implemented on a national basis and in consultation with all interested parties including the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, the community, conservation and animal welfare groups, and industry. The development of these strategies will be overseen by a working group which consists of representatives of the Vertebrate Pests Committee, the Australian Conservation Foundation, the National Farmers' Federation, and the Standing Committee on Conservation of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council.

13.A number of the recommendations contained in the Senate Select Committee's report will be partly addressed in the context of the Bureau's project. The Government notes, however, that the above mentioned working group does not include a representative of an animal welfare body.

14.The Government is concerned that the mustering and long distance transport of feral horses does have the potential to cause welfare problems. However, continuation of integrated feral horse control programs initiated by landholders rely on the revenue generated by the sale of captured horses. If controls arising from animal welfare concerns become too restrictive and increase costs of transport, the resolve of landholders to continue control efforts could be reduced.
