As a longer term measure, the Government would prefer to see mobile abattoirs and field shooting for game and pet meat, substituted to the extent possible for long distance transport to abattoirs.

15.The Bureau of Rural Resources issued a report on the Welfare of Horses Being Transported in November 1990, the recommendations of which were considered by the Senate Select Committee in its deliberations. The report outlines the need for further research to establish the particular conditions most suited for horse transport. Generally, the recommendations offer the potential for improving the conditions of all horses being transported, without limiting the focus to feral horses only.

16.A joint Commonwealth/State/Northern Territory Task Force has partially completed investigating the options for a uniform volume loading regime for the transport of livestock by road. It is expected that this work will be passed to the National Road Transport Commission for its consideration and completion as appropriate. The Government considers that as consignors of animals demand that value loss from bruising, maiming and death in transit does not occur, livestock transporters are generally acutely aware of the need to load to acceptable limits in a real business sense, as they require continuity of trade to survive. It is aware, however, that such commercial considerations are not always sufficient to prevent welfare problems arising.

17.The Government wishes to encourage the adoption of a nationally consistent approach to the management of vertebrate pests. The responsibility for deciding whether or not to implement many of the Senate Select Committee's recommendations, however, rests with State and Territory Governments. The relevant recommendations have therefore been referred to State and Territory Ministers of Agriculture through the Australian Agricultural Council at its meeting in February 1992. That Council will henceforth be known as the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand.
18.I am now in a position to provide the Government's response to each of the Senate Select Committee's individual recommendations.

1.The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy publish Model Codes of Practice on Animal Welfare in a more compact, durable and professional format. The Committee further recommends that the Department, in conjunction with State and Territory Governments, ensure that these Codes are readily available to interested parties, including government and non-government personnel.

PARA.TAB: Government Response
Supported in principle.

The Government agrees that the national model codes of practice should be properly published. The Standing Committee on Agriculture (SCA) decided in 1989 that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) would be responsible for publishing the codes as part of the SCA Technical Report series. CSIRO has since published six codes in an updated format. The remaining codes, which are currently under review, and any new codes, will also be published in a similar format.

Model codes of practice are usually modified by State and Territory Governments to better suit local situations. Dissemination of these codes is undertaken by States and Territories as they have legislative responsibility for animal welfare. State and Territory Governments, although limited by the availability of funds, are acutely aware of the need to achieve wider dissemination and greater awareness of the codes and are addressing this issue through the Sub Committee on Animal Welfare (SCAW) within SCA.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government, through its various research and funding agencies, extend research into the agricultural, environmental and economic impact of feral animals.
Government Response
Supported.

PARA.TAB: The Vertebrate Pest Committee, established by the Standing Committee on Agriculture in conjunction with the Bureau of Rural Resources, is currently preparing national strategies for managing the agricultural and environmental impact of major vertebrate pests. One of the aims of the strategies will be to identify where additional research or other studies are required. The rural industries research and development corporations and councils under the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, which are funded jointly by the Commonwealth Government and the relevant industries, support some research into the impact and control of vertebrate pests. The Government will explore with these bodies the possibility of extending this research.

Research into some environmental aspects of introduced animal control is funded by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS). Some funding may also be available from the Australian Research Council (ARC). However, as control of introduced animals is not considered to warrant the status of a priority area for ARC funding, any grants for that service would be awarded on the basis of the quality of the researcher and the excellence of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: 3.The Committee recommends that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service let contracts for removal of feral animals only to those private contractors who can satisfy the Service that they pay due attention to the welfare of animals. Additionally, contracts for the removal of feral animals should contain provisions for immediate termination if there is evidence of maltreatment or inattention to the welfare of stock.
Government Response
Supported.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service issued its last contract for mustering and removal of feral buffalo in August 1990. It does not expect to issue contracts in the foreseeable future because of low numbers of buffalo and horses in the Kakadu National Park due to the Service's compliance with BTEC requirements. The last contract did, however, provide for the contractor to give due regard to the welfare of animals handled under the contract, and for termination of the contract if stock were found to be in an unacceptably poor or unreasonably stressed condition. The Service will ensure that any future contract will contain similar provisions for the well-being of the mustered animals.
The Government recommends that State and Territory authorities responsible for vertebrate pest control adopt a similar approach.

SPEECH.PARA: 4.The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council, review the continuing use of feral horses in the export horse-meat industry, with particular regard to animal welfare issues associated with this industry.

5.The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council, consider, and where appropriate, implement the recommendations contained in the working paper by the Bureau of Rural Resources on the Welfare of Horses being Transported.
Government Response
Both recommendations are supported in principle.

PARA.TAB: The recommendations contained in this report, the Bureau of Rural Resources report on the Welfare of Horses being Transported and the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare's report The Transport of Livestock Within Australia were referred to the Australian Agricultural Council at its meeting in February 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth, Northern Territory and other State governments introduce accreditation or licensing schemes for government and non-government personnel involved in helicopter culling operations.
Government Response
Supported in principle.

PARA.TAB: The Government concurs with the view of the Committee that helicopter shooting represents the most humane method of controlling feral animals in inaccessible locations and that only experienced and appropriately trained marksmen should be used. It also considers that a national approach to a training and accreditation scheme for shooters needs to be developed to minimise the risk of several schemes being implemented with varying levels of effectiveness. This recommendation has been referred to the Australian Agricultural Council.

SPEECH.PARA: 7.The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council, examine ways in which feral animal populations, reduced by activities associated with BTEC, may continue to be controlled following the completion of BTEC in 1992.
Government Response
Supported.

PARA.TAB: The continued control of feral animal populations will be examined by the Bureau of Rural Resources in its development of national strategies on managing vertebrate pests.

SPEECH.PARA: 8.The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government, through relevant departmental, industry and research agencies and inter-governmental arrangements, accord priority to research into non-lethal, humane and long-term methods of control of feral animals.
Government Response
Supported.

PARA.TAB: The question of non-lethal control in wildlife management was addressed in a Bureau of Rural Resources report entitled "A Role for Fertility Control in Wildlife Management?". The report concluded that fertility control is likely to be of more value in preventing or reducing the rate of growth of pest populations that have been reduced to levels well below their uncontrolled density by other means such as drought, disease or conventional control. Fertility control for horses and other large animals is thought to be high risk research with a low probability of a successful outcome, particularly as alternative fertility control approaches, such as the delivery of immunogens by dart gun, are already considered not to be either practical or economic for the management of Australia's feral horse population.

After the Committee produced its report, the Commonwealth Government allocated more than $12 million towards a Cooperative Research Centre on biological control of vertebrate populations. This Centre will primarily investigate fertility control for wildlife damage control and will concentrate on foxes and rabbits. Further investment in research in this field is not warranted until the success of current research can be assessed.
The issue of fertility control will be considered, where relevant, in the context of the Bureau of Rural Resources' and Vertebrate Pest Committee's project on vertebrate pest management.

SPEECH.PARA: 9.The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy assess current and proposed mechanisms for national co-ordination of measures to alleviate the problems associated with vertebrate pests, including feral animals.

10.The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers, consider the establishment of a national committee or task force to provide a concerted and co-ordinated approach to the control or elimination of feral animals.

PARA.TAB: Government Response
Both recommendations are supported in principle.

The Government concurs with the view of the Senate Select Committee that a concerted and co-ordinated approach is necessary. The Vertebrate Pest Committee of the Standing Committee on Agriculture has terms of reference which would enable it to undertake the functions of the proposed national committee. As stated above, the VPC, in conjunction with the Bureau of Rural Resources, has established a working group to oversee the development of strategic documents for the management of Australia's major vertebrate pests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Government has responded to this report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I wonder when the Government will respond to the kangaroo report, which took eight years in the making and which still has not been replied to.
—It's hopping along!

—Obviously. This inquiry was one of the last that the then Select Committee on Animal Welfare conducted. It was quite controversial. The inquiry was brought about as a result of unfavourable publicity we received overseas and locally, particularly through the television media, about the culling of horses and buffalo.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity that Senator Cooney is not here, because we conducted a wide-ranging inquiry into this. We came to the conclusion that there was only one way in which we could protect the native flora and fauna of northern Australia: that is, by the eradication of horses, buffalo and other feral animals, no matter how distasteful it may seem. I can understand the reactions of people when they see photographs of horses being shot. Articles on this have appeared quite regularly on television and in the print media.

The Committee had many representations from concerned citizens about cruelty to animals and the possibility of injuring them during this culling. Nevertheless, in the interests of retaining our native flora and fauna, particularly the bilby, we came to that conclusion. I am surprised that the Australian Democrats are not here—they have been quite vocal with respect to the bilby. The bilby population used to extend from Western Australia to Victoria and into the Northern Territory. Their numbers have shrunk quite considerably and these unique animals are now found in very small pockets.

This has occurred because they have had tremendous competition from feral animals, particularly horses. We looked at the culling of wild horses in and around Alice Springs; we inspected a horse abattoir at Peterborough in South Australia; we had quite intensive investigations into the methods of shooting horses, particularly from helicopters. We came to the conclusion that there was no alternative to helicopter shooting for the eradication of these wild horses. There are other methods, of course, such as mustering. At the end of the day, to get the numbers of wild horses sufficiently reduced to limit the risk to the native animals, the terrain is such that there is no other humane way of doing it.

My colleague Senator Patterson asked me a while ago what I know about Walers. Senator Brownhill would know that they were one of the major reasons why this investigation was taken on board. `Walers' is a generic name that was applied to stockhorse types that were used in the Middle East during the First World War. Anzac Day in Hobart brought back memories of the Walers because a particular contingent of returned servicemen marched with some horses purported to be Walers—or at least they were decked out as Walers. They were not Walers because there are no Walers as such left in Australia at the moment. However, there may be some descendants who have interbred with the local brumbies.

Make no mistake about it: whilst these animals and other wild animals may seem attractive, the feral animal problem—not just horses and buffalo but also wild pigs and camels; the introduced animal species abounding northern Australia in great numbers—is horrific. It is probably one of the most disastrous states of affairs as far as our native flora and fauna are concerned.

I am pleased to see that the Government has responded to our report. I note that it supports some of our recommendations. For example, we recommended that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council, review the continued use of feral horses in the export horse meat industry. We were concerned that some of the practices involved in this industry were not in the best interests of the animals. There was certainly some cruelty in evidence. I notice that the Government has supported that recommendation.

I also notice that the Government has supported the recommendations in principle on the transportation of horses. It also supports the recommendations concerning the vertebrate pest committee. The Government supports in principle our recommendations on a code of practice.

All in all, I notice from looking through the report that the Government has either fully supported or supported in principle every recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. It is rather pleasing to see that the bipartisan recommendations made by that former Committee have been supported by the Government. I look forward to seeing those recommendations carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Calvert, who was on this inquiry. Of all the inquiries we had on animal welfare issues, this was the only one that I unfortunately missed because I was out of the country representing this Parliament at the United Nations at the time.

PARA.TAB: I know a little about the history of, and the reasons for, the inquiry. As Senator Calvert said, the inquiry was established because of a sentimental attachment to horses and camels which had served this country very well in the past. This applied particularly to the descendants of the Walers, which is the generic name applied to the stockhorse type which was widely used as cavalry mounts, originally for the British army in India. The inquiry was also instituted because of the commercial value of pigs and the tourist potential of horses, buffaloes and camels in the northern parts of Australia.

Having read the report, I believe the Committee did a very good and thorough job. As Senator Calvert said, all the recommendations that were made by the Committee have basically been supported by the Government. I also agree with Senator Calvert that it would be very nice—I know this is not always possible—if the Government's responses to committee reports were brought down a bit quicker. If the Government's response to this report had been brought down before the end of last year, it would have been a little more relevant than it is now to the members of the inquiry and to the witnesses who gave evidence. I commend the response to the chamber and to the community at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had only three or four minutes to consider the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I congratulate the Government on adopting the report of the Committee. I wish to raise a few matters. This report was to be about the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory, but I am delighted to see that the Committee went beyond its terms of reference and referred in its report to all feral animals and to introduced animal pests—not in the more restrictive sense of members of a domestic species which have reverted to a wild state.

PARA.TAB: The Government's response to the report acknowledged that Australia's feral animal population poses a major problem. It refers to damage to agricultural production, the extreme harm done to the environment and a potential major reservoir of endemic diseases. Domestic animals have started to run riot in this country and they are doing enormous damage to our environment. Like Senator Calvert, I am surprised that the representatives of the Australian Democrats are not in the chamber making speeches about this subject at present. The problem of wild cats, wild dogs and wild pigs in our bush country is enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Horrific!

—My colleague says that it is horrific, and I agree with that word. Something has to be done about this situation. We must start in our cities. Our State governments must be required to take action on domestic dogs and cats. I make no bones about this matter. I say clearly where I stand. I believe that all such animals should be required to be registered. Those held as domestic animals for friendship purposes ought to have a low registration fee of, say, $5 per annum. One of the conditions of registration ought to be that all domestic animals be de-sexed. Any such animal which is not de-sexed and which is held for breeding purposes ought to have an annual registration fee of about $100 per annum. That would ensure that the animal's owners are using it properly and are paying the monetary penalty for holding such an animal. These conditions should ensure that such animals do not run astray.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge that after a period of five or six years animals might be thought to be beyond their breeding time. In those circumstances it would perhaps be unfair to continue to charge a fee of $100 a year. After the owner has paid an annual registration fee for five years, such animals could be kept at the lower rate. By then they would have become pets that would be kept in people's homes. We must start with those animals. As to how we get rid of our wild feral pigs—other than by having major shooting parties going out and shooting them—I do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Potential time bomb.

—I think the time bomb has erupted. These pigs have to be eliminated. Senator Calvert is referring to the time bomb of foot and mouth disease. I was saying that there are so many wild pigs around Australia that if we get any sort of endemic disease it will run riot through our outback and create enormous environmental problems. It is a pity that they are so difficult to eradicate. In its report, the Government says that it is so difficult that:

SPEECH.PARA: the use of the term "control" instead of "elimination" is more appropriate as it reflects achievable aims.
I do not disagree with that conclusion. I want to refer to paragraph 4 of the Government's response which says:
Over the years Governments have been confronted with many conflicting considerations regarding feral animal control.
It then refers to the historical and sentimental value of camels and horses, particularly the descendants of walers. Paragraph 5 says:

The control of vertebrate pests is one of several animal welfare issues which have assumed international significance. The Commonwealth Government receives many letters of complaint from overseas countries, particularly Europe and the United States, about the perceived inhumaneness of vertebrate pest management in Australia.

I simply say to the Government that if it ignores such complaints, it will have my full support. Those people who live in the very urbanised cities of Europe and the United States simply do not understand the nature of the problems that we are confronted with.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are stirred up by local animal activists in Australia.

—I have no doubt that that is what happens to them. They do not understand the nature of the problem that we face. If they had the number of wild animals running around in their countryside that we have, they would be doing something to eliminate them. I refer to the shortage of tigers in India and such places. No-one is saying that we ought to do something about keeping the tiger population of India and those countries alive. If the people of various European cities had wild feral pigs running around their cities, they would be eliminating them in same way that I suggest Australians have to eliminate them.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, except in very limited areas, this is not the responsibility of the Federal Government. It behoves us in the Senate to make our views clear on these matters, to draw the attention of State governments to these problems and to encourage State governments to take action along these lines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add some comments to those that have been made by Senator Calvert, Senator Brownhill and Senator Lewis. They are the three who have spoken so far and with whose remarks I agree. This is a very important issue. Senator Brownhill and Senator Calvert are examples of the sort of people I am about to speak of. We have great admiration for the Aborigines because they are capable of identifying with the land. The dreamtime is a manifestation of how they feel at one with the country.

PARA.TAB: That situation is now developing in respect of people who have been here for some time. The families of people like Senator Calvert, Senator Brownhill and Senator Lewis have lived in the country for some time and are becoming more and more, as it were, identified with it.

In many cases feral animals are destroying the native animals and threatening their existence. Those feral animals which are damaging the very texture of the soil must be eliminated.Feral animals should not be eliminated simply because we believe that we should take this course of action. However, in balancing the proper, humane treatment which those animals deserve against the desperate need to preserve unique Australian fauna and flora, the major weights must be put into the pan which represents the native animals.

As Senator Lewis said, it is true that there has been criticism from overseas. But again, Senator Calvert and Senator Brownhill would agree with me that the people who do the shooting from helicopters deserve much praise. It must be remembered that they dramatically increase the risk to their lives by making sure that their targets are killed instantly. Helicopters must be flown at a very low height. They must then turn back to check to see whether the shot has killed the target. So it can be seen that the killing takes place in the most humane way.

I am very pleased to see that the Government has taken very seriously the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare and has agreed to act in response to it. We looked at feral animals in the outback. Senator Lewis made the very good point that the same problem arises in the city, particularly with lyrebirds and cats around Sherbrooke Forest. It is incumbent upon this chamber to continue to look at what happens in this area. This is a report and a response which I would hate to see just disappear. Perhaps we could come to some sort of tacit agreement here today that we will raise the issue from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to report No. 3 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1987 Federal election. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document and incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT NO. 3 OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

PARA.TAB: 1. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal continue to review enrolment decisions for all States including joint roll States.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
2. The Minister for Administrative Services approach State governments with a view to having the review of all enrolment decisions undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
3. Section 102(1)(b)(v) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be deleted to enable streamlined processing of enrolment cards.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

4. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that all persons who change their address are required to notify the Australian Electoral Commission and thereby change their address on the Electoral Roll.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
5. Section 176 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that a candidate who has a silent enrolment may be exempt from having his or her address published.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

6. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to provide Senators and Members of the House of Representatives with a choice of recording either their enrolment address or place of residence when completing a nomination form.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

7. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that candidates endorsed by a party can authorise, by means of a standard letter formulated by the Australian Electoral Commission, their respective Registered Officer or Deputy Registered Officer to nominate them as candidates for elections for the House of Representatives.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

8. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that the Registered Officer or Deputy Registered Officer of a party may lodge the nominations for all candidates in a State or Territory endorsed by the party with the Australian Electoral Officer for each State or Territory up to 48 hours before the close of nominations.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

9. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for nominations to be forwarded by facsimile to either Divisional Returning Officers or the Australian Electoral Officer in each State. Nominations made by facsimile must be received 48 hours before the close of nominations in the case of Australian Electoral Officers and up until the close of roll in the case of Divisional Returning Officers.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
10. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to:
a) define those classes persons who hold an office of profit under the Crown; and
b) state the requirement for such persons to resign their office before nominating for election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth.
—See Recommendation 11.

11. Those people affected by the requirement to resign from an office of profit under the Crown before nominating for election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth, for which they are subsequently unsuccessful, have their employment and entitlements protected by suitable legislation.

—Recommendations 10-11 propose that the constitutional phrase `office of profit under the Crown', which prevents a person from standing for election, be defined by legislation, that persons who hold such an office should resign before nomination, and that the employment and entitlements of such persons should be protected. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that a definition in legislation cannot resolve the uncertainty about the meaning of the phrase used in the Constitution. This issue is a complex one that was the subject of considerable discussion in the 1981 Report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled "The Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament". That Report pointed out the definitional problems associated with the interpretation of section 44(iv) of the Constitution. It is generally accepted that Commonwealth, State and Territory public servants, employees of some (but not all) Commonwealth statutory authorities, some statutory office holders and members of the Defence Forces are considered to hold an "office of profit" within the meaning of section 44(iv). While it is straightforward to provide that such officers resign before nomination, several problems arise with the proposal that the reinstatement of such officers be guaranteed. In particular, problems arise with the reinstatement of statutory office holders in relation to the sensitivity of some positions. It is already the case that the Public Service Act 1922 currently protects the employment and entitlements of public service officers (except Secretaries and unattached Secretaries) and the Defence (Parliamentary Candidates) Act 1969 provides for discretionary reinstatement of Defence Forces personnel who resign to contest elections. The Government considers that those officers generally accepted to hold an `office of profit under the Crown' should be required to resign before nominating, including State and Territory officers, in accordance with the accepted interpretation of section 44(iv) of the Constitution. The Government does not consider that Commonwealth legislation should provide that State or Territory officers have their employment and entitlements protected if unsuccessful. The State and Territory Governments are to be approached with a view to the introduction of complementary legislation with regard to reinstatement rights. The Government supports the alternative to the Committee's proposal whereby specified Commonwealth, State and Territory public service officers, statutory office holders and employees of statutory authorities and members of the Defence Forces (that is those officers generally accepted to hold an office of profit under the Crown) must resign before nominating. Further consideration will be given to the reinstatement rights of affected officers in addition to those provisions that currently apply.
12. The nomination forms used by the Australian Electoral Commission be revised so that candidates are required to declare their eligibility to nominate in terms of all the eligibility criteria.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
13. Candidates completing a nomination form and claiming to be an Australian citizen state:
a) how they became Australian citizens (that is either by birth or naturalisation); and
b) if the candidates were naturalised, where and when the naturalisation took place.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

14. Section 339 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that any person making a claim in his or her nomination form which is false or misleading in material respect shall be subject to a maximum penalty of $3,000 and/or imprisonment for 6 months.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

15. The Australian Electoral Commission take all possible steps to inform prospective candidates and candidates of the penalties to which they are subject for recording false or misleading claims on their nomination forms.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
16. Penalties for the recording of false or misleading claims on nomination forms be printed on nomination forms.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
17. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the completion of a modified electoral enrolment form at the time a person applies for Australian citizenship.
—See Recommendation 18.

18. Consequent upon the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 being so amended, the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs act in conjunction to implement a system of enrolment for those persons applying for citizenship, the system to be that described in paragraphs 3.85-3.87 of this Report.

—Recommendations 17 and 18 propose that new citizens apply for "provisional" enrolment when completing citizenship application forms. While this proposal has merit, its implementation would create considerable problems with the joint roll arrangements with the States. Each State government would have to enact complementary legislation for such "provisional" enrolment to effect both Commonwealth and State enrolment. In the absence of complementary legislation, such "provisional" enrolment would only apply for Commonwealth purposes and new citizens enrolled under this scheme would be required to enrol again for State purposes. Such a requirement would be needlessly bureaucratic. Given the difficulties involved and the considerable time lapses that occur in reaching agreement with all the States on the enactment of complementary legislation, an administrative alternative to the Committee's proposal that will not require legislation is to be sought by the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.
19. The Australian Electoral Commission amend the electoral enrolment form so that it contains questions which ask:
a) how a person became an Australian citizen; and
b) if the person is naturalised, where and when the naturalisation took place.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
20. The Australian Electoral Commission conduct regular random checks of those electoral enrolment forms completed by persons born overseas and claiming to be Australian citizens.
—See Recommendation 21.

21. The Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs work in conjunction to formulate and implement a system of checking the citizenship of persons born overseas and seeking to be added to the Electoral Roll.

—Recommendations 20 and 21 propose random checks of citizenship qualifications for enrolment where a person is born overseas and claims to be an Australian citizen. These recommendations have not been accepted on the grounds that such checking would be resource intensive, hamstrung by incomplete records, likely to offend the ethnic community, and inconsistent with the principles of the Privacy Act 1988.

22. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide that electors can only once be restored automatically to the Commonwealth Electoral Roll after they have been removed by habitation review. Such electors may then only be added to the Electoral Roll by means of completing an electoral enrolment form.
—See Recommendation 23.

23. The Australian Electoral Commission ensure that an accurate record is maintained of all voters who, at the time of an election, claim a declaration vote for an address for which they are not enrolled but for which they claim to have been enrolled at a previous election. Such a list should be publicly available.

—Recommendations 22-23 propose that electors should be only once restored automatically to the electoral roll after they have been removed by objection action and subsequently cast a declaration vote. The proposal is based on the perception that large numbers of people are maintaining incorrect enrolment addresses by the process of declaration voting. Subsequent to the Committee's deliberations the Australian Electoral Commission has introduced a revised declaration form which the Government believes will largely resolve the problem. It should also be noted that the Committee's proposal is likely to result in the disenfranchising of a significant number of voters who do in fact reside at the enrolled address.
24. Nomination forms be amended to require candidates to state their membership of any registered political party.
—See Recommendation 25.
25. There be a penalty for a candidate failing to state his or her membership of any registered political party on a nomination form. The penalty to be $6,000.

—Recommendations 24-25 propose that candidates should be required to indicate membership of a registered political party—penalty $6000. In view of the fact that the incidence of candidates who are members of registered political parties nominating without party endorsement or belonging to more than one registered political party is low, the Government does not consider that this further complication of the nomination form is warranted.
26. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to permit licensed premises to be used as polling places subject to the Electoral Commissioner being satisfied that:
a) no liquor will be sold or consumed on that part of the premises being used for polling;
b) the part of the premises to be used for polling is segregated from areas where alcohol is being sold or consumed; and
c) voters have easy access to the part of the premises to be used for polling which does not involve passage through an area where alcohol is being sold or consumed.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
27. The Australian Electoral Commission make every effort to ensure cardboard screens and ballot boxes are recycled.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
28. The Australian Electoral Commission's program for the training of relevant polling staff be modified to give additional emphasis to the assembly and emptying of cardboard ballot boxes.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
29. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended or a regulation be made so that the prompt, PLEASE READ THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE YOU VOTE, appears in bold type on all ballot papers.
—In the light of the recent redesign of the House of Representatives ballot-paper, this additional prompt is not considered necessary.

30. Section 211A(8) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to allow the name of a candidate who is using s.211A(1) or s.211A(2) to be recorded along with the word `Independent' in the top portion of the Senate ballot paper.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

31. Prior to the next federal election the Australian Electoral Commission introduce a system of double enveloping or an appropriately designed ready-to-assemble envelope for the purpose of postal voting.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

32. Australia Post make arrangements to receive and postmark all mail addressed to the Australian Electoral Commission or officers of the Australian Electoral Commission and lodged at Post Offices up until 5.00pm on the Friday immediately preceding an election. This includes mail lodged in locked mail bags.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
33. The Australian Electoral Commission provide full information to postal voters on the procedures for making postal votes including arrangements made by Australia Post.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
34. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that mobile polling stations at federal elections become polling places for the purposes of registration of general postal voters.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

35. The Australian Electoral Commission develop and implement a charging policy to apply to media organisations for their access to, and usage of, the National Tally Room wherever and whenever it is set up for elections of the Parliament of the Commonwealth.

—The Government believes that the media perform a valuable public service in broadcasting election results on polling night, in effect serving as part of the overall operation and the democratic process by conveying the election results to the nation. On that basis the Government believes that it would be inappropriate to charge media organisations for access to the National Tally Room.
36. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to allow for a second scrutiny of all declaration votes which have been rejected at the first scrutiny.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
37. An infringement notice system be introduced to replace the present system of enforcement of compulsory voting.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
38. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to extend the definition of `electoral advertisement' to cover video material.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
39. The Australian Electoral Commission ensure newspaper publishers are fully aware of the provisions of s.328 and s.331 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

40. Section 328 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that newspaper advertisements appearing as double page advertisements carry authorisation details on both pages of the advertisement unless the advertisement extends across the two pages and is contained within one box or is printed across the seam of the two pages in which case only one authorisation statement need be printed.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

41. Section 328 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that business cards which promote a person's candidacy for election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth be exempt from the requirement to display authorisation details.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

42. Section 328(3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to add to the category of material that do not require authorisation under subsection (1), letters and cards (other than how-to-vote cards) which are marked with the name and address of the sender so as to make it clear who is responsible for the material.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

43. Section 351 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to delete the requirement to prove a matter is published on behalf of any association, league, organisation or other body of persons.

—This proposal will have the effect of creating an offence of claiming that a candidate is associated with or supports the policies of any organisation. Such an offence would be very broad and would constitute a major restriction of free speech. Because of these unintended results, it is suggested that the Committee should reconsider the recommendation.
44. Section 351(3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide that the person whose name is printed as the authoriser of a how-to-vote card is deemed to be the publisher.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

45. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the distribution to each candidate, as soon as practicable after the close of rolls, one copy of the certified list of voters for the Division in which the candidate seeks election.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

46. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide that after an election for the Senate or a Division or Divisions of the House of Representatives, each Member of the House of Representatives be given three copies of the certified list of voters used in his or her Division for the election.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

47. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide that after each election for the Senate or the House of Representatives each Senator be provided with one copy of the certified lists for his or her State or Territory.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

48. For the next federal election the Australian Electoral Commission conduct a thorough examination of those persons added to the rolls of two marginal Divisions before the election and those persons deleted from the rolls of the same Divisions after the election. One Division shall be a Government held Division and the other an Opposition held Division.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
49. Subsections 191(1) and 191(2) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be repealed.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
50. Subsections 64(1) and 64(2) of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 be repealed.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

51. Proposed ss. 191(1), 191(2), 200H(1) and 200H(2) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and proposed ss. 64(1), 64(2), 73G(1) and 73G(2) of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 which are contained in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 not be enacted.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

52. Section 208 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the certification of certified lists by the Electoral Commissioner or an officer or officers appointed by him for that purpose.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

53. At the next federal election the Australian Electoral Commission code on the laser printed certified lists the names of those voters believed to be dead but for which no official advice has been received from the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages.

—The Government does not favour this proposal because it is highly likely to delay the availability of Certified Lists, including to candidates. Further, the proposal will only be effective if polling officials are authorised to question the voter on his or her supposed death. Such questioning would place further strain on polling officials and it is difficult to see how the supposedly dead person could be prevented from voting if he or she insisted.

54. The penalties for election offences under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be substantially increased with those penalties currently set at $1,000 or 6 months imprisonment being increased to $12,000 or imprisonment for not more than two years.

—The Government does not support this proposal at this time but does support a review of penalties for election offences, as proposed by Recommendation 55. The Attorney-General's Department will conduct such a review as soon as possible.
55. All election penalties be subject to regular review.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
56. Future audits of Divisional Offices be conducted according to the strictest audit standards.
—This recommendation has been accepted.
57. The Auditor-General revise his schedule of planned efficiency audits so that an efficiency audit of the Australian Electoral Commission may commence as soon as possible.
—This recommendation has been accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly about the Government's response to report No. 3 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I should like to point out to the Senate that this response relates to report No. 3 of the Standing Committee on the 1987 Federal election, for goodness sake. If my memory is correct—and I do not have the report with me—I believe that the report came down either late in 1989 or sometime early in 1990.

PARA.TAB: It is a disgrace that the Government has waited over two years to respond to something so fundamentally important to our democracy as the electoral process. No matter what words those opposite may mouth, this delay reflects very badly on the Government. It demonstrates the Government's attitude, its arrogance and its absolute lack of interest in the democratic process and the integrity of the voting system. Of course, the voting system is vital to a continuation of democracy of this country.

I would like to comment on a few of the recommendations because they are important, and one of them in particular has real relevance at this time. However, before I do that I note that many of these recommendations have already been incorporated in amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and I repeat that I find it extraordinary that it took two years or more for the Government to respond to this Committee.

The Committee itself is bipartisan; it is a joint committee of both the House of Representatives and the Senate. From reading the report—and when I said `bipartisan', I meant it—it is clear that there were determined efforts by the members of that Committee to improve, where possible, the voting system as a result of the 1987 election. However, there is one point that needs particular attention—in fact, it came up in an amendment to the Electoral Act last year, I believe, because I can recall debating it—and that is the attempt to define those people who hold an office of profit under the Crown.

This is a constitutional requirement and—again, if my memory is correct—we did attempt to introduce some amendments to define an office of profit under the Crown and were advised that the difficulties involved were such that definition may bring about further problems. My understanding was that the Government was going to look at it further through the Attorney-General's Department to see whether it could come up with a definition. By way of example, I cite my own situation prior to coming into this place when I was the Deputy Chairman of the Queensland Institute of Technology. That was a non-paying job but, on legal advice received at the time I was appointed to the Senate, I did not take any risk because, even though no pay was involved, it could well be classified as an office of profit under the Crown.

This question was again raised by the recent amendments to the Electoral Act. I believe that the Opposition did move for an amendment but that it was blocked because of this definitional difficulty. I may be incorrect about that; I am just speaking from memory. However, I think it is very relevant because Mr Cleary, who was recently elected as the member for Wills, is under challenge on this very matter of holding an office of profit under the Crown. I will not go further, except to say that sooner or later we will have to define it to get rid of the uncertainty.

That is the thing that concerns most people, whether they be candidates or even members—the uncertainty relating to it. The uncertainty arises because the Constitution appears to be very clear and a great deal of advice has been given to governments from both sides, but there has to be an attempt sooner or later to define this matter to get rid of the uncertainty.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the High Court.
—I guess that is where it will be determined but, whatever comes from the High Court, eventually we must arrive at a definitional position.

PARA.TAB: There were other recommendations which I believe that the Government should have accepted. One was recommendation 21:

SPEECH.PARA: The Electoral Commission and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs work in conjunction to formulate and implement a system for checking the citizenship of persons born overseas and seeking to be added to the Electoral Roll.

The Government has knocked back that recommendation because it believes that such checking could be resource intensive and `hamstrung by incomplete records'. That term is a worry. I do not really know what it means, but I think `hamstrung by incomplete records' means that the act of applying for enrolment should be a more stringent procedure.

PARA.TAB: The Government also feels that such checking would also be likely to offend the ethnic community, and would be inconsistent with the principles of the Privacy Act.I will not touch on the Privacy Act, except to say that it is my belief that once people have accepted Australian citizenship they are Australians; they are not some other race, whether it be Irish, Scottish, Greek or anything else. To talk about not doing something, which I believe to be an audit process in order to support the integrity of the electoral roll, does not make any sense and should be looked at again.

There is a great concern about declaration voting. The important thing about the voting system is to be sure of the electoral roll so that people cannot cheat during election campaigns. We always hear complaints—and I am sure that the Minister would probably receive more complaints than I do—after an election which, in the main, cannot be substantiated. They are mainly anecdotal stories about people voting more than once. The old story is to vote early and vote often.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dead people.

—There are stories of dead people voting and people registered at cemeteries. I have heard Senator Bishop talk about this in the past. My son, who helped to cleanse the electoral rolls at one time, claimed that he found 12 people enrolled on a vacant lot, which presumably was reported back to the Electoral Commissioner.
—They're all Nationals!

—Generally, when those charges are made they relate to people from the government side of politics. A recommendation was made for nomination forms to be amended to require candidates to state their membership of any registered political party and that a penalty would be incurred if a candidate failed to state his or her membership of any registered political party. The reason for that recommendation was presumably to stop the phoney candidates. We have always suspected phoney candidates in many instances, the so-called independents who run mainly for the Labor Party. In my recollection it happened recently in Queensland, which you would recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, in a by-election for a State seat—I think it was in Nundah. The incumbent Labor member ran off and was found somewhere in a motel in Lismore. As a result there was a by-election and the person who ran as a so-called independent green was considered to be a member of the Labor Party. The purpose of the recommendation was to make it clear that a person should state his party membership or suffer a penalty of $6,000.

PARA.TAB: The Government recommendation is that it does not consider that further complication of the nomination form is warranted. I understand that, if this amendment were made to the Electoral Act, it would be simple to get around. For that reason, I tend to go along with the Government because it would only need that phoney candidate to resign from the Party some time earlier and legitimately run as an independent.

Recommendation 37 is quite an extraordinary one. It states that an infringement notice system should be introduced to replace the present system of enforcement of compulsory voting. This is quite curious. It is already an amendment to the Act. I think we amended the Act last year. The recommendation means that now for the privilege of not voting people can pay $20; if people just send $20, they will not be fined.

I find this extraordinary. I know why the Electoral Commissioner has looked at it because it means that it will be easier to collect the money. Normally, come a Federal election, somewhere in the order of half a million or 600,000 people elect not to vote. This raises the whole question of sensibility in a free society of compulsory voting.

As honourable senators in this chamber will appreciate, I have in fact floated the idea of voluntary voting a number of times. The thing that has always intrigued me about it is the response from the Labor Party when this has happened. Again, I hope I am not quoting the wrong people. I am quoting from memory but, if my memory is correct, Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services, made the remark that it would disenfranchise voters. Mr Wayne Swan, the Secretary of the Labor Party in Brisbane, said that it was a sinister attack on democracy. What an extraordinary statement. Australia is the only English speaking country in the world with compulsory voting, and yet he says it is a sinister attack on democracy. I do not see countries such as New Zealand—

TALK.START.PARA: —The United Kingdom and the United States.

—Yes, Senator Bishop is correct. One can go on and on. In fact, we are the only English speaking democracy in the world with it. The reason I draw it to the chamber's attention is that one can still not vote if one does not want to: just send $20. One gets the notice, sends $20, and that is the end of it. So one pays $20 for the privilege of exercising one's right not to turn up at the polling booth. Some of the bizarre things we have in this country!

PARA.TAB: One other recommendation I would like to speak to briefly is about people who have died and vote while still on the electoral roll—a concern that is expressed after each election. There would not be an honourable member or senator who does not get this concern expressed to him or her. As I mentioned earlier, Senator Bishop has raised this issue on a number of occasions in the past. The recommendation comes from 1987 and shows the great interest of the Labor Party in the democratic process. We have had an election since this recommendation has come down. The recommendation reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the next federal election the Australian Electoral Commission code on the laser printed certified lists the names of those voters believed to be dead but for which no official advice has been received from the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages.

The argument put is that the Government does not favour this proposal because it is highly likely to delay the availability of certified lists, including to candidates. If it improves the integrity of the roll, the candidates will be delighted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our candidates.

—Our candidates will be delighted. The recommendation goes on to say that the proposal will only be effective if polling officials are authorised to question the voter on his or her supposed death. The recommendation does not talk about supposed death. It talks about `the names of those voters believed to be dead but for which no official advice has been received'. The recommendation talks about strain on polling officials and the difficulty in seeing how the supposed dead person could be prevented from voting if he or she insisted. I am sure that could be easily addressed. It would simply be a matter of getting some sort of identification at the time. Even though people say this would be some sort of invasion of privacy, when a report is in that a person who was supposedly on the roll is dead and turns up to vote, for goodness sake, there is something awfully wrong with our system if something does not exist that enables officers to check it.

PARA.TAB: Most of the recommendations have already been adopted in amendments to the Electoral Act. The reservations I raised have to be looked at in the future. I think it is an absolute disgrace that right at the end of April 1992 we are looking at the Government's response to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters for the 1987 Federal election.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion with some concern about the lateness of the annual report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The report was for the year to June 1991 and is dated 13 April 1992. I might say that the report has been expeditiously sent by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to the Parliament. The delay, according to the Chairperson of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, has been due to the need to comply with the new guidelines for financial statements for Commonwealth entities issued by the Minister for Finance in 1991. I can understand those delays. A real problem, however, is the Auditor-General's report, which dramatises expenditure relating to $194m and has brought this response from the Auditor-General:
I have been unable to determine whether all this expenditure is valid and I do not express an opinion on this item.
That is $194m of taxpayers' money. The Auditor-General says:

In Note 5 to the statements, the Commission acknowledges that due to inadequacies in its accounts and records it is unable to verify that all expenditure relating to Community Development Employment Projects ($194,101,000) has been made in respect of eligible participants resident in the relevant Community.

This obviously has been a factor in the report's delay, but I foreshadow that it is the Opposition's intention to refer this incredible situation to a relevant parliamentary committee to examine why this extraordinary situation obtains. I also mention that there are some other less significant problems: for example, Baruwei Enterprises Proprietary Ltd has not presented financial statements for the year ended June 30 1991. The Auditor-General says:

. . . its statements have not been included in the group financial statements. Therefore the consolidated financial statements do not comply with the relevant accounting standards of AAS 24 (Consolidated Financial Statements). The financial effect on the consolidated financial statements of this cannot be quantified.
The report also notes:

The audit report on Morr Morr Pastoral Company Pty Ltd was qualified because, as indicated in Note 1 (1) to the group statements, the Company did not conduct a stocktake at 30 June 1991. Accordingly, I was unable to attest the value of the livestock held at 30 June.
This qualification did not have a material effect on the group accounts as at 30 June 1991.

There is no doubt that there are real difficulties involved in accounting for this very significant program. The Government's attempts to resolve the problem have clearly not been satisfactory; they have not been satisfactorily resolved. The notes to the account say:

CDEP funding involves an obligation on the part of communities to provide regular participant schedules to the Commission. Some Communities have experienced difficulties meeting this obligation and the Commission has therefore been unable to verify that all payments to communities have been based on accurate participant schedules. To assist in overcoming this verification problem, a new administrative system, designed to enhance verification procedures, was implemented on 1 April 1991. Under the new system, CDEP grantees are required to provide the Commission with a quarterly schedule, listing all participants, four weeks before the beginning of a quarter or with a monthly scheduled two weeks before the beginning of a month. The schedule must be accompanied by a certification, signed by the chairperson of the organisation or authorised employee, stating that all of those persons whose names are listed in the schedule, are eligible to participate in the scheme. In addition, the Commission is planning to undertake a complete census of CDEP communities in 1992, and introduce new monitoring procedures aimed at further improving the level of accountability.
In view of the fact that this is such a major issue, if no-one else is speaking to this paper, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This long awaited report No. 19 from the Industry Commission into the Australian sugar industry certainly is not the answer to the sugar industry and the problems it is currently facing. As one of Queensland's senators, I believe it is very important that I speak to this report today. The report, promised in 1988, has been presented at a time when many sugar growers are facing virtual bankruptcy due to this Government's unfair and discriminatory taxes and legislation.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the report does not provide any hope for those in the sugar industry, as it seeks to abolish tariffs without providing any truly adequate assistance measures. I have always believed that it is no good reducing tariffs if the Government does not provide reasonable and fair assistance to the growers in other ways. Tariff cuts without reforms in industrial relations and the waterfront and reductions in fuel excise and tax, such as those proposed in the coalition's Fightback package, will only reduce sugar growers to peasants.

During the recess I had the opportunity to spend a week in north Queensland travelling around, meeting many groups and individuals and hearing personally of their current problems. I was told again and again of the struggle many people in rural areas are facing. Those in the sugar industry talked of the problems they face because they have had to battle with reduced production as a result of droughts and floods which cost them $300m last year. In addition, they have had to battle with accelerated tariff cuts which cost the industry $16m last year and will cost a further $14m this year. There has been a third reduction in this year's US quota to 109,671 tonnes and this means a loss of $18m. This is far below the 800,000 tonnes exported to the United States prior to the introduction of the quota in 1981. In addition, the growers have suffered from depressed world prices because of subsidies and overproduction.

As a result, the industry is experiencing its worst season since 1979, with 1991 returns reduced by 25 per cent despite record expansion. This is evidenced by the fact that 48,000 hectares of expansion has not been taken up. Most growers are in their second or third years of negative income and they are suffering from increasing input costs and low production and returns as a result of droughts and floods.

Furthermore, sugar growers are forced to operate on corrupted world markets. They are expected to compete with the treasuries of the United States and the European Community. Government intervention and volatile world prices are the central characteristics of the world sugar market. All other sugar producing countries have one or more forms of support, such as guaranteed cane prices, domestic prices, quotas or import bans.

Japan, the EC and the United States cause the major distortions on the world sugar market. The tariff situation in Japan is a tariff equivalent of 360.43 per cent. In the European Community it is 170 per cent and in the United States it is 102 per cent. In the EC there is a guaranteed price of $551 per tonne or 26c a pound. In the US the guaranteed price is $357 per tonne or 23c a pound and in Thailand it is $447 per tonne or 20c a pound.

I was amazed to learn on a recent trip to Maryborough that currently this Government is, as part of its overseas aid program, providing assistance for Australia to build a sugar mill for Thailand. The sugar mill to be sent to Thailand will be paid for by our taxes, including the taxes of sugar growers, and that country will then subsidise its sugar producers at the rate of $447 per tonne. That mill will be used to encourage the growth of an industry which in turn will result in putting Australians out of work. How ridiculous can we get! How ridiculous it is to place our faith in blind, crass economic theories!

It is no good saying to the sugar industry that, because we are on the altar of free trade, because we want to be able to hold our hands on our hearts and say to the Europeans, the Americans and the Japanese that we are acting as we believe they should act, we will be in a better position to ensure that they do so. Unfortunately, we are placing a number of our major industries in a position where there will be even more unemployment. We will find that imports will take over the sugar industry's market share. These are some of the problems that are being experienced by the sugar industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission inquiry was promised when tariffs were introduced in 1988, following the lifting of the embargo. However, last year the Government broke its agreement and reduced tariffs below the agreed schedule. This resulted in an immediate loss of $16m to the sugar industry and changed the certainty on which the industry was basing its future decisions and investments.

PARA.TAB: The final report of this Industry Commission recommends the end of production and marketing controls in Queensland and the privatisation of the bulk sugar terminals. These are all areas which fall within Queensland State Government responsibility. It also recommends the abolition of tariffs or their replacement by a one-off payment to the industry once compulsory acquisition ceases.
As President Eisenhower once said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's easy to know all about farming when you're not standing behind the plough.
It would not hurt a few of these people who produce these reports to get out behind the plough.

TALK.START.PARA: —In front of it!

—Well, even in front of it. That is what the IC report is all about. It is all very well for the Commission to predict the economic benefits of deregulation. The Commission concludes—although admitting that it cannot forecast possible benefits—that it sees that a 30 per cent expansion would result in a $375m increase a year.

PARA.TAB: In reality, following the total reorganisation of the industry two years ago, expansion now takes place at an annual rate of 2.5 per cent. This is something the Commission makes no acknowledgment of. Presently, 48,000 hectares of land that is available for cane growing under the present system has not been taken up by anyone, either established growers or newcomers to the industry. Expansion involves major investment, which is a recipe to go broke at the present time when high interest rates of the Labor Government have deterred investment. The industry is exposed to corrupt world prices which are below the cost of production.

In spite of the Commission's perception, the industry has worked enormously hard to increase efficiencies to wear the tag of one of the most efficient and low cost producers in the world. It has adopted such initiatives as bulk handling, efficient marketing systems and industry owned and financed transport systems. It is a world leader in technology and research. Efficient new industrial practices, such as continuous crushing, and environmentally advanced methods of green harvesting and trash blanketing have been adopted by growers and millers alike. There are many towns right along the coast of Queensland and northern New South Wales which are supported and sustained by the sugar industry, as are many manufacturing industries and world class sugar research institutes.

The report recommends abolishing compulsory acquisition so as to promote competition among the sellers and reduce the price of raw sugar to around export parity prices. In spite of the efficiencies achieved by single desk selling in holding premium markets, ensuring quality and guaranteed supplies—with all the world's export markets consisting of single desk buyers—there is also the question of what export parity price really is. Export parity price is set by the 20 per cent residue of other producers—that is, producers from such places as the EC and Thailand—with every one of them subsidising its producers.

The report acknowledges that the EC common sugar policy enabled the EC to go from a net importer to the world's second largest exporter. Intervention prices of 39c a pound currently exist, while the world price is 9.5c a pound. Export subsidies are given from the EC budget. In the US the quota is solely aimed at supporting the US producer at around 23c a pound. In Thailand, our least protected competitor, the Government sets the domestic price, bans imports and controls exports.

The IC wants to destroy our industry by exposing it to world export prices which are based on subsidies and not on the cost of production. I believe that Mr Crean has said that he will not be driven by the IC report. I hope he honours that commitment to the Queensland and New South Wales sugarcane industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Senate to guess what the Government's shock troop—the Industry Commission—has reported in its report on sugar. As we would anticipate, it has reported that all existing tariff protection on sugar should be removed by 1998. All of the other reports put out by the Industry Commission, with the exception of the one on the car industry, came to the same conclusion—that all protection should be dismantled and all regulation should be dispensed with. The only reason that the car industry was spared from a zero tariff regime by the year 2000 was that the original draft report of the Commission, which recommended 15 per cent by 1996, was doctored at the behest of the Government. So, there is one precedent.

PARA.TAB: By 1998 there will be no tariffs on sugar nor will there be a guaranteed market for the sugar growers. However, this is supposed to stimulate activity and employment in the processed food, confectionery and beverage industries. We can be certain, can we not, that these industries will pass their savings on to all the rest of us?

Where is the evidence for this contention of stimulating activity and employment? There is an economic model which tells us. This is the Orani food model which was used in these calculations after making the heroic assumptions that, because of tariff phase-outs, there will be a 30 per cent increase in land under sugar cultivation and a 9 per cent reduction in on-farm costs. As the report states at page 151, if there is no reduction in farm costs there will not be any economy-wide gains. But, as the previous speakers have said, why would farmers expand their sugar output by acquiring more land when the price they receive on the domestic market will be reduced by about $76 per tonne from the current level? We are going to say to them, `Go out and produce more but you will get less for it'. It just does not make sense.

The Democrats are very wary of gains supposedly proven by models. This provides another example of the sometimes ludicrous results which a simple mathematical representation of complex relationships sometimes yields. The same model predicts that the mining sector will actually contract by 1.6 per cent if deregulation goes ahead.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter in today's Australian from Agnes Pini of Proserpine in Queensland entitled, `Saving the small cane farmer'.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter read as follows:

PARA.TAB: Tim Duncan's article on protectionism in The Weekend Australian (25-26/4) misrepresents the sugar industry. This industry is unique and complex in its structure, and it cannot be written off in two paragraphs.

Briefly, it is neither pure capitalism nor pure socialism, but a mixture of both. Initially, it was structured by caring Labor governments in the early part of this century, long before there was a National Party. Ironically, then issues of both defence and immigration were of concern. Initiatives were needed to populate North Queensland as the majority of people preferred to live in Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne, and it was feared that an empty north would invite invasion. The sugar industry was initially structured on the plantation principle, and these were owned by overseas landlords.

These plantations were cut up into family sized farms, and as an incentive, a guarantee was given for the purchase of a certain amount of cane from each farm each year. This amount eventually became the peak, and a basic peak could keep a family as in a basic wage. The milling of cane was controlled in that cane lands were assigned to specific mills, and that became known as assignment. Cane could be grown only on assigned land.

Initially, therefore, the regulations were there for valid reasons. Both peak and assignment were negotiable. Over the years, farmers have had to buy into the industry. It was a free market. Anyone with the necessary finance could buy a cane farm. The regulating authorities had power, and at times abused this power by being petty about decisions.

The technology used by the sugar industry is the best in the world. It has been developed here and has been given or sold to just about every sugar producing country. Queensland farmers are technologically competitive, but they cannot compete with Third World wages and the subsidised American and European markets.

The Industry Commission report was commissioned by the CSR Company, which has a vested interest in the industry, both here and overseas. It owns four mills in the Burdekin district. Large tracts of land in the area have become suitable for cane growing with the completion of the Burdekin Dam. Is there a possible connection between the development of this new land as large cane farms, and the CSR lobby for tariff reduction? When new policy is being lobbied by a particular group, the question to ask is—what is in it for them?

We have been told that the future of the industry (without tariffs) will be large corporate plantations such as this. We will have come a full circle. The little Australian will have lost another battle. The small farmer will go and small towns may die. Multinational companies may run a sugar industry without protection, but how will that help the Australian economy if the profits are siphoned overseas?

Cane farming is hard work, but it is a lifestyle. You are working for yourself, and the successful farmers are the hard workers. Many farmers' sons are opting out of the industry because they want a softer life—Dad works too hard—or because they see no future in the industry. Farmers who have invested in peak and assignment have had the value wiped from them with deregulation.
