A huge slice of Queensland's economy is built on and around the sugar industry. Thousands of jobs are at stake. Could Tim Duncan visit both Proserpine and the Burdekin district to talk to farmers, and then write the real story?

SPEECH.PARA: AGNES PINI
Proserpine, Qld.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I draw attention to a small section from that letter. Agnes Pini says:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told that the future of the industry (without tariffs) will be large corporate plantations such as this. We will have come a full circle. The little Australian will have lost another battle. The small farmer will go and small towns may die. Multinational companies may run a sugar industry without protection, but how will that help the Australian economy if the profits are siphoned overseas?
Cane farming is hard work, but it is a lifestyle. . .
A huge slice of Queensland's economy is built on and around the sugar industry.
Her view is that people need to get the real story.

PARA.TAB: I would argue that the real agenda of the Industry Commission is to wipe out the family farmer and allow the big corporate farms to take over the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the Industry Commission's report on the Australian sugar industry. Previous speakers have indicated that this report is in some way or another fatally flawed. Senator Boswell said—and he would know better than I, he coming from Queensland and I from Victoria—that apparently there are 48,000 hectares of land currently available to be farmed for sugar or on which sugarcane could be grown but which is not being taken up because it is currently being grown at a loss.

PARA.TAB: This report says that, although there are many things which ought to be done in relation to the world market:

SPEECH.PARA: One factor which is clearly subject to the influence of governments in Australia is the regulatory controls imposed on the Queensland industry. This is the most significant factor impeding the achievement of higher levels of efficiency.

That is a very interesting comment. Then it goes on to say that if the report were adopted, there would be a substantial increase in the quantity of land in Australia which was being farmed for sugar. That is quite the opposite of what Senator Boswell and other speakers have suggested. The Commission also says that one of the consequences of its report would be that:
One study estimated that economy-wide employment would increase by at least 3,000 if the size of the industry was not constrained by regulation.

It goes on to talk about the possibility of the area of land under cane expanding by 30 per cent. That then leads to the suggested increase in the value of output and exports by around $375m annually.

PARA.TAB: I say to the Australian sugar industry that if this report is fatally flawed, then it is for the industry to let us know in detail in what way it is flawed. It is not a question of the raising of motions and it is not a question of telling us how overseas growers are assisted by their governments. I understand that that might be relevant from their point of view, but that does not deal with the fundamental issue here, which is that this Industry Commission is saying, `If you were to take away these constraints, this would be the result'.

It is no good talking to me about what is happening in Thailand or in any other areas in relation to this particular argument. I say to the Queensland sugar industry that we, who are not participants in that industry or not members of parliament representing those areas, rely on reports such as these and upon the industry's response to such reports to enable us to make up our minds.

For example—and this occurred at a time when I was responsible for industry for the Opposition—ICI was confronted with a reduction in its tariff protection from 5 per cent—it was only 5 per cent—down to zero over a period of five years. ICI was horrified as to what the consequences would be, so it settled down to decide how it could solve that problem within the industry. That organisation has made itself into a magnificent company—so good that even Mr Keating, on page 50 of his One Nation statement, got around to quoting the results that ICI is producing at Botany. ICI did that because of the reduction in tariff protection. It forced that company to address its problems and those of the industry.

That is what the Industry Commission is saying to the sugar industry in Australia. It is asking it to please address the problems. If these problems can be overcome, then we should overcome them. The Industry Commission puts one proposition; maybe the sugar industry will put another. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this debate on the Industry Commission report on sugar. However, after hearing some of the suggestions, particularly from members of the National Party, I feel compelled to enter the debate. I would remind people that this is a report from the Industry Commission and that it is not a government report. However, it is one to which the Government will respond at a later date. I think it is important that honourable senators read and note what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) said in the other place:

SPEECH.PARA: What I have to say in relation to sugar is this. Whilst we will have regard to the Industry Commission report, we will not be driven by it. We will consult with the industry about the appropriate form of assistance and the means by which we can expand what is already an efficient industry. We do not want to wipe the industry out. We want it to grow.

He then went on to outline how he will facilitate this consultation by setting up meetings with all sections involved in the industry, which of course is not just canefarmers and millers. It is also those who have to use the product at the end of its manufacture.

PARA.TAB: The Minister will be setting up meetings of those involved in the industry under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Hinkler, Brian Courtice, to work at arriving at a solution and decisions as to which way the sugar industry will be going. It is what we have done with the dairy industry. But it is very important that, if we wish to change things within a particular industry, we must consult with those involved in it—and this is what is going to happen in this place.

It is very important, therefore, for people not to run around the countryside saying that it is government policy because it is in the Industry Commission report. The recommendations of the Industry Commission as it is now, the Industries Assistance Commission as it was, have been rejected wholeheartedly and totally on many occasions. I am not too sure whether any honourable senator could name me any Industry Commission or Industry Assistance Commission report in which all the recommendations were accepted by government. I doubt that it has ever happened.

That is why it is important for people to realise that we are reading the Industry Commission's report and we will be discussing it with the sugar industry. People should be bringing this report to the attention of the industry—I think we are fairly well aware of it because of all of the publicity—and discussing it with the industry. The industry should work out its future direction. It is the best way to get compliance; it is the best way for the people who know the industry to work out which way to go, to make themselves more competitive, more profitable and to give themselves a better lifestyle.

I cannot reiterate strongly enough that there has been a lot of hot air expended on this issue but not a great deal of light in comparison to the amount of heat that has been generated. This is a report of the Industry Commission; it is not government policy. The Government will be consulting with all sectors of the industry in the formulation of the Government response.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the note on Austudy in the National Report on Schooling in Australia by the Australian Education Council. The report states:

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that during the 1982-83 economic recession, retention rates to Year 12 remained relatively static. Since retention rates have risen significantly during the current recession, this suggests that the availability of AUSTUDY may have had a positive impact on the number of students continuing on at school.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt about that; it is a recognition of what has happened. In many instances Austudy has become an alternative to the dole. Young people who are unemployed are quite rightly being encouraged to go back to school.

PARA.TAB: The fact remains that the Australian Bureau of Statistics youth unemployment figures are much lower and do not fully reflect the real unemployment level for the reason that this report outlines. Austudy is being used in this recession as a way of hiding the true level of youth unemployment, which is horrific enough. One in three of the young people aged between 15 and 19 wanting a full time job are unable to find one; one in four of those who are prepared to put up with part-time jobs are unable to find one.

There is no doubt that Austudy is a great help to people with lower socio-economic backgrounds. In a recent survey of 1,800 parents, one third considered that they would be unable to send their children to school if they were not receiving Austudy. This dramatises the fact that young people from low socio-economic backgrounds are being hit hardest by this recession that we had to have. Instead of being on unemployment benefits, they are not shown as being unemployed because they are accepting Austudy and going back, hopefully, to increase their job options as a result of increasing their skill levels.
There are many more things that should be said about this report, and I look forward to doing so. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 28 of 1991-92, Project Audit, Australian Taxation Office, Prescribed Payments System.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report—the Auditor-General's audit report No. 28, Project Audit, Australian Taxation Office, Prescribed Payments System—was in response to recommendation 38 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the reform of the Australian Audit Office. That recommendation stated that the Auditor-General should devote significant resources to follow up performance audits and adopt a systematic approach to such findings. There was a performance audit of the Tax Office in September 1986.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, Senator Watson and Senator Bishop, who are both on the Public Accounts Committee and who had hoped to participate in this debate, are obliged to attend a meeting of the Public Accounts Committee this afternoon. That dramatises how totally unsatisfactory it is that we have committees of this Parliament proceeding at a time when important matters such as this are before the chamber for debate. It is a ludicrous situation. On behalf of those two senators, I protest at what has happened.

I do not wish to speak at great length on this report; I am sure that Senator Short will consider making some sort of contribution to the debate. He is certainly much better qualified to do so than I am. I am speaking because neither Senator Bishop nor Senator Watson can participate in this debate because of a totally unsatisfactory situation.

Senator Watson has every right to participate in this debate. At a recent Estimates committee hearing he raised some matters about the way in which the Australian Taxation Office was handling the prescribed payments system. An officer of the ATO, Mr Highfield, in a quite disparaging way, suggested to Senator Watson that he had a lot of misconceptions. In an answer to Senator Watson, Mr Highfield said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this also relates to a number of other misconceptions that seem to be reflected in other questions that you have raised.
The Auditor-General has a very good response to Mr Highfield on Senator Watson's behalf. There are no misconceptions.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the recommendations that the Australian National Audit Office has made about this. The audit objectives were to review progress with the implementation of the recommendations of the efficiency audit; the audit also assessed the current management systems and administration of the prescribed payment system; and a major focus of the audit was on Australian Taxation Office enforcement activity. One of the findings states:

SPEECH.PARA: Payer enforcement reports highlighted credit and debit discrepancies, failure to remit cases and payers under-deducting the correct rate of tax. The reports are supplemented by audit activity which currently focuses mainly on failure to deduct cases.
Another of the findings states:

The Australian National Audit Office considered that there was a strong need to develop national and more effective payer enforcement strategies. This would require increased audit activity, modifications to the computer system and the enhancement of various reports.
Yet another of the findings states:

The PPS database was recording a large number of cases as unidentified creditors. The value of these creditors was $129m for the 1990 income tax year. These records represent tax credits with invalid or mis-keyed tax file numbers. The ANAO considered that the ATO should attempt to reduce this balance by identifying and actioning high value cases.

PARA.TAB: I will briefly go through the key findings of the report. Recommendation 8 of the efficiency audit, on which this report is based, was mainly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to implement stronger inspection activity to enforce PPS requirements . . .
The Auditor-General established that recommendation 8 had not been fully implemented. The report states:

Although the ATO reported increased inspection activity in 1988, the ANAO considered audit inspection activity was low during 1989 and 1990 and recommended that the audit coverage of PPS payers be increased. The ATO considered, however, that the efficiency audit recommendation had been implemented through the refinement of enforcement strategies and that present PPS audit coverage was properly balanced to maximise coverage across all revenue lines.

PARA.TAB: Another finding was that although a range of PPS management information was available, there was no automated facility for the evaluation of PPS processing activities against performance standards. Other findings include: a need to develop national and more effective PPS payer enforcement strategies; income matching checks on PPS payees could be enhanced by implementing national case selection standards; nationally promulgated procedures had not been issued for key PPS processing activities; and there were inconsistent practices between branch offices in the use of PPS generated information.

The National Audit Office has made a series of recommendations which, if implemented, it believes should enhance the performance of the prescribed payments system and lead to the identification of additional taxation revenue. As I say, that is a very brief comment on the key findings. Senator Watson in particular asked me to commend the Audit Office for proceeding with this follow-up report arising out of its efficiency audit. I commend the Audit Office's recommendations to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the things that I wished to say have already been said by my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume. I will not go over the same points. I just confirm and reaffirm my support for his comments on the recommendations in the Auditor-General's audit report No. 28 of 1991-92, particularly on recommendation 8 of the original efficiency report. That was a very important recommendation to implement stronger inspection activity to enforce PPS requirements. The fact that that has not been fully implemented has important consequences. I welcome this project audit conducted by the Auditor-General into the implementation of the recommendations of the 1986 efficiency report, and this report's recommendation to ensure that those 1986 recommendations are implemented.

PARA.TAB: Given that I will not go over all the detail that Senator Baume covered, the main point I want to stress yet again in this place is the essential role of the Australian National Audit Office in providing an independent and highly professional evaluation of the performance of government functions. There can be no more important a function or responsibility of government than to correctly and properly handle the finances of the nation, because they are not the finances of governments but of each and every Australian taxpayer.

I regret to say that as a result of the gross mismanagement in many instances by the Government of its finances, there have been increasingly numerous examples over recent years of the Audit Office finding deficiencies in properly caring for and utilising the moneys that the Commonwealth has entrusted to it. For that reason, I continually commend the Audit Office for its work, and also for that reason, I yet again condemn the Government for the inordinate delay it has introduced in the implementation of the major rewrite of the audit legislation that it undertook several years ago, and which was supposed to be in operation on 1 July this year.

The draft legislation has not even been introduced into this Parliament. I do not know whether it will be introduced this session so that we can have a look at it over the recess with a view to its possible implementation in the Budget session. I recall from our discussion with Senator McMullan and officials in the Estimates Committee hearings recently that even that timetable has slipped. So the prospect of getting proper revised audit legislation in being before 1 July 1993 has now become almost impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's diminishing its capacity to operate.

—Absolutely. As Senator Baume says, the uncertainty and confusion that is resulting from this delay is having a very deleterious effect on the efficiency of the Audit Office. I believe that it is a matter not just for condemnation of the Government but also of very real concern that taxpayers' money, which amounts to tens of billions of dollars each year, is not being properly administered. When it is not being properly administered, the Audit Office—the Government's own auditor, the nation's auditor, the taxpayers' auditor—is not being placed in a proper position to make the necessary audit scrutiny. That is a matter of very serious concern.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Opposition, I repeat the plea to the Government to get on with the job of drafting and introducing this legislation to revise the audit legislation. It is major legislation and serves a major function. Amongst other things, it provides the very mandate under which the Auditor-General operates in our nation. These further continuing delays put at very grave risk the proper financing and administration of the finances of this nation.

I join Senator Baume in commending the Audit Office on both its work and this report. I hope that the Australian Taxation Office will take fully on board the recommendations of this project audit and fully implement the recommendations that, quite frankly, should have been implemented some considerable time ago.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Schacht, I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ACIAR
TABLING SPEECH
THURSDAY 30 APRIL 1992
Senator Chris Schacht—Chairman
The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade examined the effectiveness of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (known as ACIAR).
Specifically the Committee looked at:

PARA.TAB: a. the effectiveness of ACIAR as an element of Australia's official development assistance program against its charter embodied in the ACIAR Act 1982;

b. the desirability or otherwise of the continued existence of the Centre as a Statutory Authority after the expiration of twelve years of operations (June 1994), the maximum length of existence specified in the current Act.

SPEECH.PARA: While Australia has extensive expertise in agricultural research, it was not until the creation of ACIAR in 1982 that that expertise was effectively applied to developing countries' agricultural problems. The Centre was established by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act 1982 as a statutory authority within the foreign affairs and trade portfolio. The legislation contained a sunset clause, disbanding the Centre after 12 years unless its continuation was recommended by a new Act.

What was a surprise to the Committee was that ACIAR is a `good news' story. Outside the field of those involved in agricultural research, the work of ACIAR is almost completely unknown. Its work has great benefit and should be more widely publicised. Furthermore, the high-level of ACIAR's performance sets an example for other statutory bodies to try to match.
The Committee has made 21 recommendations covering the areas of:

PARA.TAB: Management and organisation;
ACIAR's research program;
Funding;
Relations with other organisations;
ACIAR in the future;
Extending ACIAR's mandate; and
Public awareness.

SPEECH.PARA: The first two recommendations cover management and organisation. The Centre has two governing bodies, a Policy Advisory Council and a Board of Management. The Policy Advisory Council provides advice to the Minister regarding:
agricultural problems of developing countries; and
programs and policies with respect to agricultural research for either or both of the following purposes,
(i) identifying agricultural problems of developing countries; and
(ii) finding solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries.

Membership of the Council currently consists of a President, the Director of the Centre, the person for the time being occupying, or performing the duties of, the Director-General of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, and not fewer than 12 nor more than 16 other members.

The Board of Management of the Centre is responsible for the conduct and control of the affairs of the Centre. It consists of the President of the Council, the Director of the Centre, the person for the time being occupying, or performing the duties of, the Director-General of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, and 3 other members appointed by the Governor-General from among the members of the Council.

The Committee believes there is scope for a reduction in the membership of the Policy Advisory Council and that the membership of Australians and non-Australians should be equal. Furthermore, the Committee believes there should be some degree of flexibility in AIDAB representation on both bodies. To this end Recommendation 1 covers an amendment to section 8(1)(c) of the ACIAR Act dealing with AIDAB representation on the ACIAR Board of Management and Recommendation 2 recommends an amendment to section 19 dealing with the membership of the Policy Advisory Council including AIDAB representation. The size of the Council is to be reduced to 12 and half the Council members are to be residents of countries other than Australia.

The Committee, in its 3rd recommendation, recommends that the quorum requirement for a meeting of the Policy Advisory Committee be reduced from 9 to 7 and that the President have a deliberative and casting vote.

With regard to ACIAR's research program the Committee has made 4 recommendations. The Committee supports ACIAR's primary focus on South East Asia and the South Pacific. However, the Committee recommends that as funding permits, ACIAR should foster collaborative projects of mutual importance to other parts of the world, including Africa, the Middle East and South America. North Africa and the Middle East, in particular, should be a priority because of Australia's expertise in dryland farming.

It is important for ACIAR and its contracted organisations to have some flexibility in determining the length of stay of Australian scientists in-country. The Committee recommends that ACIAR in conjunction with its commissioned organisations and partner institutions continue to evaluate the length of stay of Australian scientists in-country on a project by project basis.

Although ACIAR's research program activities have been successful, improvement is still possible in several areas. Project length is currently 3 years, but in some cases this has not been sufficient. The Committee recommends that ACIAR be more flexible in determining project length, allowing projects to be approved on a case by case basis for periods of between 3 to 5 years.

There have been some difficulties in the past relations between ACIAR research program co-ordinators and Australian scientists in the commissioned organisations. While most problems could be described as personality driven, rather than institutional, the Committee sees merit in ACIAR setting out clear guidelines governing the relationship between ACIAR and the commissioned Australian research institutions, and detailing the relevant responsibilities of each position.

The Committee looked closely at the question of the economic returns to the partner countries from the annual expenditure by ACIAR of $17-18 million per year. The figures, which ACIAR provided the Committee, based on an economic assessment of the costs and returns of 12 research projects are very impressive. Based on these 12 research projects alone, ACIAR claims that for a total research cost of $27.4 million (1990 dollars) the expected benefits over the next 15-20 years would be $816.7 million (1990 dollars).

The Committee was rigorous in its questioning of the basis of the cost benefit analysis, but even with a sizeable error factor built in, the Committee acknowledges that the outcome of ACIAR's research to date has, at the very least, proved cost efficient, unlike a number of projects undertaken under the general aid program.

With regard to funding the Committee has made 3 recommendations. The Committee was satisfied that the financial operations and measures, to ensure accountability, were sufficiently rigorous to ensure that the disposal of its funds were in keeping with the objectives for which they were appropriated. The Committee noted the Auditor-General's concerns over the question of financial delegations, and the related issues of payments into the Trust Fund and the types of financial statements required at present. The Committee recommends amendment to the ACIAR Act as a matter of urgency to rectify these technical problems.

Given the success of ACIAR's work and the fact that funding levels have remained in the range of 1.3 to 1.48 per cent of total official development assistance, the Committee believes there is room for a significant increase in the budget allocation for ACIAR. The Committee therefore recommends that ACIAR's priority within the aid budget be increased, and that by 1997 approximately 3.5 per cent of the aid budget should be allocated to ACIAR.

ACIAR does not meet the full cost of some of its activities for the Australian commissioned organisations. The Committee agrees that there needs to be clear guidelines established, detailing what will and will not be funded by ACIAR and therefore recommends that the ACIAR Board of Management formalise and issue a policy on the matter of overheads and cost recovery for the information and guidance of Australian collaborative institutions.

The relationship with ACIAR and AIDAB is long standing and extensive and appears to be of mutual benefit. Similarly, relations between ACIAR and its commissioned organisations and their partner institutions are generally productive.

Although Australia contributes to the core funding of International Agricultural Research Centres, there has been a significant decline in our contributions since 1986 and the current allocation of $7.4 million is equivalent to approximately one half of one per cent of the total aid budget. These contributions are administered by AIDAB, but ACIAR has a close working relationship with these Centres. The Committee makes two recommendations on relations with other organisations:
First, that funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres, together with the resources needed to administer these funds, be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR; and

Second, the Committee further recommends that the funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres is to be additional to the increase in ACIAR core funding recommended earlier (in Recommendation 9); and that the level of International Agricultural Research Centre core funding be increased to 1.5 per cent of total official development assistance over 5 years.

Under its Terms of Reference the Committee was charged to examine `the desirability or otherwise of the continued existence of the Centre as a Statutory Authority after the expiration of twelve years of operations (June 1994), the maximum length of existence specified in the current Act'.
The Committee was unanimous in its opinion that ACIAR should continue and that it should retain its statutory authority status within the foreign affairs and trade portfolio.

While sympathetic to ACIAR's wish to have the uncertainties of the sunset clause removed, there was a strongly held view on the Committee that the existence of a sunset clause had distinct advantages. Indeed, the Committee is of the view that greater use should be made of sunset clauses to review the performance of all statutory bodies. The role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities should be the subject of examination and the Committee recommends that the appropriate Parliamentary Committee inquire into the role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities.
As other statutory authorities do not have sunset clauses, ACIAR argued that it could see no reason why it should be treated in a totally different way to any other statutory body created.

There was a strong belief on the Committee that there was considerable benefit in retaining the sunset clause as it kept the organisation at a high level of performance with the achievement of excellent results. On equity grounds the Committee does not recommend the imposition of a further sunset clause on ACIAR. However, to ensure the continued strong performance of the organisation, the Committee does recommend that the new Act to continue ACIAR include a fundamental review, every 5 years, of ACIAR's Terms of Reference including the continued existence of the organisation; and that the review of ACIAR be carried out by a Parliamentary Committee as this will assist in achieving greater public awareness of the value of ACIAR's work; and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is the appropriate body to conduct such a review.

The mandate of the Centre is closely defined, with functions such as training and extension programs precluded from its activities. The Committee has made four recommendations which are in essence an extension of ACIAR's charter. On the training side, the Committee recommends that the ACIAR Act be revised to allow ACIAR to conduct project-related training (both informal and post-graduate); and that responsibility for the administration of ACIAR's training scheme together with the concomitant resources, be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR.

With regard to the utilisation of research results the Committee recommends that AIDAB establish a Technical Advisory Committee with the task of monitoring ACIAR research projects to enable earlier identification of results that could be developed through the AIDAB program. The Technical Advisory Committee should be chaired by the Director, Country Programs, AIDAB and should include representatives from ACIAR as well as AIDAB.

However, the Committee was conscious that there will be times when valuable research results will not be taken up by AIDAB in projects. Therefore, the Committee recommends that, when AIDAB has declined to conduct a follow up project utilising ACIAR research results, ACIAR should have the option of extending the post-project phase to include a small pilot program, with Board of Management approval.

It was put to the Committee that the charter should be expanded to allow ACIAR to become involved in extending research and development assistance in non-agricultural sectors. The Committee does not agree that ACIAR is the most appropriate body to conduct this and recommends that the Australian Government examine the possibility of establishing an organisation along the same lines as ACIAR with the purpose of providing research and development assistance to regional countries in manufacturing systems, human resource development, etc.
ACIAR has to be one of the best kept secrets. As mentioned the work of ACIAR is almost completely unknown outside the field of those involved in agricultural research.

The first press article I have seen reporting ACIAR's work was published in The Australian on Tuesday 21 April 1992. The article reports on the work of Dr Philip Larkin and Dr Phillip Banks of the CSIRO Division of Plant Industry on the use of biotechnology to provide resistance in wheat to barley yellow dwarf virus. The project to find wheat plants resistant to barley yellow dwarf virus was done in collaboration with colleagues at the Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences. The benefit of this work is that all wheat-growing countries stand to gain from this unique research that will for the first time permit control of this universally serious virus.

The Committee's final recommendation addresses the lack of public awareness and recommends that ACIAR consult with AIDAB on ways to increase public awareness of the importance and achievements of ACIAR's work in solving major agricultural problems.
Mr President, the Committee found the ACIAR inquiry to be a positive one because the Centre is such a `good news' story. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I table a report on a visit by the Defence Subcommittee to Nurrungar-Woomera and Northern Territory. I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement and to move a motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT ON THE VISIT OF THE DEFENCE SUB-COMMITTEE OF THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE TO NURRUNGAR-WOOMERA AND NORTHERN TERRITORY, OCTOBER 1991

Mr President, the Defence Sub-Committee has a long tradition of inspecting Defence establishments and units across Australia. In line with this tradition, last October the Defence Sub-Committee inspected the Joint Defence Facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap and several Defence establishments in the Northern Territory.

The decision by the Defence Sub-Committee to visit northern Australia reflects the recent focus of defence planners on the north. In August the Sub-Committee conducted the first phase of its inspections of northern defence establishments when it visited north Queensland and the Torres Strait. This report describes the second phase of the Sub-Committee's inspections in the north.

This visit coincided with the final stages of the Sub-Committee's inquiry into Australian Defence Force Reserves. The inquiry benefited from the opportunity for the Sub-Committee to inspect the Reserve force, NORFORCE, which is one of three RFSUs (Regional Force Surveillance Units) located in Northern Australia. NORFORCE was raised on 1 July 1981 to provide a tactical ground surveillance capability of the Top End. It is unique among Army Reserve units because it is on 28 days notice to move for operations.

The Sub-Committee inspected soldiers of the Darwin Squadron, NORFORCE, based on Melville and Bathurst Islands. Members were impressed by both the high calibre of the Reserve soldiers and the high standard of the unit. The inspections of NORFORCE resulted in Members of the Sub-Committee gaining a wider appreciation of Reserve operations in the difficult conditions of the north.

The visit to the Northern Territory provided opportunities for the Sub-Committee to inspect RAAF Bases Tindal and Darwin. We were briefed on the respective roles of these two bases. Some concern was expressed to the Sub-Committee that some projects had been delayed as a result of uncertainty about the future of RAAF Base Darwin in light of the role ascribed to Tindal. The view was put to the Sub-Committee that RAAF Base Darwin can only be defended from Darwin—this cannot effectively be done from Tindal.

The Sub-Committee was made aware that some concerns are held, firstly, about the impact of civilianisation in the particular situation of the Darwin base being located in a cyclone and, secondly, about the impact of DRSR (Defence Regional Support Review) on operational readiness at Darwin.

Given the expansion of the Defence presence in northern Australia, the Sub-Committee was briefed on recent developments in the north by the Commander Northern Command, Brigadier Frank Hickling. We were told about the impact of the Force Structure Review on the northern area with respect to the continuing build-up of defence strength, particularly through the relocation of 2 Cavalry Regiment.

The briefing given by the Naval Officer Commanding Northern Australia, Captain Tim Lewis, complemented the briefings on surveillance of the northern coastline provided during the Sub-Committee's earlier trip to north Queensland. The Sub-Committee gained an appreciation of some of the difficulties encountered in patrolling northern waters and the ease with which fishing boats could be successfully camouflaged in the mangroves of estuarine waters was clearly demonstrated to us.

The Sub-Committee's itinerary included the Joint Facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap. While Members appreciated the opportunity to see facilities at first-hand, it should be noted that the Sub-Committee received an unclassified briefing.

The Sub-Committee was very concerned to find that publicly available printed knowledge of the Joint Facilities exceeded the information which was made available to the Sub-Committee during the briefing. Indeed, the Sub-Committee noted that information appearing on the Congressional Record in the United States is not officially made available to Australian Members of Parliament.

At Nurrungar, the Sub-Committee was told that there has been a significant change made to the position of the Deputy Commander, who is the Government of Australia Representative—the Deputy Commander is now fully briefed and therefore in a position to take over fully the Joint Defence Facility Nurrungar. The Sub-Committee observed, however, that the change in the position of the Government of Australia Representative was not reflected in the relationship which exists between the Minister and the media with respect to public disclosure of information. Information publicly available in Australia does not parallel that which is publicly available in the United States.

Nonetheless, the Sub-Committee is appreciative of the efforts made by all concerned in the arrangements for the inspections and for the opportunities provided for informal discussions. Members are also grateful to the Minister for Defence for making available the special purpose aircraft to the Sub-Committee.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the elements in the tabling statement expresses the unanimous concern of the members of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade at the level of the briefings available to them at the joint defence facilities. Quite bluntly, we heard nothing there that was not available from the popular press. In contrast, United States senators and members of similar committees apparently have available to them far deeper briefings. Certainly, the publications of their committees in the US Congress are a very valuable source of detailed, technical information. These reports often form the basis for what Australian authors write on the joint defence facilities.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to remain on the narrow point of the availability of information from the joint defence facilities to the Defence Subcommittee of the Australian Parliament. I will move to the wider field of the availability of information relating to intelligence matters to senators and members of the Australian Parliament. This has always been an interest of mine.

Let me state the position: no such information is made available to members of the Australian Parliament through any formal channels. Ministers who have responsibility for certain agencies—namely the Minister for Defence, for the Defence Signals Directorate and the Defence Intelligence Agency; the Attorney-General, for ASIO; the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, for ASIS—are fully briefed by their relevant agencies, and Cabinet committees have briefings where relevant. On occasions, the entire Cabinet or even the whole Ministry will be briefed. There is nothing else available on a regular basis to members of the Australian Parliament. This conforms to the basic rule of intelligence, which is: there is a need to know and if one does not have a need to know, one is not informed. The system we follow in the Australian Parliament fulfils and satisfies that requirement.

My personal view is that that is unsatisfactory. I believe it is important that the Parliament has some knowledge of and access to intelligence information. The very great difficulty is how it should be done. I am very conscious of the colleagueship, the innate equality, of all honourable senators within this chamber. It is an equality that denies the President of the Senate the right to have a casting vote, which would be the normal procedure under the standing orders of most bodies, in the event of a tied vote. That is how far we take our equality. Nevertheless, it is clearly impractical to have open access to all intelligence information to the Parliament as a whole.

Different countries approach this matter in different ways. Leaving out the totalitarian regimes, which do not transmit anything to their token parliaments, the democracies have a range of practices which cover the whole spectrum—from total denial of information to full disclosure. As far as I am aware, the parliament of the United Kingdom has no intelligence committees of any sort and no regular channels of communication. The United States Congress has a number of committees which have access to information and one of them which I had some experience with—the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence—characterises the range of information that is available. They have full and complete access to all information.

I will state briefly why I find the present system unsatisfactory. As I said before, it has always been my belief that it is not in the best interests of the Parliament to deny access to this sort of information. I have refrained from speaking on this matter for a number of years because I recognise the great complexity of the issue and the fact that there is no simple answer to it. I raise this matter this afternoon in the hope that it will initiate some discussion in the Senate.

My first point is that, as members of parliament, we are fully accountable for the expenditure of all public moneys. If no-one, apart from the Minister, knows what the various intelligence agencies are doing, no-one in the Parliament can truthfully account to the public for the expenditure of that money. Secondly, information has to be shared so that opinions can be formed and decisions made by informed minds. At the end of the day, information is collected to be used, not to be hoarded. To take an extreme case, a senator could quite genuinely, but in ignorance, propose some policy or campaign publicly for something which was clearly against the national interest.

My third point is that, in our system, the executive government is responsible to the Parliament for the exercise of its authority. It therefore follows that it is proper for the Parliament to be informed on intelligence matters. As I said before, there are no regular channels in this Parliament for that to take place. It could be argued that the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, set up under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act, provides such a channel for one sort of intelligence. In my experience as a former and recent member of that Committee, it does not.

Clearly, the access to information has to be restricted to a select few. That causes some problems in a democratic parliament, but I can see no other solution. It is not unreasonable to assume that any senator wishing to serve on a committee which receives this information should apply for and obtain a security clearance at the highest rating. I do not wish, at this stage, to take the matter any further, but it is a matter of concern. As the longest serving member of the defence sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, there have been numerous occasions on which the availability of briefings at an adequate level of secrecy has affected the operation of that Committee and its ability to form a judgment on some issues.

The particular point which led me to speak this afternoon on this matter was the fact that information is made available more freely to my foreign counterparts than it is to members of the Committee on which I serve. We feel that that is an unjust imposition on the members of the Australian Parliament. But as I said earlier, I think the issue is considerably wider than the joint defence facilities. It applies to all intelligence gathering agencies, not only those in the defence field. It is a matter which I respectfully bring before the Senate in the hope that, if the matter is discussed in a mature way, some advance can be made on the present situation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first report of the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I pay tribute to Dr Max Whitten, the Chairman of this relatively new body. Dr Whitten, the head of the Department of Entomology at the CSIRO, has made an enormous contribution to his area over many years. In particular, he has done an enormous amount for the beekeepers and the honey industry of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Bees are no different from any other livestock and the treatment they get is much the same. It is all a matter of breeding and feeding, the development of strains, disease determination, the provision of superior stock, and market development. It is just the same as any other livestock based industry.

As the honey industry is small and deals with small animals, it does not get nearly as much publicity as it should. The value of pollination alone in rural industries is estimated at between $600m and $1,200m to the farmers. The pollination advantages are very great. The beekeepers have paid a levy of 0.5c per kilogram on all their honey exports as from 1 January 1991.

The industry always has some conflict of interest with farmers, sawmillers and various other people. There always seems to be a problem with scrub clearance, blackberry eradication, Paterson's curse elimination and so on. Understanding of the industry is improving: the farmers in particular are fully aware that it is necessary to have the bees adequately fed and housed. Provision is now being made much more regularly for the beekeepers to be able to provide adequate shelter and coverage for their stock.

The honey industry in Australia is not enormously large. At the time of this report, the Research and Development Council was involved with 36 projects. The budget for those projects was $360,000 for the year. While it is not a very big industry and while it is one that usually proceeds without much fuss, I do pay tribute to it and, particularly, to Max Whitten, the Chairman of the Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Anti-Dumping Authority on its annual report and the work that it does in investigating and identifying areas of goods dumped onto the Australian market. Page 5 of the report notes:

SPEECH.PARA: Under current Australian law, the Government may take action against only one kind of dumping: that is, which causes or threatens material injury to the Australian industry producing like goods to those being dumped, or which materially hinders the establishment of such an industry. And a broadly similar rule applies in the case of subsidisation.

In the year of investigation, the Anti-Dumping Authority looked into a wide range of cases ranging from cooling systems, pasta, carpet backing, pipe fittings, canned ham, lead acid storage batteries, vinyl floor sheeting, sodium cyanide and plaster of paris bandages. I do not know too much about many of those goods, but I do know a little about the wide range of horticultural goods which are currently being dumped onto the Australian domestic market.

PARA.TAB: On many occasions my colleague Senator Boswell has raised this issue and spoken of the plight of many farmers who not only have to fight the rural crisis but also see their products competing in the supermarket shelves with goods dumped from overseas. I am pleased that I have been able to speak on this issue on the various occasions when Senator Boswell has raised it in the Senate.

In the midst of the crisis currently hitting our rural community, Australia is importing more than $2 billion worth of food products every year. Australian horticultural products are fast becoming an endangered species. The list is growing every week. First it was pineapples; now it is bananas, canned fruit, peanuts, navy beans, peas, beetroot, beans, potatoes and other vegetables, as well as apricots, dried vine fruits, rice, orange juice, apple juice, jams, mushrooms, dairy products and fresh meat.

One industry which is still suffering from dumped goods is the peanut industry. That is an industry that I know very well because many growers in my home district are centred on Kingaroy. The peanut industry has not been able to convince the Authority of its plight. In February this year I moved a motion condemning the Government for its refusal to implement anti-dumping and countervailing measures against the dumping of Chinese peanuts on the Australian market. The Australian Customs inquiry into the importation of the Chinese peanuts established that these imports have increased 300 per cent in the past three years. It admitted that the cheaper imports were being dumped and that Australian producers were suffering as a result. It also admitted that these actions were having a serious impact on Queensland's $30m a year peanut industry.

Furthermore, tests on the Chinese peanuts have identified high levels of chemical residues, which are illegal in the Australian industry. The thing that annoys me very much is that some of these imported Chinese peanuts are being mixed with good Australian peanuts by some firms which then try to promote them as Australian peanuts. That is very wrong. The Government should take immediate action to halt the importation of these peanuts and thus provide a fair go for Australian peanut farmers instead of support for those in China.

As I said earlier, a whole smorgasbord of imported food is entering our market as subsidised products. At the same time, our farmers are having to plough back their products into the soil. This problem is not just one for farmers. I can understand housewives who, under current economic circumstances, try to buy the cheapest products when shopping. Who can blame them when we have seen our household incomes seriously eroded since this Government came to power? Many of those households now face life on the dole as unemployment rises steadily. Of course, any sensible shopper tries to cut costs by buying cheaper brands, but with many of these dumped brands the products are not as tasty nor as nutritious as Australian grown fruit and vegetables.

Most housewives would know that Australian grown and processed products guarantee the best quality in the world. When I go home on the weekend in between the sittings of the Senate and do my shopping, I certainly like to buy Australian products. Our goods are grown under strict guidelines and processed under high standards of hygiene using the best and most advanced technology available. But we have to remember that it is not only the farmers but also the people who live and work in the community who can be affected. There is an entire support network servicing the farmers and their products. I am pleased to have been able to speak to the report of the Anti-Dumping Authority today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to say a few words on the Anti-Dumping Authority's annual report of 1990-91. I note that the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority's primary reason for existence is to recommend to its Minister whether or not he should take anti-dumping action. Such action usually takes the form of imposing special duties on imports into Australia of specified goods from specified overseas suppliers.

Other points are made in the report which I think should be explained to some of the people at large so they know how the Authority works and how many references have been received in the last year. Nineteen references were received by the Authority during the year under review compared with 10 in 1988-89 and 17 in 1989-90. While these 19 references each result in a formal report by the Authority, they cover just 11 commodities in total. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has already made a point about those commodities.

PARA.TAB: My major concern relating to the dumping legislation is that—this point is made in the report—Customs must by law reach a prima facie case decision within 35 days of the receipt of an application. That application has to be a formal application that the goods were being dumped or subsidised resulting in material injury being caused or threatened to the Australian industry producing like goods.

I notice that that time has been shortened, and the Government has announced that it will be shortened again to 25 days, which will be a great help for people in industries who do have a complaint. If that decision is in favour of the applicant, Customs then accepts the complaint and proceeds to investigate it. Customs then reaches a preliminary finding on whether dumping or subsidisation has caused or is threatening material injury. That finding has to come in within 100 days. If that finding too is in favour of the complainant, that is the Australian complainant, Customs may, and usually does, put provisional anti-dumping or countervailing measures in place. On receipt of such reference, Customs calls for further submissions for which the Authority allows another 40 days.

The Authority can send officers overseas for discussions with the producers and exporters of the allegedly dumped goods and may ask the overseas representatives of the Australian Customs Service to undertake any necessary investigations overseas on behalf of the Authority. The report must by law be sent to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce within 120 days of the receipt of the reference to Customs. But all this happens too slowly because 120 days is nearly four months, which is a long time for a company to sustain dumping.

Recently one company brought to my notice the example of sun-dried tomatoes. I refer to a couple of points that were made in the letter that I have in my hands. The company refers to the most unbelievable situation related to the recent granting of anti-dumping action approved by the Federal Government in respect of canned tomatoes imported from Italy, Spain, Thailand and China. This company was aware at the time that the canned tomato industry applied for anti-dumping provisions and advised Customs that similar damage to its industry was occurring at the same time. The company sought to join the canning industry in supporting the anti-dumping applications, particularly as the products affected both industries in terms of goods entering Australia under the same time tariff item for classification. The companies were advised though at the time that this was not technically possible.

Obviously there is a problem, and I have spoken in this place before about anti-dumping legislation. I am concerned that it is not quite as easy as it should be to protect some of our home industries that do suffer big injury from a dumped product. I urge the Anti-Dumping Authority and the Government to try to fix up some of these anomalies that are still there. I know the Authority and the Government are always looking for those anomalies because last time I spoke on this somebody from the Authority came to see me.

While the Authority and the Government are moving some way to solve the problem, there is still a lot to be done. There are larger problems at large. Edgell-Birds Eye is closing factories in the Cowra area at the moment, which to some degree has been caused by the dumping of vegetables.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, welcome the annual report of the Anti-Dumping Authority. But I regret to say that the procedures under which the Anti-Dumping Authority is currently carrying out its work simply do not do justice to the current economic position of our industries. The Anti-Dumping Authority has as its task, to put it very plainly and bluntly, the protection of our industries against dumping from countries which seek to import products which are priced below the production costs in those countries.

PARA.TAB: I leave aside for the moment the extension that I would like to see, of what I call the exploitation index, which I believe should be used to assess products as dumped products if they are produced under unacceptably low working conditions, wages, environmental safeguards and so on in other countries. We should ensure that global standards are raised rather than that the hard-fought-for conditions in our industries are dragged down to the lowest common denominator.

In particular I am concerned about the long delay that is still in place, despite the recent reductions and despite the reductions that the Government has foreshadowed, before an anti-dumping claim is concluded. This ties in with the onus of proof. Once an Australian company has shown that products are being dumped in our market below the level of the domestic prices being charged in the exporting country, then the onus of proof should revert to the importer rather than be at the door of the Australian producer or industry. This reversal of onus of proof is important if we are to protect our industries

There is another aspect that is causing concern to a number of enterprises and industries, and that is the attitude of the officers who actually investigate these complaints. There seems to be a presumption that—and I use the unfortunate words of one public servant—`unless there is blood on the factory floor' they would not consider that injury has been done to the Australian industry.

I have had representations from a Victorian firm, Caford Castors, which has found that, although it has gone to inordinate lengths to prove and show that competing products have been imported into Australia at prices below the domestic cost in the exporting country, it has still not received satisfaction or protection through a countervailing duty. It is a case that I have taken up with the office of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

I am looking forward to a review of this and other cases where Australian industries have suffered at the hands of public servants who, for some reason, seem to subscribe to the concept that the level playing field is doing us a lot of good. Whereas I believe that it is destroying our industries and is helping industries and employers in other countries to create jobs there rather than bring down the one million unemployed we have in our country here.

These are questions of principle which should be addressed by the Government. The Government should look at them again, despite the very recent inquiry into our anti-dumping procedure, which to my mind has not come down with recommendations that substantively and desirably alter the conditions under which the Authority should operate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I asked questions in the recent Estimates Committee about who paid for the visit of Professor Kutchinsky. PARA.TAB: Professor Kutchinsky addressed that conference and his thesis was that the greater availability of pornography had not been accompanied by an increase in the frequency of rape or sexual offences. That included questioning his use of statistics. Indeed, the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies has received a paper by Dr John H. I have that paper in my hand and at the end of my speech I will seek leave to table it because I think it is important that it be tabled. The following is the abstract to that paper:

Evidence advanced by Kutchinsky (1991), purporting to show a causal relationship between available pornography and the frequency of rape in four countries is critiqued. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have often said in debates in this chamber on the wool industry—and it seems there have been a number of them in recent years—Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. The wool industry over time has provided much of our export earnings. Until the troubles of recent years—a period which is covered in this report—the industry had been Australia's greatest earner of export dollars.

PARA.TAB: As the annual report of the Australian Wool Corporation says, 1990-91 saw the end of an era in the history of the Australian wool industry, a year when the reserve price scheme, the foundation of a wool marketing scheme that served the industry well for 20 years, was abandoned. 1990-91 was one of the most difficult years in the history of the Australian wool industry. Depressed demand, due largely to the withdrawal of China and the USSR from the market, coupled with large wool supplies, put the reserve price scheme under increasing pressure. While the decision by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, to lower the guaranteed minimum floor price to 700c in May 1990 was intended to stimulate demand, it failed to do so and speculation on the future of the reserve price scheme persisted. As the report notes on page 7:

SPEECH.PARA: AWC purchases reached record levels, accounting for 50-70% of weekly offerings, with stocks purchased through the scheme reaching 4.7 million bales by the end of January 1991. On 11 February, on the Board's reluctant recommendation, the Government suspended the scheme.

The scheme operated successfully for all but the last 18 months of those years, providing price stability for both the growers and the wool textile industry. This in turn helped to position wool as a leading textile fibre, made wool growing a profitable farm enterprise and earned vital export income for this nation. The combination of adverse world economic and wool supply factors, the equal of which had never been seen before in the industry's history, put unprecedented pressure on the capacity of the scheme to cope. However, as the report notes on page 12:
. . . it was the surrounding debate and continuing speculation about the sustainability of the scheme that ultimately killed it.

Indeed, the wool crisis was brought about by a series of events here in Australia, in our overseas markets, and in Government. It was in no way connected with the management and structure of the AWC, which had been carefully developed by commercial exports over many years.

PARA.TAB: This report ends with the period when, under legislation introduced in June 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation was replaced by three bodies effective from 1 July 1991: the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, a new Australian Wool Corporation, and the Wool Research and Development Corporation. In introducing legislation on this issue, it was astonishing to read in the former Minister's second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now a new era. The recriminations and disappointments of the past 18 months should remain in the past, and all efforts and energy should be devoted to building a revitalised and sustainable industry.
If ever there was a case of trying to dissociate oneself from some of the blame for what has happened, this is what the Minister was surely trying to do.

PARA.TAB: The origins of the wool crisis can be traced back to 1987 with the introduction of the Wool Marketing Bill when the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Bill seeks to place the Australian Wool Corporation on a sound commercial footing so that it is equipped to respond now and into the future to the pressures of the market-place. Secondly, the Bill is designed to introduce appropriate arrangements to ensure that the Corporation is fully accountable to industry and government without disturbing its commercial performance.
I am sure that those words must come back to haunt the Minister because, no matter how hard he tried to achieve that, he failed dismally.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, until recent years the industry managed to operate a market scheme, a reserve price scheme, very effectively. For 20 years the Australian wool industry benefited from unprecedented price stability. Yet the Government decided to intervene purely because it was unhappy that money was not going into the Treasury coffers quickly enough to cover Australia's enormous balance of payments difficulties.

As I have told the Senate in a number of debates on this issue, nowhere had it been demonstrated, as distinct from asserted, that, were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered, there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained. Interference by the Government would only ruin the reserve price scheme and ravage future orderly wool marketing. Yet in the previous year the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is one central message I want to convey to you today, it is the commitment of the Australian industry and the Australian Government to stand behind the decision to lower the floor price and to work to overcome the problems that we confront.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, will comment on the Australian Wool Corporation report and some matters relating to the operations of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. The situation for wool growers at this time is certainly looking much better than what it was at the same time last year. The market has responded in a stronger fashion than I think most people anticipated. The Opposition's calculations in terms of the wool industry at this time last year were absolutely accurate.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to the role of the Wool Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commission and their direction from here. I take this opportunity to acknowledge very strongly that the role that the Wool Realisation Commission and the Wool Corporation have played in terms of the amount of wool that has been sold has certainly exceeded most of our expectations and it has put the industry in a much stronger position. That leads to the fact that we can look at levying a much lower tax in terms of the operations and the requirement for the coming year. I suggest very strongly that we set the overall tax take, allowing for research and development of what is required to run the various aspects of the Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commission, as low as 6 per cent, and certainly no higher than 8 per cent of the total take.

It is very important that the additional money that was extracted from growers last year, in terms of the requirement to run the various institutions, should be reflected in a lower tax so as to give wool growers the maximum opportunity to maximise their incomes and for many of them to get out of a deficit situation—at least to go close to breaking even—while we go through the next two or three years which will still be difficult but nonetheless better than most people have anticipated.

I raise two points in particular with regard to the operations of the Wool Corporation, its structures and the annual general meeting on May 6. I hope the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) takes note of my comments on this because I think there is a serious anomaly in terms of the setting of the structures and how those annual general meetings are run. The situation which is of grave concern is the fact that under the voting system any motions that come forward from within the operations of those organisations require only a 33 per vote for acceptance. Yet any motions that come forward from the growers or the shareholders require a 66 per cent majority. I find that a serious anomaly in terms of the democratic process within an industry.

The Government is responsible for the setting up of the industry. I think it requires a massive—and I would also suggest magnificent—input from the Opposition. But we have that anomaly that exists now and while it cannot be corrected this year it most certainly should be corrected for next year. I give notice now that I will be proceeding down those lines to have it corrected.

The other point I wish to raise in terms of the annual general meeting is a situation which exists as far as shareholders are concerned. It absolutely amazes me that we have a situation through the methodology that was used that many wool growers who contributed this year will not be able to have a vote purely and simply because the method for notifying them was not satisfactory. The Wool Realisation Commission would have known quite simply all those people who sold wool this year by virtue of the collection of that levy. The growers should have been notified directly of that fact rather than in a magazine that some growers get or by notices in the paper. When it comes to the process of collecting funds or requiring the industry to do something, the organisations are quite capable of getting in touch with the growers. I find that a very serious anomaly—one that could interfere with the process that is required. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 23 August 1990, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill seeks to ensure that there is a referendum before the flag is changed. As I understand it, that is the principal objective of the Bill. I concur with that. I think the Australian people, irrespective of what they feel about the flag, are entitled to have their views expressed in a proper constitutional manner.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other people in the Government have been saying that the flag will not be changed until we have an indication of public support. I suppose questions could be raised whether that indication of public support should be a vote at a particular election, which will just tot up the number of people who have voted a certain way and the number of people who have voted another way. I do not think that that would be appropriate because, before the flag is changed, there must be a proposition; there has to be a new flag, and presumably that would be as a result of some sort of competition. But, if there is a competition, I assume that some sort of guidelines would be needed, which would be set to guide the people who were making the suggestions as to the change.

Those guidelines are either going to be set in the first instance by the Government or by the Parliament. In my view they ought to be set in the first instance by the Parliament rather than by the Government because the Parliament is comprised of elected representatives of the people.

Whilst the Government can claim that it has a mandate in certain areas, these matters, as they touch on issues which should be bipartisan—issues which go to the image and values of the country and the principles upon which the country was founded and stands—ought to be determined in the first place by the Parliament. I think that is reasonable and logical.

We, as elected representatives of the people, should have a say in what guidelines ought to be used for any such competition in the event of the Government deciding that there should be a competition for a new flag. I do not know whether the Government has decided yet whether there should be a new flag. But if the Government makes such a decision, then, in the first instance, the elected representatives of the people ought also to have a say in the guidelines for the competition.

The results of the competition, obviously, have to go before a panel. Who will comprise the panel? I think the persons who will comprise the panel ought to be appointed by this Parliament. Ultimately, if the matter is to go before the people, it ought to come before the House of Representatives and the Senate for a vote. It then ought to be put to the people in a referendum.

The referendum procedures should be followed because this is a vital issue in terms of image of this country. If a referendum can be held on such matters as simultaneous elections, why cannot this matter go to the people in a referendum context where a decision will be made by the majority of voters in the majority of States. That is the issue. I think that is the way in which this matter should be dealt with. But we are all getting ahead of ourselves. I do not think the issue of whether or not we should have a new flag is of tremendous importance at this stage. I think there are an enormous number of other issues that need to be looked at.

I accept that the Prime Minister would not put this issue forward as a diversion, but the fact is that it is a diversion. Our attention is being diverted from the real problem. As everybody can see, I had my hair cut on Monday morning. The issue of whether we are going to have a republic or whether we are going to have a new flag was the burning issue in the barber's shop. For crying out loud, the workers of Glenorchy are having their attention diverted when families with three children who are not eligible for FAS have had a loss in real disposable income of 11.3 per cent over the last seven years. Why divert their attention away from that issue? We ought to be concerned about what is happening to them. We ought to be focusing very clearly on that.
I agree that there is no harm in debating and talking about the flag, but it does not appear to me to be an issue which is of such burning importance and concern—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is everybody talking about it, then?

—Because the Prime Minister has talked about it. Senator Schacht does not seem to understand that his Prime Minister is an important person. He is a well-respected person in this community and people talk about what he says.
—What is wrong with that?

—The point is that he talks about it and other people talk about it. I do not impugn incorrect motives to his raising the point. I want to make that perfectly clear. I do not think he has raised this matter as a diversion; I think he firmly believes in it. But the fact is that it is a diversion from some of the very pressing problems that we have in our community today. When one analyses the issue, one will wonder, `Why get so heated up? Why have a brawl in the barber's shop about this?'

PARA.TAB: I would like to say that I agree with the legislation which has been brought forward by Senator Parer. I think it is important that, whatever our views about the subject or whether we have any views about the subject, there ought to be a procedure which everybody understands will be used if the flag is going to be changed. That procedure is laid down in Senator Parer's Bill—namely, that the referendum procedures be followed. I support that as being a logical and reasonable approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Harradine for his most timely and very interesting remarks on the Flags Amendment Bill. The Democrats agree that one of the two most important official symbols of this nation is the Australian flag. We also agree that it is not up to politicians but up to people to change that official symbol. It was, in essence, up to the people to change the other official symbol—our anthem. We do not think anything less should be afforded to a change in the flag.

PARA.TAB: We would like to see any change start with a competition. We would get a group of people together, and I think Senator Harradine had some very interesting ideas on this. One of the people who would judge that flag competition would be a person from the returned services organisations. There would be people from all over Australia and from all walks of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not Bruce Ruxton, surely.

—Senator Schacht says, `Not Bruce Ruxton, surely'. I think we could find somebody from some returned services organisation who would be very interested in this and who would have a great deal to offer to the search for a new flag, if indeed we had a new one at all.

PARA.TAB: So we would have a competition and we would end up with three or four flag designs. We could then put those choices to a referendum to find out what the final flag design would be. We could get used to that for a while. We could look at it for a few months. We could use it at sporting organisation dinners and at football matches. We could use it at events around Australia just to see what we thought of it. Finally, I think we would have to hold a referendum to see whether we would change it at all. We cannot just change the flag and expect everybody to like it. Senator Parer has the right idea: in the end I think we have to have a referendum.
