The other parts of Senator Parer's Bill are very timely, too. The change to section 5 of the Australian National Flags Act 1953 is an important one; he is absolutely right about that. That section allows the Governor-General to permit more flags to be used in Australia than just the Australian blue ensign, as the national flag is now called. It would be possible for us to have a flag which we called the flag of the Australian Government which could be used on official occasions, and a flag of the Australian people which could be used on any occasion to represent Australia, without having a referendum or even changing the Flags Act. Senator Parer has done well in putting that in the Bill.

The Democrats will be supporting this Bill. We congratulate Senator Parer on it and think it is very timely. We expect this Bill to go to the House of Representatives very soon and be voted on as soon as possible. We expect to see a competition for a new flag; we expect to see a referendum as to whether we should have a new flag at all, when we have a final design; and we hope to see this in, possibly, the next two or three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Flags Amendment Bill 1990.
—Not the human rights expert.

—Senator Kemp has had a good week. He has been made Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader on Senate Liaison. I presume that means he is the messenger boy who takes the messages from Robert Hill's office over to John Hewson's office. That is about the level of his ability—messenger boy, to take messages because someone in Senator Hill's office cannot make a phone call. It is the most extraordinary appointment in many years in this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition front bench now has 33 shadow Ministers and three or four shadow Parliamentary Secretaries because John Hewson keeps adding a couple more to his front bench to preserve his numbers in the parliamentary Liberal Party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paul couldn't find a place for you.

—Senator Kemp interjects loudly. He has had a good week and risen to the height of his own ability, which is about the lowest level in the Liberal Party—Senate liaison officer. I cannot think of a more demeaning position to hold in parliament. It is better just to be an ordinary backbencher than Senate liaison officer. When I heard it I thought that maybe the Liberal Party thinks the Senate transport office or the Senate printing office needs assistance. It is such an astonishing appointment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Schacht might talk about the flag, if he does not mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would have to agree that it was an astonishing appointment that can only be called bizarre.
—I raise a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise your point of the relevance to this debate of the speech being given by Senator Schacht.

—I oppose this Bill because it is a stunt. It was a stunt in August 1990 when it was first introduced and it still is a stunt. I oppose the Bill because it is unnecessary at the moment. It is quite appropriate that there will be a process of public consultation and public acceptance. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made the comment that the flag will not be changed unless a clear majority of Australians are in favour of a change. That is a clear indication.

PARA.TAB: I, who openly favour changing the flag and removing the Union Jack, believe it would be a grave mistake to introduce a new flag without a period of debate and consultation in the community. I also want to point out to those opposite in the Liberal Party that changes to the flag have occurred because legislation has gone through this chamber on several occasions. When Bob Menzies introduced the legislation in 1953 nobody called for a referendum. It was moved straight away and put through the Parliament as a short Bill establishing the blue ensign as the Australian national flag.
It is interesting to note that it was not until 1953 that the blue ensign, as it is called, became the Australian national flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —Formally.

—Yes, formally. Until then we had two national flags, the blue ensign and the red ensign. We had those flags for 52 years of Federation and this myth that people opposite go on about, that every soldier who fought for Australia served under the blue ensign and some died under the blue ensign, is incorrect. In fact, most of them unfortunately died under other flags, the Union Jack and the red ensign. It should be put on the record. This mischief or myth that the blue ensign has been the only Australian flag since 1901 should be cleared up.

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned this before and I will keep mentioning it. The blue ensign, and its variation the red ensign, were adopted in 1901 after a competition to find a design for an Australian flag. I want to draw the attention of members opposite to the rules of that competition. Talk about a rigged set of rules! The rules said:

SPEECH.PARA: The flag should be based on the British ensign, as the flags of the countries added to its folds, signalling to the beholder that it is an imperial union ensign of the British Empire.

I do not think there is a more appropriate description of where the Liberal Party is today than back in the British Empire. John Howard said some six weeks ago that the Menzies period was the golden age in Australia and that we should all hanker back to it. Now those in the Liberal Party are saying, `Let us go back to the nineteenth century and the British Empire because that is the appropriate period'. At this rate, in another six months they will be asking to go back to the medieval age, because that was supposed to be the golden age. They are going backwards at an ever increasing rate. They will prove that the big bang theory was wrong and go back 15 billion years in history. People in Australia ought to be aware of what the rules were for the creation of the Australian flag. The flag had to show that we were part of the British Empire, an empire that no longer exists.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to the referendum itself. In his Bill Senator Parer calls it a `referendum' and Senator Bourne says that the Democrats support a referendum. Are the rules of the referendum going to be the same as the rules of a referendum that is needed to change the Constitution? That is, is it necessary to get a majority vote in a majority of the States to get a particular design adopted?

When we had the plebiscite in 1977 instigated by Mr Fraser, several choices were available for the national anthem. It was a popular vote; it was not the vote of a referendum where there had to be an absolute majority in an absolute majority of States. There just had to be a vote to find out which anthem the simple majority of Australians liked. I ask Senator Bourne whether she favours the rules of a referendum to change the Constitution in such a referendum, where there has to be an absolute majority of the vote in an absolute majority of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not in the Bill either.

—Senator Bourne used the word `referendum' and I want to make sure that we get it clear. For the sake of clarification, people in Australia should understand that we are not actually calling a referendum, because people understand a referendum in terms of changing the Constitution, which means that a particular result has to be achieved. A copy of the Bill has just been put in front of me and it says that it should be approved by a majority of all the electors voting. That is fine, and may well be an appropriate way to deal with it.

PARA.TAB: However, does the phrase `a majority of all electors' mean—I ask this of Senator Parer and he may respond later on—a simple majority or an absolute majority for one particular design? That is a matter the honourable senator may care to comment on later. I suspect, as is usual and as it was in the national anthem competition, there may be an absolute majority but we may well get a third, a third and a third for three different designs, including perhaps the existing flag. I want to know exactly what the honourable senator means by `a majority'. I do not think we ought to get hung up on getting an absolute majority, particularly when there are a number of optional designs. I think there should be a number of designs in any sort of plebiscite—and I would rather use that word than `referendum' because referendum signifies a change to the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not. Look at daylight saving in Queensland.

—Yes. I think we have used and do use—and I have been as guilty as Senator Parer or anyone else—the word `referendum' very loosely when in fact in Australia it means a change to the Constitution. I think `plebiscite' is probably a better word. Whether the process is a plebiscite or a public vote, I fully support that it should take place only after some considerable debate in the community.

PARA.TAB: Unlike Senator Harradine, I am not afraid of a lengthy debate in the Australian community. I am not afraid of people in Australia being able to handle several major issues. I do not think this issue is a diversion. In fact, this week it has been members of the Opposition who have been belting the desks and beating the drum on the issue, asking all the questions in parliament. They are the ones who have made it into an issue. I am quite happy to have it as an issue, but I do not think it is a diversion. I think it is a genuine debate whose time has come and which will take place now, I suspect, not for several more weeks but for several more years—and so it should.

The Canadians debated their flag in the 1960s and I understand it took nearly 10 years. I think that is appropriate, because in the end, though we may have some differing opinions, I believe Australia will adopt a new flag. But it should be done, even though there are people who may oppose it or a particular aspect of it, so that there is genuine consensus afterwards that the result is acceptable, just as it was in Canada. I understand a majority of Canadians, who were not consulted by way of a plebiscite or referendum, opposed removing the Union Jack, but within a year all Canadians welcomed and accepted the new Canadian flag, the maple leaf, as a symbol of their sovereignty and independence of their country and now fly it with great honour.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is falling apart now. You have Quebec wanting to put the fleur-de-lis back.

—I think we must accept, though, that when the flag was proclaimed the Canadians adopted it with alacrity and have used it with great enthusiasm. Of course, the flag is a symbol for Canada that is recognisable around the world. I believe that is one of the great difficulties with our present flag—it is not easily recognised around the world.

PARA.TAB: There was comment the other day reminding us of when the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, visited Canada in 1985, and the flags flown in Ottawa to welcome him were actually New Zealand flags; the Canadians had got the flag wrong because they could not distinguish between the New Zealand and Australian flags. I think that really does sum up the problem with the present flag. People mistake us for some other place; the flag does not have a distinctively Australian design. The Southern Cross is distinctive, but with the Union Jack perhaps we appear to be New Zealand, Hong Kong or, as the original description says, part of the British Empire. I believe it is more than time we have a flag that does not signify we are part of the British Empire but signifies that we are an independent country in our part of the world with our own distinctive symbol.

I am sure this debate will continue. This stunt Bill will obviously be carried here with the support of the Democrats. But that is as far as it will go until—I emphasise this for Senator Bourne's benefit—the discussion concludes and the Government, quite appropriately, makes an announcement in the near future about the process. I do not think we should be rushed into what process we use to finally adopt it.

However, I concede that in the end there may have to be a plebiscite—I think I would call it, rather than a referendum, to stop the confusion on constitutional change—and that may be the best way to proceed. But, once again, I do not think we should be rushed into it until, as Senator Parer has said, there is a proper competition. A good cross-section of Australians should be asked to make up the judging panel. Its members should not be the usual suspects that the conservatives round up to run those sorts of things; it should be a cross-section. A representative from the RSL would be quite appropriate, just as representatives from the Aboriginal community in Australia, the Chamber of Commerce and the trade union movement would be appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the ACTU.

—I must say, though, to Senator Kemp that I do not think a representative of the Senate liaison committee, for which he has now apparently become the parliamentary secretary or something, would be appropriate.
—Don't be jealous, Chris.
—How could I be jealous of being a messenger boy between Senator Hill and Dr Hewson? The most demeaning job—
—Order! Senator Schacht, would you resume your seat. Senator Crane, you are persistently interjecting and it is annoying. Would you please desist.
—It is Senator Kemp.
—Senator Kemp. I apologise to Senator Crane. He does not do those things.
—I do not think Senator Crane would go on with such drivel.
—No, he is much more amicable.

—I believe that the process of a competition is a very appropriate way to go. I hope that the rules of the competition are not rigged as they were in 1901 and state that we still have to show that we are part of the British Empire. But a competition with a range of judges reflecting the diversity of the Australian community would be most useful. It may take some time.

PARA.TAB: I draw to the attention of the Senate that today the Adelaide Advertiser completed its competition on the design for a new Australian flag and published in colour a range of flags. It was obviously a competition that many people enjoyed contributing to, which I believe shows that the debate is a real one and a real issue in the community, and one that people are genuine about contributing to—and not a diversion, as the Opposition says.

I do not think Opposition senators really believe it is a diversion. They have entered the debate so enthusiastically in defence of the present flag that they obviously do not believe it is a diversion. They want to get on with the debate—that is their choice—and it will be enjoined around Australia. In the end, their backward views will not be those of the majority of Australians. Some time within the next decade, this place will have an Australian flag flying from the magnificent flagpole over Parliament House which will be uniquely Australian, and I look forward with many other Australians to what will be a very memorable day in the history of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for contributing to this debate. I make the point right from the outset that the coalition unequivocally and proudly supports our Australian flag. We do so because we see ourselves as Australians with no identity problems. The same obviously cannot be said about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in particular and the members of the Australian Labor Party in general who do not seem to know who they are.

PARA.TAB: It is quite extraordinary that when the Prime Minister first raised this issue the general view was that he was letting loose a diversionary hare. Senator Harradine in his speech said he would give the Prime Minister the benefit of the doubt and believe that maybe he was serious. My belief is that he did let loose a hare to take away the attention of his fellow Australians from the economic disaster he has imposed upon this country—record unemployment with no light at the end of the tunnel; record bankruptcies; jobs destroyed, and no potential for restoring those jobs. So he let loose the hare. But he got caught up in it and he had no option but to continue. Going down the diversionary tactic, as an historian like Senator Schacht would know, is as old as history itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you fall for it?

—The fact is that the issue was raised by the Prime Minister; Senator Harradine said that. In fact, we did nothing for a couple of days until we saw that the Prime Minister was hell-bent on going down this route. Hence, we responded, as is right and proper. We were responding on behalf of the vast majority of Australians—loyal, nationalistic Australians—who want to see our flag protected. Before I was interrupted by Senator Schacht I was saying that this diversionary tactic is as old as history. It was a tactic used in the Roman days. When things were bad economically back in those days they would run a show at the Colosseum and throw a few Christians to the lions to divert the attention of the people away from the economic conditions.

PARA.TAB: It is very disconcerting—this again supports the views expressed by Senator Harradine—that the Prime Minister, instead of directing his energy and attention to the disastrous economy, has seen fit to run the flag issue. As I indicated earlier, as the Prime Minister has done so we must respond. Whether Senator Schacht likes it or not, the Opposition represents the view of the majority of Australians who are pretty proud of the flag that we have.
I will outline a little bit of history. Senator Schacht makes great play of the fact that the flag only became our flag in 1953. Nothing could be further from the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the 1953 Act.

—I know exactly what the 1953 Act is all about and I will come to it. At the time of Federation, the government of the day had a competition. There were some 30,000-odd entries in that competition. I might add that that was out of a population of about 3.5 million people. There was quite an extraordinary response.
—Wasn't there a #10,000 prize? It was a good inducement.
—For Senator Schacht's edification, the prize was #200.
—I was quoting in today's figures.

—What a marvellous exaggeration—#10,000! It just shows how much credibility we can put on the other remarks of Senator Schacht. One of the successful entrants in the competition was a 14-year-old schoolboy named Ivor Evans. His family still makes the flags today. I think it is great that that sort of tradition continues in this country. In fact, Ivor's father was a flag maker back in the 1890s or thereabouts. In today's Australian there is an article about Ivor Evans's son. Ivor is now about 67 years of age. His son said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a bloody good flag, it's a beautiful flag.

What is the flag and what does it represent? I think we have to spell this out. The Prime Minister started this debate. Senator Schacht and everyone else is saying, `Let's have the debate'. I am very happy to say, `Let's commence the debate'. What is our flag? We had the competition and 30,000-odd entries were received. It came down to a list of a few and a judgment was made.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht indicated that there was some criteria about the Union Jack. I say to him quite honestly that there is a grey area with respect to that. The gazette that went out did not mention any criteria at all. I suspect—we have been trying to do some research on this—that because of the number of entries the six or seven judges, from a broad range of Australian people, started to set their own rules as to how they would limit the judgment of 30,000-odd entries down to four or five. I think four successful people shared the prize because they had identical entries.

What is the flag? We all know that it is a symbol. Some Labor parliamentarians have said in years gone by that it is a tatty bit of cloth—and so it might be. To refer to it like that is the same as referring to the Taj Mahal as dirt, sand and cement—and so it is. The flag is a symbol and a symbol of our country. I think it is a great symbol. It has the Southern Cross on it. The Southern Cross is neither unique to Australia nor to our flag: there are a lot of countries with the Southern Cross on their flag. For example, Papua New Guinea has the Southern Cross on its flag. It represents something important to Australia; it represents our timeless land. Senator Schacht talked about the big bang. That is when the Southern Cross appeared. If he is suggesting that we should not retain the Southern Cross because it was formed at the time of the big bang in the universe, let us get rid of that too. It is utterly illogical.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't do that.
—I can understand Senator Panizza's concern because he comes from Southern Cross.
—And very proud of it.

—I thank Senator Panizza. Prior to the days of technology, the Southern Cross was used by navigators to find their way in the Southern Hemisphere. The Southern Cross has a very important place: it represents the past, the methods of navigation which were used to discover this country and the timeless land which for many years has been a description of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the Union Jack. It is symbolic of our past. No-one denies that we went through a colonial phase. In 1901 we received independence. It was decided to include the Union Jack on the flag. The Union Jack is simply a symbolic representative of the crosses of Saint Patrick, Saint George and Saint Andrew, who are the patron saints of Ireland, England and Scotland. Some people may say: does this not represent some sort of a hang-up with colonialism? Of course it does not.

We should bear in mind that from that part of our history we have got our language. Will we hear next from the Prime Minister that he thinks, because of our long connections with Britain, that we should get a new language? Will he suggest some sort of a blend—Esperanto? To be consistent, if we are embarrassed about our background, our history, we should change our language. The Union Jack also represents the democracy we have in Australia, the Westminster system and all of our laws. The three-cross position is symbolic of our total Christian traditions which we continue to have in this country. It is reflected in the fact that every time this Parliament sits the Lord's Prayer is recited. We have the seven-pointed star which represents the six States and the colonies.

We had Federation in 1901. No-one that I know—except perhaps the Prime Minister—would argue that we have not been independent or recognised as such since 1901. That was the view and the spirit. We hear about the Anzac spirit. Many people who were involved in the Anzacs and Gallipoli would not have been born in this country, but they saw themselves as Australian. My 86 year old mother-in-law was born in Scotland, but every chance she gets she says, `I'm an Aussie'. She does not see herself as being a Scot; she sees herself as being an Australian. What came out of Federation and the flag was the slogan—everyone should know the slogan from 1901—`One people, one destiny, one flag'. Our flag stands for that tradition.

Yesterday I heard Senator Collins say in this place that he was Irish. I then checked my own origins. Going back well over 100 years, the population of this country was 75 per cent Irish and 25 per cent Spanish. I am neither of those nationalities; I am an Australian and a very nationalistic one.

People who came to our great country and who continue to do so have done so for a number of reasons. I am going right back in time. Of course, no-one denies that the Aboriginals came here about 40,000 years ago. There is no doubt that they migrated south when the countries of the world were joined together. People came here for various reasons: some by force as convicts; they were hounded out of their own countries by oppressive governments; or they wanted a better way of life for their families. Much of that latter group came after the Second World War when they saw Europe devastated. They would have said, `We really do not want our children to go through what we have gone through over the past six or seven years'. When these migrants came and stayed they became Australians, represented in the country by our flag.

We have this newfound phoney nationalism by the Prime Minister. All of us were ashamed—even Senator Bolkus would have been ashamed—by the comments of the Prime Minister in Indonesia. Senator Evans said that the reason the Prime Minister was doing this was to promote an image. Senator Evans said that this move was to promote some sort of image.

I have this incredible view of what occurred in Indonesia. We would have said, `Look, we are over here to make friends and promote trade'. The Indonesians would have said, `Great, what are you going to offer?'. We would have said, `We are going to change the flag'. Imagine the reaction! All our problems would be solved, our balance of payments would be fixed, and our relations with the Indonesians would be strengthened.

What would be our reaction if some people came to Australia from a neighbouring country, said they had a disaster of an economy because of the actions of the person speaking to them, and then said, `Look, we really want to come over, let bygones be bygones and sort out our problems. There are a few things we would like to suggest to you'. We would ask, `What are they?'. If they then said, `We are going to change our flag', we would say, `Big deal, if you want to go that route. That has nothing to do with us; that is an internal problem'.

Frankly, as someone who had a lot of bad experiences from the effects of the Second World War—I was born in Papua New Guinea—I found the comments of the Prime Minister there appalling. The Prime Minister discovered some new names—he obviously did not learn them at school—with places such as Milne Bay and Kokoda. In fact, the great history of the war has become a legend in Australia because of the actions of my uncle who filmed the Kokoda Trail. It is a little ironic that Damien Parer made famous the people of Kokoda, the fuzzy wuzzy angels and battles such as the battle of the Bismarck Sea. I could go on and on. Damien Parer was killed in action by the Japanese whilst filming Americans fighting in Peleliu Island. Why was he there? He was there because the Australian Labor Government of the day was not interested in the work he had done. That is not generally public knowledge, but I am telling honourable senators this because I know it.

Interviews were held with the then Minister for Information, Mr Calwell. He showed no interest whatsoever in Damien's work in Kokoda and other places. It is a very sad situation. All I know is that Damien was an extraordinarily nationalistic person. Even though he switched to Paramount, because it gave him proper equipment to use on the filming of the Kokoda Trail, he insisted on wearing his Australian uniform. He was killed while wearing his Australian uniform.

Today we are introducing the Flags Amendment Bill to amend the Flags Act so that there will be no change to the Australian flag without a referendum. Nothing really could be simpler than that. Such legislation has been passed in this place in past years. It was introduced by me after the last election simply because we did not trust this Government to do the right thing when it came to changing the major symbol of Australia.

In remarking on Senator Harradine's comments, it is my view that it would be improper to engage in a competition without people having first decided whether they want to change the flag. That is the first question to be asked; otherwise we could have a sort of a devious, rat cunning way of doing things that influences people's perceptions and builds their expectations without them having first decided that they want to change the flag.

I thank Senator Bourne for her contribution. She talked about going down the track of deciding the judges in a competition. It is my view that the first question the people of Australia should be asked is whether they want a change.

Senator Schacht made some interesting remarks. Surprise, surprise, he said he would oppose the Bill. Here is the person who talks about freedoms and the freedom of democracies—he goes on about it at length. He believes that a referendum to ask the people whether they want to change our flag is a stunt. He should be ashamed of himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —He got something right at last.

—I like that interjection. I said, `Senator Schacht should be ashamed of himself'. Senator Bolkus said, `You have got something right'. Senator Schacht said that the matter needs debate. We do not dispute that. We would like a debate, and we would like it to continue, but all we are saying is that, before the Prime Minister and the Labor Government changes our flag, the people should be given a chance to express their views by way of a referendum. Senator Schacht also referred to the majority that is required in a referendum. I will not go into a debate on that because it is clearly spelt out in the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that the coalition makes no bones about the fact that we support the flag. It is our flag and it is a flag that was developed at Federation. It has been part of our history for the past 90 years. The splitting of hairs as to it being red or blue at certain times is immaterial. That flag was accepted in 1903. In fact, in Townsville I believe that it was raised for the first time by Lord Hopetoun in 1901.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure about that?
—There is a little uncertainty as to whether that was the first time it was raised, not that it was raised. I am pleased to see that we have another historian sitting opposite.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the flag has gone through a period of crises in Australia's history: the Great War—World War I—World War II, the Korean War, the Vietnam War and, more recently, the Gulf War. I support the view of Dr Hewson, Senator Harradine and a lot of people that it is a pity that this matter has become an issue, because there are greater issues in Australia today that we should be addressing and to which our energies should be directed. The first issue, of course, is correcting the economy.

However, this is not an issue of our making; it was raised by the Prime Minister. He did not just raise it once or twice, he kept it going and going. I think it was appalling—apart from the remarks I made earlier about the Prime Minister's comments in Indonesia, which were an embarrassment—to say to a bunch of children in New Guinea at the Anzac Day celebrations, `We are going to get you a new flag'. Yet Senator Schacht stood up here today saying, `Let us have a long debate. It might go on for two to 10 years'. That is fine, but it is not in keeping with what the Prime Minister said in New Guinea: `Instead of waving your flag with the Union Jack and the Southern Cross and the seven-pointed star, we are going to get you a new flag'. What an arrogant person; what a presumptuous person. The vast majority of people in this country want to hang on to what they have.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Parer) proposed:
That this Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, a process is going on in the Senate at the moment which has meant that in order to expedite consideration of business—particularly business which is coming up after this particular matter—we will not embark upon a mainstream debate on this issue at this time. We on this side of the chamber have not called for a division, given the fact that it has been made quite evident that both the Democrats and the Opposition support the Flags Amendment Bill which is before the Parliament. However, for the sake of the record, it needs to be understood that the Government does not support the Bill, nor does it support the process which has been encompassed in Senator Parer's Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made it clear that, in respect of any changes to the flag, he would be putting some process to Cabinet in due course. He has also made it clear that he would not seek to change the nomination of the official flag without clear evidence of public support. As he has said, and as I have also said, we have not in any sense embraced a process which would give consideration to how the flag would be changed if, in fact, it were changed. The process of referendum is obviously one that is available to us, but we feel that any settled process at this stage is premature. I tried to put that view to the Australian Democrats before they put their position in this chamber and have tried since. I reiterate for the record that we have not embarked upon a process. We think that to adopt one now is premature; it would basically control the direction of the debate even before the debate had started.

I have made it clear this week that, in my view, as Minister responsible for the flag, the time for the flag we have now has just about run out. There is a growing feeling out in the electorate that the flag should change. Debate, discussion and public awareness of alternatives will be very important in determining what the alternative will be. That process is one that we believe should be settled further down the track. As a consequence, we do not support the legislation which is now before the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the resignation of Commissioner Turbet from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC),
(ii)with deep concern, the circumstances which led Commissioner Turbet to take the extraordinary step of resigning,
(iii)that the role of the AIRC has been replaced with shady deals between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Secretary of the ACTU (Mr Kelty), and
(iv)that as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is not part of these `deals', he is therefore too weak to protect the independence and integrity of the AIRC; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Minister for Industrial Relations to resign.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very serious matter to call for the resignation of a Minister. I start my comments by quoting from an answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in Question Time today. The Minister said:

The attitude of this Government to the Australia Industrial Relations Commission is best summarised by saying that we may disagree from time to time with some of its judgments but we will fight to the death to protect the institution and its right to make those judgments free of outside interference or involvement.
This statement does not sit very comfortably with what Mr Keating had to say on 1 May 1991 in an interview with the Australian. This is what was said:
Q: But wouldn't you have preferred enterprise bargaining under the umbrella of the IRC?
A: No. Because the enterprise bargaining arrangement we struck in Accord Mark VI never had reference back to the IRC for the simple reason that it cannot examine each specific enterprise arrangement.
Q: Does the Cabinet formally support the ACTU decision to reject the national wage outcome?
A: Yes. Because the decision is in substantial measure a rejection of the elements of Accord Mark VI. . .
Q: What sort of role is the commission going to play in this new system?
A: I think for the moment not much.
These are hardly answers to questions that support the position put by the Minister to this chamber today. Let us look at what happened on 20 May 1991. Mr Willis said:
. . . the IRC's role was not entirely clear at present but the Government would wait and see how it treated the next round of agreements before it.
He then went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Exactly what the IRC role will be is not entirely clear at the present time because a number of agreements which are now being arrived at outside the commission are going back to the commission for commission endorsement, or not, as the commission sees fit.

Now to the extent that the commission endorses those agreements, obviously it's role will be enhanced. To the extent to which it says it won't endorse them, then obviously it's saying to the parties, well, it's either our principles as announced in the national wage decision or nothing at all as far as we're concerned. In which case there'd be a much reduced role for the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: These statements from the Prime Minister and Mr Willis, the Minister representing Senator Cook, make it quite clear that after the national wage case in April 1991 the Government was on a road to undermining the role and the position of the Industrial Relations Commission. It is not correct to stand up here today and pretend otherwise. In fact, Mr Willis's answer of `Do as we want or do what we put before you, otherwise you're on the way out', would suggest typical bully tactics.

PARA.TAB: This motion before the Senate stems directly from what we have known for a long period—that is, most of the commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission have lost confidence in the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook, to allow the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to carry out its function with independence and integrity. This was brought to a head by the extraordinary letter of resignation by Commissioner Turbet dated 14 April 1992.

This dissatisfaction runs from the high office of the President of the Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, through to almost every commissioner who serves on the bench. The possible only exceptions—and the Minister would not answer a question about this today—are those recent Government-cum-ACTU-cum-Bill Kelty appointments. An article about the annual report of the Industrial Relations Commission says:

SPEECH.PARA: A Federal Government-sponsored inquiry into the pay and structure of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission would be seen as further damaging the integrity and independence of the Commission, according to its president, Justice Barry Maddern.

There is interference in two main areas: firstly, government interference in the decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal; and, secondly, government interference in the national wage case brought down in April 1991, and that has continued. I will deal with the second one first. The April 1991 national wage case decision is significant. Commissioner Turbet, in his statement, as reported in the Weekend Australian of 25 and 26 April, said:

PARA.TAB: The process of the Accord is now no more than a meeting between the Prime Minister and the Secretary of the ACTU. Everybody else, the whole of the trade union movement and this commission, is expected to toe the line.

After the April 1991 decision, the ACTU held a special unions conference at which a document was circulated outlining all of the terrible things that were going to happen if this decision was implemented.
Now a year has passed, the decision was implemented six months later and not one of those terrible things which Bill Kelty said was going to happen has actually happened.
In purely economic terms, in the facts, it is difficult to say that the Accord process in its later manifestations has produced results which really benefit the Australian workforce.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement—delivered by a man who was a former national secretary of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, a former ALP member and a Labor candidate in the 1969 election—highlights quite clearly that the Government, through the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations, undermined the independence and integrity of the Commission.

PARA.TAB: What we have been saying on this side of the chamber for a long time is that the accord is a failure. The accord has not produced lifts in the productivity that this country requires. It has not protected employees who are in a weak position. It has contributed significantly to the level of unemployment that now exists in this country and the record levels of bankruptcies. Let us always remember that it did not protect those people who are now on the dole. As I said, it is one of the significant contributors to the level of unemployment we have today.

In fact, the accord encourages the worst work practices imaginable and cannot give any reward for those who are prepared to do a bit extra or work harder. It has failed this country miserably. Until such time as it is abolished and true workplace enterprise agreements are introduced, where employers and employees can make their own work place agreements without interference from government or the unions, or anybody else for that matter, we will see little or no improvement.
Commissioner Turbet went on to say this about the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: He didn't stand up for the Commission following the April 1991 national wage case decision. In fact, Senator Cook issued his guidelines for enterprise bargaining, which, on the face of them, were written by a junior clerk in his office. They were an absolute sham and had been completely disregarded by the Australian industrial community.
Then he delivered his greatest indictment of the Minister when he went on to say:
People say that Senator Cook is the Minister assisting the Secretary of the ACTU. It's really a bad show when public comments like that are made.

This is no different from what I have said in this place previously—that he is no more than the Minister acting for the BWIU. We will be debating this issue when the contractors' amendments come before this place in the near future.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to deal with some aspects of Commissioner Turbet's letter. The first point I wish to deal with is the matter relating to the Remuneration Tribunal. His letter states:

Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word. A classic and simple example is your about face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation in regard to recognition of the Remuneration Tribunal.
Gleeson recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: "The Government should only seek to disallow remuneration determination of the Tribunal if extraordinary circumstances arise.

PARA.TAB: To which cabinet responded:
"The need to maintain the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal is recognised and the Government accepts that it should only seek to disallow determinations in exceptional circumstances.

Yet, the first determination you receive from the Remuneration Tribunal concerning the AIRC following this announcement of policy you reject. There are no "extraordinary or exceptional circumstances" surrounding the reasoning supporting the decision. The word of the Government in the form of the official policy statement just wasn't worth the paper it was written on.

SPEECH.PARA: This highlights quite clearly once again the interference by this Government in its Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which it calls the umpire—but only the umpire if it puts its finger up when the Government wants it to do so. Secondly, I wish to deal with the points relating to the Constitution. Once again, I quote:

PARA.TAB: Finally, my third and most compelling reason for resigning is your Government's total lack of understanding of and respect for the Constitutional requirements of Section 51(xxxv) of the Constitution. There have been five referenda directed at altering this provision. All have failed. The Industrial Relations power is therefore in the same terms as when originally drafted in 1900. The AIRC has been established under s.51(xxxv) and its jurisdiction and power is limited by the Section as interpreted by the High Court. For my part I have been directly involved in two cases which have contributed to a significant expansion of the Commonwealth's power in this area. I refer to Turbet's case (144 CLR 335) and the Social Welfare case (153 CLR 299) where I was a member of the Full Bench whose decision went to the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: This once again highlights the fact that when it suits them, this Government, and this Minister in particular, move outside the law and try to do their own thing. They only have respect for it when it suits them.

PARA.TAB: My third point relates to statements, which I have already quoted, by the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister. Once again, I quote from the letter:

Statements by the then Treasurer, now the current Prime Minister, that the April 1991 National Wage decision was made by just "five officials" and that "the Accord is the primary national income determining institution, not the Commission" reveal either a complete lack of understanding of the Nation's Constitution or a deliberate endeavour to administer the Nation's affairs in a manner inconsistent with its provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make the point that this highlights quite clearly that, while this Government has said that the Commission has a role to play and that that role has not been changed, the Government has changed very significantly and undermined that role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I had just finished quoting from the letter from Commissioner Turbet on the position of the Prime Minister in relation to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Further to this unquestionable lack of confidence that the Government has created in the Commission by its lack of support for the institution—the Government's umpire—I make the following point: this is not a debate about the coalition's position and the coalition's role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; it is about the constant undermining of the Commission by Senator Cook on behalf of the ACTU. That is why he is now known as the Minister representing the Secretary of the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: I make the following points: first, the Government had a national wage case in April 1991 which the Government, on behalf of the ACTU, rejected; secondly, the Government's industrial relations policy is in total disarray because of its inconsistencies—a wishy-washy industrial relations statement was brought down in October of last year; and, thirdly, in October 1991 a national wage case decision was handed down when the principles of enterprise bargaining were established. The Government then released the statement contained in the One Nation package. There are significant contradictions in the positions that the Government has adopted between each of these matters.

The Government accepts the Commission's decisions only if it suits Mr Keating and Mr Kelty. Is it the Government's intention to make a further major statement on industrial relations at the end of June? Does Senator Cook intend to change the name of the Department of Industrial Relations? Will it be known as the Department to Satisfy Bill Kelty? Is it not a fact that the Department recommended that the head of the Construction Industry Reform Agency should be paid approximately $90,000 and that the Minister overrode this recommendation and has appointed a person who will be paid approximately $160,000?

Not only has the Australian Industrial Relations Commission lost confidence in the Minister but also have many of his staff in his Department because of his high-handed approach. In this case, with regard to the salary setting, I suspect that the Minister's staff have lost confidence in him because he is serving the BWIU and ignoring their recommendations.

This is a serious matter. Moving a motion calling for the resignation of a Minister is a serious matter. But the time has come for Senator Cook to consider his position. Most of the members of the Arbitration Commission, including the President, whom I quoted, have lost faith in him. The Minister has undermined the institution that he claims he stands up for and calls the `umpire'. His problem is that he will only accept the decision of that umpire when it suits him. His problem is that he cannot do the job without being overruled and instructed by the Secretary of the ACTU.

The Minister has forgotten that in any industrial policy there are two sides to the equation—the processes of establishing the accord and the operations of the Government with regard to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Minister has forgotten one side of the equation, and that is the employers. He has tried to foist on them, amongst other things, massive increases in occupational superannuation which will just lead to further unemployment and further increases in bankruptcies.

The Minister's subservience to the BWIU is now legendary. His determination through the introduction of the contractors' amendments proved that he is out to destroy Troubleshooters. He has no respect for Justice Woodward of the Federal Court, the Full Bench of the Federal Court or the High Court which all upheld the Troubleshooters' case. He has consistently denigrated companies such as Robe River for their use of the courts of the land.

He says constantly that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is the umpire. Yet when Bill Kelty tells him to oppose the decisions of the Commission, such as the April 1991 wage case, he attacks the Commission publicly and undermines his umpire—not our umpire, but his umpire. He has destroyed the independence and credibility of the Commission. The Minister has done this by stealth. His words of support for the AIRC do not match the Government's action or his own. The Minister no longer represents fairly the full spectrum of industrial relations in this country. Therefore, he should resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to deal with a number of issues in respect of this motion. Part (c) of the motion notes that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has been replaced with shady deals between the Prime Minister and the Secretary of the ACTU;
Part (d) notes that:
. . . as the Minister for Industrial Relations is not part of these "deals", he is therefore too weak to protect the independence and integrity of the AIRC.

It goes on to call for the resignation of Senator Cook because he is allegedly too weak and not part of the deals that are allegedly taking place. Presumably, if Senator Cook was part of the alleged deals that are taking place—which are certainly not taking place—he would be a strong Minister and the Opposition would be congratulating him. It just highlights the absurd wording of the motion.

PARA.TAB: I intend to deal with a number of issues in this debate, in particular the accusations by former Commissioner Turbet that have been seized upon by those opposite, not in a particularly inspiring and dramatic way as evidenced by the speech that has just occurred, but in order to continue a campaign of denigration and undermining of the Arbitration Commission by the Liberal and National parties. I will draw the attention of the Senate to that continued campaign of denigration by those opposite.

I will deal with some of the charges and comments made by Commissioner Turbet. I will then look at some of the considerable array of alleged misconduct by Senator Cook that ranges from accusations and assertions by Senator Crane: that he has allegedly lost the confidence of most of the commissioners of the Industrial Relations Commission; that Senator Cook does not accept decisions of the Commission; that he intends to change the name of his Department—big deal; that he is foisting on the country and employers a heavier burden with superannuation payments; that he intends to wipe out, through the contractors amendments legislation, companies such as Troubleshooters; and that he continues to denigrate Robe River. A considerable array of charges have been put forward and I will make some comments on those a little later. If I have time, I will then go into the real reasons for the Liberal-National parties' attack on the Industrial Commission and on Senator Cook and why, as a consequence, Senator Cook should certainly not resign but should be congratulated by this Senate for his excellent performance as Minister.

Firstly, I will deal with Commissioner Turbet who resigned last week and made a series of claims in his resignation letter. I will deal with a number of the comments that Commissioner Turbet made that were not really in any way significantly alluded to by Senator Crane, and yet they seem to form the basis of the motion that he has put before the Senate tonight. However, there was very little reference to them.

One of the accusations made by Commissioner Turbet is that he claimed that the Government's decision to reject the Remuneration Tribunal determination concerning the Australian Industrial Relations Commission shows that its word cannot be trusted. I certainly refute that accusation. The Government has not gone back on its word. With respect to the Remuneration Tribunal, the Gleeson Committee—as it was known—recommended that the Government seek only to disallow Remuneration Tribunal determinations in exceptional circumstances.

The Gleeson review that was carried out was a full and open inquiry into the restructuring of the Commission. It was broadly representative and its findings were unanimous. The restructuring of the Commission and the creation of the positions of vice-president and senior deputy president were endorsed by the Government and agreed upon by this Parliament.

But the Remuneration Tribunal failed to fulfil its responsibility to determine the rates of pay for all the Commission positions as requested by the Government. This, therefore, was the exceptional circumstance which has been a substantial influence on the Government's decision to present legislation to the Parliament to change the Tribunal's determination. So it is not a matter, as Commissioner Turbet has charged, of an attack on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

There is an allegation that there has been disenchantment within the Industrial Relations Commission and that there have been resignations. In fact, two members have resigned, Mr Justice Peterson and Commissioner Turbet. Mr Justice Peterson resigned on 28 April to take up a position with the New South Wales Industrial Commission and the New South Wales Industrial Court. He had been a member of the Commission since 1987. He has not indicated in any direct way that he decided to resign over the so-called pay issue.

Commissioner Turbet submitted his letter last week, on 14 April. He joined the Commission in 1978 and he has decided, for his own stated reasons, to retire early. Commissioner Turbet did not approach the Government to put his views or to seek an explanation of the Government's position before acting. He did not seek to take up any of the particular concerns. No matter how much we on the Government side rejected his concerns, he did not seek to take them up with the Government. I do not believe Commissioner Turbet's actions can be taken in good faith in that regard. If Commissioner Turbet chooses to resign, that is a matter for him.

There is an allegation that there has been a continuing deterioration in the Government's relationship with the Commission. As Senator Cook indicated today in Question Time, he has taken the initiative and on 8 April wrote to the President of the Commission expressing his willingness to meet with members of the Commission to discuss any matters of concern. I understand that to date Commission members have not met with Senator Cook, if indeed they have any concerns.

The further charge is the potential bias in the appointment of new members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In examining the allegation of bias, which has been taken up certainly by Mr John Howard with a fair amount of gusto, let us have a look at the cross-section of membership of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Certainly Commissioner Turbet has ignored the very clear evidence that there is a broad and fair cross-section of the industrial relations community on the Industrial Relations Commission.

Of the 13 deputy presidents appointed since the election of this Government in March 1983, five have union backgrounds; five practised as industrial lawyers; one was a former politician, and one a leading academic. That is hardly domination from the industrial union movement. Three of the five union persons have worked with the ACTU. One of the lawyers, Justice Peterson, has just resigned. So the Government has sought to maintain a balance on the Commission.

Let us look at the background of the current Commissioners, of whom there are 30. Of those, 13 are from a union background; 12 are from employer backgrounds; five are from government; and there are no legal or academic representatives. So again the balance is roughly equal. We certainly cannot claim that there has been any domination by union representatives.

The only complaint I would make about the representation on the Commission is that there is no-one from Tasmania. I think that is an appalling state of affairs. If one wants to criticise the background of the Commissioners, the only criticism I would seek to make is that it is unfortunate that they are from Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide, three from Brisbane and one from Perth. It is about time we had someone from Tasmania on the Commission, but that is certainly the only criticism that could legitimately be made. They are the sorts of comments that Commissioner Turbet raises in his correspondence.

The other issue that I should like to deal with tonight is the reaction of the Opposition, particularly that of Mr John Howard, to this letter of resignation. Mr John Howard made an outrageous statement. Let me quote his comments, which really get down to the real reasons why the Liberal-National parties are continuing to denigrate and attack the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National parties will not guarantee the security of tenure of future appointments by the Keating Government to the Industrial Relations Commission.

If that is not an attack on the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission, I do not know what is. It must rival the statement by the Victorian Leader of the Opposition, Jeff Kennett, that he would retrospectively take away the superannuation entitlements of Labor politicians who did not resign. Mr Howard's statement rivals that sort of crass and quiet undemocratic attack on government institutions in this country.

PARA.TAB: On the particular charge outlined by Senator Crane that most of the Commissioners have lost confidence in the Minister, Senator Peter Cook, where is the evidence? We have one letter of resignation—one only. There is no evidence to suggest any significant discontent by the Commission with Senator Cook. So it is purely an assertion that is being made.

Where is the evidence that Senator Cook does not accept the decisions? On occasions Senator Cook has stated publicly his concern as to a number of decisions by the Industrial Relations Commission. But overwhelmingly Senator Cook has accepted the decisions of the Commission, as indeed have the ACTU and the employer movement. In fact, Senator Cook and the trade union movement in this country have done nothing more than the employers occasionally do, which is to complain about a decision.

From my experience in the industrial relations arena, quite frequently employers and unions do complain publicly about the outcome of a decision, and not infrequently governments complain about a particular decision. But the important thing in this democratic country with an independent industrial commission is that we accept the outcomes. There is no evidence to suggest that Senator Cook in any way has attempted to undermine or reverse any sort of industrial relations decision.

We have an absurd charge from Senator Crane that Senator Cook wants to change the name of the Department. As I have already said, what a big deal. We have a charge that he wants to foist increases on superannuation. That is a separate issue. The issue of superannuation benefits for Australian workers will be debated. I am chairing the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which is looking at that legislation and those issues. That issue will be debated in this forum on another occasion. That is an attempt to ensure that the working community in this country receives a fair, just and reasonable retirement income through improved superannuation benefits as a result not of legislation coming from Senator Cook's Department but from Treasury. It is ridiculous to make that sort of absurd accusation as the basis for Senator Cook to resign.

If those Opposition senators have concerns, I suggest they wait to see the legislation relating to contractors legislation before they start asserting that it shows Senator Cook's subservience to the union movement in the industrial relations community.

There is a further charge that Senator Cook has denigrated Robe River. Well, good on Senator Cook for denigrating Robe River. He has quite correctly criticised the appalling industrial relations processes there. The Peko company at Robe River set out to intimidate individual workers, to strip away their wages and conditions, to sack them, and to use its enormous financial clout in the industrial and legal courts to thwart any fair play and justice by the workers concerned or their trade union representatives. So good on Senator Cook for fairly and legitimately criticising Robe River.

I can recall Senator Cook on occasions criticising the trade union movement. I can recall statements made by Senator Cook criticising the Builders Labourers Federation. But no mention was made of those occurrences this evening by Senator Crane. If we examine the balance of Senator Cook's record, the charges being made tonight are absurd and ridiculous, and they should be rejected.

I will now reveal the real reason for this weak and pathetically moved and debated resolution. If those opposite want to launch a full scale urgency debate, I suggest the time for that was earlier today. The real reason is presented in the article on the front page of today's Financial Review. It discloses the real Hewson-Howard agenda—the big bang theory. The big bang theory is that industrial awards are done away with overnight; workers without union representation will have no award protection and will not be able to go to an independent industrial commission; they must individually front up to the employers and attempt to bargain for a fair set of wages and conditions. That is what has happened in New Zealand where Dr Hewson was last week along with many others opposite.

In New Zealand there has been a quite appalling compression and reduction in conditions and wages. The notion that an individual employee can bargain equally with an individual employer is absolute nonsense. For example, in New Zealand junior persons under the age of 20 have absolutely no protection at all; there are no minimum wages and conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might have a job—unlike 40 per cent of those here.

—The unemployment rate in New Zealand is still very high. If it improves, it will be because of genuine increases in productivity and genuine improvement in the economy. If those opposite are suggesting the cheap wage option, why are they not honest about it and point out the consequences of their industrial relations policy? They keep talking about it—we have statements coming constantly from Mr Howard and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, about what they might or might not do—but we still have not seen it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook ably outlined the gross misrepresentations, if not lies, made by Dr Hewson when he alleged that there had been a 6 per cent improvement in productivity in New Zealand as a result of industrial relations changes whilst there was a decline in productivity here. Senator Cook's explanation showed that that was absolutely untrue and exposed the practice of grossly manipulating figures to suit the particular ideological bent of those opposite. Dr Hewson did not think he would get caught out on it, but of course he was.

The continuing campaign of denigration and criticism of the Commission by those opposite is so that, if they ever do get into office—I do not think they will—they can remove the Australian Industrial Relations Commission from the industrial scene. The Industrial Relations Commission serves a very important function. It acts as an independent umpire to fairly determine wages and conditions, particularly for those who are not in a strong industrial bargaining position. If those opposite want to do away with the Industrial Relations Commission, if they want to remove commissioners retrospectively, if that is the sort of approach they are going to take, they should be open and honest about it to the Australian community. That is the real reason the Liberal-National parties are concerned about Commissioner Turbet's letter.

The Liberal-National parties have raised the issue that Commissioner Turbet was a former union official and a former Labor candidate. Big deal! So what! Every Commissioner before whom I have appeared in the Federal or State jurisdiction, irrespective of their background—whether they were employer or union representatives—has behaved very fairly and very justly. I cannot think of a single example out of the hundreds of appearances I have made before Federal and State commissions where an employer commissioner behaved unfairly in a case. That is a hallmark of the commissioners that we have in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Commissioners with union backgrounds tend to be a little harder on their former colleagues, the union movement, when making decisions because they want to show that they are independent and not currying favour. As regards the current membership of the Commission and any persons who are appointed or who may be appointed in the next few months, I am quite confident that the strong tradition of independence and impartiality will continue.

We have a hotch-potch of accusations and assertions. We have a letter from Commissioner Turbet making allegations. I will not speculate about the reasons for his resignation, but he has made a series of allegations which do not stand up to factual analysis. Therefore, we have a series of charges which are not proved, and the onus is on the Liberal and National parties to prove the litany of assertions they have made.

I conclude by summarising those assertions. There is the reference to Commissioner Turbet's letter—which I think I have rebutted—and the criticisms he made therein. That was one letter from one commissioner who has resigned. There is no evidence to support the charge made by Senator Crane that most of the commissioners have lost confidence in the Minister. Where is the evidence? There is no evidence that Senator Cook does not accept decisions. He has only very occasionally criticised decisions, but that is no more than any government—State or Federal, Labor or Liberal—has done in the past 10 or 20 years. That he will change the name of his Department is a fairly absurd allegation of poor behaviour by Senator Cook. I will enter into the debate another time on the allegation that he is foisting superannuation on the Australian community, but I think it is appropriate that this Government is attempting to ensure a fair and just retirement for the Australian work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't matter how many jobs it costs—one million and going up.

—We will enter into the debate as to whether it causes any unemployment when the Senate Committee examines the legislation. There is no subservience to the will of the ACTU; there is clearly no evidence of that. As for the fact that he has denigrated Robe River, I congratulate Senator Cook for that and for drawing to the attention of the Australian community the appalling behaviour of Peko at Robe River. Indeed, I also congratulate Senator Cook for occasionally attacking the appalling behaviour of some trade unions, particularly the Builders Labourers Federation.

PARA.TAB: From my dealings with and experience of Senator Peter Cook, he is a Minister who has a very comprehensive knowledge of industrial relations. He has acted fairly at all times. He has the total confidence of his Department and of his staff. The motion before us this evening, moved by Senator Crane, should quite clearly be rejected. The charges made are not proved. They are assertions and nothing more. It is simply a cover-up by those opposite in an attempt to continue their campaign to introduce individual employment contracts a la New Zealand. It is part of their campaign to continue to remove the various industrial wages and conditions that workers in this country have come to regard as being fair. It is a continuing part of that campaign. This Government will take it up to them over this next year and, as in so many other areas, we will beat them at the next election on issues such as this.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This afternoon before Question Time at 2 p.m. I was not feeling well. By about 4 p.m. I was feeling decidedly worse, the main cause of my discomfort being severe nausea. I sought treatment from the nursing sisters at Parliament House. After checking my condition, it was suggested that I should go to Woden Valley Hospital for further medical attention. I did so, but after some time I was permitted to leave the hospital. Still not feeling well, I intend to go home before the Senate rises tonight. I mention this matter because at least one news report tonight said that I had collapsed in the Senate. This is not correct. I did not collapse anywhere and I fully expect to be back in the chamber on Monday afternoon. I thank the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Crane in the moving of his motion calling on Senator Cook to resign for four very specific reasons that are set out in his motion. I think the bare bones of the case that has been made out by Senator Crane are contained in the exchange of letters between Commissioner Turbet and `Senator the Honourable'—and I question in this context the `Honourable'—`Peter Cook'.

PARA.TAB: Former Commissioner Turbet sets out in his letter the salient points for his resignation. He sets them out in the context of describing himself as having been a Commission member for 14 years, which was preceded by 16 years service in the trade union movement and 20 years membership of the Australian Labor Party. In that context, he sets out to show how the Government has undermined the integrity and independence of the Industrial Relations Commission. Indeed, it is an irony that the Government, which purports to say that it can sustain a centralised wage fixing system because it somehow has an independent arbiter in the IRC, by its own actions has torpedoed any reputation, or any belief that anyone would have, that the Commission remains independent.

Setting out the facts as they are in his letter of 14 April, former Commissioner Turbet makes some very salient points. His first reason for resigning is that the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is self-evident.

—My colleague Senator Baume says that that is a self-evident statement. Those of us who are dealing with the Government on a day to day basis are well aware of it. It is more important and becomes more important that the wider community also becomes aware of it. Here is testimony from a man who comes from within that Labor Party movement and who says finally, `Enough is enough'.

PARA.TAB: He gives the example of why the Government's word cannot be trusted. He deals with the Government's about-face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation with regard to the recognition of the Remuneration Tribunal. Anybody who comes from New South Wales knows very well the strength and connections with the Labor Party that Gerry Gleeson has. The long-serving head of Premier Wran's department, a figure who was noted as having much power, could never be described as being unsympathetic to the Labor Party or its movement. Yet, that Gleeson report recommended as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should only seek to disallow a remuneration determination of the Tribunal if extraordinary circumstances arise.
The Cabinet's response was:
The need to maintain the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal is recognised and the Government accepts that it should only seek to disallow determinations in exceptional circumstances.

Former Commissioner Turbet goes on to say that the first determination that was received from the Remuneration Tribunal following that acceptance of the recommendation was an announcement of the policy that was rejected. Former Commissioner Turbet quite simply says:

There are no "extraordinary or exceptional circumstances" surrounding the Remuneration Tribunal's decision. There are, in fact, 15 pages of detailed reasoning supporting the decision. The word of the Government in the form of an official policy statement just wasn't worth the paper it was written on.
What response did we get from Senator Cook—`Senator the Honourable Peter Cook', as he is addressed in Mr Turbet's letter? Senator Cook says:
The Remuneration Tribunal failed to fulfil its responsibility to determine rates of pay for all Commission positions as requested by the Government.

That is the acid test: `as requested by the Government'. What a nice euphemism—`as requested by the Government'. As intervened by the Government, as intermeddling by the Government, as being dictatorial by the Government, caving into the demands of Mr Kelty. In other words, the Government directed that the Tribunal should break the nexus between judges and the Commission. Therefore, former Commissioner Turbet is quite right when he says that he did not as, so-called, requested by the Government carry out that direction.

PARA.TAB: What is the next complaint Commissioner Turbet makes? He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, actions by you—
That is Senator Cook personally—

and your Government have damaged the public's perception of the independence and integrity of the AIRC. I acknowledge that this is difficult to prove and is denied by Government. However, as a person who lives and works in the industrial community I know it to be a fact. It does not happen overnight and it is not caused by one event or one statement. As a Government and as the responsible Minister you could at least be seen as standing by the Commission, showing support for the principles of conciliation and arbitration.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want to stand by the Commission; you want to abolish it.

—Senator Collins is purporting to interpret our policy. The difference between Senator Collins's position and the Opposition's policy is that we are up-front in that we say we are opposed to centralised wage fixing systems and the Government says that it is in favour of them. The linchpin of that centralised wage fixing system is the Industrial Relations Commission.
—Stop being hypocritical and sit down.

—There is nothing hypocritical in what I have to say. The distinction I am making is that we say we do not believe in a centralised wage fixing system. We say we believe in a quite radical suggestion that employees and employers should actually be able to talk to each other without trade unions being interposed.

PARA.TAB: We also believe that people should have not only the freedom to join a trade union but also the freedom not to join a trade union; that we should not have closed union shops; that we ought to be able to have a dismantling of those deals that were done at the time of Federation in order that Federation could take place then with protectionism, with a centralised wage fixing system and the larger States paying the mendicant States in return for federalism.
Former Commissioner Turbet goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The public's perception of the independence and integrity of the Commission is the appointment process. The Commission should represent a fair cross-section of the Australian community. It is essential that the presidential level contains good lawyers together with persons qualified in economics, and those with acknowledged industrial relations skills and experience. Over recent times the top lawyers have retired, among them two QC's. They have not been replaced. Is it that the standing of the Commission has fallen so low that the "silks" who regularly appear before us would never accept an appointment?

PARA.TAB: It also damages the institution. . . when the names of prospective appointees are being speculated upon in the press and in industry journals. If the appointment comes to pass they are perceived to be stooges for the side of industry from which they come. If not, they stand humiliated in the eyes of their peers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite interesting, I think, that it says:

Currently, the press and self-styled informed newsletters are touting Jenny Acton from the ACTU staff as a Deputy President. One newspaper article headcounted the Presidential members noting that Ms Acton will make it four directly out of the ACTU office, plus another two who were members of the ACTU Executive. It cannot be denied that four Deputy Presidents from the ACTU office is hardly a fair cross-section of the Australian industrial community.

So much for Senator Sherry's rather curious speech; he seemed to have a different interpretation of the letter which he did not bother to read into the record. He said in fact that one letter of resignation did not matter a row of beans. We all know the old adage that one letter written in fact represents a lot of discontent by those of a similar mind.
