DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report on Employment of People with Disabilities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I as Chair of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs tabled this report on employment of people with disabilities during the last sitting week we were under severe time constraints, as we often are in this place, and I confined myself to the tabling statement. I now wish to add briefly to that statement.

PARA.TAB: This report had a very long gestation. We were given the reference in August 1988, which is more than three years ago and a lengthy period for a Standing Committee inquiry. However, those three years were not continuous. After we had held a number of hearings and visited a number of relevant work places, in mid-1989 we were given a reference with a limited timeframe to inquire into accommodation for people with disabilities.

By the time we were able to report on that reference—in the meantime having been delayed by the pilots' dispute which inhibited our travel and by the dissolution of Parliament in March 1990—it was May 1990. After that election there were some changes in the membership of the Committee and we lost some valuable expertise. We also had a number of staff changes in the secretariat which meant a sharp learning curve was needed for some Committee members and some of our support staff. A further delay resulted from the institution of the Bills to committee procedures, because this Committee is one which has had a number of references on Bills, some of which required a great deal of committee time.

In the meantime we have also received two further references in the area of health. Yesterday we reported on radiological services in relation to the Medicare benefit schedule and next week we are due to report on pharmaceutical restructuring. Thus we apologise to all those out in the community with a vital interest in the employment of people with disabilities for the delay in presenting the report, but we believe we have produced a thorough and useful appraisal.

Most of the present Committee, and also the previous Committee, have been associated in some way over a number of years with support work in the area of disability. Therefore, we brought a lot of our own experience, and in some cases professional expertise, to our work on this inquiry. We carried out many visits to the workplaces of people with disabilities. These were particularly valuable because we were able to check with our own eyes and ears what we had heard and read in evidence and they enabled us to talk informally with workers with disabilities and others who work with them. This was a very useful experience. For example, on one occasion we saw very unsafe work practices which alerted us to the need to pay more regard to industrial health and safety issues.

I thank all those who gave evidence and enabled us to make visits to workplaces. For my own part, I would like to thank service providers and others in Darwin, whom I visited as Chair on behalf of the Committee, and government officials in several parts of Germany, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom who not only gave me information on their own provisions in this policy area but also discussed with me very openly the minuses as well as the pluses in their experience of service provision.

I thank the numerous staff who assisted us in our work and the former members of the Committee who I hope will read our report with approval. Finally, I pay tribute to the work of Don Grimes, the former Minister for Community Services, who was responsible for the passage of the Disability Services Act and the work which preceded it. It was landmark legislation which is looked up to in other countries as well. In his second reading speech on that Bill, Don Grimes said that it represented:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the culmination of sustained effort by a broad cross-section of those many people, both within and outside government, concerned for the future of people with disabilities and of the families who have a person with a disability.

I support those words and add that in the intervening years their contributions have continued, linked with the efforts of people with disabilities themselves, to enable as many people with disabilities as possible to be able to participate as fully as possible in the community, in employment as well as in other ways.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report on mergers, monopolies and acquisitions: Adequacy of existing legislative controls

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry into mergers, monopolies and acquisitions was initiated by a Democrat motion on 16 May 1991. This followed a series of amendments which were moved. We felt that the current law on mergers and acquisitions was somewhat outdated in the light of fast-moving economic changes in our community.

PARA.TAB: The philosophy underlying part IV of the Trade Practices Act 1974 is the protection and enhancement of competition. Implicit in part IV is the assumption that acts or occurrences which substantially lessen competition contravene the Act, unless authorised by the Trade Practices Commission on public benefit grounds.

However, the existence of section 50, which specifies the dominance test in the area of merger regulation, is difficult to reconcile with the essential thrust of the Act, which is directed to preventing anti-competitive conduct. It is perhaps useful to recall that it was the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, who, in 1977, changed the then existing test to lessen competition to one of dominance to enable the takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times by the Murdoch companies.

In looking at the question of section 50 and the test that should be applied to mergers and acquisitions, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs acknowledged business concerns that the law governing mergers should be certain and predictable. The Committee noted and adopted the observations made in the 1984 OECD report on merger policies and recent trends in mergers, to the effect that:

SPEECH.PARA: Member countries should make as transparent as possible the criteria they apply (to mergers). . . Such criteria could include for instance the determination of the relevant market—
and I would add, that includes international markets—
in merger analysis, the level of concentration in the market, barriers to entry and factors relating to the firm's conduct and performance.

While the section 50 dominance threshold has been in operation since 1977, it has accumulated a body of interpretive law. However, between 1974 and 1977, the alternative threshold of substantially lessening competition was used, and that also accumulated a substantial body of legal precedent which has given it a degree of certainty. The Committee held the view that:
Changes to section 50 should not be introduced lightly. This is because amendments to the Trade Practices Act may well bring about uncertainty which should not be readily risked.
It went on to say:

On the other hand, if reform is needed, it should be made unless the harm caused by it outweighs the good obtained. The Committee considers that change is needed to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act and that the benefit likely to flow from it will clearly outweigh any detriment that may arise.

In making the recommendation that the test be changed, the Committee paid a great deal of heed to the work of Professor Michael Porter. Briefly, Professor Michael Porter argues that internal competition is more beneficial in getting industry more competitive in international markets than the mere size of industry. Much has been made of the fact that Professor Michael Porter's work does not include a specific study on Australian industry. However, Australia is not so different from other OECD countries and Professor Porter's work spans a lot of assessments in OECD countries of which we should take note.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Committee's recommendations should be taken very seriously indeed by the Government. We are going through a period where a lot of government enterprises are being privatised, and we must be careful that we do not exchange a public monopoly for a private monopoly. We must also be careful that, in a period of deregulation, the interests of consumers are protected. Last but not least, we must pay attention to Professor Porter's thesis that our international competitiveness will be best enhanced if we have competitive conditions obtaining in our domestic industries. I believe that, therefore, it must be a matter of some regret that some press reports seem to indicate that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is still considering whether or not the Government will adopt this recommendation. I trust that the decision has not yet been made and that the Attorney-General is open to argument on this issue.

As a final point, even if, on the basis of lessening competition without looking at any other factors, the decision is reached that a particular merger should not proceed, there is the possibility open—and this is anchored in the legislation—that, nevertheless, such a merger may be authorised if there is a net public benefit to be derived. I believe that that is a safety catch provision which should be taken into account.

Again, arguments have been led to the effect that this imposes a considerable burden on the companies seeking to merge or to take another company over. However, it seems to me that when a company engages in such an exercise, it will assess the industry, the possible markets and relative capacities. Therefore, the basic research and material that would need to be advanced to obtain authorisation is already collected and simply needs to be compiled. On these grounds, I would once again call on the Government to think very long and hard before this recommendation of the Committee is rejected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report on social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors: Government response

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this report the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs deals with the duties and responsibilities of company directors and notes that any change in the regulation of directors activities `must be warranted and a sensible balance must be found between measures necessary to promote corporate activity in a way which will be of benefit to all' and the individual interests of directors.

PARA.TAB: The report deals with the duties directors owe under company law to entities outside the company. The case law has in recent times imposed a duty on directors to creditors, and this is considered in chapter 5 of the report. The basis for this development is the closeness of the relationship between a company at times of insolvency or near insolvency and its creditors. Often at these times directors will have dealt with the assets of creditors rather than the assets of the company's owners. The courts have decided that in those circumstances directors owe duties to creditors.

In chapter 6, the Committee considers the interests of entities other than the company, the shareholders and creditors, and the extent to which directors are entitled to take account of extrinsic factors in their decision making. However, the main duty that directors owe is clearly to shareholders of the company. In this sense, they are the trustees of the company's activity and assets. The duty of directors in taking particular decisions in the marketplace has been the subject of considerable debate and legislation.

Recommendation 2 of the report is that a business judgment rule be introduced into Australian company law to set the objective standard, as recommended by recommendation 1, for a director's duty of care. This rule is currently part of American jurisprudence. The purpose of the rule is to provide special protection to directors who make informed business decisions; that is, directors who make a business judgment in good faith. However, the Government, in its response to the report, says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not at this stage convinced that it is appropriate to introduce in isolation this one aspect of American jurisprudence into the Australian law on directors' duties.

PARA.TAB: The draft currently placed on the public record for general discussion—the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992—deals with this matter in section 232 by listing a number of criteria which should be used in assessing whether a director has met the obligation which would otherwise be expressed in the business judgment rule. The items listed for criteria include the following. The information that the officer has required; the meetings that the officer has attended; how far the officer has exercised an active discretion in the matters concerned; what the officer did to ensure that the corporation made adequate arrangements; what arrangements have been made to ensure that decisions made by one person on the corporation's behalf were in fact adequately monitored; and what arrangements were made to ensure that persons who have made decisions on the corporation's behalf had adequate information about the subject matter of the decisions.

It has been argued recently by corporate lawyers and business organisations that this black letter law, in specifically describing the criteria that must be met before a director is judged to have met his obligations and discharged his duty of care, is too onerous and too detailed. However, since it merely describes—admittedly in some detail—the criteria that could be used in assessing what a discharging of a particular director's duty is, I cannot help feeling that these criticisms are misplaced and that this enumeration is helpful.

The other area which has come under criticism is that of loans to directors. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has indicated that he might consider changing the fairly detailed black letter requirements in the draft legislation to one that is more general and enables some discretion in its interpretation. I would caution against law that is too fuzzy, if I can use that expression. In the 1980s we experienced a period where the corporate cowboys brought our business world and its practices into disrepute. I believe that we should encourage the Attorney-General to bring into this House legislation directed towards rectifying and preventing such behaviour in the future to restore the reputation of our businessmen in the eyes of the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the final report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure with respect to the proposal for a very fast train. It is surprising to note how Australia seems to have forgotten the very fast train project in the past six or seven months. I will later suggest why I believe that interest has disappeared.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry was brought about to consider the very fast train proposal from Sydney to Melbourne. It was to decide on either the sea route or the inland route. In time the project was to have been extended to Brisbane and Adelaide, though I doubt whether it ever would have reached Perth. There are various reasons why this proposal could go ahead. In the limited time that I have available to me on this report, I will address the topic as to how the Committee saw the project and refer to some of its final recommendations.

The Committee recommended that a project such as this could proceed without government assistance. I believe that would have been the way to go. That does not mean that that should preclude taxation incentives—not necessarily a tax holiday but, say, a tax deferral system such as that used in other parts of the world. This project has often been compared with the Snowy River scheme and the North West Shelf gas line. These sorts of projects take a lot of finance to get off the ground but, even though these things can be done by private enterprise, government can play a role in getting them underway.

The Committee's terms of reference did not cover all the aspects of the very fast train proposal. As the inquiry continued, more terms of reference could have been added, but the inquiry could not go on for ever. The inquiry started off on the basics of the very fast train proposal and progressed to some very fine detail.

The proponents may yet decide—and this report is fairly old now—that the project is not to proceed. Indeed, I understand they have decided not to proceed at present as the project is not financially viable at the moment. In my view the project is not proceeding at present because of the recession. A recession of this kind has been unheard of since the 1930s, but we are starting to get beyond that point—even Senator Collins would admit that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you complaining about, Senator? We have got the inflation rate down to the same level as your IQ.

—Senator Collins says that the inflation rate is down, but does anyone know the temperature of a dead body? There is no blood pressure or high temperature in a dead body—when it is gone, it is gone. Inflation is down because the economy has been ruined owing to the actions of the present Government.
—You just don't know where to put the thermometer.

—Senator Aulich does not know too much about what goes on in Tasmania, let alone anywhere else. Because we are in a recession, this worthwhile project need not be shelved for ever. The Committee put a lot of work into a report which will find its way onto a lot of shelves. The economy undoubtedly will pick up under a Hewson government. At that time, with the expansion of industry, the expansion of population and the expansion of the economy of Australia, I believe this project can be looked at again. A lot of the groundwork—whether financial, basic engineering or high-tech engineering—has already been done. In future different proponents will be able to pick up the project and cause it to take off. The inquiry could have gone on forever and a day; terms of reference would have been added as more problems or benefits from a very fast train arose over the years.

PARA.TAB: Four governments were involved in the original reference—the Victorian Government, the New South Wales Government, the ACT Government and the Federal Government. They worked together pretty well. I hope that those four governments do not forget the project altogether in years to come. Irrespective of whatever happens to the project in the future—whether it goes ahead in the next 10 years or not—I believe that some valuable work has been done. Processes like this open the eyes of governments, industries and all sorts of other organisations around Australia to what can be done with technology and transport. The Snowy River scheme, the North West Shelf gas line and, in 1903, the Kalgoorlie water supply were all big projects that were mooted but sat there waiting for someone to have a go.

Mr Ernie Bridge, the Minister for Water Resources in Western Australia, has a concept of bringing water down from the north-west. Many people are criticising that proposal, but I am certainly not criticising it. It was not totally his idea, but he is the latest person to run with it. I wish Mr Bridge good luck. He has been criticised by many people, including my colleagues in Western Australia. In time, that project will be implemented. None of us in this chamber will be around to see it, but I believe that a project like that will get under way. The same will happen with the VFT. I believe that when we have the right population, the right economy and the right sort of government in Australia, that project will get off the ground.

By American and English standards, our airways are not cluttered. However, one would think the opposite with the current condition of Sydney airport. If members of this Federal Government got off their backsides and did something about the third runway, things would improve there.

The need for a very fast train, something similar to those projects in other parts of the world, between Sydney and Melbourne and later to Adelaide, will arise and the opportunity will exist. Hopefully, the work that has been done by this Committee will have a bearing on that opportunity in time to come. I commend the Committee for the work it did. I was only a member of the Committee towards the end when I became a token replacement for Senator Reid. I recognise her work on that Committee. I congratulate the Committee on the way it carried out the inquiry and the recommendations and the report it produced. As I said, it will be a valuable piece of research to be looked at in time to come.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Childs:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On 7 November 1990, the Senate referred the issue of anti-dumping and countervailing legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. This was as a result of an inquiry initiated by Senator Ron Boswell, who at that stage had a well developed sense of protection towards Australia's industries.

PARA.TAB: Over the following several months, the Industry, Science and Technology Committee made a very thorough inquiry of all the people who claimed to have been affected. Evidence was heard from organisations and people such as the dairy farmers of Victoria; the Australian Dairy Industry Conference; the canned fruit industry of Australia; Castle Bacon Pty Ltd; the Food and Beverage Importers Association; the National Industry Associations Anti-Dumping Task Force; horticultural growers; titanium dioxide pigment manufacturers; the Victorian State Government; the Society for Balanced Free Trade; the Winemakers Federation of Australia; the United Farmers and Stockowners; citrus growers; the Dried Fruits Association; Murray citrus growers; Berrivale Orchards Ltd; the South Australian Canning Fruit Growers Association; Murray Valley Citrus Marketing Board; canegrowers; the Navy Bean Marketing Board; Connor Shea Napier Ltd; Queensland Pork Producers State Council; the Australian Customs Service; the National Farmers Federation; the Metal Trades Industry Association; apparel importers; the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association; the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the cement industry; pasta producers; CSR; and others. It was a very thorough inquiry.

We took evidence from all these people who had or believed that they had experience of dumping or countervailing. We heard all sorts of different reasons as to why they suffered or believed they suffered. I really believe that by the time the inquiry finished, the Committee members were well and truly assured that the main problem that had arisen was the variation in the value of the Australian dollar relative to our trading partners.

I believe that most of the troubles we suffer in our trade are linked entirely to the value of our dollar. While I certainly would not want to talk the dollar down, it is very clear to everybody who watches the trade weighted index of our dollar that the figure at which it is now on the market is quite unrealistic. If the dollar were priced in relation to our trade weighted index, our trading position would improve markedly overnight.

I feel tremendously sorry for many of those whom I have mentioned—the sugar, fruit and dairy people and the small industries which make specific things and which find that it is possible to have similar goods dumped on our doorstep by overseas countries. The end of the line processing, whereby a certain amount left over in a country is just sent overseas so that that country can get what it can, may wreck an industry.

There is also predatory dumping. Countries are carefully looked at with a view to seeing where a product can be discharged onto a market to slowly but surely erode that home market and destroy it. At present, this may be what has happened to the asparagus market. It has certainly happened with much of the apparel and footwear industries and with various machine tools and engines and so on in that line.

Of all the things that we deal with in this Parliament, nothing is more difficult to deal with than dumping. In the world of trade and commerce, nothing is more difficult to cope with than dumping. It is so hard to see and prove. I hear of many people who have, or who believe they have, problems involving dumping. We have to look at them very carefully. What is most difficult is that those claims have to be dealt with expeditiously. That is not easy either. It takes time to make thorough investigations. There are often times when what looks like dumping is not; it may be variations of costs or values in other places and other reasons. So it goes on.

The Committee made various recommendations about the manner in which this issue should be dealt with. We came to the conclusion that there were variations in the procedures which could be attended to and that we should continue our efforts through GATT to get a more responsible attitude by other countries on how this should be handled. We believe that the system of dealing through Customs and the dumping authority was too clumsy; there was no need to be dealing with two different authorities in the one area. I believe that the time factors recommended looked all right at that stage. However, I am pleased to say that the coalition's recently publicised dumping policy provides for an even shorter time. I am sure that it can be met and still provide all the justice that is necessary for both sides.

It is clear to the Committee that there is still room for improvement in the legislation. It will still be possible for us to make it less attractive for people to dump produce into Australian markets for whatever reason. The Committee recommended that the Customs Service be empowered to conduct confidential examinations of dumping complaints using information suppressed or aggregated on confidentiality grounds where complainants can demonstrate there is sufficient evidence that dumping is occurring. This is not possible at present. But this recommendation gives us an opportunity to get at the books and the figures that would otherwise be impossible to get at. We recommended that there be a review of the application of confidentiality provisions to the import statistics.

We went to several places and we interviewed a lot of witnesses here in Parliament House. We made field inspections in various States. We brought down this report in June 1991. For anybody interested or involved in the dumping or countervailing area, the report is quite a helpful reference. As far as the Government is concerned, the Committee's report shows that there are ways to improve the handling of dumping or countervailing problems in the community. All in all, I think it was a very useful exercise. The members of the Committee found it a very helpful and educative process to delve into this subject to the depth that we did. Anybody involved in industry and commerce or in law or accounting would find it beneficial to get a copy of this report and read it from cover to cover. It is well worth while.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly address the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. My remarks will be directed towards the anti-dumping measures. Perhaps the history books will record that this week was the week of tariffs and, more particularly, sugar tariffs. On 1 July the Government is going to decrease the tariff on sugar from $77 to $55. The legislation to do this was put in place some 12 months ago. As 1 July approaches, the focus is coming back to this tariff reduction and Queensland sugar growers are letting the rest of Australia know what their problems are.

PARA.TAB: Even though the time taken to bring in anti-dumping action has been far too long, I believe that an improved anti-dumping system will have its future in Australia. It will be more important as tariffs continue to be removed.

In the past 12 months or two years, we have heard how different organisations and industries around Australia are being affected by dumped products on the world market. We are told that the world price for sugar is corrupt. There are signs that that is the case. So rather than keep the tariff in place, we should introduce anti-dumping measures.

We have heard from banana growers, pea growers, tomato growers and pineapple growers. A tomato cannery in Cowra is closing down this week or next week. The big issue for the last few years, which Senator Cook may know something about, has been the pig producers' complaint on imported pig meat from Canada. I know that all of the problems that the industries have told us about are alive and well. They are really there.

The way the Australian Government is going, those industries will not be able to get their internal costs down as they will under the Hewson package. At the present moment we have a Labor government which is not changing the economic strategy so as to get those internal costs down. When tariffs are removed and these industries are exposed to the world market, they have problems. In the short term that is where anti-dumping will have a part to play. I suggest to the sugar industry that where there are problems, anti-dumping is the way to go, especially until we can get around to lowering the internal costs which are stopping Australian industries from competing with the rest of the world.

Senator Archer pointed out that small industries in Australia—not big by world standards—like tomatoes, peas, pineapples and asparagus, can be wiped out in 12 months. A company that has a surplus can target Australia and dump its goods here this year and that Australian industry will be wiped out. Next year, perhaps that company does not have a surplus to dump, or it finds somewhere else to dump where it may get more money for its goods, but the Australian industry will have been wiped out. It means that the prices for those goods to the consumer would treble from the previous year.

It is very important for anti-dumping actions to be taken the right way and that we have a good system put in place so that if an industry needs protection from corrupt world prices, that can be done. In the past 12 months we have told the sugar industry, the banana industry, the pea growers and the tomato growers that anti-dumping is the way to go. When it comes to other industries, I wish the Government would practice what it preaches.

I turn to the importation of second-hand cars from Japan and other parts of the world. Senator Button told us emphatically, in answer to a backbench question from Senator Foreman, that he would protect the Australian car industry—whether new or second-hand—to the nth degree. He would put in place a $12,000 tariff. If that measure is not enough—he would like to make it higher—he would find some other measure to keep those imported second-hand cars out of Australia. Why has he not told them? The other day I shouted across the chamber, `Send them out to anti-dumping'. His answer was, `That shows you what you know about anti-dumping'.

If the second hand car industry—and such cars are value added in Australia—needs protection, is not anti-dumping the way to go? I know it will take 12 months or more to put the anti-dumping system in place, but why not go out there—and Senator Foreman may like to tell me why the Government does not go out there—and take that action? Then see whether there is a tariff. I do not know why it is not an ad valorem rate instead of a flat figure of $12,000, but I believe we are dealing with only one type of vehicle, so I suppose a flat figure would be as good as any. So we will forgive Senator Button for that.

The chemical industry sometimes takes anti-dumping action. Even though it does not manufacture chemicals in Australia—it gets the base component from the United States and mixes it with a solution here—the industry behaves as though it manufactures the chemical and demands tariffs on other imports.

This second-hand car industry was importing good five-year-old second-hand cars from Japan, which is much less than the age of the average car in Australia. During Estimates, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce could not tell us the average age of cars in Australia, even though it recommended against letting these cars in.

The Government believes that these prices are a result of anti-dumping measures. Japan, for instance, has a limit of five years in which one can register a car. It can be registered for longer, but there are punitive measures in the way of licences if one wishes to do so. That may depress the market for those cars. Who says that they are being dumped? Why will the Minister not tell the Australian car industry to do the same and go down the anti-dumping track? Not having the fortitude to send them out to anti-dumping, I presume that the Industry Commission or the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce would have had a far-reaching inquiry to find out why the car industry needs $12,000 if they are being dumped. At Estimates we were told that it did not carry out an inquiry.

Where do we go? What will it be next week? Will we be importing second-hand engines, tyres or new tyres? We will just go on and on. I suggest to the Government that if it wants to get the rural industry to take anti-dumping action instead of imposing tariffs—I believe tariffs should be cut out by the year 2000, as is our policy—why not send the car industry or any other industry, such as the motorbike industry or the tractor industry, to anti-dumping if it is frightened of second-hand machines coming in? I commend the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
