DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Registration and Declaration of Senators' Interests

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate adopt the following resolution relating to the registration and declaration of Senators' interests, such resolution to continue in force unless amended or revoked by the Senate in this or a subsequent Parliament:
Declaration of Senators' interests

SPEECH.PARA: 1.(1)That, within 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation of allegiance as a Senator, each Senator shall provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of—
(a)the Senator's registrable interests; and
(b)the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware
(i)of the Senators' spouse; and
(ii)of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support,

in accordance with this resolution and in a form determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time, and shall also notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar within 28 days of that alteration occurring.
(2)Any Senator who—
(a)knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests by the due date;
(b)knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring; or
(c)knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interests,
shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly.
Registrable interests

2.That the statement of a Senator's registrable interests to be provided by a Senator shall include the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware (a) of the Senator's spouse; and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and shall cover the following matters:
(i)shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(ii)family and business trusts and nominee companies-
(a)in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

(b)in which the Senator, the Senator's spouse, or a child who is wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, is a trustee (but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children), indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(iii)real estate, including the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(iv)registered directorships of companies;
(v)partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership;
(vi)liabilities, indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(vii)the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(viii)saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(ix)the nature of any other assets (excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5,000;
(x)the nature of any other substantial sources of income;

(xi)gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources, provided that a gift received by a Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be registered unless the Senator judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist;
(xii)any sponsored travel or hospitality received;
(xiii)membership of any organisation; and
(xiv)any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
Register and Registrar of Senators' Interests
3.That-

(a)at the commencement of each Parliament, and at other times as necessary, the President shall appoint an officer of the Department of the Senate as the Registrar of Senators' Interests and that officer shall also be Secretary of the Committee of Senators' Interests;

(b)the Registrar of Senators' Interests shall, in accordance with procedures determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests, maintain a Register of Senators' Interests in a form to be determined by that Committee from time to time;

(c)as soon as possible after the commencement of each Parliament, the Chairman of the Committee of Senators' Interests shall table in the Senate a copy of the completed Register of Senators' Interests and shall also table from time to time as required any notification by a Senator of alteration of those interests; and
(d)the Register of Senators' Interests shall be available for inspection by any person under conditions to be laid down by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time.
Declaration of interest in debate and other proceedings

4.That, notwithstanding the lodgment by a Senator of a statement of the Senator's registrable interests and the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware (a) of the Senator's spouse; and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and the incorporation of that statement in a Register of Senators' Interests, a Senator shall declare any relevant interest—
(a)at the beginning of his or her speech if the Senator participates in debate in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House, and

(b)as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House if the Senator proposes to vote in that division, and
the declaration shall be recorded and indexed in the Journals of the Senate or minutes of proceedings of the committee and in any Hansard report of those proceedings or that division,
but it shall not be necessary for a Senator to declare an interest when directing a question seeking information in accordance with standing order 72 or 74.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 26 March.
Clause 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 is a sad and sorry tale of government intransigence. It is a case of unbalanced reporting of the issues in my home State in Tasmania, so much so that my colleagues and I spent thousands of dollars to get some of the unreported story told to our constituents by way of advertisements. It perhaps says something about the power of mighty companies in Australia. It also says a lot about the importance of this pulp mill to the economy of my State, whereby jobs are so desperately needed for young Tasmanians in particular that the pulp mill would almost be accepted on any terms in order to try to turn around our economy.

PARA.TAB: Those of us who represent the State of Tasmania here have a responsibility not only to represent the State and its interests but also to act as members of a house of review. This legislation is totally unacceptable in its present form. As members of a house of review scrutinising government legislation, we were honour bound not to allow it to go through in its original form and in its existing form, unfortunately.

Over many months negotiations have gone on and attempts have been made by the Opposition to have the Government look again at its legislation. In this we were supported by the industry, which recognised that only a handful of major pulp mills stood to get any benefit from the protection that was supposedly provided under this legislation.

Despite the fact that practically everybody who looked at the legislation wanted it changed, the Government was not even prepared to consider the matter. When we compare that with the way legislation is routinely treated in this place, a way is usually found for majority views to be accommodated and for amendments to be put into place which will lead to an improvement in the legislation, which will facilitate industry and which will lead to consensus amongst the political parties. That is the normal way that things happen in this place, although the press would have people believe otherwise.

It is extraordinary that this piece of legislation was somehow cut out for very special treatment. I am glad to see that it is acknowledged by the adviser to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who has just managed to slip him a wink. We know very well that the Government had another agenda on this legislation. That is very sad. As I said earlier—Senator Aulich would realise this only too well—the jobs of Tasmanians are involved in this and it is too important for governmental games.

The negotiations creaked along to little or no effect until such time that the matter came up for second reading debate in this place and the Senate decided to send the legislation to a committee. Mr Temporary Chairman, you would recall that that Committee took evidence over three days. I was there to hear all the witnesses. One of the things that was so noticeable was that on the first day every single witness told the Committee that this legislation needed to be amended. The second interesting thing about that first day of evidence was how the Tasmanian newspapers did not print a single word of that evidence. Any Tasmanian not getting mainland newspapers would have no idea that anybody other than the five Tasmanian Liberal senators believed that this legislation was crook. But in fact the ACTU, the major union representing the forest industry workers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one is that?
—It is the one consisting of about four words; Senator Aulich knows the one I mean. I forget its initials. Mr Murphy will fill him in and help him as well as me.
—He is always helpful.

—Yes, he is always helpful. He takes people's places in Senate tickets too, I understand. The ACTU, the major union involved, the National Association of Forest Industries, Petersville-Sleigh, which operates a number of major forestry concerns in our State, and APPM all acknowledged that this legislation was very flawed and needed amending.

PARA.TAB: APPM was honest enough to say that, despite the fact that the legislation needed amendment, it was all right for its purposes and APPM would accept it as it was. I recognise that the commercial necessities of life tend to make corporations look to the narrow self-interest, so I do not aim to be casting blame on APPM. But APPM was at least prepared to acknowledge publicly that it would be the only beneficiary of the legislation. That was something that the Government has consistently refused, until recently, to acknowledge.

Some of the things that we have had to advertise in the Tasmanian newspapers about the failure of this legislation are: that the legislation provides no compensation if resources are taken away by the Commonwealth; that there is no resource security for sawmillers; that there is no provision in the legislation for State or regional forest industry plans; and that Canberra will have increased powers on land use matters.

Over the last decade or so in Tasmania we have had a very sorry tale to tell with respect to Canberra's involvement in our land use, and any thinking Tasmanian would be very wary of allowing something to go through in a defective form in this place for the sake of one project if it meant that Canberra's land use powers were going to be increased. We have suffered too much for too long to grasp the immediate benefit for the sake of long term damage.

We continued, on this side, to hold out for an improvement to the legislation, believing that the Government could not be prepared to play politics to the wire on this important legislation. We have tried everything we could to get the Government to change its mind on this. Then, after Easter, the National Association of Forest Industries received a letter from the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). The letter that was initiated by him straight after Easter proposed a meeting with the industry association. There have been some speeches earlier in the day trying to muddy the water on this, but the initiative after Easter came from the Government.

Mr Griffith's office arranged a meeting with the industry for Monday of this week. The Minister suggested that he should have negotiations with the industry and he set out the parameters within which he could negotiate. He said that he would have to go back to Cabinet for approval, but he indicated that he felt it was within his scope to negotiate. Two days of negotiations led to an agreement by Tuesday afternoon of this week. The agreement was between Mr Griffiths, the National Association of Forest Industries, Forest Industries Association of Tasmania, the Tasmanian Government and the Forestry Protection Society.

After the agreement was reached, the National Association of Forest Industries took that agreement to the Opposition on Tuesday afternoon of this week. The Opposition indicated informally that it would receive a positive response, and NAFI indicated this to the Government. Mr Griffith's office then said that a formal letter would come from the Government to the Opposition seeking formal endorsement to the agreement. NAFI was once told that the formal letter was 15 minutes away. There were a number of other promises about when it would be received, and then the Association of Forest Industries was told that the Government would not support the agreement; that was yesterday afternoon.

Mr Lloyd's endeavours in this matter were purely in response to the Minister, Mr Griffiths. Mr Lloyd was not offering concessions; they were being negotiated between the Government and the industry and they were endorsed by the Opposition after agreement was reached.

That agreement was in writing by the Minister responsible for resources; the Minister responsible for this legislation. Yet when the Minister went to his leadership he was left in the lurch, he was not supported, and I remind the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) who is at the table just what that means for the future. It is no longer just a question of resource security. The question is: does anybody in this country in the future have any confidence on any negotiations or agreements reached with a Minister in this Government? The agreement was believed by all the parties including the Minister to be a firm agreement in writing.

Who can believe this Government or any Minister in future? There is a Minister, holding himself out to be operating within the parameters for which he had an entitlement to negotiate: negotiating a position; putting it in writing; having it endorsed by the Opposition as well as the industry; and then being dumped by his Prime Minister because of the pull and power of the left wing faction of the Labor Party. This means that nobody can trust any agreement negotiated with a Minister in this Government again. Does Senator Cook have authority to negotiate as Minister Griffiths negotiated? When can anybody trust the word of a Minister in the Keating Government again?

It is an extremely serious allegation, as I am sure the Minister will realise. That is why the Minister should let his Government consider this very seriously over this weekend because it is no longer just a question of resource security; it is a question of the reputation and the credibility of the Keating Government. It will have an extremely difficult job to do in the year ahead if its word and the word of its Ministers cannot be relied upon. This is an important piece of legislation for my State, but it has now become a very important piece of legislation for the credibility and the trustworthiness of this Government.

Many people in this country would like to get rid of this Government right now. Sadly, until Mr Keating calls an election, they will not have that opportunity. But the events of the last few days over this piece of legislation are but one more nail in the coffin of this Government because, when a government has lost its credibility, with what does it clothe itself?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that I follow Senator Newman as a Tasmanian senator and one who is particularly intrigued by the demeanour of Senator Newman tonight, compared with the usual rambunctious, argumentative and dominating type of approach that she normally takes. She is, in fact, extremely subdued tonight, and I think she has a very good reason. For the first time she has found that opposing government legislation has not borne the appropriate political support that she thought she would get.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is good. It appropriately will achieve what the Government wants to do. Senator Newman has some problem with it. She has a problem with it primarily because the Government brought it in. A Labor Government did something which allows an industry, and conservationists for that matter, to know the procedures. At least the procedures are laid down so that people can process an application, a project, in an orderly way and in a way that is predictable and gives people of all persuasions and interests the opportunity to have their say. That, in itself, is an achievement.

Why does Senator Newman oppose the legislation? I still have not worked out why. She finds that most people do not share her views. Somehow or other she is unable to get through to the community at large her real reason for opposing Labor Government legislation. So what does she do? She blames unbalanced reporting in her home State of Tasmania. Is this not wonderful?

Senator Newman, who is now about to walk out of the chamber because she cannot stand the heat, blames the newspapers in Tasmania. I have never heard her blame the media in Tasmania before because, on the whole, in the past they looked after her party pretty well, as I found out after 15 years in politics in that State. But on this issue, Senator Newman finds that the newspapers north and south do not agree with her. How naughty of them! So she blames the newspapers to begin with and the media as a whole. `Unbalanced reporting', she says.

Then Senator Newman makes personal remarks about the various members of this Senate. She says that I do not live in Tasmania. Yet at least three letters from Senator Newman seem to have arrived in my letterbox over the last couple of years saying nice things about my home town and so on. And yet Senator Newman says that I do not live there. She is leaving again. She cannot stand the heat so she gets out of the kitchen.

Senator Newman makes personal remarks about advisers in this place. Quite frankly, I find that pretty inappropriate. The gestures, the mannerisms and the seating position of advisers are not matters for senators in this place to comment on. Those advisers do not have the opportunity to reply. I do not mind what Opposition senators say about other senators in this place, provided that it is within Standing Orders, but it is inappropriate and unfair to talk about an adviser in this place. Senator Newman has done that. She is leaving the chamber because she cannot bear to listen to the issues being discussed. She also tries to browbeat North Broken Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: Senator Newman has had to go out for other reasons—to attend a meeting. I do not think a slur should be directed at anyone for leaving the chamber when Senator Aulich is speaking. It would obviously be a great relief for anybody to leave the chamber.

—On the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: there is no point of order. This is a pretence. An opportunity has been seized under the disguise of taking a point of order to make a political point. This debate would be helped if senators opposite would confine themselves to Standing Orders.
—On the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: if somebody leaves the chamber for any reason at all, it is a slur to say that that person has left the chamber because he or she cannot stand the heat.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! There is no point of order. It might be judged by some to be tasteless to ascribe motives for people's personal conduct in and out of the chamber but it is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. Once again, we have a cheap attempt to interrupt what I am saying. So we get back to the response of Senator Newman to the fact that everyone does not believe everything she says. What does she try to do? She and others try to browbeat North Broken Hill. They try to take on a company and say, `You aren't supporting us. You should support us. After all, we are Liberals. We support capitalist enterprises and you should therefore support us per se'. That is the sort of thinking that belonged to the Melbourne Club in 1930. It does not belong in Australia of 1992.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators can make as much noise as they like but the simple fact is that I am going to have my say on this one. I have listened to them for long enough. I have listened to the noises they have made in the newspapers and looked at their paid advertisements. Their points are not getting through because they are not making them consistently or intelligently. That is the reason the media and most of the industry at the moment do not particularly like what members of the Opposition are saying and why the coverage they are getting is very poor indeed.

Senator Newman then goes on, having attacked advisers, the media, North Broken Hill, me and other honourable senators in this chamber, to blame the left unions—the old bogey. We have moved from the 1930s of the Melbourne Club approach to the 1950s Menzies approach—we blame the left unions for this legislation.

The simple fact is that this legislation has been introduced because it is a logical and fair way to approach this issue. Those people who live in States where there has not been a veritable civil war going on in terms of the use of natural resources ought to look at the Tasmanian situation where, over the years, all the political parties have made a proper mess of it. Opposition senators can come in here and blame one political party or another. But the simple fact is that the politics of Tasmania have not been good in terms of sensible, long term decisions being made about the proper uses of natural resources in that State.

For example, Senator Newman talks about the intervention of the Federal Government in these matters. If the Federal Government had not intervened, we would have had a billion dollar dam on our hands which very few people would need. In other words, we have sufficient power in Tasmania to meet the needs of industry. Yet the Opposition was totally in favour of building that dam. Senator Watson and former Senator Peter Rae were the only ones with any sense to look at the whole thing and say, `That dam would have been an economic and environmental disaster'. So, with the exception of Senator Watson, their track record on major issues relating to resource development has not been a particularly good one.

It is all very well for Senator Newman to come in here and blame the left wing unions; to blame the Tasmanian media for being anti-Liberal, for heaven's sake; and to blame the advisers and everyone around the place. The simple fact is she has no rational argument that she can use to oppose this legislation. If Senator Newman opposes the legislation simply because it is brought forward by a Labor Government, she ought to say so. She ought to say, `Look, I am voting against it because of my political prejudices and because I believe that people I thought were my friends in industry will not support me'. She should give some real reason appropriate to the particular approach that she is taking.

In Tasmania we have looked at how one should strike that balance, year in year out, between the proper use of natural resources, protection of the environment and the development of the State to create jobs. It is not an easy task because there are conflicting and sometimes irreconcilable differences. But those differences will only be reconciled if people of goodwill from all political parties get together on this issue.

Yet we find that the views, for example, of the Liberal Premier of Tasmania, Ray Groom, have been totally ignored by the five Tasmanian Liberal Senators. They have simply said, `Stay out of it. This is a chance for us to have a go at the Labor Government in Canberra'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where you live.

—Are we back to that again? Senator Newman then ought to stop sending letters to my home address if she says I do not live in Tasmania. And Senator Watson ought not send letters to my address because I get them from him as well. So let us not go through that again. That is one of the cheapest tricks in the book. Let us get back to the issue.
—Clarify that, go on!

—I have had letters from Senator Watson which have been sent to my home address. Let us get back to this issue. There are people waiting in the community. Businesses, developers, investors and conservationists are waiting for this Parliament to finally lay down a proper order for the approval, or the gaining of approval, of major resource development in this country. Although not perfect, this legislation does as well as any legislation could.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators have a responsibility to examine that legislation without political prejudice, to set aside their political prejudices and to join with the Government. They are being universally criticised by the Tasmanian media, by the union movement, by the Liberal State Premier of Tasmania and by major industries in that State. Surely it ought to be getting through to them that they have taken the wrong path. They have done so out of political prejudice. They have taken the opportunity to score points rather than work their way through this legislation. If they had started with the right attitude that they wanted to make this thing work, it might have helped. But they started with the attitude that they simply wanted to make trouble for this Government.

I do not put all Liberal senators in that category. I exclude Senator Watson from that statement. He is a person who genuinely tries to work through the issues, who in fact has a better knowledge of economic realities than the majority of his comrades over there, and who in some ways has been railroaded by his colleagues—other people, noisier people—in the Tasmanian Liberal senator faction.

The Tasmanian Liberal senator faction has stopped being the voice of the developers in Tasmania, because there are many sensible developers in that State who are fed up with the Liberal senators. The demeanour of Senator Newman tonight was a very good example of the effect of this behaviour. Liberal senators know that they went down the wrong track. The Liberal Premier in Tasmania has told them so, as have many of their Party members, yet they still do not get the point. It is not only that they are attempting to save pride; they are simply not prepared to look at this issue on its merits and go with us on this Bill.

This Parliament needs the support of those opposite in order to bury once and for all this endemic civil war that we have been having in Tasmania on the use of natural resources. If we do not do something about this matter in the next year or so, it will go on and on in that State to the detriment of the people who believe in conserving their natural resources, those who believe in developing them, and those who take the middle position. The people of Tasmania are with politicians and the way we are handling this issue. In increasing numbers the people are saying so. Tasmanian politics, particularly in the State Parliament, is polarised to the level where it is becoming a laughing-stock; where neither of the two major political parties seem to be able to galvanise the community behind them. There is a very good reason for that, and that has been shown by the attitude that those opposite have taken here tonight on this particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on something of a point of order. I believe that you, Senator Crichton-Browne, have been extremely tolerant, as were your predecessors in the Chair this morning. We have been debating this matter for quite a number of hours and as yet the first proposed amendment by the Opposition has not been formally put. Most of the debate that has gone on so far, with the indulgence of all senators, has concerned the substantive issues regarding the 17 other amendments that the Opposition wishes to put.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that it would be appropriate if the Opposition were to put its first amendment, which is simply on the title of the Bill—the replacement of one word with two other words—and then allow us to get formally into the proper debate which really relates to the 17 other amendments which the Opposition quite rightly wants to debate. Most of the remarks that have been made so far on both sides have not really been related in any way to the amendment that is about to be put. I would invite you the Chair to ask Senator Tambling to put that amendment formally so that we can get past that and get onto the substantive matters that the Opposition wishes to debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has put a reasonable proposition to me, but we do have before us clause 1 and the Standing Committee's report. That gives a greater latitude than would normally be the case. However, I am very conscious of the point Senator Coulter has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the title of the Bill rather than to the point of order raised by Senator Coulter. However, before discussing the short title—which is that `This Act may be cited as the Forest Conservation and Development Act 1991'—I have a point to make about Senator Tambling's proposed amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 1, page 1, omit `development', substitute `major projects'.

I think it is quite right to put the matter in that way. On 26 March the Standing Committee on Selection of Bills referred this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. That Committee was set the fairly daunting task of examining the legislation, calling witnesses and reporting back to the Senate by 2 April. It was made very clear to me that this Bill would not give me or Senator Faulkner, as senators from New South Wales, or our State the resource security that hopefully was to be given to one specific project in Tasmania. That is the point that Senator Tambling, on behalf of the Opposition, is fairly making in his amendment that seeks to change the title of the Bill. If all honourable senators in this chamber had read the evidence, I believe that they would take the same view. They would say, `What will it do for all the other projects around Australia that seek resource security?'.

PARA.TAB: The Committee deliberated and deliberated and, having heard a fairly wide range of witnesses, eventually agreed. Before making any detailed comments about the validity of the evidence presented, I must note—as I did at the time—that it seems absurd that the conservation movement, in all its guises, was given several platforms at this inquiry and yet in each instance had the same spokesperson. Even Senator Coulter would agree that that was rather a pity. I do not think the Democrats were able to make their points to the Committee as clearly as would have occurred if they had had different people speaking on the different issues. Given the critical time frame, I thought that was foolish and I think they actually wasted the time of the Committee by having the same people speaking all the time.

As honourable senators will be aware, a number of senators—namely, Senator Calvert, Senator Crane and myself—moved a dissenting report. In that dissenting report we noted that we had the support of all Opposition Tasmanian senators. We disagreed with the main Committee on two issues. First, the Opposition amendments put to the Committee were a genuine attempt to provide appropriate legislation for the industry. Our amendments were supported by the industry. If accepted, they would have saved this Bill and made it meaningful for the overwhelming bulk of the forestry industries.

The second point was that the Bill be agreed to without amendment. Again, we had to disagree with the majority of Committee members. In our opposition we again had the support of the industry and the trade union movement. In fact, there was not one industry or union that actually supported the Bill as presented to the Committee. Any fairminded senator who read the evidence would reach the same conclusion.

I note the comment by the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, that he wanted this legislation to pass, even if flawed, so that it could be tested out in the community. I do not believe that it is our job in this place to allow legislation to be carried knowing that it is flawed and expecting the community to sort through its deficiencies. That is not the Senate's job. The Senate's job is to approve legislation that comes to this place if the House of Representatives has done the right thing. I do not want to be too parochial, but there are times when the Senate plays a magnificent role in the government of Australia because we sort out the badly framed legislation, fix it up and send it back to the House of Representatives for it to act on our improvements.

I think the attitude of the Minister is horrific if he expects people out in the community to check out the legislation to see if it does or does not work. I think that explains why so much legislation has been proposed by the Keating Labor Government and by its predecessor, the Hawke Government. The legislation has been faulty and this place has fixed it up. In most cases it has fixed it up in a way that has been a credit to members on both sides of this chamber. It is almost as though the Government has its very own job creation scheme in the rewriting of Bills. I do not think that is any way to run a government.

One point I did not make when I started to talk about the short title of this Bill was that the Minister made a comment to the chamber earlier tonight—Senator Cook, of course, was the Minister for Resources and, I believe, a worthwhile Minister for Resources—that the forests were a finite resource. If I am wrong I will apologise, but I am pretty sure I am right in saying that the Minister said that. The Minister, whom I admired for the job he did as far as the national soil conservation program is concerned, made a fatal error by saying that, because forests are not a finite resource, they are a renewable resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concede that.

—I think the Minister said earlier tonight that they were a finite resource. I was surprised to hear him say it because I know that he is a former Minister in this portfolio. That just did not strike quite true to his aspirations, the things he has said and the commonsense he spoke with when he was the Minister.

PARA.TAB: I will speak for a minute about Minister Griffiths. If one reads the paper—I believe what I read in the paper; it is not always completely correct, but in most cases it is reasonably correct and picks up the story, as we all know—one will see that it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Minister Griffiths was scuttled yesterday by the Minister for the Environment, Mrs Kelly, and the ALP Left.
It goes on to say:

After three days of intense negotiations, Mr Griffiths had stitched up a deal between the Opposition, formerly bitter opponents of the legislation, the forestry industry and the Tasmanian Government which involved only minor amendments. He was then told by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that he would also have to secure the agreement of Mrs Kelly and the left faction of the ALP before the deal could go ahead. Mrs Kelly and the Left took the opportunity to dump the legislation they had bitterly opposed when it was forced through the Cabinet by the then Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, last year.
Listen to this point:
Mr Keating, then Treasurer, also vehemently argued against the legislation at that Cabinet meeting.
So he has done a bit of a back flip. It continues:
After he became Prime Minister, Mr Keating announced during the Tasmanian election campaign, where the State ALP supported the plan, that the previous Cabinet decision would stand.
There is a bit of a change there, I think.

PARA.TAB: The point I would like to make is that Minister Griffiths went to the Forest Industry Association of Tasmania and he went to the Tasmanian Government. He also stitched up a deal with the Forest Protection Society which then went to the Opposition, to Mr Lloyd. Mr Lloyd then went back to Mr Griffiths to try to get a position so that this legislation could pass through this place. I know that Senator Tambling earlier here tonight has made the point—and has read out that negotiated agreement, or whatever people want to call it, that Mr Griffiths put together—that if that had been the case, that would have gone through here tonight.

That brings me back again to the short title of the Bill and the fact that it was going to be more project specific. In other words, the Bill was going to substitute for the word `Development' the words `major projects' which is the project people have been talking about in the State of Tasmania.

I do not personally believe that the flaw in this Bill is only in the title because I think it has omissions which are contained in quite a lot of other places as well. It is just as flawed as a lot of the other legislation, as I said earlier. I think the Government's total refusal to negotiate on Senator Tambling's proposed amendment really suggests a lack of commitment to the Bill, to the resource security and to the security of those employed in the industry and those who have invested in the industry. I quote again from the paper. I think it is Dr Robert Baume who said:

SPEECH.PARA: If this legislation fails in the Senate tomorrow and thousands of jobs are lost in the forest industry, it is 100 per cent the Government's fault. Mr Griffiths has been left out on a limb.

I do not know the Minister, Alan Griffiths, as well as I know the previous Minister, who is at the table at the moment, Senator Cook, but from dealings I have had with him, I think he is basically an honourable person. I feel very sorry that he has been scuttled by his own Party and by his Prime Minister who, as I said earlier, has done a couple of back flips as far as this is concerned.

PARA.TAB: This legislation ought not to be just about big businesses because the forest industry itself is not just about big operators. There are myriad small operators. Many senators in previous debates have quoted from letters that they have received from some of those small operators. If those small operators are to get resource security all over Australia in all their different ways, this legislation will not give it to them because the evidence we have heard does not do it, unfortunately, and that is the reason why I take my position on this side.

I heard all the evidence. Senator Cook gave evidence. I was obviously not entirely in agreement with him all the time. But I think if he looked into his eyes in the mirror in the morning or at night he would know in his own heart of hearts, having been a good former Minister for Resources, that he would have had some concerns about it as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some of the Hansards he asked us to consider it during the three weeks it went on and then Griffiths pulled it.
—Senator Tambling is correct.
—That's a good point.

—Yes, it is. The Committee hearings demonstrated time and time again that it was evident that the legislation was not going to do anything for those little people. That is the point we are trying to make. Minister Alan Griffiths, having received the Committee's report, must have realised the flaws in it. After all, even the ACTU opposed the Bill. The ACTU said that it is flawed, that it needs fixing up and that some things must be done.

PARA.TAB: I must say that it surprised me that Mr Robert Richardson, the Industrial Officer of the ACTU, attended. First of all, he gave very good evidence. That is the first thing that was noted. In his evidence, Mr Richardson summed up the view of probably everybody on all sides of the debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate immediately that if Senator Tambling wants the call I will yield and resume my seat. I think we are getting to a stage at which it is approaching the ridiculous that an amendment has been foreshadowed; it has not been put. To some extent the Senate is brought into disrepute if, in a matter that has been canvassed so widely and arduously over such as long time as this and for which there is a foreshadowed amendment, we do not even attract the foreshadowed amendment tonight. If the feeling of those in the Opposition camp is that somehow in some weird way over the weekend the Government will capitulate to its demands, I can assure them that that is a misguided view. Through you, Mr Chairman, I invite Senator Tambling to put forward his amendment tonight so that we have something before the Chair that can be dealt with.
—There are other speakers yet.

—Since the indication is that he does not intend to do that, I will take an extra minute to say that an interesting dialogue has been started by Senator Brownhill about forestry as a finite resource. I was not meaning it in the context that Senator Brownhill was implying, because his context is quite right. I meant finite in the sense that there is a maximum yield or cut that can be taken in perpetuity, but if one extends beyond that maximum yield of cut the resource will be degraded and run down. In that sense there is a finite resource. In the sense of taking it at replacement level, there is a sustained yield.
—It is a renewable resource.

—It is a renewable resource in that sense, but the point I was making earlier, where the contextual argument has arisen, is that if it is drawn upon at a higher rate than it can replenish itself then it is being degraded.
—But modern practices don't permit that.

—We could have a whole field of debate, but the Opposition wants to filibuster and I do not. I am simply replying to a question that was raised and I now resume my seat with the entreaty—I think the colloquial expression is `piss or get off the pot' but I have used that expression once before and been pulled up in this chamber—that it would help us if Senator Tambling would put forward his amendment tonight at the very least.

—I thank the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) for clarifying his definition of the word `finite'. I can assure the Minister that there has been no filibustering by me. A lot of evidence was given at that inquiry and it is good to debate it. That is what this place is about. The committee stage always gives us the opportunity to bring out all those points so that everyone can be very sure of them. There are many people in this place who do not always read every report that has had a lot of work put into it.

—I rise to speak in this debate for two reasons: first, as a member of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs; and, secondly, to make some observations on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill as far as it affects Western Australia. As far as I am aware, apart from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) who is from Western Australia, I have been the only Western Australian senator to get to his or her feet in this debate—and I do not do so to filibuster.

PARA.TAB: I compliment Minister Griffiths, the shadow Minister, Bruce Lloyd, and in particular Robert Bain of NAFI for the negotiated position that they reached. Having negotiated the changes to allow this legislation to go through—in fact they reflect the legislation—it has now been neutered by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), which is indeed very unfortunate. It demonstrates quite clearly that, whilst there is much talk of compromise and working out the best and most satisfactory solution for the various people involved, that has not been accepted in this case. Part of the Government itself has not accepted it; it is not the Opposition, the forestry industry or the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not actually saying something good about the trade union movement, are you? This is an historic moment.
—I often say good things about the trade union movement, as the Minister well knows, and I will say a few more good things about it in a few moments.
—Bob Richardson was interested in his own people.

—Yes, and we saw a very sensible, considerate and concerned Mr Bob Richardson. I shall come to some of the things he had to say later on. The Minister knows full well that there have been many times when I have complimented unions on certain actions they have taken and there have been times when I have criticised them. I acknowledge, without any trouble at all, that Mr Bob Richardson was there on behalf of the ACTU. If it makes the Minister feel any better, I will put out a press release complimenting Mr Bob Richardson for his performance, because he was quite rational and sensible.
—Would you sack him if we appointed him to the Industrial Relations Commission?
—I will not personally be sacking him.
—I just wonder how far this mutual admiration society goes.

—I am not bloody-minded. I take things at face value. I am quite entitled to do that and, what is more, I will continue to do it. I want to take this opportunity to acknowledge the work of Alan Griffiths with the National Association of Forest Industries and the work of our shadow Minister, Bruce Lloyd. If the Minister was still in that position, he would have probably done the same work and come to the same conclusion. In fact, I am certain he would have done so, because it was a sensible position to take. In essence, the agreement ensured that the legislation reflected the changes.

PARA.TAB: I now wish to talk a little about Western Australia. Charges have been made in here tonight by Senator Aulich. He was quite critical of politicians and the political process in Tasmania. In fact, the dead opposite has occurred in Western Australia in forestry development and management, such as the EHC-CALM agreement and its development. The forest is being managed in such a way that the various values of the forest are being preserved. For example, some wilderness areas have been put aside, there are national parks, areas for harvesting hardwood and wood chipping and a program of replanting.

The situation in Western Australia is quite different from the position which exists in Tasmania, as the Minister would know. In its current form, this legislation has little chance of giving any security to the forest industry in Western Australia. I want to dwell on that point for a moment. The forest industry in Western Australia is made up of a number of minor players. When I say `minor players' I am talking about $100m projects. There could well be $10m, $15m or $20m projects such as the operations of CALM and the on-farm forestry plantation program. I acknowledge the work of the Hon. Julian Grill. I was involved very extensively with him in putting together an on-farm forestry policy. That was accepted by him as Minister and now stands as the principles under which forestry will be developed on private farms in Western Australia.

The problem we have is that the suggestion that various projects can be put together to build up the $100m is totally unrealistic. In fact, it is not attainable or achievable, purely and simply because the various arms of the forestry industry in Western Australia are locked in competition. They compete with one another in their operations. It is just not practical or achievable to try to get competitors together and put their businesses into one. In fact, if they did, we would find that the productivity which currently exists in the forestry industry in Western Australia would diminish.

The other problem is that, as the Minister would be well aware, selected areas are being harvested in Western Australia. When the structure is looked at, the projects simply do not fit together. Various areas at different places are being harvested and planted in the forestry industry in Western Australia at different times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia is a good model.

—It is a good model; there is no question about that. That is how it should be done. Unfortunately, this legislation does not solve potential problems which could occur in Western Australia. I would hope in due course that legislation will be passed—certainly it will when we are in government—that would give resource security to each of those operators. I turn to the report itself and some of the evidence which was given to us. It is quite interesting to note that in all cases other than the conservation groups—
