DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Closure of Edgell Plant at Cowra

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to canvass issues which were televised tonight on the 7.30 Report relating to Pacific Dunlop's announcement of the closure of the Edgell plant at three sites in Australia. The one that concerns me most and the one that concerned the program is the Cowra factory.

PARA.TAB: This plant has been in this town for about 50 years, so its technology is World War II vintage. It is a plant that, for those of us who were born and who have grown up in the town from World War II onwards, has always been there. Yesterday Pacific Dunlop announced the closure of this plant. It did so because it has recently taken over the company, Adsteam, which was having financial difficulties, and has had to rationalise—which is an appropriate and sensible business decision—the factories within this food processing industry. This has left Cowra, Greenacre and Bairnsdale in Victoria to be closed.

More upsetting and more annoying, I think, is the fact that the 7.30 Report tonight could not let facts get in the way of a good story. I have to highlight some of the gross inaccuracies that were reported in this program. It talked about the dumping of tomatoes in Australia. It left one with the impression that the Federal Government only took action on this two days ago. That is either mischievous or displays a lack of knowledge of the subject or, if it was not unparliamentary, I would say it is a lie, but I have to find some other word to use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or all of them.

—It could be, or it could be playing politics by some other people as well. I draw honourable senators' attention to a Financial Review advertisement that appeared on Wednesday, 11 December 1991 for the Australian Customs Service. This was signed by Marion Estelle Grant, delegate of the Comptroller-General, and dated 5 December 1991. It is a preliminary finding into the alleged dumping and subsidisation of canned whole tomatoes, canned tomato pieces and canned crushed tomatoes in water or juice from Italy, Spain, Thailand and the People's Republic of China. The notice of inquiry was published on 27 August last year under a subsection of the Customs Act. A preliminary decision was made to take effect on or after 6 December 1981.

PARA.TAB: For those people who do not understand—and I take one of those to be Ben Cheshire of the ABC—that means that that is when the countervailing duties start to be applied. Therefore, from 6 December of last year there have been no dumped tomatoes from those places coming into this country. The crop for this season's tomatoes did not commence to be harvested in the Cowra area until January 1992. I would also add as a by-line that, of course, imported tomatoes do have tariff applied to them.

It is absolutely incorrect to say that we have no tariffs on this particular industry and that the tomatoes are being dumped, because quite clearly they are not being dumped and have not been dumped since 6 December last year. That, however, has not stopped honourable people around the place from asserting or giving people the impression that that is not the case. In an interview on this program we had Ben Cheshire saying that the Australian market, as every shopper knows, is being flooded with cheap subsidised tins—of tomatoes, I would presume—from Thailand, China and Europe. That is not accurate and I have just explained why it is not accurate, but he does not seem to have understood that.

This week we had an announcement from the Minister that the Anti-Dumping Authority had upheld the Customs Service's finding of dumping of canned tomatoes. What has now taken place is that anti-dumping and countervailing levies have been applied to tomatoes for three years. So the industry and those involved in processing of tomatoes in this country know that those countries that do import tomatoes into this country—China, Thailand, Italy and Spain—will not be able to import their tomatoes without countervailing dumping being applied. This, of course, means that these tomatoes are not dumped and have not been dumped since December of last year.

Those who are interested would also get the impression from this program that we take no action on any products as far as dumping goes. I would just like to remind honourable senators that, since early 1991, dumping has been found with canned ham from Ireland, the Netherlands and Denmark; canned peaches and pears from China, Spain and Greece; dried eggwhite from Sweden and the Netherlands; glace cherries from France and Ireland; and now we have tomatoes. That indicates to me that we have taken action against any countries which are proved to be dumping processed primary produce into this country.

If people care to read the Financial Review they will see that it is not uncommon to find preliminary dumping findings made by the Australian Customs Service. It happens, I would say, reasonably frequently and it belies the lies that are told and allegations that are made that this Government does not stop dumping. I think it is very important that we make sure that people know this.

The program dealt with Australia being the victim of world surpluses. There were allegations from Mr Armstrong, the New South Wales State Minister for agriculture, on the 7.30 Report that Australia is rapidly becoming the victim of world surpluses and other processing countries that have tomatoes, beetroot or asparagus, for instance. It was said that when they have a surplus they look at Australia and say, `Oh, Australia, you're fairly relaxed about that'. I have proved that there is no dumping of tomatoes in Australia; there are countervailing levies and duties.

There have been no applications or approaches made to the Customs Service to investigate the possibility of there being dumping of beetroot and asparagus. I would urge any company which thinks there is dumping to contact the customer service liaison section in the Customs Service to discuss its concerns. The Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority are very keen to act upon these sorts of things. They have a record of having done so.

I also draw the Senate's attention to the fact that we have one of the shortest periods within which this process has to take place. The key words on the dates and times within which this has to take place are `up to'. That means that it does not have to take the full time. I am told—I presume reliably—that in some cases the Customs Service has been able to put out a preliminary dumping finding within a couple of weeks of the prima facie case being brought to its attention. It is very important that people know this and stop running around the countryside perpetuating these untruths that Australia does absolutely nothing about dumping, and that Australia has removed all tariffs from processed primary produce, because it is not accurate.

As I have said, Ben Cheshire left us with that impression. He said that two days ago the Anti-Dumping Authority announced steps to counteract dumping. That is too late for Cowra. I wish the gentleman had spoken to those people who know about the issue; he would have been informed otherwise. He also looked at the shelves and compared prices. He found that they were different. I think he needs to ask a few people why—perhaps he could start with New South Wales. I am told that New South Wales has tomato marketing orders. The companies have mentioned that that is an impediment to the efficient production in that State because it establishes a minimum price for tomatoes for processing for the growers. It means that the companies cannot be competitive because they have to pay excessive prices for their products. Perhaps Mr Armstrong might like to advise us of what he plans to do to make sure that the factories in his State can obtain produce at a fair and reasonable competitive price.

This morning we had the New South Wales Minister for State Development, Mr Yabsley, saying that there was nothing the State could do to prevent the closure of the cannery in Cowra. Perhaps Mr Yabsley, as a good Liberal, might like to talk to Mr Armstrong, the National Party person, about the fact that there is a New South Wales tomato marketing order which is affecting the factories. Mr Yabsley might care to look at that issue.

I also get the impression from this article that Pacific Dunlop has closed down and walked away from the food processing operations altogether. One should be aware that it was not a closure announcement but a restructuring announcement. Pacific Dunlop will be concentrating on food processing in its seven remaining production centres throughout Australia. Over the next two years it will be investing $66m in major capital works. It will be upgrading the potato processing plant in Ulverstone, Tasmania, at $26m to make it the largest facility of its kind in the Southern Hemisphere. I wish that some of my colleagues from Tasmania were here to hear that.

The factory in Bathurst, which is in receipt of a best practice award, will be getting an investment to increase its capacity for the `quick shot' range of microwave products. The vegetable canning capacity in Manly, Queensland, will be expanded by 40 per cent. Those are certainly not the actions of a company that is about to remove itself from the food processing business in Australia.

It is very important that people realise that a lot of untruths have been said. A lot of mischievous or inaccurate things have been said which have not done anything to help the people in Cowra overcome their grief at seeing a major and important structure in their town changed and removed. I feel very sad for them. I know that this Government will do all that it can to assist with retraining, education and that type of thing. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) made that announcement today.

It is important to know the reason for the closure. When I spoke to the Pacific Dunlop plant I was given a lot of reasons as to why it was looking at closing or rationalising to close this plant. One of the reasons was the amount of money it was losing each year—in excess of $3m. Another reason included the availability of the produce and the reliability of the weather. I actually had to ask whether dumping was an issue. I was told that it might have been but, if it was, it was inconsequential. An article in the Cowra Guardian of 8 April states:
According to Mr Armstrong, one of the main problems facing all the parties is the age and antiquity of the equipment at Cowra.
Although this factory has been profitable for Edgells for many years, no money was put back into upgrading the technology and equipment.
The previous owners have let the factory become out of date and inefficient . . .
Mr Armstrong acknowledged that millions of dollars needed to be pumped into the factory to make it competitive. . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is obviously the major point. The previous owners of that factory had done nothing at all to upgrade, to take advantage of accelerated depreciation on capital and plant. None of those things were done. We have people commiserating, feeling sorry and apportioning blame—I do not like to think they are apportioning blame. Instead of recognising the factors involved in the closure, we have mistruths, distortions and gross inaccuracies. That does absolutely nothing to help anybody.

PARA.TAB: I feel very sad. I do not know how much editing was done on this story, but the quotes of the State Minister and the local shire president indicate that they either do not understand or a lot has been left on the cutting room floor. It is sad that I had to do this tonight. But I find that I cannot let these inaccuracies and mistruths continue any further. I want to make sure that everybody is aware of them.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Reverend Thich Don Hau

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the death in Vietnam last week of the Reverend Thich Don Hau. This matter has been brought to my attention by some in the Vietnamese community in Canberra. Reverend Thich Don Hau was a patriarch of the Buddhist church and his funeral was to have been held this Sunday. It was undoubtedly to have been a big event in Vietnam as he was a well-respected and well-known Buddhist.

PARA.TAB: The Government of Vietnam has set up its own committee to arrange the funeral of Thich Don Hau. This has caused concern. The Government has rescheduled the service until Wednesday of next week. Apparently it has done this on the grounds that many years ago the monk was a member of parliament for a short time. I am told he had a seat in the parliament at that time only because he was virtually forced to do so by the government of the time. He subsequently resigned from parliament and returned to being a full time monk. I am told that he was quite outspoken about the government of that time and its attitude to human rights in Vietnam.

Many of the supporters of the church here feel that the Government's intervention in setting up its own committee to arrange his funeral has less to do with honouring him for the work that he has done as a monk and more to do with attempting to make it appear that, as former member of the parliament, he was a supporter of the then government. The supporters feel that that is a distortion of the life of the man. They also feel that changing the funeral service from Sunday to Wednesday will significantly restrict the number of people who would be able to attend.

There seems to be some evidence to support their concerns. A number of senior monks in Vietnam have gone on a hunger strike against the government committee organising the funeral. I am told that initially the Government had said that it would not allow senior monks in prison to attend the service. However, there is some suggestion that it may allow this to occur. Honourable senators will remember that I have previously referred to the fact that Buddhist monks are still being held in prison in Vietnam and property of the Buddhist church being held by the Government has still not been returned to it. That is a pity.

I have been approached and asked to raise this matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). I have been requested to ask him to make representations to the Vietnamese Government to allow the funeral of the patriarch Thich Don Hau to proceed in accordance with the wishes of members of the Buddhist church in Vietnam and not attempt to make it secular by organising it. This is undoubtedly a delicate matter. However, perhaps the Minister may be able to use his good offices with the Vietnamese Government. He has intervened previously and made representations on human rights concerns and on behalf of Buddhist monks who have been held in prison and sentenced to death—a matter I have referred to previously in the Parliament.

It seems a pity that something like a funeral cannot be organised in a way which is not divisive for the Buddhists who support the patriarch and which would allow them to honour him and his funeral service in the way that they would like. I ask the Minister on duty here tonight, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins), to convey the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to see whether any appropriate representations might be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a further issue regarding the ABC. Earlier today, the Senate was told about the absurdity of a decision of the Managing Director, David Hill, to have Mr George Manning and Mr Ian Haselby taken off air in Western Australia because they are standing for local government elections in Western Australia next Saturday. The decision involving Mr Manning was taken after a recent visit to Broome by Mr Hill when he met with the Broome community council, which protested about him being on air while Mr Manning is, as you would be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, an apolitical and non-aligned local government candidate.

PARA.TAB: Being a Western Australian, Madam Acting Deputy President, you would also be aware that local councillors are unpaid, yet this high-handed decision runs counter to the decision that was taken in the case of Mr Peter Holland when he stood for the 1984 Federal election for the Australian Labor Party. He was taken off air in Perth and relocated to the ABC in Bunbury. Bunbury just happens to be the major town in the electorate for which he had nominated. Where is the fairness in the ABC and why is the ABC denying these two gentlemen the right to serve the community in an unpaid capacity?

Talking about fairness in the ABC, let me give another example of the illogical decision making process that it exercises. Mr Liam Bartlett, the local anchorman of the 7.30 Report, has submitted his resignation to the ABC and has given 16 weeks notice. Legal advice has stated that this is well within the terms of his contract. The ABC in Perth accepted Mr Bartlett's resignation only to have another high-handed decision made in Sydney which overturned the Perth management's decision. When will the ABC ever learn that Western Australia is capable of standing on its own two feet and making its own decisions? Quite frankly, I would be here all night if I were to relate all the decisions handed down from on high by the ABC in Sydney which take no account of Western Australian circumstances.

Clearly, Mr Bartlett no longer wishes to work for the ABC, yet it is demanding that he stay there until December or it will take him to court. I understand that Mr Bartlett has done an excellent job with the ABC, both as a reporter and an anchorman, and that he has lifted the ratings of the 7.30 Report to a very high level every single solitary night since he has been acting in those capacities. Congratulations go to him for doing so.

At a time when the country is broke, when the ABC budget has been cut by 20 per cent between 1985-86 and 1990-91 and when staffing has been reduced by 10 per cent between March 1990 and September 1991, why is the ABC prepared to waste taxpayers' money—and plenty of it—to keep someone who does not want to work there? In such a situation very little legal advice under $100,000 can be gained, yet Mr Hill is quite prepared to waste more taxpayers' money at a time when the tax burden is falling on fewer and fewer people due to the high unemployment policies of this Labor Government.

As a Western Australian, I am sick and tired of taxpayer funded corporations such as the ABC not allowing local management to make decisions that are beneficial to Western Australia. Mr Bartlett fully knows and understands that he is under contract to the ABC. That is why he has sought to give four months—not four minutes—notice.

The ABC in Perth has always struggled to get adequate funding for the 7.30 Report. It is purely city based at present. If the ABC has the money to throw away, why does it not give it to the 7.30 Report so that it can have the resources to cover the country areas? Surely, that would be a more wise use of the funds than taking an individual who no longer wishes to work for the ABC to court. I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins) at the table: why will this Government allow the ABC to waste more taxpayers's money in fighting the inevitable?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take five minutes of the Senate's time tonight to place on record some of the activities of an organisation of which I have the pleasure to have been a member for several years—namely, the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers, or ATCV as it is commonly known. The Trust is a non-profit community based organisation and it is completely non-political. By means of the considerable voluntary manpower latent in our community from which the Trust taps, it performs practical tasks to the benefit of the environment. The Trust runs on a high level of voluntary input—indeed, that is its essential ingredient—under the direction of employed field officers and a secretariat. The budget of the organisation is very small relative to its work.

PARA.TAB: Environmental problems are the main focus of activity. The Trust has paid particular attention to salinity, soil erosion and the loss of native flora and fauna. The ATCV aims to assist local groups in management projects on public lands; to link the land-holder and the volunteer in conservation orientated projects; and to develop training programs which enable volunteers to acquire practical skills in ecological management.

Each ATCV team is a self-contained group. It is furnished with a vehicle, food and cooking facilities, hand tools and first aid equipment. The organisation has officers operating in Victoria, South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania. An office for Western Australia is planned for the near future and may well have opened by now.

Of all the community organisations—indeed, of all the organisations in Australia concerned with conservation and the environment—as I understand it, the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers is the only example of an organisation running full time environment volunteers throughout the year on a national basis. The ATCV conducts projects during both weekends and weeks throughout the year. It is a major contributor of voluntary labour to farm, tree and land care groups and national parks and wildlife services in most States. The methodology for managing volunteers on a full time basis is based on having trained task force leaders in charge of groups of up to a maximum of 10 volunteers. These task groups have travelled the length and breadth of Australia to undertake projects. The success of the approach adopted by ATCV has led to a steady growth in community recognition and a significant increase in corporate support. The operations of ATCV provide a very sound basis on which to build a program to increase community participation voluntarily using a network of community groups.

The ATCV is a unique conservation group in Australia. It is dedicated to practical conservation. The volunteers are working conservationists who consider themselves doers rather than talkers. It is for that reason that I have such a strong feeling of support for the organisation. It has done a great deal to encourage voluntarism in Australia, particularly in conservation and environmental matters. It has a small and very dedicated staff. Its executive director is Mr Colin Jackson; the national operations manager is Terry Peacock; the administrative assistant is Sandy Farley; and the bookkeeper, who is a very old friend of mine, is Mr Alf Bailey. That staff, together with other field staff who are stationed around Australia, run a very dedicated operation.

True conservation activities in Australia will be successful only if they have a very wide spread of community support. Given the limited resources—particularly financial resources—of governments and organisations, that means a heavy reliance on voluntarism. Expert, trained volunteers are the key to the future of successful conservation in Australia. The ATCV is playing a very important role in that respect.

Any organisation, even one which relies on volunteers as much as ATCV, needs sponsors. The organisation has been very fortunate in having strong, very supportive sponsors for several years. Sponsors include Yellow Pages, Shell Australia, Batesville Casket Company, SEC Victoria, Nissan Australia, Stihl Australia, Boral Cyclone, K-Mart, Alcoa Australia, STA Travel, the National Trust in the Northern Territory, the huge mining company of Western Mining, another major mining company Energy Resources Australia, Portland Aluminium Smelter, Renison Goldfields Consolidated Ltd, Greening Australia, Bus Australia and Queensland Cotton. All those sponsors are recognised in the 1991 annual report of the Trust. I commend those organisations for their sponsorship of what I believe is a very important organisation. It is a widely spread, community based organisation, and one which I hope will be built upon by those interested in proper conservation in Australia in future. It is of great concern and interest to all Australians to have an adequate and proper conservation movement.

Far too often those movements have been heavily politically oriented. The great virtue of this organisation is that it is a doer and not a talker. It is not a political organisation. It has a very strong practical record. I look forward with great confidence to seeing the ATCV go forward in future on behalf of conservation generally, and for the benefit of all Australians. I commend all those who are presently concerned with the ATCV for the work they have already done.

I recommend those Australians who have not had much, if any, connection with the ATCV to look at that body and to see whether they can get behind it. We should seek to build on community effort in the preservation and conservation of our environment and many of those aspects of the Australian way of life that are so important to us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow the Australian National Gallery opens its doors to artists to give them the opportunity to have a look at the refurbishing that has been done to a large part of the gallery to turn an appalling and incompetent building into an art gallery.

PARA.TAB: There has been a great deal of comment about the Australian National Gallery building. It simply has not worked. It has been a disaster that has cost Australian taxpayers multi-millions of dollars. For example, its roof did not work; we had to spend $5m replacing it. That is just the beginning. One would think one of the basic requirements of a building is that it keeps the rain out. Apparently that is not a requirement with architects in Canberra these days, because that is not the only building that has had to cope with that problem. There seems to be a trend among architects these days that it does not matter what the purpose of the building is. The building is to be a monument to the architect, not a place in which functions actually occur.

This chamber is a place where talking goes on, yet the walls are clad with sound absorbent material so that there is no reverberation. The only way you can be heard is with the support of artificial sound reinforcement. Any architect who designed this place for talking to take place knows nothing about talking. It is exactly the same with the Australian National Gallery. The architect who designed that building knows nothing about art and knows less about art galleries. It is a pathetic building. What intrigues me is that the original architect, Mr Madigan, is now complaining bitterly about the fact that this appalling building has been turned into quite a respectable art gallery because of major changes done by a very able architect, Mr Andersons.

Some of the points I would like to make emerge from a very interesting article written by Peter Cochrane of the Sydney Morning Herald. In that article, Mr Cochrane was incredibly kind to Mr Madigan, who is a partner in the Sydney firm of Edwards Madigan Torzillo Briggs, because he did not even mention the fact that the roof after only a few years has had to be totally replaced at public cost. Unfortunately, whoever was responsible—Mr Madigan has yet to establish, in my mind at least, that he did not play a major role in the roof not working—Mr Madigan or anybody else, is not capable of being sued for their incompetence. But Mr Cochrane reports that the major paintings in that gallery are now for the first time able to be displayed in sympathetic conditions. Colin Madigan, however, is complaining. The report quotes Mr Madigan as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: "The building was designed to take a lot of abuse, but now it is getting a raw deal. I nearly go bloody berserk thinking about it.
Quite frankly, he must have been berserk when he designed the place, because it is not an acceptable art gallery. The report continues:

Today he talks of the building refurbishments in terms of "betrayal" and "abandonment". "The new director and new council know nothing about . . . the sensitivities and sensibilities of architecture and design, and they've vandalised it.
All I can say to Mr Madigan is, `Good, it needed vandalising; it needed to be turned into an art gallery, not a monument'. Mr Madigan goes on to say:

"I am arguing—pleading—for a consciousness of what that building is all about. In architectural terms, it represented an image, an icon of that era, particularly the Whitlam years when Australia was, to some extent, in a stage of enlightenment.

If that is an icon to the Whitlam years, I guess it is appropriate. It cost too much, it did not work, and it has had to have been fixed up. So Madigan is right: it is an icon to the Whitlam years—an icon we can well and truly do without.

PARA.TAB: Mr Madigan complains that Gallery 10—`a beautiful high-space gallery'—was cut in half to create the Nomura Court. I wish to say a couple of words about this lovely high space gallery. It was made of cement, of concrete, of off-form concrete which had not been shaken down the forms properly. It was full of holes. It was multi-coloured because of discolouration as a result of failure, I presume, of quality control. I will deal with that in a minute. Worse than that, the cement keeps flaking off this off-form concrete and damages the paintings. Apart from that, it is terrific! It is a great monument but a lousy art gallery.

Architects do not seem to care much about people who actually use buildings. I would like to force the architect of this place to work for a year as a waitress in the members' dining room and carry full trays of food up and down the flight of seven stairs the waitresses have to negotiate because the architect thought it looked nice. But it is not terribly user-friendly. We have the same problem in this place. The architect goes on:
In my opinion, a gallery is supposed to act like a cathedral, to lift the spirits of the people . . . would they have added a mezzanine floor to St Paul's Cathedral?

SPEECH.PARA: What arrogant humbug! St Paul's Cathedral looks like a factory. This is no St Paul's Cathedral. It is an art gallery where people can have their spirits lifted by looking at the works of art. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: The refurbishment of Galleries 2 and 3—the main contemporary art spaces—was undertaken without Madigan's co-operation.

SPEECH.PARA: Andrew Andersons was brought in to refurbish it. Betty Churcher, the Director of the Gallery, says:

PARA.TAB: I couldn't get Col—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, Madigan—
back because he was too antagonistic to any suggestion of change, and he wouldn't argue from the point of view of the art, only from the point of view of the building.
As I said, he could not care less that it was supposed to be an art gallery. Madigan believes that his design is:
the antithesis of the `ad hockery' which now prevails . . . the visionless, small-minded, mundane, almost banal, approach to problem-solving.
Mr Madigan's problem is his building and his design. If there is any problem-solving to emerge, it is because of what he did. Madigan goes on:

PARA.TAB: Fancy anyone in authority, sitting on the council, saying `We will divide Gallery 8 in half, we will put a mezzanine over the restaurant, we will close off the sky light to Gallery 2, we will put cardboard boxes around the walls of Galleries 1 and 3.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose he is equally offended at the thought that we will put a new roof on to keep out the rain. The arrogance of architects knows no bounds. This lack of concern about function reminds me of a conversation I had the other day with Harry Seidler, who was protesting enormously about the inside of the Sydney Opera House's concert hall, saying how appalling it looks and that every architect who comes from overseas complains about what a disgraceful provincial interior there is to this brilliant and exciting shell outside. I said to him, `Harry, what does the music sound like inside it?'. It was almost a revolutionary concept that I should actually expect the concert hall to sound good and that I was concerned more about that than how it looked from the inside. He could not grasp the concept. That probably explains everything about architects' approach to buildings, particularly ones such as this. One of the main curators said:

PARA.TAB: I've tried to hang these galleries—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, existing galleries in the National Gallery—
for 10 years, but the fact is they are at their best when there is nothing in them.

That is absolutely correct. It was designed as a monument to the architect, not as a place to hang paintings. The gallery got the new architect, Andrew Andersons, to create spaces where paintings could be hung. According to Betty Churcher, his solution was absolutely inspired. I believe that is true. Mr Lloyd, one of the curators, said:

When you come in now you're still aware of the scale of the architecture, but you will not miss anything and you will not get lost. People were always getting lost before. Now, there's a strong access point and points of orientation along the way.
No wonder the original architect is complaining. People can actually use the gallery now without getting lost and can actually look at paintings. The article continues:
Andersons wrote a letter to Madigan, describing his approach to the refurbishment; Madigan replied "indirectly".
Andersons said:
He's understandably upset that his building is being modified, as any architect would be. I think that the ANG was probably the most important project in Col's career.

All I can say is that I hope something better happens in his career, because if that was his top point, I would hate to see his bottom point. The simple fact is that the previous configuration simply did not meet the users' needs. How many times have we heard that sort of thing in architecture?

PARA.TAB: One of the major problems facing the Australian National Gallery was not only that the art was dominated, or diminished, by the architecture but also that the bush-hammered concrete walls shed dust, which threatened to damage paintings, and the lighting was a major headache. Mr Lloyd said:

The walls shed a particularly nasty, corrosive concrete dust with a high alkalinity content which reacts badly with heavy pigments such as cadmium and lead white, which are not uncommon in artworks. . . A chemical reaction is set up so that if you are not careful it can alter the original pigment. Recently, we vacuumed all the triagrid ceilings, prior to painting the galleries once they had been clad, and the amount of concrete dust sucked up was horrific.

As to whether any measurable damage has been done to the paintings, I don't think our conservation department would be prepared to say. Some dust did get into the textiles in the Asian gallery next door. It threw the curators into a panic, and they spent some months getting it out.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Madigan countered that by saying:
. . . probably the result of building work carried out recently when, in effect, Gallery 8 was destroyed. . . as part of a roofing contract.

Mr Madigan, the architect, was not prepared to tell the Sydney Morning Herald that a `roofing contract' meant replacing the roof that his design and his builders were not capable of doing in such a way that it kept out the rain. As I understand, rain is supposed to be kept off paintings in an art gallery. He went on:
In covering the bush-hammered walls of Galleries 1, 2 and 3 with plasterboard, Betty—
that is, Betty Churcher—
has destroyed the cohesion of the building, from inside to outside.

If he wanted a cohesive building, would it not have been a nice idea if he had designed one to be an art gallery? Now it is one, and I am glad. Let us look at the sort of user unfriendly proposition that emerges when we give architects free reign to design monuments themselves. Mr Lloyd said:

PARA.TAB: The lighting is attached to the so-called space-frame ceiling. The only way we can access those lights is with a movable platform on which is mounted a cherry picker. In here—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, in the gallery—

we have to push it around between the sculpture and the showcases. It can take an hour to change a light bulb in Galleries 2 or 3, involving at least three people, and it becomes a screaming match between the curator on the floor and the electrician above. The electrician can't actually see the picture, so the curator has to yell at him: `Move it a bit to the right, or to the left.'

PARA.TAB: Imagine trying to throw a framed beam of light from a 15-metre high ceiling, at an angle, on to a Cezanne that is 30cm x 25cm. That's a terrific achievement—we can do it, but it means that the light, once the shutters are locked into place, must not move. A millimetre of movement in the shutters would magnify over that distance into centimetres and you get this big blue shadow moving across the picture.

The air-conditioning ducts are also located in the ceiling, and so you get constant low-level vibration. Over a period of time all the shutters would shift. It's like painting the Sydney Harbour Bridge—you get to one end of the gallery and have to start again, realigning the lights.
Churcher adds a fourth concern: "The concrete walls and the floor are light-absorbent, which doesn't help maintain the vitality of the light coming from way up above.

SPEECH.PARA: Having seen the Rubens exhibition, Senator Collins would have noted that the art gallery authorities have very sensibly lined that area with a deep red, which is a brilliant backdrop to the paintings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very effective.
—I acknowledge the Minister's interjection that it is very effective. At last, under dynamic leadership, this place is looking like an art gallery. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The dust problem and the lack of reflective surfaces in Gallery 3, a monumental space that has in the past intimidated curators, has been solved by cladding the walls from top to bottom in plasterboard.

PARA.TAB: `We mean to hang it, without any internal walls, with very contemporary art,' Lloyd says. `Big pictures, hung sparsely, with a regular turnover.'
It is in Gallery 2, home of Blue Poles, that Andrew Andersons has attempted a sympathetic refurbishment.

He divided the space into four rooms, with six-metre high free-standing walls and state-of-the-art lighting mounted on a pelmet attached to coving. A 90-centimetre wide ledge now skirts the floor, serving both as a barrier and also to reflect the light.

SPEECH.PARA: So at last we have a situation where a disastrous building has been converted—at enormous expense, by the way, in terms of the roof, but at modest expense in terms of the rest—into what I hope will be regarded as a most satisfactory art gallery.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is the arrogance of the original architect who is offended that this monument to himself is being turned into what he was supposed to design in the first place—an art gallery. I hope that in the future architects will take heed of the lessons that should be learnt from buildings like this one, the Australian National Gallery, and recognise that if they fail to meet the requirements of the users of those buildings, their monuments may well be changed after the event, their monuments may well be tampered with and the so-called integrity might be damaged—and just as well.

The reason I have risen very briefly is simply to indicate to Senator Reid that I have drawn the attention of Senator Evans's office to the concern she raised during the adjournment debate this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 18 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are jet aircraft required to fly extended flight paths, supposedly to limit serious noise fanout over the suburbs of Brisbane; if so, does the noise problem remain acute.

(2) Is there a requirement for all jet aircraft landing into the north between 10.00pm and 6.00am to fly along the same flight path and fly below 3000 feet; if so, is the Minister aware that these procedures cause extreme distress, discomfort and potential financial loss to the residents of Brisbane who now find themselves living under the flight path and in surrounding areas.

(3) Why has the problem become worse, given that over $600 million was spent in 1988 on Brisbane Airport, with the purported intention of minimising the noise problem caused by flight paths over the suburbs.

(4) As it is the Government's stated intention in the One Nation program to spend more money on Brisbane's International Airport and thus potentially increase the air traffic in the Brisbane area, what action will be taken to address the problem of aircraft noise pollution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Flight paths at Brisbane have been developed with a view to minimising residents' exposure to aircraft noise, including two recent flight path modifications for this purpose. The noise problem at Brisbane cannot be considered acute when compared with the level of aircraft noise at other major Australian cities.

(2) No. However, under certain weather conditions aircraft are required to use the Instrument Landing System (ILS) for approach to runway 01 at Brisbane Airport, rather than visual approach, commencing descent at a height of 3000 feet at Archerfield. Noise abatement procedures in place at Brisbane Airport ensure, as far as practicable, that distress and discomfort to residents is minimised. In this regard, over 90% of aircraft operating during the hours between 10.00pm and 6.00am land from the north over Moreton Bay
(3) The Brisbane Airport Task Force, which reported in June 1991, found that since the new Brisbane Airport opened in March 1988 the total noise impact on residential areas has been reduced.

(4) Brisbane Airport has been designed to cope with increased traffic operations. The problem of aircraft noise emissions will continue to be dealt with through noise abatement procedures in place at the Airport. In addition, the Government has regulated to phase out older and noisier subsonic jet aircraft by the year 2002. The phasing out of these aircraft should minimise aircraft noise pollution in Australia in the medium to long term.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 18 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal funding of road construction changes to Albany Highway, Cannington, Western Australia:
(1) What is the value of Federal funding recently given to road construction changes on the Albany Highway, Cannington, Western Australia.
(2) What influence does the Federal Government have over how this money will be spent.

(3) Has any consideration been given to the construction of a pedestrian overpass to the regional centre; if so, is it expected to comply with design specifications that make its use amenable to senior citizens and the disabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Land Transport approved on 12 March 1990 $21.2 million for the preconstruction work required for the reconstruction and widening of 5.6km of the Albany Highway between Oats Street East Victoria Park and William Street Beckenham.

(2) The Federal Government determines how funds are spent on proposals submitted by the States. In this case Federal approval is limited to pre-construction works. Of the $21.2 million approved, $17.2 million will be used specifically for land acquisition, and the remaining expenditure of $4 million will be for preconstruction work related to relocation of services and design and planning activities necessary for the widening of Albany Highway from a 4-lane undivided road to a 6-lane divided road.

(3) A footbridge was constructed across Albany Highway approximately 120 metres south of Cecil Avenue in 1982 to improve pedestrian access to the Carousel Shopping Centre. Although used extensively by pedestrians the existing steep ramp approaches make its use less amenable to senior citizens and the disabled.

Main Roads Department Western Australia has examined the possibility of modifying this footbridge and two proposals are currently being considered. One proposal is to provide flatter ramps. This proposal would require the acquisition of some additional land and is not favoured because of the high cost involved—in excess of $1.0m. The second proposal is the provision of hydraulic lifts at either end of the existing footbridge. This would greatly improve accessibility, for senior citizens and the disabled. Preliminary indications are that glass walled lifts can be provided which would reduce concerns about the security of users. The estimated cost of installation of these lifts is $0.6m. However, a decision has not yet been reached on possible modifications to this existing footbridge.

The recently completed Canning Regional Centre Study identified a need for a second footbridge over Albany Highway, near Cockram Street approximately 260 metres south of the existing footbridge. The construction timing of this footbridge will be determined by the future expansion of the Regional Centre. This bridge will be designed to ensure that it can be effectively used by senior citizens and the disabled.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How will the $115m allocated in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement for the standardisation of the Melbourne to Adelaide railway actually bring about that standardisation.

(2) Will the existing broad gauge track simply be converted to standard gauge in 1992/93 and 1993/ 94; if so, will the standardisation be brought about by the laying of a third rail inside the existing broad gauge track.
(3) Will the new sleepers laid for the existing track in recent months by AN enable three rail operation or will they enable only two rail standard gauge operation after conversion.
(4) If the option in (2) is adopted, will Adelaide Metropolitan Passenger Traffic be accommodated by the laying of a third rail from Adelaide to Belair.

(5) If the option in (2) is adopted, will the existing grain and fertiliser rail traffic in the Murraylands and south east of South Australia be accommodated by the conversion of branch lines to standard gauge.
(6) Does AN have plans to standardise the Tailem Bend to Pinnaroo and Tailem Bend to Alawoona branch lines.

(7) If there are no plans to standardise branch lines in South Australia and if the third rail option is not chosen for the Melbourne to Adelaide railway, what branch and mainline railways will remain in South Australia after standardisation.
(8) Is the safety of three rail operation less than that of two rail operation in areas where trains would be expected to run at higher speeds.
(9) How many employment positions would be made redundant at the Dry Creek Railway Wagon Bogie Exchange by the conversion of the Melbourne to Adelaide railway to standard gauge.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth has established a Working Group comprising officials from the National Rail Corporation (NRC), the States and their rail systems and Australian National to develop the details of the project and examine the best method of completing the job. In particular, the Working Group will resolve the best route and other options to ensure that productivity is maximised (such as curve straightening in the Adelaide Hills).

(2) The precise method to be adopted in standardising the line has yet to be determined. However, I am advised that the simplest and most likely procedure would be a two stage process involving the insertion of dual gauge sleepers followed by moving one of the existing rails inward.

I am advised that there are safety considerations with high speed third rail operation and that if third rail operation were adopted, there could be operating restrictions. As installation of the third rail would significantly increase the cost of this project, a third rail (broad gauge) over the whole route will not be retained.

(3) Gauge convertible concrete sleepers are being used for the resleepering of a 100 km section of track between Coonalpyn and the Victorian border. This track will be converted to standard gauge by shifting one rail inward. Only standard gauge operation will be possible after standardisation.

(4) Detailed planning has not been completed, but an option is for one of the broad gauge tracks to be converted to standard gauge while one remains as broad gauge for metropolitan passenger movements.
(5) and (6) Australian National has been asked for advice about which South Australian branch lines affected by the standardisation should be gauge converted. This is not yet available.

(7) All existing main lines (ie Adelaide to Melbourne, Sydney, Perth and Alice Springs) will be retained. The existing standard gauge branch lines to Whyalla and Leigh Creek will also be retained. As indicated in the answers to questions (5) and (6), no decisions have been made about the future of lines in the south east of the State. Standardisation will have no direct effect on broad gauge branch lines in the mid-north of South Australia, or on the Eyre Peninsula lines.

(8) As the gap between the second and third rail is close (16.5cm), ballast and similar material could become wedged between the rails, which has the potential to derail trains running at high speeds. This raises safety considerations for three rail operations at high speed that do not apply to two rail operations.
(9) There are 30 positions at the Dry Creek Bogie Exchange facility which would be affected by standardisation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 26 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many roadside signs informing people that a road has been Federally funded have been erected since 1 July 1986.
(2) What was the cost in each fiscal year since 1 July 1986.
(3) How many signs were erected in each of the States and Territories during this period.
(4) What maintenance costs for these signs have been incurred during this period.
(5) Who produces the signs and on what basis are the contracts negotiated.
(6) What are the various specific wordings on the signs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1 to 5) Legislation providing for each Federal road program since 1 July 1986 has required that road signs be erected and maintained in accordance with requirements notified to a State or authority from time to time, being signs that indicate that the construction or maintenance of a road is being or has been funded by the Commonwealth. Signs were required to be erected at the commencement of construction and maintained for the life of the Federal program or for at least one year after the opening of the project to traffic. Details of arrangements made by States for producing these signs as well as the numbers erected and cost of signs have been included in the overall cost of road projects and are not separately available.

(6) Words and other requirements for signs have been set out in Notes on Administration, as amended, issued under each Federal road program. Under the current Federal program sign sizes, text sizes, style, colour and material shall be in accordance with the attached Drawing A. Size 1 provides for projects in open road locations whereas size 2 is for locations where physical space is limited. Panels A and B are for use where the project is in view and alternate panels for use where the project is obscured from the travelling public.
